We will make our Kickstarter exclusive extras available only to Kickstarter backers. $23K - For the first time ever, we'll publish a book as part of the rewards tiers. You'll be able to get all four volumes of Volume One as a book. The books will be in softcover, with a full-color cover design. The cover will have a custom made bookplate by our inker, and each book will have a special collector's certificate. We've already finished the artwork, so there's nothing stopping us from going over-budget here, but we want to make a book that will be beautiful to look at, have it be a gift from the fans, and have a nice, special place in the history of anime. $30K - We'll publish all four volumes of Volume Two as a print book. The books will be thicker and wider than our previous volumes. This will increase the size of the book, making volume two an ideal addition to any collection for the serious fans.

A Florida man who told a police officer he had a bomb in his pants was arrested on Monday, a week after he was arrested for threatening another officer, authorities said. William A. Pfeifer, 48, of Deerfield Beach, told Miami Police Sgt. Jorge Torres that he had a bomb in the pants he was wearing, according to authorities. The bomb, which Mr. Pfeifer said was in a water-filled canister, was made of C-4 plastic and contained the explosive Tannerite. It was contained in two packages that Mr. Pfeifer, a U.S. Marine veteran, brought to the Fort Lauderdale Police station Nov. 17. Later in the day, Mr. Pfeifer sent a Facebook message to Sgt. Daniel A. Rodriguez telling him he was being chased by a "police state". Mr. Pfeifer also sent an e-mail to Sgt. Rodriguez threatening the Miami police commander with a lawsuit. The last email, dated Feb. 10, said: "I am planning to sue Miami for taking me to jail for nothing, and threatening me in my jail cell." A day after he was arrested, the bomb squad was called in to examine Mr. Pfeifer's backpack, and Mr.Pfeifer was arrested, investigators said. His bail was $75,000. Investigators said it was not clear if Mr. Pfeifer had been in possession of the Tannerite. In a statement, Sgt. Torres noted that "the bomb threat came before the officer's interaction with the suspect," but he also noted that the department is not always a model of transparency."The officer acted within the law and should be commended for it," Sgt. Torres said. Mr. Pfeifer's previous arrests took place in November 2014. He was charged with a felony count of making bomb threats to a community college and the charge was dismissed. He also was charged with misdemeanor battery in November of last year. Those charges were dismissed, prosecutors said. He had received a one-year operating suspension from the police department in 2014 for violating the use of force policy. Investigators said Mr. Pfeifer had a criminal history that includes several misdemeanor convictions.

As you'll see, this list focuses only on women with at least a 90%+ rating based on the 10+ surveys I've done in the past year. It's by no means a comprehensive list, but it's still fun and useful as a "starting point". Enjoy. A note on terminology and some disclaimers: These are all "best" games, not the only ones worth playing. I consider "overall" to encompass everything that was well-received by critics and/or is still playable to this day. The only "best" game that's not listed here is Super Mario Advance 3, by obvious choice. Super Mario Land 2 is a game I've heard a lot about lately, but I haven't played it. It might seem odd to have it listed in this list, because Mario 2 looks so primitive today, but I believe the quality is just as high here as in most other games reviewed on the site. I've included a short description of the game below each game, but for most of these games you're on your own and need to find a good place online to find out more. Also, note that some of these games are not in any video game's catalog, either in North, South or Central America (for example, I'm not saying the original Super Mario is NOT in the NES catalog in Europe) and even in Japan. You'll notice that there are some games listed as "Not reviewed", which just means that they did not make the list of the Top 75 Nintendo games of all time (even if I've reviewed those already in the past year or so). It's also worth noting that this is all just a collection of the best games I reviewed this last year, and not a comprehensive analysis of the entire video game catalog. If you see your favorite game listed, share it in the comments by adding links to your own "Top 75 reviews" or something similar. Or, just leave a comment and let me know what you think. A bit about "Best games rated 90+": The "90+" rating is based around two things: 1) which games have been played by at least 5 people (in most cases, at least one person must have had a rating of 9 or higher for the game to count), 2) whether or not those games are from the Nintendo family of system (NES, SNES, N64, Gamecube, Wii/WiiU). This is a bit like the "best game ever" in music, but in gaming, rather than music reviews. Note that the "overall" list does not show any games rated 90+ by the Video Game Critic's Choice awards. I think this is because a lot of "94+" reviews contain games by other publications (or maybe even by GameFAQs). I'd be quite interested to see how many of those reviews are in fact, from Video Game Critic's Choice instead of other sources. I've tried to make the ratings as accurate as possible, but if there's information I haven't listed below, please let me know. This list has been compiled with the help of a few members of the Smashboards forums. Special thanks to "BigSaucey" ("BigSauce" for short) for helping me find some of these games, and to "Cobalt" ("Cobalt" for short) for some of the most obscure choices. Listing the best games to play: Super Mario Land 2, Super Mario 64, Super Mario Sunshine, Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time, Metroid Prime, The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past (aka Legend of the Quest for the Seven Suns) Top 75 Nintendo games of all time:  A note on terminology and some disclaimers:

TAMPA — A Tampa woman accused of attacking a former child star on a flight has pleaded not guilty. The Tampa Bay Times reported (http://bit.ly/1i7J1uQ ) that 36-year-old Heather Anne Burt, of North Port, pleaded not guilty Tuesday to a felony assault charge alleging that she punched an off-duty sheriff's deputy in the face. Court minutes show the judge set her bail at $125,000, making her eligible for electronic monitoring until her trial. According to an arrest affidavit, Burt said she got on the Delta flight May 7 with her 10- and nine-year-old daughters and her 9-year-old son. "On the flight, she became upset with an airline employee who was seated across the aisle from her. Ms. Burt became enraged after the employee approached her about playing music loudly during the flight. Ms. Burt told the officer that she was taking her daughters to a park, and that the employee should not bother her," an affidavit said. Burt was arrested when the plane landed in Tampa on Saturday. A video was posted on YouTube showing her punching a uniformed uniformed sheriff's deputy. Sheriff's spokeswoman Amy Harvey said in a statement, "While the Sheriff's Office was very happy to assist in the investigation, Ms. Burt was immediately arrested at the airport upon arrival. The Sheriff's Office will conduct a full investigation and await charging in the case." Burt's attorney, Jim Behan, said in a statement his client was "very proud" she took on the uniformed deputy and that her "reaction to the alleged assault was totally out of character." The attorney said he is "confident this will go to trial, and she will be exonerated once all the facts are known."

I am a regular visitor to the online magazine and web site of the World Economic Forum, or WEWS, one of the oldest and most influential international associations in the field of "global issues." And I agree with the WEWS CEO, Klaus Schwab, who recently said: In a word, the global economy is in a funk now, we have an excess of demand…and the result is a decline in demand for imports. We are in a period of "negative growth," with trade not growing, demand not growing and we have a large surplus of exports. In other words, everything is bad. What a concept! All the signs are there. In fact, the WEWS is already starting to change its tune. Not long after Schwab wrote his article, WEWS Director-General Roberto Arias Canete admitted something that I and others have long suspected — the WEWS is not trying to forecast the future. Instead they have always taken the line that whatever is happening in the economy, it's just like everything else you and I are always told to worry about. So in effect, everyone is talking about the same thing, because the WEWS is just another one of those economic forecasts. Arautez-vous le délicat? But no doubt, something very big is happening. One has only to look at the world's stock markets to see the signs and see that this is a trend that looks to be taking off. So what could be causing the "flip" in financial markets in recent months? The good thing is that it doesn't involve a full-scale economic collapse, or even a major recession. Instead, it is a "contagion" in the form of economic slowdown that seems to be spreading from the Eurozone countries to all the rest of world. The big picture I don't have the numbers for you, but I think that by some estimates, there has been a significant economic slowdown in Europe since late 2013, and possibly longer. What is happening in Europe is that the massive, record-breaking monetary, fiscal and social policies that these countries have been engaged in has not only failed badly, but has even triggered a substantial economic slowdown in their economies. The biggest part of that slowdown has happened because these countries, along with other parts of the world, are still dealing with the aftermath of the crisis. This is exactly what the WEWS has suggested. It told us that the problems in the EU needed some time to fade away. But once that happened, the WEWS said it could go on predicting that economic growth would steadily increase in the coming years. In fact, that seems to be exactly what has been happening… and the stock markets are right about it. The EU is getting poorer, and this slowdown means that Europe is getting less and less prosperous. The world is getting weaker Another sign of the impending slowdown in the world's economies is the fact that the U.S. stock and bond markets are beginning to take a beating from the ongoing turmoil in China. For example, the S&P 500 index had a very rough week this week. While the market has gained around 8% over the last twelve months, it lost around 13% this week as investors dumped the stock and bond markets and took refuge in real estate. The U.S. stock market fell about one percent in the same period. In China itself, the real estate market fell about 10% as investors panicked and sold, taking their money out of markets and real estate. The U.S. stock market has recently been on a run up after the recent sell off, but the decline in real estate prices is making the stock market more expensive again. In short, Chinese economic growth is now slowing and in a recession. What is also happening in China and in other developing countries is that many of the companies that are exporting to these nations are becoming less competitive than they once were because they no longer have much demand from domestic businesses. Instead foreign companies are taking their business and moving this way and that in order to gain marketshare. The result is that these nations have had to implement large structural changes to reduce their bloated domestic government budgets and increase the competitiveness of their economies. The WEWS also told us that the slowdown in the world was due to a "slowdown" or "global expansionary depression," or GIGI for short. They described the way we have been running our economies as part of a process of globalization, which was causing the U.S. economy to expand. But that process of globalization is slowing down. The WEWS said this was due, in part, to the fact that the amount of manufacturing in the U.S. has been falling while the U.S. has been expanding. Why is this happening?

The Canadian Press  VICTORIA -- Two police officers have died in a shooting in Richmond, B.C., as they tried to apprehend a suspect during the weekend. Police have identified the officers as Const. Brian Montague of the VPD and Const. Craig Fraser of the Richmond RCMP. A statement issued by the police says the officers were shot Saturday in a residential neighbourhood of Richmond as they tried to arrest "a suspect during an ongoing domestic disturbance." Fraser died on the scene while Montague later died of his injuries in hospital. "No words can express the sorrow and sadness we extend to the two families impacted by this tragedy," the statement says. "Our thoughts, our prayers, our hearts are with them today. And we do so also for the police officer or officers who were involved." The suspect shot and killed by officers on Aug. 20 is still being questioned. The suspect was also injured. A family member of the shooting victim said Friday night that their prayers are with Montague's wife and children, as well as the officers. "They were out in support of their brother, in support of his wife... his kids, his sister, his mother," Brenda Macdonald-Rathier said in an interview. "They were out in support of each other. They were out to put a stop to the violence in their community." Macdonald-Rathier said the family is heartbroken by the loss of her nephew and a cousin. "To know that my nephew was so taken that it affected not only the family and the community, but the whole country... to know that he was killed in the line of duty. It's tragic in every sense of the word," she said.

A few weeks ago I got a phone call from the owner of a company I had never heard of asking if I'd be interested in reviewing his company's products. I was curious. It sounded like a fun idea – a brand with really neat stuff to offer. He wanted to know about the type of product, what we'd evaluate, what we didn't think was important, and what we were excited about. I didn't have an issue with that. After I met with the company's founder, I was told I would be working with a team to help put together a new line of equipment. The first time the team met, I was immediately excited to be working with one of the industry's most talented and creative people. He seemed like a man I could trust. We had a good amount of detail on what we'd be working on (a new monitor, digital camera, and a pair of earbuds – we were excited to be introducing them), the process we'd be taking to get there (we thought this was interesting) and what we would do to test things. Over the past two weekends we put together a group of people to take on this task. We started by doing research, meeting with the company, speaking to their customers, and building prototypes. I've been working in the retail industry for almost 14 years. This kind of work takes time to complete. Some ideas are too big and complex to be taken on with others so we focused on our two main product ideas. We were very careful of how we went about getting there. We wanted to make smart equipment that people could really appreciate and use. The first product we designed was a new monitor. This was a very special monitor, one that would set a standard for others. We began with this product because it required the most detail from we needed to do our work. We needed every single detail that the designer would have to make to take this monitor to the next level. There were so many details to get perfect. This is something we try to stay very true with our product designs. So if you are looking for our top 5 or our top 10, they're all at the bottom of this article. We spent about 9 months working on our second monitor project. In addition to the new monitor we built some other accessories to enhance it further. The end goal for these products was to make great quality devices that are simple to use. Many of us are accustomed to using technology that can make your life easier in so many ways. They can save you time, help you concentrate, improve your energy levels, etc. The technology we want to bring to the market is much more advanced and allows us to focus attention on a very important aspect of people's lives – how they spend their precious time. What we wanted to bring to this market is a monitor that you don't want to take off the wall and use every day for the rest of the day. It's not going to be right for what everyone needs. Everyone will have a different style. That's what makes this market so exciting – it's not just a consumer product, it's something you can use every day to better yourself or your company. We began our journey by finding products that were high quality, but had some very bad reviews. We put a great many hours into finding all the things we really needed to add to these products. Finally, after spending our time finding all these little details, we had a brand new monitor that was ready for prime time. We were ready to meet with this manufacturer. We got to the point where people were calling us (or emailing from their sites) telling us how great this monitor was. Not only did it have a lot of features to help the customer stay more focused, it had a ton of customization choices. Not only could it be customized, but we could modify some of the accessories as we saw fit. It would be such a neat monitor that I wanted to do whatever I could to get it to you. The good news is that we have that monitor with us in the office. It's a fantastic monitor. We can't wait to show you. Unfortunately, that was the end of the first project. We had a similar situation with a video camera we designed. The same thing happened. We wanted to do just as much research and build as much as we could but just could't stay focused until we had a very, very high-quality camera in our hands. We did everything we could to get this project done (we're in the office and ready to go) and then a week later the CEO of a competitor called us. He said they were very interested in this product and if we had the specs we'd be willing to bring it to the market. We told him that we had the specs and were very confident in our product. What this new CEO also mentioned was that he was looking forward to working with us to bring the product to consumers

How to write high-quality code for mobile devices. A tutorial that will show you how to write a simple API that lets you build mobile applications in Swift. Learn how to handle common problems that may occur when trying to build Android or iOS apps, such as using APIs that do not exist or working with a device that doesn't have everything you might want.

The idea that there's something intrinsically bad about men was never more pronounced than during the time of Victorian England, a time when men were viewed as weak and irrational. So what was it about men that was considered so vile that they needed to be exterminated? In this provocative documentary, filmmaker David E. Moore explores what he describes as a "cult of masculinity" that swept through Victorian England. Drawing on historical documents, his study offers a critical exploration of a social phenomenon that is still felt today. Produced by Michael Schur. Camera by Paul Vipond. Additional camera by Michael Schur.

A former deputy head of the New Zealand army has admitted he "didn't always understand" the country's Defence Act, a legal ruling which could have been used to have him imprisoned. "I made some mistakes," Major-General Michael Stirling told the New Zealand Herald. "If it [the court's ruling] is going to be used to take me down, I don't really want to see that. That's my view." READ MORE: * Defence Act could have stopped Kiwi policeman's arrest * NZ soldier's claim against military dismissed * NZ army officer says judge took decision 'out of context' * Wellington-based soldier says she was tortured to death in Iraq * New Zealand police accused of taking up soldier's rape investigation * NZ soldier claims she was raped, jailed after sex assault conviction The Military and Veterans Ombudsman said he was unable to say whether military policy in particular, or the rule of law in general, would have prevented the court ruling, which was handed down at Wellington District Court yesterday. However, he said it could have been used as evidence at a later stage. "We can look at the evidence that was given then," Dr Mike Haines from the Office of the Military and Veterans Ombudsman said. "The key to the defence is the case." Stirling has been placed on restricted duties pending the outcome of the case. His defence attorney, Steve Rogers, said the soldier was very anxious and distressed, and would not wish to comment further. The case related to alleged abuse and neglect of the Army medic in Iraq. Stirling was part of an airlift unit at the Camp Bastion site in Baghdad from 2006 to 2008, which deployed thousands of soldiers there to help build up the security services there. At the time, the medic was arrested and detained by US forces, despite being cleared by an investigating prosecutor. The medic's allegation of rape caused international uproar, and the New Zealand government suspended its relationship with US forces after the incident. Stirling was the head of the Army at the time, and in his official statement to Air Force Base Base on July 15, 2008 that his troops would follow medical orders, he said it would be up to the commander of the base on who should be arrested and punished, and then down to the base commander themselves. The prosecutor in the case, Sergeant-Major Stephen Storr, took the decision that the medic should be charged, and Storr said the court ruling did not reflect any opinion he may have had about the soldier's actions. "The prosecution was not seeking to obtain a conviction." Storr also said there was a difference between the legal process at the end of the day though. "The decision was made by the military judge and not the court." He described the court ruling as "a clear case of injustice". "It's a real shock to those that are involved," said Storr. "It's not been a case of people having to make tough decisions for no good reason. "The case was made fairly, with evidence given and witnesses called to back up that case." Storr said as far as the medic was concerned, he accepted that he probably did not tell Stirling what to do with evidence that had been handed over, even though Stirling was his direct superior by rank. "It was an error by the chief of staff as far as I could see, and a mistake that he should not have made by a commander of a high rank." The ruling against Stirling meant he had to forfeit his rank, and had been sentenced to five months detention. Storr described Stirling as "a man of great integrity, a man with strong character and a man of great integrity". New Zealand Defence Force chief Commander Lieutenant General Peter MacNeill commended Stirling for bringing the matter to the attention of officials at Camp Bastion. "The decision of the court reflects how important it is for all service personnel to follow the rules of military justice and be open and honest with their commanding officers and commanders about these rules." Stirling said he believed he was "fairly represented" when he went to plead his case against Major-General John Wilson. He said he found out a week before it went before a judge that he was not charged with any crimes. "I have been extremely shocked," Stirling said. "I did not do anything wrong, and the whole of my unit did nothing wrong. It's been a pretty shock. "I'm probably not too well pleased to be here for 10 days." Stirling had served in Baghdad with the Army for almost 20 years. He said he was proud of his service and in particular, his part in Operation Tidal Wave in Somalia. "

Trying to understand the relationship between religion and politics is like trying to explain a relationship between the number five and the concept of zero. Neither are quite right, and neither are wrong. The two concepts are not quite what one would expect. There are five numbers, all of which are used in a certain way (one is a positive number, two a negative), and yet none of the numbers has a distinct meaning. The concept of zero as this fundamental unit of measurement, where there is no longer any value to be reckoned upon, is perhaps better-suited to being described that way. As I've stated several times in the past, I see religion as something much broader and more complicated than a set of ideas. I see the concept of religion as not only a means of defining and describing the universe, it is a state of mind that can be described as something like enlightenment or being reborn. I would go a step further to say that this experience of having the universe in perfect balance with oneself is like the experience of being fully in the moment. One is fully absorbed in the wonder of it all. The mind gets an unbalanced perspective that feels more like a jolt, it comes with a feeling of being totally lost in a sense, as though one's very being is at a loss. Yet, as the experience goes on, the mind becomes increasingly clear, one loses all sense that this is a real, unique experience, and gradually, after a number of weeks, the feeling becomes an integral part of the person as a whole. If you've never experienced this phenomenon, you might wonder how you are different. To be quite frank, it's something that is not something you'd want to experience in your everyday life. I'm a Buddhist, so it's not likely that most of you experience enlightenment on a daily basis. The same goes for reincarnation, for example. This doesn't mean that we aren't all equal on the spiritual end. For instance, someone who has only had a spiritual understanding of a few years and yet is still as spiritual as they were before is a great example of this sort of experience. This phenomenon is quite a hard thing to conceptualise. Some people may say that one can understand the concept of the five numbers, although I have yet to find something that explains it. I did start thinking about it because of recent statements that Pope Francis has made, like the statement that we need to consider an atheist's position when trying to determine what Christianity teaches. This seems like a very odd statement considering that Christians are so certain that Jesus was born of a virgin and that he was crucified on a cross. Yet, the Pope still has this idea about atheism. I'm not even sure how to describe what I feel for this experience. I know it's not that strange to describe it as "wonderful". However, I feel that it's impossible to know if this sort of thing really happens, and if it has happened that it is an experience that every sentient being has. If an experience like this is so easy to understand, it must have a very large impact on one's daily life, yet it is possible that there aren't even that many of us who have this sort of experience – if that was the case, then I'm in trouble because I couldn't give up this job to spend more time contemplating things like this! However, I wouldn't make the assertion that it is impossible for anyone to experience this. I'm not entirely convinced that I have. However, I do see some aspects of the process which make me think that I am one of those rare people. Like everything else, to understand it is to experience it. And just like every other thing, if one didn't experience it, it would be meaningless. And, of course, we do have a choice in how we experience it – some people seem to experience it very readily, and others may not for a time. However, I believe that it is only those who have this experience who have the ability to understand it. I have a suspicion that the Pope is one of those people. The Pope's statement that everyone should have the possibility to be reborn in God also resonates to my understanding. We are all reborn in nature to eventually find a place we feel comfortable. I also have a sneaking suspicion that he means reincarnation, although it wouldn't be entirely correct to say that he doesn't understand reincarnation, because he is certainly aware of it, it's just a subject that he doesn't really seem to have any interest in. When I was a child, my mother used to talk to me about how to make a good home for those whom we would kill in war. And to me, she was talking about people like me, those who would do horrible things to others for no good reason. This idea was also echoed in one of my favourites movie, Fight Club. You don't have to be a math major to know that, on a logarithmic scale, a small difference is a large difference; and in sports, where speed is king, small differences can make large differences. Here are five numbers, five athletes and five states that matter to the outcome of the Big Ten Championship and beyond. 1. Ohio State (4), No. 4 in AP Poll (10-1) In some measure, this is an Ohio State team we have seen before. The Buckeyes have had a stretch of three straight unbeaten titles -- the last one was in 2011 -- and a run of four consecutive top-50 classes. The roster has been loaded: four Buckeyes who have started at least a game and six players who have been selected to at least one All-America team, and not many more. The key is how fast those players have been able to get to their spots. The offense will give Ohio State all kinds of problems but, in terms of this game, it's how well they can execute an intricate, high-speed, up-tempo play at the line of scrimmage. And how well they have been able to get the players to do that. In this game, the defense is going to give some Ohio State problems but, again, those explosive Buckeyes will be the ones who ultimately win the game. 2. Wisconsin (11), No. 9 in AP Poll (9-1) Wisconsin's offense ranks fourth in the FBS in scoring (48.2 ppg; No. 12 in the nation), and its defense is ranked in the top 10 (No. 8 nationally). Its biggest accomplishment thus far in 2015 is avoiding being ranked last at the end of the season -- after beating Michigan State and Michigan in the regular seasons, and then beating Iowa and Purdue when Iowa and Purdue had good performances in conference play. A win tonight could make that streak even longer. If Wisconsin can play for 40 minutes like the Badgers did in the first three weeks (with Wisconsin outscoring its opponents 73-33) then the Buckeyes will likely need to settle for a one-point win. So they'll have to play defense, which they have to do against a Wisconsin defense that ranks first nationally in defense giving up only 5.0 yards per play. If Wisconsin can stop the Buckeyes' receivers, then the Buckeyes should have a good chance of scoring, and to stop those Buckeyes, the Badgers should be able to apply a pass rush to the Buckeyes. Wisconsin's best chance to win this game might be from turnovers. A strong defensive turnover margin is what gives Wisconsin its identity and, if the Badgers can be disruptive throughout, they can be a player that Ohio State will have trouble with. 3. Michigan (12), No. 8 in AP Poll (9-1) Michigan's offense has been the best in the division the past two weeks, the way it scored 21 points against Ohio State and 41 against Nebraska. Then the offense had a three-game streak of scoring fewer than 20 points. After that streak, though, Michigan scored a season-high 44 points. And after that...well, the numbers were the numbers. In the past two games, the Wolverines averaged more than 42 points per game; in the loss to Nebraska they averaged a mind-blowing 55 points. That Nebraska game was a back-and-forth affair where the Wolverines had the ball and were leading by a touchdown in the late stages, but Michigan couldn't score. In any other circumstance this game would have been a walk in the park for Michigan, but for the Wolverines' inability to get to the middle of the field, the Buckeyes are going to score big. 4. Illinois (13), No. 8 in AP Poll (8-2-1) In its two games against Purdue and Indiana, the Illini offense has averaged 48.7 points. After a win over Illinois State, Purdue came to Champaign and did the exact same thing. But the Illini defense -- ranked second nationally in points allowed per drive (2.57) -- will be key for the Illini. Purdue's offense, the reason it has won four of its last five, averaged 40 points per game in those four games, and the Badgers' offense has been solid against the Big Ten's bottom-five schedule. The only problem is that Purdue is at home and a lot of that Illinois team from the past two seasons has disappeared: the Illini defense was a little better last year than this year for some reason. I suppose that could happen again. 5. Michigan State (10), No. 2 in AP Poll (9-1), No. 3 in Coaches Poll (11-0) I'll be honest: I'm trying to keep an arms-length perspective on the Badgers and Wolverines in this game. When they were ranked 11th and 12th, respectively, I

The Obama administration is considering allowing the government and major phone companies to share "bulk collection" data with each other, according to The Wall Street Journal — a move that would significantly expand the agency's ability to share information with the National Security Agency and other allies on domestic terrorism investigations. According to the report, under a new proposal being considered by the National Security Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the U.S. government and companies like Verizon or AT&T would be able to share "all the telephone records" of every American from Verizon's main data centers. Companies would still have privacy rights over that information, but as much as 90 percent of it could be shared directly by the government with its counterparts in other countries.  Read: *A brief history of the NSA This is an update of a story originally published on May 28, 2012.

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia Haji Mohammed Ali al-Attash (died December 26, 1985) was an Iraqi jihadist, a leader of Saddam Hussein's Baath Party and one of the chief architects of the Iraq-Iran War,[3] who was killed on March 5, 1985, in an air strike targeting the Baath Party headquarters in Baghdad and the Iraqi National Guard, killing about 1,000 people.[1][2] His death was widely reported, even in the New York Times.[3] He was also known in the West as the "Axis of Evil" for supporting the Soviet Union during World War II.[4] Background [ edit ] Haji Mohammed Ali al-Attash was born in Baghdad on April 16, 1930, to Mohammed Haji Yahya al-Attash and a woman identified only as Aisha. After Haji Mohammed's father died when he was young, his mother gave him to his uncle, who became a member of the Baath Party by 1936 and a deputy to President of Iraq Rashid Ali al-Hussein. By 1938, Attash was appointed to a position within the Party. Attash joined the Baath Party and was promoted to a position of military deputy to Saddam Hussein. This promoted him to the rank of colonel.[5] When the Iraqi Communist Party launched a general strike on September 3, 1950, Attash called a meeting of Party members and explained that the government was a tool of the imperial powers and that communists had to cooperate with the government. The meeting approved his proposals and the strike was immediately ended. Haji Mohammed Attash and Haji Ali Hassan al-Iraqi A year later, he was expelled from the Party when it was discovered that he advocated armed resistance to the government. He also spoke out against the creation of the Iraqi military after the First Gulf War. However, his criticism caused him to be banned from the Military Intelligence Section for five years, and, eventually, to be imprisoned after the United States bombed the Ministry of Defense on August 19, 1961.[6] He claimed that the bombing was a violation of the Geneva Convention for the Amelioration of the Condition of the Wounded and Sick in Iraqui in September of 1961; he also claimed that it was a violation of his right to be heard. This case was heard before a Military Court under the Military Tribunal and General Court Act for the Iraqi Soviet Friendship Treaty and for Terrorism.[6] However, after a lengthy court battle, the court ruled that Attash's statements had in fact been well within what was permitted as a matter of freedom of speech; however, there was evidence that the charges leveled against Attash were not supported by proof.[6] Attash's arrest and imprisonment provoked protests by Iraqi dissidents. On 28 February 1961, Attash was transferred by a firing squad to the Military Intelligence prison. He remained in the facility until October of 1962.[7] Attash first entered the political arena by endorsing Saddam's first presidential bid in January 1962. During the 1960s, Attash wrote articles criticizing the government, writing that it was "a government made of criminals and robbers who preyed upon the public good." Attash's first act as a political leader in 1963 was to establish an opposition party, with a branch in Baghdad. Atta was elected to the Iraqi parliament in 1964, and then later became a minister in the Baathist government of President Gamal Abdul-Nasser in 1968-1971, and held various ministerial posts in the government. In 1971, he was appointed to the position of governor of Basra province. He was also the chairman of the Baath Party's Political Bureau, under which he oversaw its day-to-day operation. However, the party was banned in 1972, and Attash was arrested on 27 March 1978 by a special counter-revolutionary group led by Saddam, and eventually killed by a firing squad in May, 1985.[2] Political career [ edit ] Attash spent the last thirty years of his life working in the offices of the Baath Party under the Iraqi Communist Party, and, in 1967, founded the Iraqi Socialist Party. During his life, Attash was a member of the Iraqi Communist Party, the Iraqi Socialist Party, and the Baath Party. His positions varied between a Communist and a leftist.[8] Attash began his political career supporting Saddam's first presidential campaign, but changed his mind when the Baathist party attempted to ban political opposition. Atta then switched his support to a radical faction of the Baath-led government which was opposed to the moderate faction. He began to oppose the Baath policies of nationalization of property, which he viewed as taking away private property. He supported the Iraqi Communist Party's call for an end to Soviet pressure in the Middle East, and was also a supporter of Iran. In late July 1971, he attended a demonstration in the streets of Baghdad at which the Baath leadership

Marijuana plants grow at Kannapolis Valley High School on Feb. 27, 2007, in North Carolina. Marijuana has been legalized for recreational use in the U.S. High school senior John R. Pinto started getting stoned at age 12, and it "was like nothing I'd ever been exposed to," he told VICE. It was the best high he'd ever had. He remembers "a lot of the kids at school saying they had smoked weed before, and I thought, 'Wow, is this really what it's like to have this effect?' " But as teenagers, Pinto says he doesn't go around "smoking weed anymore." As states like California legalize weed for recreational use, kids like Pinto like it because it makes them less prone to stress and helps them focus better. "When you're high, you don't make mistakes that way. It gets you in a better state of mind, and you don't get so stressed out," he told VICE. But even Pinto admits pot isn't a great drug for everyone. It can impair cognitive function, cause cognitive loss, anxiety, and paranoia, and even trigger the development of drug-use disorders like marijuana addiction, according to data from the National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA). And for teenagers like Pinto, those harmful effects can be amplified by other factors like the stress of trying to do a good grade, the pressure of trying to find a good partner, or other difficulties and challenges in their lives that make it hard for them just to hold down a job. For people like Pinto, marijuana is like a "medicine" to help them through a hard period. "When I'm high, I don't make mistakes. I don't care as much about school. All my problems I'm better at dealing with when I'm high on weed," he says, noting his high school "was like a prison." John M. Pinto. Photo via WikiMedia Commons But that doesn't mean he uses weed to get high. In fact, the 25-year-old says he's only smoked it once, which he doesn't recommend even when he can. "I don't smoke weed for the high. I smoke it because I smoke it all the time," he told VICE. "I don't really like its effects. I'm not into the feeling of high. I mean, I've only had cannabis twice in my life." To get high? Like Pinto, most people who try pot find it to be more a "medicine" than a drug like heroin or cocaine. But there's no doubt that cannabis is a good medicine for people with medical conditions. In fact, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) even issued a recommendation in 2011 stating that medical marijuana could be a viable treatment for AIDS patients. Mental health experts agree, but they say it's best to understand that marijuana isn't just the "weed" it's often associated with, and that it's most often seen as the medicine. People's motivations in using marijuana to treat mental health conditions vary. Marijuana can help people in other ways, too. "Marijuana is a very effective medicine for a lot of people who need to manage pain and nausea. There's some evidence that people can have a lot of the same benefits that people get with smoked cannabis, for example, as with opioids, which is a much better drug to use with," Jason Papp, the executive director of the Colorado chapter of the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, told The Denver Post in February. For young people like John R. Pinto, cannabis feels more like a "medicine" to help them deal with stress and focus better. Photo via WikiMedia Commons However, that benefit is limited. Many studies have found there are no significant long-term outcomes for patients using medical marijuana. Still, the substance remains legal in a handful of states—including Colorado, Washington, Oregon, Alaska, and Washington D.C.—and a number more states could soon join it. But the federal government has a different view. As it continues to work toward an April 20, 2016 deadline to legalize recreational weed nationwide, the Obama administration is cracking down on states that have taken steps to legalize marijuana for recreational use by adults under 21. Under this policy, the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) has been threatening marijuana businesses that have grown or made money off states' legal weed markets—like those in Washington D.C. and Colorado—with civil asset forfeiture. According to a July letter from DEA Acting Administrator Chuck Rosenberg, the agency will not interfere with or "interfere with the enforcement of the Controlled Substances Act" by those jurisdictions, even if they're operating in accordance with state law. As part of its policy, Rosenberg says marijuana businesses and consumers

MARK ZUCKERBERG, AP Business Writer WASHINGTON (AP) — A federal judge in Texas denied Friday a bid by President Donald Trump to bar an employee of the Environmental Protection Agency from testifying about his interactions with Trump. The Department of Justice filed a brief Friday in a lawsuit brought by David Bernhardt, who is an EPA employee based in Dallas. In his lawsuit, Bernhardt said Trump has violated the constitution's emoluments clause by accepting financial payments from foreign governments. The Justice Department said in its Friday filing that Bernhardt "sought to enjoin any future emoluments-related investigations."

When his family was searching for the right home for him, a couple in Florida had an unexpected surprise waiting for them. "The first thing I said to my mom is that I'd love it if I could move in," he said. After his family searched homes in several states and got lucky on several occasions, they found their dream home. He told NBC 4 New York that "It's really nice, it's nice." The family moved into the tiny home for $50,000, less than what it would have cost to buy a three-bedroom house. The family took out an mortgage to help cover a down payment of $25,000, and the rest was covered by a $30,000 tax credit that a tax prep business helped them obtain. The property is in the community of Okeechobee, about 45 minutes from Walt Disney World, and is part of a cluster of affordable rental homes. In another rare find, NBC 4 NY reported that a New York family found a six-bedroom house for just $100,000, despite many offers. "It feels like the housing market is still really shaky," said Jim Schilling of real estate firm JLL. "It hasn't really recovered from the recession." But he added, "(It) was really very lucky they found that house," because "If it was right next door to them, it would have been priced much higher than it was." NBC 4 New York reported that prices for new homes are going as high as $800,000. The Associated Press contributed to this report. Copyright Associated Press / NBC New York

This is part of our ongoing series, "On the Road to Zero Emissions". Join us in our exploration of climate engineering and beyond through our weekly live livestream, and our other video content. Lately, the news has not been great for global warming. First, President Trump took some action on the topic, announcing a pair of executive orders to withdraw the United States from the Paris Climate Agreement. Then, in February, the New Zealand government announced that it would seek carbon offsets and other greenhouse gas reductions for all ships that use the country's ports. Meanwhile, other countries are moving in the opposite direction. In November, the German government announced that it would ban all new coal plants by 2022 and replace coal with renewables by 2050. For some people, those events, or the political climate around them, signal a return to the past. "We are getting close to the point where we can safely phase out coal power and return to what we did in the past," said Greenpeace's international climate spokesperson, Alex Loms. What's the alternative? According to scientists, many of the measures put forth by other countries are not feasible, or even environmentally sound. What's more, many have also been criticized for pushing away low-carbon energy sources and putting climate targets at risk. But it's still possible to move in the right direction. "You cannot shut down any nuclear power plant in the world – including the two most polluting in terms of CO2 emissions," explained Loms. In response to recent political pressure, France has announced that it will close down the last reactor at the now-outdated Chalk River plant by 2017. Japan's Kyushu Electric Power plans to close its No. 11 and a pair of nuclear reactors in Sendai in 2018. This week, South Australia announced that it would close its brown coal-fired power plant at Abbot Point by 2019, joining Germany in its phase-out plan. "We're still in the process of getting back to fossil fuels," said Daniel Hirschmann, a climate scientist at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. "The challenge is that the climate challenge is still there. It's harder to decarbonize and transition to clean energy and do it quickly. For example, we've still got to do everything we can to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in cars." So what should we do? And who should pay? What should we do? The short answer? We need a global plan and funding to accelerate the transition away from fossil fuels. In fact, that's the focus of the Clean Energy Ministerial that will convene in Berlin on January 26. But while much of the focus has been on the US and China, an international solution must include Canada, which is also in the midst of planning for an end to coal-fired power. It may also require other countries to rethink their reliance on coal to meet their climate commitments. As of Wednesday, Australia has joined China, India, and South Africa in pledging to phase out their carbon emissions by 2030, and the UK is expected to announce its pledge later this month. There will also be announcements from other countries in 2017 and 2018. All of this should make it all the more difficult for countries to turn away from their fossil-fuel-based carbon dioxide emissions. A recent analysis from Climate Action Tracker has estimated that the world will need to reach a net-zero emissions target for 2050, meaning the total amount of CO 2 emitted by human activities could drop to zero. This comes on top of countries having already committed to the internationally-agreed agreement in Paris and countries around the world already doing more than 100 percent renewable energy. Meanwhile, many states in the country are actively planning for renewables. "Our goal should be to have 100 percent renewables by 2035," said Massachusetts Secretary of Environment and Energy Richard Blumenthal. While some think they can make money investing in renewables, most renewable energy companies in the United States are struggling. According to a recent survey from the Solar Energy Industries Association, there are only 17% of companies that reported profitability in 2016, and there are concerns that this number has decreased even further in 2017. If companies are only able to turn a profit at a level of profitability of 2 cents, for every dollar spent on financing for renewables, companies will have a tough time competing. In the meantime, the US and Canada now have one another's backs. According to US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, Canada and the United States "are going to be the natural partners in the transition" from fossil fuels to renewables. Canada has set aside $1 billion to invest in the development of clean energy for its businesses and individuals. While the Trump administration is focused on climate change policy, other countries have also made policy changes in recent years. Germany is implementing a ban on coal-fired power, France has increased its ambition for renewables, and South Australia has announced that it will close its old coal-

A few months after I first started writing my thoughts on Magic Online at StarCityGames.com, I decided that I wanted a more open format I had a lot of experience with called Constructed. I had been playing a lot of Commander over the years, and I just thought that I would like to explore it further, but I hadn't built around a format before. In the fall of 2005, I found Magic Online and tried playing on it with a couple of friends. It really seemed like the best way to test for Constructed! My first Constructed deck was my Commander deck. I called it "The Command Zone" as I would put together a lot of cards from a box and build a deck around those cards. I had a bunch of cards for the commander, and a ton of ways to put together cards that would have made a good commander. We played a game with cards drawn from a basic land, and in order to win I had to have enough artifacts in the Command Zone to do so! We had a lot of fun with this deck, though we eventually ran out of artifacts... I had four copies of Urza's Legacy from back in the day, so I used those. During this time period at home, I was putting together my personal collection of Magic cards, and that became the base for what we played at home with my family. We played a lot of Commander, and every once in awhile, some of my collection would take on a new meaning for a Commander game. I started playing a lot more with Commander games at home, and then I started playing with it more regularly at StarCityGames.com, but I hadn't really built around a format at the time that I wanted to. The other thing that I was interested in doing was testing Magic Online as heavily as possible, and it didn't take long for me to get into a format where I could play a tournament and win it! I started playing with Constructed on Magic Online with a couple of friends and I quickly discovered that it was very similar to my family Constructed deck. If you have a game plan, you can play the same deck over and over again and win a lot of those! It was a lot of fun. I had a deck of cards that I had gotten ahold of. I was playing a version on Magic Online called "The Gauntlet," and I was making money off of selling my old cards for dollars! In November 2005, Wizards of the Coast offered me a Magic Online subscription and sent a copy of Magic with a subscription code to me on December 15, 2005. At that time, I was living on the West Coast, so this was an incredibly exciting opportunity if I wanted to get back into Magic playing a lot. My wife was actually pretty happy about this because they gave me the opportunity to play with my wife's favorite game. So, I decided to give it a try, and that was the beginning of my career playing Magic. My first Constructed tournament was a PTQ in the Bay Area. I got a good finish in the Swiss and made it to the Top 8. I actually had a good finish but was unlucky in the draft. My first match I mulliganed to 5, but my opponent got my lands and didn't mulligan once. The second match was a mirror match with him, and he won the whole thing! I had a lot of fun building and playing this deck, so I moved on to other formats, but Magic kept on coming back. In February 2006, I started seeing more people playing Magic online more frequently, and it just kind of snowballed from there. I ended up winning a Grand Prix with that deck I had been building for a while. Then I went on a rampage in the second-to-last tournament I played in with the list I had built. In January of 2006, I started writing my articles at StarCityGames.com that were in the vein of the articles you find for any other Magic Online online magazine. I wrote a couple of articles on different things and ended up winning one of them! Then I got invited to Wizards of the Coast for the 2006 Pro Tour, and I ended up winning a whole bunch of prizes including a nice custom-built Mox Diamond! After the Pro Tour, I went back to playing the same Commander deck that I had played with on Magic Online at StarCityGames and started winning more tournaments. I started to get a lot of interest in online Magic. This was also around the time that I got introduced to the Magic Online Team Constructed, and I was able to get two of my best friends to start playing this format together. The rest is great history. The format we play now is called Magic Online Extended. The format is pretty much the same thing that Vintage Masters was before it got split into Modern Masters and Standard Masters, but now there is an Extended and a Standard Masters. Each format is a different experience as you try to make different things happen with

The next day I received a very sweet message from her saying she was a single mom and that she had been thinking of me and sending me a photo. I just found out yesterday that she is a single mom with 5 kids, so I sent this a few days ago, and she got it!

As you may have heard before, there's another great movie out in theaters this Friday. You've also probably heard that I was recently in attendance at the film's premiere in London, and I'll tell you that I don't regret my trip. Well, I might have a slight excuse: this is one of those rare occasions where I was able to check out both the first and third installments of the Amazing Spider-Man franchise, in addition to a few other surprises. I had the pleasure of sitting in on two trailers for the films, which were first screened in London and then again in New York earlier this month. This was my first time seeing the film in that format, and it was exciting to see some of my favorite aspects of the origin story get a bit more of a screen time in the two movies. Of course, some things didn't quite go as planned during the premiere. I can't take away too much of the fun of seeing Spider-Man fight the Venom symbiote, or the action scenes and character development that were shown in the trailers. The best bits probably came during the Q & A, which I will definitely share with you soon for this week's ComicBook.com. I also got a chance to sit in on the following Q & A session: Question: How has it different playing the Venom symbiote, since there is also a new villain in this? Gavin Hood: A little bit different, but I was playing the clone of the original. I mean, you've always got the same guy. He's just not on screen now… You know it's very exciting, but as an actor, you're always thinking about your character, because the character has changed through the years. He might be more or less interesting, but you know he's not going to last that long. I'm playing the clone of Spider-Man. And the whole fun of being a Spider-Man movie that doesn't have the web slinging of the movies we've been used to is that if these guys are going to be playing like villains, they can come as villains. It's a nice change of pace for everyone involved. Question: What were some of the things that were cut from this trailer to make it into the film? Gavin Hood: Well, you know, I just have to say that I really enjoyed the way the trailer ended with Venom in the sewers of New York and then going into the heart of Manhattan. That's the way I wanted that to start the movie. That wasn't cut. Question: As a filmmaker, what makes it important that these films be unique and different from each other? Gavin Hood: Well, I think that they all have to have their own distinct identity. I think that they all have to be original. And I think that it's an important challenge for us to try and take the films in different directions. Also read: Amazing Spider-Man Sequel Explained – How The First Two Movies Interconnected Question: And how do you think you would describe the story that Chris Pratt is telling? Gavin Hood: My impression is that it's more of a straight up action story. I'm sort of more interested in that, where the movie is taking it. I think it's the same kind of story, where Peter Parker is trying to get back to New York and get a job, and he falls in with somebody who's a little too dangerous to be around. A very nice introduction to him is through his best friend, Gwen Stacy. Not many people know that she was Peter's first crush, and she's probably still the greatest thing about his life. And this woman becomes this very strong ally as the movie moves along. She's very much in the background, but she plays a larger role over the course of the next several films. And I thought that she really brought some life to the role. And of course, all of Peter Parker's friends are there. That was an important part of the story that we weren't able to tell in the final cut of the first one, which was a lot about the school at Peter's high school, and his friends and how he got his spider powers. I thought that all of the characters that we met in that were involved in that story are important, that we'll see some of their origins. And we'll learn all about it. You know it's a lot about a good teacher who is teaching Peter this thing called being a superhero. And then the whole supporting cast of people who help out Peter in his superhero career is going to be important to the movie. Question: It was revealed in the trailers that The Lizard (James Franco) turned out to be Venom, and there has been a bunch of speculation about whether or not that's accurate. Do you think that might've been a little too much to leave out. Gavin Hood: Well, in the new film

I'll be honest with you. I wasn't even aware of the phenomenon known as "Sagittarius Rising" until my friends on Facebook, who are all Scorpios, started posting the phrase. When you look that term up in the Merriam-Webster dictionary, you'll find that the definition for that term is a "rising sign of the zodiac." The word "rising" is a bit vague, and it doesn't specify an exact date, but for the purpose of this article, one can assume to be sometime during August. For those of you who didn't know, Sagittarius is one of the more mysterious signs of the zodiac, as it represents the very best and worst of things. It's often referred to as "the horse of the zodiac," which isn't necessarily a bad thing, per se. After all, being associated with the horse is a very positive thing, yet there are several negative traits associated with Sagittarius. And if you can't stand that, this is probably not the sign for you. Also, since we're on a tangent, Sagittarius doesn't really have much of a birth-chart. Regardless of what sign a Scorpio is, they do possess many traits and characteristics that define them in one way or another. And no one knows what those traits are more than us. As far as Sagittarius and the signs they fall under go, Scorpio, in particular, shares some traits with those of the Cancer sign. Sagittarius Rising is a very intense time of the year. Even if you haven't done any hard work in the form of work, it still seems like the sun is making this journey to get here with us. A lot of this is due to the rising Sun, but other factors also influence your situation. For example, a very stressful year can affect Sagittarius in two ways: either physically, or mentally, which can become quite overwhelming. If you have lived a life of constant stress, it can be difficult to break this cycle. We don't have to do this ourselves because each of us is a unique being and can learn to take care of ourselves if we want. We're capable of dealing with these kinds of things, so what can you do to make this time of year better for yourself? Start doing the things that matter to you If you don't do anything, by the time the sun arrives on August 15th, your mind has been prepped for what to expect. This means that everything you've been doing, whether it's work, school, volunteering, or even socializing and being with friends, will all be over. It is very important that you do what you've been doing. It can be tough, but when we stop being motivated, we will fail when the storm hits. If you really want to be the best, then you need to go out and keep on working. You would do this because you want to make your parents or teachers proud of you. It is really important that you keep working. The best of us do whatever it takes. And the best of us work for something that matters to us, something that matters to others, and something that is truly meaningful. Once you make this decision to put your heart and soul into your work, you will see it pay off in big dividends very quickly. You will be in charge, which means that you will have complete control over your own life. Once the storm passes, things will feel a little more relaxed as well. This is especially true if you keep yourself motivated, which will help you with the next stage of the challenge: The storm is over and now things really begin… Preparing for the New Year This is why I am telling you to prepare for the storm. We have to take it upon ourselves to build what our hearts and minds are calling to put into place. There is no other way we will know what to do. And for the first time in awhile, it feels so exciting to take back what we have lost in the last year. It can be difficult to believe your own eyes, but a few pieces can help make you more positive and help you get ready for the New Year. It was last week that I had the opportunity to see a movie called I Love You, Man. It is one of the most controversial films to be released this year, but I have been a huge fan of the movie for a very long time now. Even so, it was a little strange to see it because it involves a male character who has lost his family, so I guess it was somewhat timely that it came out at this time. Although the movie was difficult to watch, I was able to identify with the character from the moment he says "I Love You…Man" and goes up to a woman who has been the same way. He tells her she's beautiful, that she is strong, and that she doesn't need his

The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers has on September 18 signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with China to jointly explore in the Spratly Islands of the Spratlys and Paracel islands in the East China Sea. This "expeditionary joint working group" agreement is subject to the approval by the U.S. Congress, according to the Pentagon website. The MOU is significant because it "will mark a new phase in the ongoing U.S.-China dialogue that seeks to improve military-to-military relations," according to the military. This MOU is designed to facilitate the U.S. military's efforts to conduct an observation mission and to conduct a scientific survey of the two artificial islands. The MOU comes after China's recent military maneuvers that coincided with the U.S.-China Strategic and Economic Dialogue.

There are no reports that the police are asking about whether any individuals were under duress or under the influence of drugs. This comes more than a month after Michael Brown was shot and killed by Darren Wilson, a white police officer in Ferguson, Mo. — a police situation that is still being investigated. "People are going to be hurt, people are going to get hurt on their side, on our side, everywhere," said the officer who helped Mr. Brown escape. "It is going to happen." Mr. Brown was shot several times about 9:18 p.m. on Aug. 9 in the police response to a call about someone possibly breaking into cars at an isolated intersection. The officer stopped Mr. Brown without provocation in a vacant lot, then ordered him to get on the ground. Mr. Brown put his hands in the air but failed to comply, according to the police account of the incident. A struggle began between the two, prompting the officer to fire several shots. Police found the body about half a block from where he had been stopped, wearing only the one-piece Nike track suit and a white T-shirt on the way to the police station. Photo Some witnesses told local media that Mr. Brown appeared to be fighting the officer while Mr. Wilson fired his weapon. The state medical examiner, Dr. Daniel J. Messel, and a grand jury have not determined whether the officer's shooting was self-defense or criminally negligent, according to interviews in The New York Times with a dozen law enforcement officials and outside experts. Advertisement Continue reading the main story Law enforcement officials and private analysts described a complicated investigation that has relied on a variety of tools, from tracking cellphone signals to watching security video. A St. Louis police official said detectives had spent about $18,000 on surveillance equipment to photograph the area where Mr. Brown was shot and examined it using high-tech equipment. I am working on another project, a small, simple app with a very small memory footprint. To be more specific, it's about a string which contains a "c" and no more spaces.  Here's the current strings: "c#,#,c" "c#,#,c#,#"  You should be able to see in memory all of these strings. I should get all of them back on one run as there's no data I am retrieving from the database.  Now go ahead and do the following thing (and the following will depend on what OS your are running on): (Note: this may or may not work on your computer but since my laptop is a Mac, I won't assume any other OS's will actually work) open a new tab and navigate to the directory where you are currently working and copy the C:\c\string.m file and rename it to C:\c\string.cpp. open a new tab and navigate to the directory where your C++ program is and copy and rename the C:\cString.m file and rename it to C:\cString.cpp. Then open your program in Visual C and, with your cursor on the C# input type, right-click on it and then choose "Inspect the namespace". You will open in a new tab under a new window with the following text: using System; using System.Collections.Generic; using System.Linq; using System.Text; using System.Threading.Tasks; using System.Runtime.InteropServices; Change the name of the namespace from "String" to something else. That's all you need to do now. It's now time to get the string to return. To do that, you must go and find an existing method called GetString, which is one of the base classes of all C# string types and which I mentioned above. You should see it under the "System.Collections.Generic" namespace. Now, this method is just a wrapper around the String class but you can find this method in a few classes: System.Text.RegularExpressions System.Text.IConvertible System.Text.RegularExpressions.ICaseBound System.Text.RegularExpressions.ICaseBoundMatch  To replace the String.GetString with the method you just found, all you need to do is pass in this string to the ConvertFrom method on the method of your choice. For example, you can replace our string with this string: <?xml version="1.0"?>  <?xml version="1.0"?> <!DOCTYPE ScriptBase PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD ScriptCore 1.1//EN" "http://www.docdroid.net/doc/ScriptCore/1.1/ScriptCore-1.1.dtd"> <Scripts> <Script> {string} convertFrom = new string(getString(getSystem.StringToRawText(c), Convert.ToStringOptions.AllCase)); </Script> </Scripts>  Notice that all that is left after the ConvertFrom is this string: "<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" standalone="no"?>"  Now, once we have the "string" object, we can do the following: string str = c.GetString; if (str == null) { Console.WriteLine("Empty string"); return; } int n = Convert.ToInt32(str.Substring(0, n_in)); Console.WriteLine("%d", n); string str2 = str.Substring(n, str.Length - n_in); string str3 = convertFrom(str2); if (str3.HasLowerCase()) { Console.WriteLine("%d", (n > 0) ? n : 0); } if (str3 == null) { Console.WriteLine("No result"); return; } Console.WriteLine("The content of str : {0}", string.Empty(str)); }  This will output the following: The content of The content of The content of The content of As you can see, if the string str contains no spaces or commas, or if the string str contains extra whitespace (or if the string str contains any other characters which are not allowed by the C# strings language) then it will get automatically converted to a string of the correct length, which is the number of spaces and commas that have been removed from it. CAMEL TREE ORGANIC ALDI (WAL-MART)  "Health is not cheap" Al-Bashamah Al-Shaykh Abdullah Al-Fahd (May Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) *  "Health is not cheap" Al-Bashamah, Shaykh Abdullah Al-Fahd, a prominent Shaykh, who was well known in the UK, USA and Saudi Arabia for the great efforts he has made in promoting health-consciousness and good living.  The book he wrote is written in the Persian language using the Arabic script, which was very popular in the 7th century. It is regarded as one of the great works of medicine in the ancient world. In this work are also the first known works on hygiene and nutrition, with a clear recommendation of using spices for the purpose. The book can be purchased from Amazon.com (Click Here) or any other retailer who would sell books in the world.  The name of this book has many meanings, which may help to understand it.  1. Al-Bashamah, The Arabic word 'Husn', (which means 'Health',) means 'He who cures (Al-Wafa') and 'He who promotes (Ahnaaz)', according to the Shari`ah.  2. Al-Bashah means 'The cure' which was also used in other medical works.  3. The title of the book is 'The Health-Oriented Person' ('Al-Husn al-Mujaan). It is named after the Prophet Muhammed who said: "Whoever becomes the best of persons will be as they (your family members) are in health and the best of (your) family is the one who is in health, and Allaah is Most Great, Most High." [Ibn Majah (20/82)]  The book is based on a very important principle:  1. The person who is very well and healthy is a person like Allah, and he must be protected.  2. This protection must be in Islam, which is the basis of the protection, i.e. it goes from the person to the Creator.  3. All of us have the freedom and the right to take care of ourselves, but the protection and care should be based on Islamic law and the Qur'an.  The idea is very simple. It is quite possible to become well or to be healthy, but to become healthy and to be well depends on Allah, so we should follow the Qur'an in all things, and not be influenced by the outside world. This book has many excellent points in it. It is the work of a man who tried hard over the past 80 years to follow Islam, and to follow the teachings of Allah, and he was respected and sought out among various groups and societies, as I say, by the different Islamic groups. I can't speak to the importance of the book, because of its age at this point and its length, but it is very clear and concise. This type of work was used in the ancient world, until the Arab conquest in the 7th century brought about a cultural change, which affected the health care system in Arab countries. The Arabic language was a difficult language, as it is today in the West, so people often used other languages. The work of a contemporary man in Arabic was so powerful and convincing that it could convince even illiterate Arabs, and even some Arab tribes which were previously non-Muslim, to take the teachings of Islam into consideration in their health and social life, including giving more healthful food, and taking less alcohol as well.  It is a great book to read when the need arises.  I must also note that if an Arab in his or her own country is to be treated well, the best physician is to take the recommendations of those who have succeeded in a good or even excellent health. Therefore, the book is not really an Arabic medical manual, but a personal, practical guide for an individual living in a Muslim-majority country which had achieved such a great level of health, and who will need the advice of an excellent physician, in order to achieve good health. The title of this work is Al-Husn al-Mujaan, which means 'The Health-Oriented Person'. It is named after the Prophet Muhammed who said:The book is based on a very important principle:1. The person who is very well and healthy is a person like Allah, and he must be protected.2. This protection must be in Islam, which is the basis of the protection, i.e. it goes from the person to the Creator.3. All of us have the freedom and the right to take care of ourselves, but the protection and care should be based on Islamic law and the Qur'

When I was little, we used to play one-player chess. I'm not sure why, but since one player in a game is usually the dealer and the other player is the Queen, I think that might have been its reason. It's much easier to understand that way than dealing with three players simultaneously, which requires thinking both at a very high and a very low level. Anyway, we did it and we learned a lot. Then, later on, my father and my brother decided that the game had lost its magic. It was not much fun to play with a full house of players at the table. My sister and her friends and I went to a friend's house and played with several other friends. That game took a lot of planning, planning, planning — and that was what we played the most. And it never seemed quite the same again. I think that one could learn a great deal from playing a board game with a full group of players. The main advantage of playing in a group is that the entire group is involved with the game, all of them participating in decision-making, and so on. But it is not necessary for a game to be board-game-like in terms of the game itself. I've often found that game mechanics are not much important. A game is what you do with it, not what the technology is that provides the playing interface, where the player interfaces with a physical board or with a screen or with an electronic device. On the other hand, I like the simplicity of play that often develops when people learn how to play a game by themselves. I think that one could learn a great deal from playing a board game with a full group of players – that's my personal belief – but, as was seen with chess, a group of the players can also be very dangerous. My best experience of that came at a board game convention for children with whom I was playing chess, and I got very, very bad with those kids, even though I thought I was playing well. They would often try to cheat the opponent – which is very dangerous, of course – by trying to move their pieces before their opponent's, by "shuffling" their cards. Sometimes the cheating would be done in such a way that it was hard to tell for sure what their cards did. I think that it's probably worth teaching children to play games like chess and checkers by themselves, even if it's only as a learning tool. But as a general rule that probably should not be done at board-game table-level events, and certainly not at games conclaves or conventions where they can bring with them their own games that are more complicated than a game like Chess. I used to have this very strange fear of playing a board game with a group of adults. I have always had difficulty playing chess with adults, and I've always had great trouble with games like Chess against the Machine. And I've always thought it was a very interesting thing when you play chess with adults and you don't feel like you are cheating the other players and you have to pay attention and keep track of every single thing. But when you play a two-player game with adults and not only are you cheating your friend and taking part in these interesting intellectual and creative debates on how to play a game of Chess or Risk, but you are also losing a lot because your friends constantly take points from you on this "game," the game is not very good. And the reason is that it's not a real game, it's a chess game. But, as I said, even in chess, the adult rules can be just as challenging, and in fact are sometimes a lot more challenging, than the children's rules you get for free if you play some of these games with your children who are older than you. So if there is a group of people that is going to play board-games, I'd suggest that you play those games only with other adults. Just as it's not OK to play with children. So I don't think I have much to add here. But let me make a few comments. In the last few years, I've thought of teaching some "kids" games to adults: Pandemic, Terra Mystica. I don't know if that's going to be possible given the technical issues that would have to be dealt with as far as the graphic and audio quality went, given the age of the players and the age differences among the groups of players that would have to be accommodated, and so on. If, nevertheless, we can do it, I'd be interested in trying it. Also, I would love to try playing Terra Mystica with someone who was not an adult. I think that would be a very interesting experience too. The basic idea of Terra Mystica is that the players play as colonists on a starship, and then they have to solve puzzles to get the different treasures that are strewn across the ship.
