AUSTIN, Texas, Feb. 18, 2014 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- (Marketwired - Feb. 18, 2014) - NU Capital Partners (the "Company" or "NU CAP"), a leading early stage cannabis investment fund and management company, announced today that it has entered into an agreement (the "Merger Agreement") to merge with The ArcView Group, LLC ("The ArcView Group"), a leading early-stage cannabis investment fund and management company, under which the Company will (i) become a wholly owned subsidiary of The ArcView Group and (ii) become the primary shareholder (a majority investor) of The ArcView Group and will provide The ArcView Group's management team with executive management services and advisory services.  A full copy of the merger agreement, which is not yet complete, will be forwarded to the Securities and Exchange Commission ("SEC") which, upon completion of the merger, will have 30 days to enter into definitive agreement to the terms of the merger agreement. Upon completion of the merger, the Company will become wholly owned and not-for-profit subsidiary of The Arcview Group. The Company will cease to be a publicly traded entity, will become known as NU Capital Partners (the "New Entrant"), and will file a registration statement (including amendments) with the SEC. The New Entrant will be governed by its own Articles of Incorporation, bylaws and board of directors. NU CAP intends to fund its operations with the proceeds of its future equity offerings, which will be made at a price that is equal to or less than the common stock closing price on the NASDAQ stock exchange ("NASDAQ").  "We are excited and proud to join forces with a long-term leadership partner with a strong track record of successfully navigating the capital-intensive and rapidly changing cannabis industry to bring together our mutual goals and expertise, which were complementary to each other," says Kevin Egan Chairman of the Board of NU Capital Partners. "The merger and our joint efforts will provide NU Capital Partners with a better foundation with which to grow its business and create shareholder value. This will assist us in realizing the full potential of investing in the cannabis industry."  "The ArcView Group prides itself on its expertise and track record of successfully navigating the often challenging waters of corporate investment in the cannabis marketplace, from the inception of The ArcView Group in 2010 to its continued operational and financial success today," said Jason M. Zonenberg, Managing Partner of The ArcView Group. "As a founding partner with NU CAP, we look forward to working together to accomplish our shared goal of realizing the strategic value of cannabis investment funds and a healthier cannabis industry."  "We are delighted that NU CAP has decided to join the expanding cannabis sector as, in its own words, 'a company that builds capital and generates value'. We are looking forward to enhancing our own efforts by leveraging this strong platform, in order to make investments that yield value-creating returns and that will have a positive impact on our industry and the environment that surrounds the industry," says Mike Leventhal, chairman of Zonenberg Capital Management.  "The combination of NU Capital Partners and The ArcView Group provides a unique opportunity for the early stage cannabis industry," said Don Robinson CEO and founder of NU Capital Partners. "The merger will give the Company access to the best talent, infrastructure and capital in the industry, making it the go-to partner in managing the expansion of the cannabis industry."  NU Capital Partners will take possession of all NU CAP's assets on February 22, 2014 and file a joint-stock proxy statement with the SEC with respect to the merger. Following the completion of the merger, The ArcView Group will remain as an operating company and will continue to manage and control NU CAP's assets and other business operations. At the meeting of shareholders on Tuesday February 20th (the "Meeting"), the Boards of Directors of each company will: Establish NUCOR'S EXISTING OFFICERS OF AUTHORITY. The Boards of Directors will appoint one independent director of NU CAP (the "Independent Director") from the NUCOR shareholder nominees list of the prior year to the degree that such director is permitted. NUCOR will appoint one board-appointed independent director of NU CAP to the extent permitted under the Delaware Limited Liability Company Act. NUCOR will appoint two independent directors of NU CAP to the respective degrees permitted under the SEC's bylaws and applicable rules. The Board of Directors will set forth an agenda for the Meeting in a notice to the company from the Board of Directors to be delivered to the company on or before February 27th. NUCOR will adjourn the Meeting and hold a further meeting of shareholders, at which time the Board of Directors (the "Board") will take action and notify the company by the date provided in an announcement to be mailed to NUCOR shareholders with the Notice. What will the government propose for their new job? This question is probably asked by many citizens as well. In a new report the International Labor Organization, ILO (pronounced eye-O-lan-oh), examines this topic. The Organization finds that governments should plan and execute programs for new jobs and their creation, as well as the training of workers for these jobs. A new job, the ILO argues, "is defined as an occupation or type of work where employers are actively seeking persons without existing qualifications as part of their own work forces. In most cases the new work is not yet operational." The ILO's recommendations are based on findings from a survey that it conducted amongst its members. It interviewed workers from 20 nations, including the United States (US), Germany, and Canada. Overall, more than half of them stated that government should "plan, fund and implement a new job program in the short term." These are the most positive answers the survey heard. This article analyzes the implications of ILO's recommendations in terms of their implications for national economies and labor markets. It also discusses questions that remain unanswered, including whether the recommendations could have beneficial effects in developing countries, and what might be more effective at creating jobs and improving economic growth in developing countries. How does the ILO define a new job? The ILO defines a new job as one that is needed because an employment model—for instance, one that requires workers to remain on temporary contracts—is not in operation or is not working. "New jobs can be short-term in nature or are part of an overall growth strategy to increase sustainable job creation and long-term employment stability," the ILO states. According to the ILO, a new job often involves training or upgrading workers for a new employment model. "For instance, there may be a need for newly identified IT specialists who, with some extra training, will be needed to provide IT services to industrial companies," the ILO writes. "Or there may be a need for IT specialists in particular industries with a large need for qualified people. A new job is often created in the short term but there could be some positive effects, such as improved training and skills, which create long-lasting employment stability for the unemployed." As with many other global labor market indicators such as unemployment and wage growth—which will be analyzed in a related article of this series—the ILO defines a new job as a job "where workers have experienced a significant improvement in their economic situation. It is not necessarily the most secure position, although most workers accept it." How do national governments plan, fund, and implement a new job program? The ILO recommends that national governments plan, fund, and implement a new job program in three stages. It is important to do so because the unemployment rate in many countries is high. In the first stage governments should identify the short-term need for workers, for instance with IT companies who are looking for workers to develop new business models. In the second stage governments should develop the new job program and its management system—which refers to how and where to recruit and train workers. The ILO defines the new job program management system as the "plan, structure, and management of the entire enterprise-wide program and associated program activities" of new jobs. In other words, the national governments will develop the program, which will involve various sectors, including education, research, and the government, and also "create appropriate mechanisms for its implementation." The ILO is careful to note that the program will have to be comprehensive with some aspects, like training, going beyond government intervention. Finally, governments should "encourage and facilitate the establishment of employment opportunities for persons in the short term through the creation of new jobs and the creation of training capacity." How can we increase unemployment in the developing world? One way to create new jobs and create better employment in the developing countries is to "bring the knowledge and skills of international experts together with the needs and aspirations of these countries." But this is difficult, according to the ILO authors. "A lack of a coherent and well-organized research and development environment in many developing countries makes it difficult to plan and undertake new jobs. The lack of training capacity makes it difficult for young people to acquire new skills. The limited number of labor-intensive industries, for instance food/agricultural, means that many poor workers do not make the most out of their opportunities that exist." Another way is to provide tax breaks, including exemptions, to companies that invest in training workers. Some countries offer direct financial incentive, such as a tax credit or a direct grant, which is a "positive approach" but there is "a lack of transparency of the system," the ILO authors warn. Another possible mechanism for creating jobs is to provide a tax credit to the unemployed or to young workers willing to return to school.

This is my new project, which I've decided to call X-Frequency. The whole concept was hatched during a weekend where I was looking for a project to help get myself out of a funk for a bit. In the mean time, I was bored and wanted to do something different. It seemed like a good idea at the time. The project is intended as a simple way to display multiple frequency signals (including sine and square wave) in a single panel, either as an "electronic guitar" on a rackmount system (like the Korg MS-20), but also as a simple way to display multi-frequency signals in a traditional 3-way rack layout. The idea is simple, simple, beautiful. The source is the very awesome Frequency Master: http://www.frequencymaster.com/ The schematic is below, and the code to display it is below. If you want a real-time view of the signals, try listening to the wave files being generated using VST. That's what everyone has been doing lately. The circuit is very simple: The output of the oscillator is fed to a transistor. The output of the transistor is then hooked up to a variable-speed DC source (I would highly recommend a variable-speed DC supply of some kind, ideally a variable-speed AC supply from a wall-wart, rather than a battery). The output of the variable-speed supply is then fed to the speaker (in my case that's an Ampeg amp, which are usually powered from the AC supply). The output of that speaker goes directly to the speaker output, from where I routed the speaker cables down the back of the unit. The audio signals are a very simple waveform, but I really like their simplicity on the output. They're quite pleasant, and the "sound" that they produce will bring a smile to your face. The schematic is basically a simplified version of the schematic I've used on my X-Wave oscillator/pulse generator circuit: http://www.doble.com.au/xwave The voltage from the amplifier is fed through a capacitor, which acts as the "base of the wave". The power from the oscillator-based waveform is fed back to the input of the X-Wave amplifier, which drives a variable-speed DC supply via a voltage divider circuit, into a switch-mode power supply. I found out that this circuit is good at driving two separate DC voltages, but in my case that didn't work. In that case, I used a 5V linear power supply to drive two separate +16V voltages to the output of the X-Wave amplifier. The output of that DC power supply is hooked in reverse into the base of the oscillator waveform, and then fed back up into the oscillator. This is the same circuit as used on my oscillator circuits, except that I have the circuit on the other side of the circuit instead of the other way around. The only thing I added in here besides the X-Wave amplifier was a variable-speed AC/DC supply. I thought that this was required so that the audio signal from the oscillator could be fed back into the AC power supply, which would improve its stability on the grid. The design is as follows:  The circuit is quite simple:The output of the oscillator is fed to a transistor. The output of the transistor is then hooked up to a variable-speed DC source (I would highly recommend a variable-speed DC supply of some kind, ideally a variable-speed AC supply from a wall-wart, rather than a battery). The output of the variable-speed supply is then fed to the speaker (in my case that's an Ampeg amp, which are usually powered from the AC supply). The output of that speaker goes directly to the speaker output, from where I routed the speaker cables down the back of the unit. The audio signals are a very simple waveform, but I really like their simplicity on the output. They're quite pleasant, and the "sound" that they produce will bring a smile to your face.The circuit is very simple:The voltage from the amplifier is fed through a capacitor, which acts as the "base of the wave".
