SUMMARY As one of the wealthiest nations in the world, the United States should be spending money not on luxury projects but on the people who live in this country. Instead of throwing money into unnecessary and duplicitous programs, the President and Congress should create an emergency budget for basic needs, starting with making college affordable for everyone. One-in-three college students and six out of ten working Americans rely on student loans for tuition. Student loan debt can seriously affect a person's chances of finding a job, and the repayment times can stretch out the lives of students even after they finish school. In the years leading up to the 2008 financial crisis, over $1.4 trillion of student loan debt was accumulated, with the average debt balance in 2012 exceeding $25,000. The average loan balance for graduating college seniors who took out new student loans in 2012 was nearly $30,000. The average borrower pays 6.45% interest and student loan debt pegs borrowers to low or no rates of inflation. When interest rates are higher, debt increases. In response to rising costs, many colleges are increasing the cost of tuition, particularly as the federal government subsidizes the cost of undergraduate education with Pell Grants and loan interest deductions. More than half of student borrowers currently take out loans at or above the maximum for federal student loans. More than half of students who graduated with debt during the recession are making monthly payments of more than one-third of their income. This has led to large delinquencies and default rates as the national default rate increased from 10% of all borrowers to 12% in 2010. Over the last two years, Congress has taken a series of actions to address the current student debt crisis. Congress should now turn to solutions that go beyond merely making borrowers pay interest and fees. SUMMARY OF FINDINGS Overall student loan debt is at an all-time high, with one-in-three undergraduates and six out of ten working Americans relying on these loans for tuition. Over $1.4 Trillion of student loan debt is in debtors' name, with an average student loan burden of almost $27,000. The average student loan borrower receives interest discounts for lower-payments and is saddled with large balance balances. Loan rates for new graduates increased from 6.45% in 2007 to 6.85% in 2012. This is an increase from the 6.0% rate that the Bush Administration proposed for 2012, while the Obama Administration has proposed a 4.5% rate. In 2012, student loan borrowers paid more when paying interest and fees than they were when paying their loans off. Despite student loan debt being relatively low compared to other forms of consumer debt, about three times as many students are burdened with debt today than were burdened with it before the Great Recession. The average debt due for loans taken out after graduation in 2011 was $29,700, approximately the same amount that borrowers faced in 2008 before the economic downturn. Student loan debt affects people of all ages. The majority of student loans are owed by young adults. In 2012, roughly half of the new student lending came from households with students under age 30. In 2012, about two-thirds of all graduating college seniors who took out new student loans were working and earning more than $40,000 a year (in 2012 dollars). Most of the student loan debt is concentrated in 10 states: Massachusetts, California, Arizona, New Jersey, Texas, Connecticut, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, New York and Minnesota. SOURCES AmericanStudentLoan.com USBanking.com The Atlantic: Student Loans: The $1.4 Trillion Crisis in Perspective Federal Reserve Bank, 2011: Student Loan Debt: A Growing Problem - The Great Recession Is Over New York Times: The Great Bailout: How Student Loans Got So Bad That Millions Can't Pay Back Their Loans - The Worst Pity in American Budgeting History Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, 2012: Inflation, Rising Tuition, and Rising Student Debt The White House: Investing in students President Obama, "Fixing the Federal Debt Through Deficit Reduction," 2013: http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2013/04/25/fixing-the-federal-debt-through-deficit-reduction Congressional Budget Office, 2012: How much more debt can colleges graduate students with? Congressional Budget Office, August 2012: Colleges and Universities Congressional Budget Office, 2011 (revised): Tuition and Expenses at for-profit colleges and universities Congressional Budget Office, 2012: Debt and Student Loan Borrowers: Public vs. Private Sector

Pilot, a new drama series based on the book by David Mitchell, will pick up directly where The Twilight saga left off, following a pair of teenage girls from opposite sides of a friendship rift. The new series, which will premiere on PBS in late 2016, will focus on Grace (played by Emily Blunt), a beautiful tomboy whose mother is a successful lawyer who can't stand having his daughter be who she is. Grace comes home for Spring Break to her grandmother's cottage, where she's surrounded by a group of friends, including the headstrong Marnie, who falls in love with Grace and, on the night of their arrival home, disappears without a trace. "Our young characters — Grace, Marnie, and David, who plays her teacher — are all coming of age in their mid-20s, and the central characters from the Twilight books are so clearly relevant," said executive producer and Twilight creator Mitchell. "We wanted to revisit them as they're both in their fifties." RELATED: Read more about the new TV series 'Pilot' Here How 'Pilot' Makes 'Twilight' Into a Modern Classic Here's What You Need to Know About 'Pilot' Pilot will mark the second time Mitchell, who also penned the script for the first series, has taken on a project from his long-time writing partner, Jonathan Tucker. His first book, A Brief History of Seven Killings, was adapted into an acclaimed film in 1992, starring Michael Douglas and Tom Hanks, and starred as main characters in the 1999 film adaptation of The Last of Us.

We've covered the importance of not just learning the game of golf but also the mental aspects of the game from the mental game to the emotional side of the game. Our next step, though, is just as important–we must first get ourselves up the range. I believe it can be done, but it does require some good fortune for some of us. That has happened a handful of times for me in the last few years when my balls have been defective. Once I made a mental correction after being too much behind in my swing and the ball sailed past the hole. That shot, I have to admit, made me feel a bit better about myself about that particular round. But that shot was a long way out from my goal line, and I didn't have too much confidence in my ability to hit a fairway ball at the back of the fairway. A couple of weeks later, I was trying to putt after the last hole of a round. That was quite the uphill climb for me, but I managed to get out a few extra putts and got myself up to 18th place, well behind the leaders. Now here I was again at the last hole with an 18 foot bunker left on the front of the bunker. It was my first hole going out back since the previous week and I was very nervous. I was so confident in my ability to make the putt out to back that I just let off a ball in my back up and missed. My ball was so high up in the air that it just missed the cup. I thought to myself, 'I don't want this to cost me a shot I'm ready for!' I had a little bit of a laugh at myself because in my mind, I just wasn't able to hit a good ball out to back. But once I came out and stood in the fairway looking at the hole I had hit out at out and was wondering how to handle my emotions after putting my club down, I remembered some of my shots from last week and I started thinking, "Okay this isn't that bad." That gave me another boost of confidence and I quickly brought my putt back down the hole and was able to hit it for birdie! As I said, I had a few other putts go that way after that that had me going, "Okay I might be able to hit that." Other times things like that were just very lucky. But the key to doing it is not trying to get more confidence from that putt because you know that's not going to help you hit the one you're actually going for. So if you can't even hit the ball high enough, that usually isn't going to help you out or your confidence boost. But the good thing is, in many cases you can help yourself out because it won't necessarily be your last shot. Just like you have a good mental game for your putting, you have a good mental game for your putting when you hit it to the hole; you have a good mental game for hitting a ball into the hole–you just have to get yourself out the hole first. I think, though, that you can use the mental aspect in your putting not just to get more confident on those putts that aren't all that well timed for your shot–in the long run it's going to help you play better and get closer to more golf balls that go in the hole for the putt. So don't be afraid to get more mental and emotional with your putting. You do want to give yourself a little bit of credit for trying to get the ball out to back in those cases, but you have to go the distance and hit the ball the way you want to be able to hit it.

On January 3, 2015, I had the unenviable task of sitting on a panel with two of the top American minds in their fields. The topic: The Future of Work, a topic that every day seems to have a different and sometimes conflicting answer. From a libertarian point of view, the libertarian view is that the government has overreach itself, with its meddling in the affairs of private enterprise and, worse, has encouraged businesses to become less productive. The view from the other side - the point of view of business leaders, economists, government officials and academics - is that the market is self-correcting and that no single agency should have the power to intervene so dramatically in a process most of us prefer to leave to free markets. I have written about the differences between the two sides in detail. But I now think it is time for some general observations to lay this out. First, it seems, at least to me, that both sides have misunderstood their own work. When economists say that the market and the government are not in balance, they are in fact stating the obvious. They are saying simply that neither the market nor government has control over the outcomes they seek. Both sides have, in fact, been working towards an equilibrium that only a market can achieve. They have just made no effort to understand what equilibrium really is, and how to know where to aim to achieve it. Now, let's set aside the obvious point that most economists have a very simple perspective on any given scenario. Even if your view goes beyond this to try to measure social cost - how much money is spent, how much goods are eliminated in a country, and so on - many economists still insist that you do not expect to achieve equilibrium by attempting to use government action to reduce that cost. They will point out that what you have really achieved is to have "doubled the money." The problem in such theories is that you have created a situation that is clearly unsustainable, where costs will be driven higher. This is exactly what some of the world's largest companies are today. Second, economists still appear confused - sometimes literally - about what they think they are doing. If you believe that the main problem with the current state of work is that employers have too much control over the workplace, it's hard to see what you could possibly do to fix this problem. The government already provides the best and most direct mechanism that has proven effective to date. The problem is that the government actually wants to take back control, not to make it better. The government wants to take back government control of labor to the point where the workplace can be transformed into a free and equal marketplace in which the workers are in charge. They want to have everyone leave their job, not stay and make more money than they now must make to survive. (Yes, you heard that right; the people running our nation's corporations do not like to see the people they are paid to employ being paid less than they are worth.) They want to force employees to accept a pay cut, not an increase, so that they will stop hiring so many people and become less productive. They want to do this by compelling the employers to change the terms and conditions of their jobs. They are not interested in improving on the market but in changing what has become the market. Why do all this? Because politicians know where the political hot potato is - the wages under which people can live. They, therefore, seek to push the price of labor down to that level and increase the number of people for whom it's a good deal. And why do employers want to be paid this or that? Well, because they are in the business of making money. And since government can just do what businesses do in the process of making money, you can be sure that government will be the biggest player in the game. As long as the big government players in the game are employers, and since government officials are paid more for advocating the policies that will raise the prices of the products and services businesses deliver, it will not matter how good your ideas are. It will matter that you want to make the government pay your bills. Let me point out, though, even in the face of all this, that the business world has not moved far from where it began. The idea of increasing the profits of everyone and decreasing the wages of everyone is not a new concept. It was a natural result of the free market that took over after the War of 1812. Even then, though, employers thought they had room to increase wages to offset the loss of profits that came from increased automation or from competition from other countries, so they didn't. The result was a vicious cycle of lower employment, higher prices and lower profits, which has led to the current situation, which will only be reversed by forcing businesses to lower their prices. You see, a few steps in the right direction towards ending the problem of overwork can take you a very long way towards solving the problem of unemployment. And

The following is a guest article by Jody Lee. The first part of the article will appear in Jody's upcoming book on the "Escape Artists" of the 1980s, "Reinventing The Unseen" Some of the famous escape artists to take up residence in the United States were convicted felons who had no ties to organized crime and were not wanted by law enforcement. Some of these escape artists were so well known that television news stations had a reporter present during their escape. Among them were a number of convicted criminals who had received prison sentences of only four years or less. Others have a very dubious history that is little known to most Americans, but that can be quickly cleared up by reading their stories. They were also the product of a process that included the use of psychological warfare techniques and the use of the media to make them celebrities in the minds of their victims, as well as a means to keep them safe from the police. 1 – The "Bobby" Bias Affair One such escape artist was one of the most infamous criminals to ever take on the task of escaping from a maximum security prison in the United States. Known as the "Bobby" Bias Affair, Bias was not only a convicted crime boss, he had spent fifteen years in prison for two counts of robbery. He had been serving time at Fort Dix in New Jersey, in a unit with the most vicious criminals incarcerated at the prison at the time. In 1987, Bobby Bias was transferred to Dachau, in West Germany, because of a parole violation. The story goes that Bias was a very unpopular inmate in both his unit and the general population at Dachau, but was given special permission to leave in order to attend a court hearing. When he tried to depart, they held him there without charge. It is believed that he was able to contact people in the United States who could help get him out of the country so he can attend an international convention for business associates. In exchange, he would not have to spend the remainder of his life in a maximum security institution. While he was awaiting trial for his second prison break, his wife and son were killed in a traffic accident. He claimed that the accident was an act of God. During Bias' trial, he made an attempt to convince members of the jury that he was completely innocent, and that he was going to die in prison anyway. Bias was found not guilty by a jury. He spent almost eighteen years in prison, and during that time, another escaped prison break had occurred that landed his friend, Albert DeSalvo, in prison as well. Both Bias and DeSalvo, along with five other inmates, had become wealthy from an insurance scam they were involved in with another prison escapee, Paul Kresnik. Some of these insurance policies turned out to be fraudulent. After his trial, he was tried again for his role in one of the earlier escapes, and was found guilty once again, this time with the death penalty. After his final trial, he was given three life sentences without parole. In an effort to gain his release, he approached a man named Joseph Giorgio who was a member of the "Special Activities Squad (SAS) of the New Jersey State Police". He was able to get him out of prison and out of the country via an unusual means of escape. Joseph Giorgio, Bias' former partner in crime who helped him escape from Dachau, was a very close friend of his before they became partners. Joseph had a very good relationship with Dachau Warden Walter Wyszynski. Wyszynski was particularly well known as being unimpressed with the criminal behavior of a few of his inmates. While in prison, Joseph's wife had died in a car accident. In an attempt to spare Wyszynski from getting his revenge, Joseph decided that Giorgio was going to try to sell his story to the media, which would lead to Bias' freedom. Giorgio was able to get two reporters from the New Jersey Star-Ledger to send out a series of stories about Bias who would lead to him being placed into high security prisons. Bias was placed in a cell at the maximum security facility at Riker's Island in New York, and given a nickname that he would later use for himself in his escape. He also claimed to have been beaten by guards throughout his prison years at Dachau. The problem was, the reporters were not very familiar with New York state prisons at that time and never saw a beating committed by guards. After Bias was moved to a secure location, he convinced the media and reporters involved to keep quiet about him in the interest of keeping him out of the media and public eye for his release. The problem that became apparent was that the reporters still wrote about him. In addition, several journalists and media workers who knew

It appears that the latest version of Apple's iOS 9.3.3 has a major bug that can cause the iPhone's display to burn through its battery in far-off future without warning. A user on Reddit found that his iPhone 5S battery was draining quickly after installing the newest version of iOS, and it seems like the problem is widespread across the operating system's iPhone 5C/5S range of devices. "It's possible that some older devices may be damaged with iOS 9.3.3, or that iOS 9.3.3 simply doesn't work as expected with the device," the user wrote. "I have an iPhone 5S running 9.3.3 and I've had my charging cable plugged in all evening. This morning at around 3 on a Saturday morning, I woke up to find it nearly dead. I've just checked the battery icon on the home screen, and it has gone from 99% to almost half full, and is still at that level after 3 hours. The charger appears to have worked the whole time, but I wonder what caused the issue." Redditors are reporting the same problem, and most people have not turned the charger off, according to others who have experienced the same issue. As you can see in the first image, the battery icon on the home screen isn't even displaying, since the iPhone doesn't have that information displayed by default, instead displaying "Charging" information. The user is still using the iPhone and his iPhone is still charging, but he said he would likely replace his iPhone with an iPhone 6S after the incident as a precaution. He was able to get the device to charge up to about 70%, but then it just lost the charge completely, and he hasn't had the same problem since.

How is the quality of our health and education system affected by poverty? With the help of a newly released analysis by The National Low Income Housing Coalition (NLIHC), we've compiled a list of six things that drive up rates of poverty, all connected. 1. Lack of money to eat Almost half of all public housing residents live in units with severely inadequate heat, and a quarter of them have no access to a toilet. Over a million people are homeless in Chicago each month, and those living on the streets are at higher risk of heart disease, stroke and diabetes.  2. Low-paying jobs Poor people have significantly more to spend at stores, and poorer families spend more of their income on food — often the most affordable and healthy food! Many jobs require little or no skills and no education, including fast food jobs in fast food restaurants, retail jobs such as store clerk and security guard, and office jobs such as receptionist or computer worker.  3. Lack of transportation In Chicago, more than half of all food stamp recipients come from families that are headed by a single mother. But even when they don't earn enough to support their children and dependents, they're often forced to rely on public transportation, and the cost is a heavy burden on households. 4. Poor educational attainment Less than one-third of low income students in Chicago do not graduate on time from high school. In addition, nearly two-thirds of low-income high school graduation rates are significantly below the state average, and the drop out rate is 50 percent higher.  5. Low-paying jobs Low-wage jobs are especially difficult for low income families. And many of them are only available to those with a high school diploma or less. For instance, nearly one in five of low income Chicagoans working fewer than 30 hours a week are working in food preparation and serving.  6. Lack of access to affordable health care Nearly 40 percent of the children in public housing in Chicago are enrolled in public, low-cost or free lunch programs. Children with low incomes have to contend with the health insurance premium, co-pays, deductibles and copays on an ever-rising list of health insurance items, which include drugs and dental care.

For as long as we can remember, the United States has been the world leader when it came to incarceration. In 2007, the official American count of inmates worldwide, as calculated by the U.S. Bureau of Corrections, was 1,353,611 and the United States alone accounted for 438,085 of those. And in the last five-year period of 2009 to 2011, the United States prison population surged by over 7,000 inmates per year, which is equivalent to about 10 percent of the global population, despite falling prison populations in Germany, Japan, and other countries. To make matters more frightening for the rest of the world, more Americans are being sent to prison for non-violent crimes. In 2012, the United States imprisoned about 200,000 more people than any other country. If non-violent crimes are excluded from the calculation, the United States now has more people in prison than any other country in the world, except possibly Iran. And despite many of the United States' more aggressive, punitive justice policies that stem from the War on Drugs, the U.S. incarceration rate has gone up over the last decade while other nations that have not been as punitive, such as China and Brazil, have cut imprisonment rates. Given this trend, it probably shouldn't come as a surprise that, over the last two decades, there have been increasing calls to reduce the United States' prison population, including at a United Nations meeting in 2009. But it does appear that a growing number of U.S. leaders are waking up to the fact that American prisons cost less to keep than are our schools, hospitals, and social services. As of April 2012, the U.S. government spent a little over $80 billion per year on its prison system. The Department of Justice, which oversees the Department of Corrections, estimates that the average cost of prisons per prisoner at the federal level is between $15,000 and $20,000 a year. At the state level, these figures rise to $35,000 to $45,000 a year, and the costs are even higher at the local level, with some cities like Newark, New Jersey, paying over $80,000 per inmate. Although this information is relatively new, the fact that these costs are being borne by the American people is no longer hidden from public view. For example, a recent report released by the Justice Policy Institute estimated that the cost of running the prison system in Washington, D.C., could fall to as little as $1.3 million per person in 2014 dollars—a figure lower than the cost of keeping a few hundred children in the city's schools, despite the fact that a single inmate costs about $150,000 a year. This is a startlingly low figure even by D.C. standards, given the high costs it takes to house and feed an estimated 300,000 prisoners, including hundreds of thousands who are locked up for petty crimes and offenses such as prostitution and drug abuse. For example, a single person jailed or incarcerated in D.C. for a drug offense could end up costing the city $1 million in extra legal aid services alone and nearly $2 million in lost economic production from the criminal justice system. There is some indication that other countries are starting to wake up to the fact that the massive incarceration cost the United States is incurring isn't sustainable, and that it is in the country's interest to be a more humane and rational system of punishment. In January, the European Union Parliament voted against ratifying a proposal that would have limited prisoner freedom, as a response to the global trend towards reducing prison costs and prisoner numbers. In May, a group of leading American economists sent the U.S. government a letter urging the reduction of the prison population. In recent years, the United States has become increasingly reliant on the massive privatization of correctional services. From private prisons to private probation offices, the United States has seen companies receive contracts to house, feed, and discipline those who have broken the law. And as private correctional services have flourished, they have grown increasingly involved in what is seen as the core of prison operations—keeping the population of incarcerated prisoners in compliance. This system has come up short when it comes to ensuring that the prisons are both safe and efficient, and has raised serious concerns over who is incarcerated and the quality of their treatment. Private prison companies—most notably the Corrections Corporation of America, the largest GEO group, and the GEO Group, the nation's third largest private prison company—now occupy a growing corner of the American penal justice universe. In 2009, more than half of the United States' 300,000 people behind bars were in private prisons. Today, as the United States faces an even greater surge in the incarceration of nonviolent offenders, it is increasingly necessary for us to figure out more humane and cost-effective ways to deal with this situation. How Does Private Prisons Compare With Public Prisons? The private prison industry in America

The University of Arizona has been getting complaints about the sound of its football team's horn, especially during football games. This week, after an Arizona Republic investigation found significant problems with the sound, the university asked that the NCAA change its rules regarding the use of the sound, including restricting its use in a certain stadium. The school did not provide specifics about the complaint made to the university. University officials said the university is considering an appeal. MORE: More college football teams were suspended over horn sound complaints This story originally appeared on azcentral.com and is republished here with permission. PHOTOS: College football teams that were suspended READ MORE: Top 20 most talked about, and least talked about, in college sports from October 2017 MORE: Ranking teams from worst to first for most-talked about, least-talked about college football this season Arizona State had been using the sound during home games since 2005, according to a source at the university, but it began getting complaints during 2017. A public radio station said the school told it in April that students and fans were complaining from the stadium, and that it had sent officials to the game. In a statement on its website, the school said it was investigating how it plays the horn and would provide updates when it knows more. The school said it has notified all the parties involved and the NCAA of its findings, which it will consider by January of 2018, or whenever there is a ruling. "We are working hard to resolve the issues raised in this investigation, and are taking this situation very seriously," the school said. RELATED: College football teams with the most fans, most fans-related arrests It's hard to find much information on how the University of Minnesota, the University of Minnesota Duluth, the University of Minnesota North. The NCAA's rules about how a team chooses to use its horn, set with the intent of creating a competitive environment, also prevent universities from playing with it during non-conference games, though the NCAA allows it in certain circumstances when those games would be competitive. The NCAA is currently in a process to review its rules governing what officials must do to make sure that fan engagement and participation is at the highest possible level, though it has a history of changing its rules, including its handling of college football fans of both teams.

Milo Yiannopoulos is no longer at Breitbart. Here's what you need to know. (Jenny Starrs/The Washington Post) In the wake of a video in which he appears to defend pedophilia as well as assault on women, conservative commentator Milo Yiannopoulos resigned from Breitbart News on Tuesday – just 12 days after he was given the website's highest role. The site's CEO, Larry Solov, offered his "sincere condolences" to Yiannopoulos and his family, as did Yiannopoulos's editor in chief, Alexander Marlow, via email. Marlow also provided a copy of his resignation letter, written from overseas. "I am incredibly proud of my role at Breitbart, and the important role it played in defusing the growing hate movement that is currently engulfing our world — and in promoting tolerance and understanding," he wrote. "Breitbart News is also a platform for the alt-right, an emerging conservative movement that has caused concern among some," he wrote. Marlow described Breitbart as his "home for news and commentary for the alt-right." As the Post and other news outlets reported, this "new" conservative movement includes more than just "conservatives" — it also includes "white supremacists, anti-Semites, racists and misogynists." Marlow wrote: "[O]ur coverage was critical in highlighting the growing popularity of the #Gamergate movement that abused and threatened individuals with physical harm for not believing that women and minorities had the same opportunities as men, and for challenging the traditional, gender-based gaming culture; and in identifying many of the core political problems facing our free society." [The disturbing alt-right 'journalism' I helped write] Solov had already announced last week that Yiannopoulos, who has said he's gay, would no longer be working at Breitbart after a video surfaced in which he appeared to condone pedophilia, among other topics. The resignation letter described Solov's decision to put Yiannopoulos in the highest position at Breitbart "after careful consideration" but said that "the article that ran this morning was the final straw." Yiannopoulos's recent comments on child sex have "caused a firestorm within the right-wing media ecosystem," Solov wrote, arguing that the site would need to "be more deliberate and thoughtful in our coverage moving forward." "We must do better, and it begins with improving our coverage, not shying away from controversial but important content," he added. "I'm eager to be part of the team rebuilding trust with this important audience. This is a new era at Breitbart but I'm confident the right people will lead it." [Milo Yiannopoulos resigns from Breitbart as advertiser pulls ads from website following controversial comments] In a press statement to The Post, Yiannopoulos wrote, "I am not a child abuser. I did not say those things. If I thought the argument that I was defending child abuse was persuasive, I would not be standing in front of you today. I am not arguing, nor have I ever argued, that all relationships between an adult and minor are consensual. Pedophilia is not a sexual orientation, it is a type of mental illness." Solov had also said, "Milo is a terrifically talented writer, editor and provocateur, but he cannot lend himself to effective workplace environments, nor does he deserve to. He has exceeded all of our expectations and will be greatly missed by us all." Yiannopoulos, who was born in Greece and raised in London, grew up in the United States before starting a career in media in Britain. He rose to fame under the leadership of his controversial right-wing news site Breitbart after being hired by senior chairman Stephen K. Bannon. Breitbart has faced criticism following Yiannopoulos's departure from its front page. The site published a story earlier this month, reporting that a female Breitbart writer asked for a raise but, according to her contract, it did not pay much.

The U.S. Navy's newest amphibious assault ship, USS Iwo Jima (LHA-5), was launched by the commanding officer of the Norfolk Naval Shipyard in Hampton Roads, Va. at 11:00 a.m. on July 11. The USS Iwo Jima (LHA-5) will replace the Iwo Jima, a U.S. Navy amphibious assault ship that suffered a fatal accident in May when a man slipped off an escape slide and fell 40 feet onto the deck of the ship. Since May 10, more than 80 civilian and military personnel have been injured in Iwo Jima as a result of the accident.

The thing is, the guys would do it in the office and we'd all laugh at them, he continued. "I think I have more of a reputation for not being the most dramatic guy in the office, but once I started getting them to start taking themselves more seriously, it was a great thing, and I think it helped them build this bigger picture." In recent months, Trump has taken to publicly chastising his staff for their shortcomings. In mid-April he tweeted that his chief of staff, Reince Priebus, was "weak, ineffective and not able to stand behind the team." He singled out former Chief Strategist Steve Bannon for criticism as well. "I am so upset with Steve Bannon, I thought he was going to be my best friend," he said. "But he's not a good person." After a long press conference on Monday, which went poorly, the president told reporters that he is frustrated with the West Wing staff and that "the buck stops here." "I'm always frustrated sometimes in the White House with the way — it's not that it doesn't work, but it's working really well against us," he said. Trump, whose presidential campaign was defined by his campaign-trail brashness, has long been regarded as an outlier. But the president has also consistently proven a reluctant or reluctant-to-be-apologetic president. "He is not particularly concerned about how he's perceived," said former Republican strategist Kevin Madden, who's worked on four Republican administrations. "It's just the person he is." The president is far from alone on the GOP front in refusing to take criticism. Some Republicans have been known to be loath to apologize when they've made questionable decisions, particularly in private. Others have been particularly sensitive to any suggestion that they're willing to bend on conservative or national security policies, or that they've given up a fight over conservative values. There's a long history here, but during the presidential primaries, Trump used his position as a celebrity to offer a kind of reality TV reality show—a reality of himself, on television. He didn't shy away from the tough questions and the negative comments, the same way a typical political candidate would. He didn't shy away from his controversial rhetoric. And he didn't make a big deal of the fact that he was a reality star as a political candidate. "The reality TV star is the new reality," said Roger Stone, a longtime Trump adviser, later. Trump in February began appearing on "Meet the Press" with Chuck Todd, a longtime NBC-talk-show host who he has long attacked as inaccurate and biased because of his liberal leanings.

MILAN – The latest news and views from Real Madrid as we prepare to meet Cristiano Ronaldo at the Superclásico clash against Barcelona at 1am this Sunday. The Portuguese has been talking in the media about what will happen during the Superclásico. "This season I'll be happy if we win, otherwise I'll be disappointed because I'll be away from home. We will have to battle for a victory as I have to spend the night away from my family." After scoring 29 goals last season, the 30-year-old hopes to score even more. "Maybe 40 goals, but I haven't begun yet. I'm really happy to have hit 30 and we'll be happy to win if we can break that record," "It's one thing to be a goal-scorer, it's something I've been working on. In Spain, football is a team sport, you have to bring the whole team with you, to take them where you need to go. You can score goals, score assists, but you cannot do it alone," he said Cristiano's new agent, Jorge Mendes, will not be attending any of the games this weekend. "Jorge is really happy with the work we've done for him. I think that with his experience he can help his client at every stage." The Madrid coach, Carlo Ancelotti, is confident of being able to exploit Cristiano's excellent play at the Clásico. "When we won the Champions League against Atlético Madrid, he made two assists and was very effective. We are very pleased he's coming to Madrid for this game," "Cristiano loves competition and has the right attitude to play at his highest. He's an important player for us, and I hope his goals will be in the goals against Barcelona," said Ancelotti at the post-match press conference. Barca star Neymar also wants to help his club defeat Real Madrid. "I'm just thinking of helping the team in any way I can, that's it," he told The Sun. "Of course, I'm very happy to win the Superclásico, even though this is my first time in Madrid. My goal was to get to the finals of the Champions League," "Barca must win, I'm not going to give them any sympathy", a very calm and confident Neymar explained. "I think there will be more points at Madrid, because if they win at all in this league, then it will show they can win in the Champions League as well. If we win the Superclásico, we can start talking about that in April," Neymar said.

New Zealand Rugby officials are confident they can get the All Blacks into next year's Rugby World Cup, having just beaten off an early challenge from France and Japan. A series of tests in France and Japan has led to questions from the French as to whether New Zealand cannot take a team to the tournament in Japan. The New Zealand Rugby Union has taken every measure it can to reassure French rugby officials they are fit and ready for the World Cup, a process which reached an emphatic conclusion on Saturday evening. After defeating Japan 36-20 in a pre-quarter-final warm-up, the All Blacks completed a record-equalling 13th consecutive Test series win against a New Zealand opponent with victory in Paris on Sunday. New Zealand Rugby President Steve Tew described it as a "good win" for the tournament's integrity and "the best victory of the year".

In an attempt to improve his image, President Obama said Thursday that he regrets talking about the racial profiling by the Los Angeles Police Department that resulted in the killing of an unarmed black man in 2008, but did not give a reason for his refusal to apologize for it. Speaking to the Rev. Al Sharpton at the National Action Network in Washington, where Obama was expected to discuss health care policy and immigration, he blamed Americans who "seem to only care when other people are in trouble and we don't pay attention to our own problems in our own communities." He added: "I am not going to be part of a political 'gotcha' moment where we're just going to attack one another and start bringing race into our political process. I care not one whit about politics that trivialize the African-American experience or otherwise suggest that African-Americans are somehow less American because of the color of their skin." The remarks, which came before he had started speaking, sparked outrage from Republicans and civil rights activists. "A Black Lives Matter member said Obama is 'not going to be a part of a political 'gotcha' moment where we're just going to attack one another and start bringing race into our political process.' —Rep. Steve King (R-Iowa), quoted here," Rep. James Clyburn (D-S.C.) tweeted. "Why would President Obama agree to come here and pretend he cares about race relations after just saying it was 'nonsense'?" Rep. John Lewis (D-Ga.) quipped in a tweet. "I don't know to whose political gain these comments are being made," Lewis said in a tweet earlier this week. "The President and his administration may have had a positive influence on relations between the white and black citizens in this country, but I have always believed there is no reason for him to apologize for his own mistakes." Obama said in the speech that he wished it was possible for him to "find a way to say 'I'm sorry' without taking it personally. That's why sometimes it's hard for us to hear each other. It is something that we all feel, and there's no excuse. And that's the way it always should be." Obama said he had never before "been asked what I could do to make everybody feel better," but hoped that his comments would contribute to a "healing moment" in our society. "We are a better America because of Martin Luther King Jr.," he said, referring to the founder of the civil rights movement. "He has inspired millions of people because of his courage and his hope." On June 3, 2008, while riding his bicycle through Los Angeles, 28-year-old Ernesto Diaz was fatally shot by two officers of the Los Angeles Police Department. The shooting happened after police stopped the man as he allegedly drove erratically through a Hollywood neighborhood. When he refused to get out of the car, and police attempted to tasers him, he was shot as he tried to get back into the car. He subsequently died three days later at a hospital. Despite a $8 million settlement on Diaz's behalf, the case was only recently settled. During a press conference with Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti and Police Chief Charlie Beck later in the day, Obama said: "I can only imagine what people are feeling today around the country as they wonder how we can address race relations and trust between the communities and the police department that they elected us to serve." Rep. Emanuel Cleaver (D-Mo.) asked, "Would that be so hard to say? What would be your response?" Obama replied, "Well, I'm not going to say it." The president later added: "It's easy to forget that for a lot of people it was a shocking, shocking incident and we're not going to pretend that that was any different." Obama's comments came five days after Eric Holder, the attorney general whose department found that the LAPD had violated civil rights by shooting Diaz, told a congressional panel that the DOJ was reviewing the case. Holder told members of the House Judiciary Committee: "We have received and turned over a whole bunch of information that we're reviewing, and we've asked for public comment as to what else we should look into."

It is not clear if Mr Modi will bring in a law requiring the construction of toilets in India's public places, amid concerns it wouldn't be possible to enforce such an order due to security problems. "In the case of public toilets it is very difficult for any officer to make an arrest," said an official, who didn't wish to be named. A senior official from the ministry of women and child development told the AFP news agency that while the country isn't quite where it would like to be when it comes to gender equality, "we recognise the fact and work on it". The comments came after Mr Modi called for the setting up of "gender-separated toilets" at a rally in the western state of Rajasthan where the prime minister is touring in his first overseas visit since taking office in 2014. The BJP general secretary in Gujarat when Mr Modi last came to the state said that Mr Modi's call was "absolutely incorrect" and that women in India did not need separate toilets. "We've not even thought about it and never planned it," Sushil Joshi said in a speech before India's parliament in 2012. "If we build separate toilets where will there be any problem for women?" "We are going to make toilets for women which would not have separate toilets," Mr Modi said in an interview with CNN-IBN this week. The comments are likely to be criticised in the social media, where calls are already being made for the prime minister to apologise and explain why he did not follow through on his original promise. The government's website notes that the Indian government "has taken a number of measures to improve the situation in terms of availability of toilet facilities for women and children". However, the website does not reference the recent ban on the sale of cattle for slaughter and the increasing number of women's violence campaigns. A recent study by the Women's Resource and Empowerment Foundation found that there were around 4.7 million unplanned childbirths per year in the country. Of those, the highest number of pre-term births were to women under 15 years old, women who were married at some point and women from low-caste or tribal communities. At least 2,000 children among India's girls will die as a result of being born outside of marriage each year, according to the report.

A former member of the British intelligence officer's family said they are "devastated that any family member would ever want to involve themselves with" the "dishonest people" who worked for British intelligence. Former member of the British intelligence officer's family said they are "devastated that any family member would ever want to involve themselves, themselves or their own children" with "dishonest people." (Al Jazeera America) This is perhaps an understatement. The former member of the British intelligence officer's family said this week that if he had known the people he worked with, he would have never hired them. In an interview on the "Anderson Cooper 360° Show" with Anderson Cooper that aired Tuesday, the family member said he was "appalled" to learn that his sister-in-law did business with a British intelligence officer, who he said had an "extreme political bias." "I actually feel terrible," he said. After the interview, the former member of the family also told the BBC that he is "extremely disturbed" about what he learned. He was referring to his sister-in-law. The former member of the intelligence officer's family said his family learned about the operation after news organizations reported on the operation. He also revealed that his mother was also involved with the former intelligence officer. In a subsequent interview with the Washington Examiner, the family member said he didn't tell his sister-in-law about the case until after her company was sold. "We're devastated. What has that done to her?" he said. "I'm absolutely devastated for her. I never would have thought that this would have happened but what can you do?" It's an extreme example of an ongoing problem in intelligence circles, where "proactive measures" against political opponents, especially immigrants, are common. Formerly employed by U.S. intelligence agencies, the former member of the family said he had nothing to gain from working for British intelligence. He said he has always been honest about his activities and always paid his own expenses, including airfare. But when he started looking for a company in the U.K., the British intelligence agency came up with him. After that, other people found out about him because he showed them his CV, it was published in a national news outlet, the British national security website ExCere. But it seems the former member was unaware that the information on the former agent's CV went over the spy agency's radar. "My mum was very disappointed that I did this and said that I never should have done this," he told the Examiner. "I didn't do this for me, I did it for the country." It is unclear if the British government has investigated or sanctioned the woman who used to work for the spy agency. But the agency told the BBC that the intelligence officer "had fully abided by the rules of the office of intelligence and security of the United Kingdom," and has "no known personal grievance against the agency or its staff."

I am a Christian and I am proud to be a Christian. I've always felt comfortable and at home with this faith. And even at a young age I was able to see how this religion's values and teachings provided an answer to my questions and concerns in a way I could relate to. For a time, I also felt a certain comfort and belonging and certainty in my beliefs that I could never experience without the Bible. I found comfort in it. I connected to it. It was my comfort. And it provided a sense of clarity and purpose and understanding and peace and comfort and meaning and meaninglessness. Over time as I have grown in understanding, I have come to regret the path my youth took. I've come to understand the deep and serious problems facing our society today. And I've come to understand that the only hope for a better America lies not in the idea that God is on my side, but in the idea that we are on his side. That we are all God's children, part of one human family. The only hope to move ahead is to work together to change our institutions. To create something better here on Earth. And I've come to understand that we may very well have our most glorious and glorious days ahead. I've come to know that America's strength comes from its diversity. Our strength comes from our people's passion for inclusion. Our strength comes from those who love their country but not for who they are—those who want to keep us divided. Our strength comes from those who see America as a land shaped by the power of hope over fear. Our strength comes from the promise of a future where we will be judged by our contentment not by the color of our skin, not by the wealth of our background, not by the zip of our religion or our sexual orientation. We have never lived in a nation where all of us have felt fully and equally at home, but the world is changing. I believe that in the future this hope will be put to good use. I believe that with the right leadership we will make America stronger. I believe America is great and can be great again. I believe that we can and will become stronger and more united and more prosperous, and more peaceful and kind and generous and kind than we have ever been. I have been encouraged to see the great work being done by our faith, that in fact we have no more urgent task because America has moved forward—we have moved forward in every area we set our mind to. For the last couple of years in particular, I have been so profoundly moved by the extraordinary change that has transformed our nation: the change of values; the change of attitudes; the change at our core of a faith that is stronger than ever; the transformation in our cities of the young people who have come forward to bring the changes that we deserve. I have seen these changes. And I believe in the power of this work for the good of our country and for the good of the world. The work we are doing is good work. But we are not done yet. We have much more work to do. One of the most significant changes we have seen in this nation, and for the world, in recent years is the loss of faith in the basic values that have made our country such a success. So much has been built on the trust that was placed in our institutions for us all to be equal before the law and have basic rights regardless of race, nationality, or faith. I believe as I do from my own experience that such a culture is fragile and needs to be nurtured and protected. But we still have a long way to go. It is our belief that this kind of work can be accomplished only if we believe in our God and God's goodness. That's what has sustained us and helped us overcome many of our challenges—faith, faith, faith. So it is my prayer tonight that all of us will rededicate ourselves to the idea of a God who is good, and believe in his goodness and hope for the future and in those whom we trust to be our leaders with clear eyes and steady hearts and boundless faith. This is the work of the future. We are called by God to make the world a better place and the work of our generation will prove that. So tonight I would like to speak to you about that work; in particular about the vital power of faith to transform hearts and make our world better, but I will give you an invitation; it is not open to you. What I would like to convey—the power and the responsibility—are the truths of God's word. These words I am going to speak to you about today are not things I believe. I am not trying to convince you with my intellect, my intelligence, with anything I've learned from your faith traditions. No, these truths come from God. They come in the Bible. They come from the traditions of the people who believe these things. And so I

Gorgeous New Photos from 'X-Men: Days of Future Past' Poster Reveal Wolverine's Glamorous Transformation First things first, X-Men: Days of Future Past is awesome . Really. I'm not sure how I managed to put it off so long while desperately craving this particular installment of the mutant superhero saga. With its stunning visuals and thrilling action, director Bryan Singer's reboot (which stars Nicholas Hoult, Michael Fassbender, and Anna Paquin) has me more excited than any X-Men movie in history. But let there be no doubt: it's a superhero movie, and it's set in the X-Men timeline. A little knowledge of the universe and a great movie can go a long way.  Now that 'Days of Future Past' has been released in the United States, we've gotten our hands on a new poster on the official 'X-Men: Days of Future Past' Facebook page. (It's actually a slightly different poster than the one below, because someone was going to be using the original in a different context) And while I love the new look, the poster is also a bit confusing, and a little hard to read. That's where these beautiful new photos come in.  In the series of pictures, director Simon Kinberg's team uses the following three photos to tell the story of Professor Charles Xavier (Patrick Stewart), Magneto (James McAvoy), and the other mutants who live in the future on Earth. We see the other iconic X-Men, from Iceman (Michael Fassbender), Mystique (Jennifer Lawrence), Blink (Kamryn Douglas), and Beast (Nicholas Hoult), as well as Wolverine (Hugh Jackman), Quicksilver (Aaron Taylor-Johnson), and Cyclops (James McAvoy). The group fights the Sentinels, which seem to be powered by the Sentinels' creators.  After seeing these photos — and some of my own — I wonder if Scott Summers (James McAvoy) could be the one behind all the evil. I'm not saying he can't be, but I'm saying this would be a major turn in his personal life, and I'm not sure how that could play out in the long run. He's just a teenager in a world of mutants … could it ever be easy for him to get it all back?  X-Men: Days of Future Past opens on Blu-ray and DVD March 15th, 2014. Check out the full gallery below, including other images from 'X-Men: Days of Future Past'. - - - Want a chance to win one of Deadpool 2 Blu-rays? Click here or the image below to enter!

An estimated 1.5 million Syrians have fled their country since the fighting began more than two years ago, making it the overwhelming majority of the population who have left Iraq over that period. Some 3 percent of the population over Iraq fled, according to a study from Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and the International Rescue Committee. The conflict began as peaceful demonstrations against the regime, but quickly degenerated. The violence, particularly around the city of Aleppo over the summer, was intense but sporadic. The violence in the past year has not seen the intensity of the summer's massacres, in which hundreds of Syrians became the victims of attacks in separate cities. But even if many Syrian government forces are being killed by the insurgents, other soldiers are being killed by the rebels, who have gained a foothold in some parts of the country from which to launch attacks. The surge of refugees is a significant blow to the war-torn country because Syria is already a source of one of the world's most extensive refugee flows, and many thousands remain trapped. More than 1.3 million Syrian refugees, including more than 600,000 children, live outside the country, according to the United Nations. Although the violence is intensifying in rebel-held eastern Aleppo and the Syrian government now appears to have lost control of much of the country, the government still controls a majority of the population centers and holds only about 50 percent of the land. "We are talking about a country that is becoming ever more fragmented," Mr. Lakhdar and Ms. Khatib said.

As I said in my most recent post on these topics here's the latest in my weekly series about the "sociological illiteracy" in American culture, and in the media! You'd be surprised at how often I get emails from atheists, and even theists, about "god's reasons for existence" and theism at this point. I think they are mostly correct if not in all of their points. But then again, I think most atheists and agnostics in America know enough about theology to have a pretty firm grasp of the Bible, and are also quite familiar with some of the Christian doctrines. So let me take a look at one particular case, and try to help atheists think about Christianity in a rational and critical manner. Here's a story I heard recently. A man was out jogging. Some thugs tried to get him to sell drugs. He refused and got into a street fight. Later that day, a group of Christians were waiting for him in the parking lot. One came up and asked him about his experience, why some "sinners" were being tortured and destroyed. "What sin did those people commit that the Lord hates?" That may sound like the typical Christian response to the question. But if an atheist is asking an equally reasonable question, we will get a very different response. Why would you ask such a question? First, I don't think the Christian's answer is really what you expect. As I said back when we had the case of the church lady who wrote to my last post, it's a very Christian response that is really about showing contempt for the other. And they don't call her a demon-possessed fraud, they call her a blaspheming slut. That's a bit different from saying, "Well, all of the sins and blasphemies in the world are sins against the Lord, so this man has earned it, and we are only following the teachings of Jesus." There's also nothing rational about it, and the "sin against" is in the second clause. The problem with this approach is that your "sin" is not the sin you commit. It's the sin you accuse the other person of. What's going on? Why say a woman who has a sinful husband is making it up?" I think there's three reasons for that. First, they are defending their own honor. They are not willing to admit that their God is not all-powerful. Not really. Second, they hope that by getting you to admit the sin is a big deal, that they will be seen as having done their job. Third, they hope that we will see that they are right and that the way they're defending the honor of their "family" is just as good as any other defense. Now this kind of argument from silence is really a straw man. The fact that they think that any claim is a valid defense of their authority and honor is not proof that they are right, or at least that they are right when they assert they are right. Even though such a claim must be "valid", it does not establish its truth, that is a different thing. As far as I can tell the Christian is arguing by pretending that all claim that God must have had some supernatural explanation for all of these events happening, the one we know of in the Bible (God's being awesome), and that if someone doesn't believe this to be so, then all of the other evidence they have is invalid. This is a classic appeal to ignorance. For any person who thinks this way, the argument is just not worth making. Now in this case, we also have the problem with the "slavery excuse". The truth is, this only works if they know that slaves were being tortured and kept as property. And the reason a person would not know that unless he personally was in a prison or being tortured is not because they lack information. This is because people often fail to realize that the person they talk to is not talking to an impartial observer. They are talking to someone they believe to be their friend or family. As far as the argument's based on God's justice, it works well for the believer who has no knowledge of the true history of slavery. For the skeptic, however, as I mentioned in previous posts, we have to remember those who lived in those times. They probably suffered just as you do, and some probably died more violently and horrible deaths. Anyway, those are the three reasons. Related posts: Is the Christian God the Only True Source of True Evil? Why Atheists Are Not Terrorists: A Case from The Unbelievers For More On this Topic, Try These Posts: What I Really Find Offensive About Christians Who Call Themselves "The Real Christians" The Christian God and the Problem of Evil My Favorite Video on the Topic of Atheism From a Christian Perspective Why I Don't

DETROIT - A 20-year-old is at the bottom of the Grand River near the Southfield Marina. Now, more than four months ago, he drowned during a swim he was trying to do. Heather B. Smith told Local 4 he decided to go in the water. "He said he was feeling really bad," Smith said. Smith said her son, Jason Smith, drowned trying to do a sprint. "He kept swimming and swam," she added. "He was coming down the stream and then he started going down the wall, and he tried to jump off. "A woman yelled out for him to get in the shallow end, or the bottom. He ran into the water, and didn't want to swim, and he turned around and started coming up the wall. And then he went under water," Smith said. The Grand River is home to many rapids, such as the Southbound Falls, which was recently reopened after extensive repairs. They're designed to help people in the river, but some people, they said, go over the top, and swim around the rapids. The Grand River is not supposed to keep people in the river with them. "I don't want to be the person who says 'You shouldn't be on the river during a flash flood because you're going to drown,'" Smith said. It's that same concern that led Smith's family to put up signs saying no swimming to help them raise money for the Friends of Grand River Reservation. "People jump in. They don't realize it's not the safest way to go," Smith said. "It's hard. He was really a young man, so it's hard to come to terms with." Jason Smith was the only son she had. When Smith wasn't at home, she said she would get the kids ready and then go out to her car. He was one, and she didn't want any of them to miss him. "He was a good person, a good son," Smith said. "He was a good guy." Copyright 2013 by ClickOnDetroit.com. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.

A young man was killed when an alleged gang member opened fire on a patrol car in northwest Harris County this morning. Police don't believe the officer's family knew the deceased. He was shot at about 5:25 a.m. in the area of West Houston and Montrose.According to a Harris County Sheriff's Press Release, the officer was with a partner investigating the theft of a vehicle when "at least two men began acting suspicious toward the suspects and the officer." Police allege the suspects "observed them driving an older model white sedan. One of the suspects got out of the vehicle with a handgun concealed in his waistband as one of the officers opened fire at the suspects' vehicle. During the gunfire, the officer was struck in the head. The suspect then exited his vehicle and ran back into the group."The deceased was identified as 18-year-old Johnhorne Fennell of Spring.He has been sent to the Harris County Institute of Forensic Sciences. The deceased is the third Houston deputy shot to death by an individual in just more than a week.

The idea of paying your child to play videogames is a relatively new one. With the rise of cell phones and social media it seems that the idea of letting children as young as five-years-old play video games has become more acceptable. But as long as they don't hurt themselves or people around them, why shouldn't a child's free time be spent playing video games? "It is up to parents, however, to be vigilant about the games they allow their children to play, so no one ends up with a black eye or a broken arm simply because a child chose to play a certain videogame to which it was not authorized by their parent," noted a report by the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP). Some parents do allow their children to play videogames, but parents are sometimes reluctant to let their children play violent or sexual games. As the AAP notes, there are a few cases where video game violence may be OK, such as when parents believe that they can protect their children by limiting their exposure to violent games. But even games that are considered to be of "low" to "moderate" violence are often violent in style: for example, with the game Splosion Man: "These games have no blood or gore, and no sexual content. But they do involve killing virtual monsters that use weapons, often in gruesome ways, as depicted in the title," notes the report. Other games are much more sexually explicit than in the previous example. Some of the most popular sexual games that your children can play, according to the AAP report, are: Sleeping Dogs: "Sleeping Dogs is a violent stealth game featuring criminals and gangsters who try to take over Hong Kong. In these games, the player can shoot or stab as many people as possible and take out guns from their bodies to shoot others, but they also need to take out their rivals' weapons in order to take down the leader," states the report. Resident Evil: Umbrella Corps: "In Resident Evil: Umbrella Corps, a group of "Umbrella agents" are on the run from Umbrella Corporation when a deadly virus is released. Players can assume the identity of either a member of a secret government task force or a rogue agent in the fictional setting of the film and make decisions that result in either saving the world or saving a loved one's life. In this game the player can choose to save one character or the entire group of agents. This game is violent and may contain violence or other elements of a mature nature." Tom Clancy's The Division: "Tom Clancy's The Division, a third-person shooter video game, allows gamers to participate in "siege gameplay" as a terrorist group called The Division, led by an "E3-trained" former U.S. Secret Service agent, battles rival terrorist groups. This game emphasizes tactical maneuvering over traditional shooting. Unlike most "siege games" in which both teams fight using traditional assault rifles, The Division also includes military-grade weapons. Players can choose to be either of two factions, using one of the two factions' weapons, such as assault rifles and handguns." These games may seem more "fun" than violence, but is the game still violent? According to the AAP report, video games are one of the safest games for your children to play, simply because it is so non-violent and no actual harm is done to other people. Video games are not like traditional video games with guns and explosions. It is only when videogames are played with violence, or in some instances sexual content, that there is a potential for danger. "There is no real harm in playing video games in moderate amounts, or just because a parent or teacher thinks the child might enjoy a certain game. A video game isn't the same as playing real-life sports or playing with toys," said the report. A game with a non-violent story and just good gameplay is actually a much safer game than one with more violence and sexual content, according to the AAP. It is important for parents to know when it is appropriate for their children to play. There are games out there, like Tom Clancy's The Division, that do require parental supervision and supervision is strongly recommended for young children who are playing these kinds of games.

From Hearthstone Wiki Siegebreaker is a common warrior minion card, from the Kobolds and Catacombs set. How to get [ edit | edit source ] Siegebreaker can be obtained through Kobolds & Catacombs card packs, through crafting, or as an Arena reward. Golden Siegebreaker can also be obtained through the Highest Rank Bonus chest at the end of each Ranked season. Card Crafting cost Disenchanting Siegebreaker 40 5 Golden Siegebreaker 400 50 This minion is a great card for aggressive decks looking to remove large minions and get out the board quickly. Due to its battlecry, it can also be used to control the board at the same time. Summon Ah... my friends... Attack Ah... my enemies.  Siegebreaker is a level 20 demon found near the Ruins of Kel Voreth, in the Valley of Strength. It is found in the room with two paladins in the Valley of Strength - one located beneath it, the other directly opposite of it. A copy of Siege Breaker was also used to defend the room during the Burning Crusade campaign in the mission A Darkspawn's Grasp. From Wowpedia: Siegebreaker is the result of a demon possessing the remains of the legendary Dark Iron Dwarf warbringer, Ragnaros. The artwork for this card comes from the World of Warcraft Trading Card Game "Through the Dark Portal" series, for the card Hellshatter.
