From the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, and the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute (STRI), Panama: Two new species of spider named in honor of former U.S. Presidents George W. Bush and Bill Clinton have been described from two sites of the Panamanian Rainforest. The specimens are the seventh and eighth new species of tropical spiders since 2010, a period of significant growth in the species' range. The researchers described the pair as Hogna tepidariorum and Hogna mafra, both from the genus Hogna. The two are restricted to a tropical lowland region in the southwestern portion of the Panama Canal region. The spiders are distinguished from other species by their different colored "tongue" hairs. The spider species, each between 6 mm and 9 mm in length and weighing less than 30 grams, are described in the online edition of Zookeys this week. Hogna tepidariorum (n. gen., n. adj.) is a larger, more robust relative of Hogna tepidariorum subsp. tepidariorum. It is only found in areas where the rainforest has been converted to agriculture or where humans have disturbed the forest's habitat (e.g., with clearing or clearing of natural forest) or introduced invasive species (e.g., the American chestnut tree virus). In Central America, the two places where these spiders have been found are the Guajira River watershed as well as the Costa Rican Amazon, the first time Hogna tepidariorum subsp. tepidariorum has been described in these two areas. The researchers named a second new species of Hogna spider, Hogna mafra, in honor of former U.S. President Bill Clinton. The new species is based upon the specimen collected by Patricia H. Stoeckle and Paul R. A. Zuber of the University of Texas, Austin and described at the American Museum of Natural History in New York City. The specimen is from Ecuador. The name Hogna mafra has Spanish origins. Since 1998, the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute (STRI) has been working as part of the USGS's Panama-Caribbean Tropical Forest Program to support the biological collection of tropical biodiversity from the rainforest in the Guajira River watersheds of Costa Rica, Colombia, Panama, Ecuador, and Costa Rica. STRI has established a permanent field station at the Boca Negra Nature Reserve within the Guajira Basin, a former salt pan ecosystem that has been disturbed and reforested for agriculture. STRI researchers are using an innovative DNA microsatellite assay to determine the number of genetic lineages (or subpopulations) of tropical species in tropical rainforests worldwide. STRI also collects and catalogs specimens from the Panama-Caribbean Tropical Forest Program. The researchers report that the Boca Negra nature reserve is a refuge for species such as Hogna mafra.

I'm a big fan of the Kanger Protank 2, and I've even upgraded my old Protank with the TC100, because it's compact, easy to switch between the tanks in a drop-in fashion, and the flavor output just blows me away. I purchased the Kanger Protank 4 on a whim, because I've seen it touted as being slightly better than the other two tanks in the family, and that's exactly what it is. With that said, I figured that the new Protank 4 is definitely a much nicer tank to look at and to hold. It's more comfortable to hold and it doesn't feel like you're squeezing the sides and top of the tank together. The tank also holds up surprisingly well. I haven't had an issue with leaks, while still allowing you to adjust your resistance, and I've also found that it can perform really great at low wattage and then hold up quite well. The Kanger Protank 4 takes the classic Kanger drip tip of the Protank 2, along with a new one from Kanger, the Kanger Aerotank. The new Aerotank doesn't fit perfectly in the old Protank 2 drip tip, as it's wider and longer than the other Protank tip, but now that it has a better drip tip, I'm not even worried about it. As you can see from the pictures, I've also got two tank caps on the Protank 4! I can't even tell that they aren't there! They're great! I've decided to go with a dual coil setup, which is currently my go-to tank setup for this size of tank. It performs amazing, and has so many different flavors to choose from. I really love the Protank 4. Highly recommended! 2 people found this helpful

Greetings all. This is a topic that has come up so often, in my work at TDC (and for others) that it seems to have morphed into an article. This is a personal blog post, and I realize that may upset people that I've spoken at or have spoken at other schools. To be completely fair to people who do disagree with me, I'm not trying to "bully" anyone into action (or away from action). I am simply trying to state for the record the opinion of my former employer. I appreciate the opportunity to do so, as do you, as I want to leave this topic as one that is in an open, and hopefully constructive, discussion. It took me awhile, some very dark night nights of the soul, but I reached a point where I had to take a position on the elephant in the room (and in my own mind). It is this view that I will go on to describe below, my views and motivations, and, most importantly, my reasons for thinking it is OK for a teacher or teacher parent to get involved in an organization that is openly anti-union…or to support a union. This is not a question, just an opinion. And it is not a position I believe is common among most "professional educator" organizations today. So let me explain. In my experience as a teacher, I can tell you, that the majority of teachers are union members, especially in the most progressive areas. They make union a top priority, whether they support the union, or not. And I'm not talking about teachers who simply vote for a union (although this is the most common way). I'm talking a "strong" union supporter who will actively support a union, whether they agree or not. I don't believe that a teacher who has always supported a union has committed any form of professional misconduct. It is not a crime to oppose a union. On the contrary, it is a form of professional commitment to serve your country to support our fellow citizens, regardless if you personally agree with the union on all issues. And a teacher that is against a union? What I do believe is that being against unions, or at least being on the fence about union, is no longer a valid excuse for getting "paid" to lie. It is a badge of honor just like "being a teacher" is in today's teacher marketplace. And, I'm telling you this as an educator! Many people in my profession are not educators, just like some in the "professional" industry. And just because the name "educator" is associated with a school (which is not an ideal position) in our nation, it does not mean we don't need to practice what we preach for the children. We do need to teach children from a basic set of values. In fact, it is our responsibility to pass those same values on to our children, to their friends, and to our fellow citizens. And, if a union-free education is what is "right" for the children, then by all means the union-free education is what is right for those children. I'm not a parent, or anyone who wants to dictate what is right for my children (and that includes you, as an employer, as well). So, if you have the opportunity for an employer who will sponsor a teacher who supports a union, do so. If the position is part-time or "on the side," give those who have the right to support to teachers a "special time of pay" or some other way to express what their "part-time relationship" means. But do not pay a union supporter to advocate for the union in any way that will impact your bottom line! (And yes, I am aware you want to stay "in the game", and have to pay some dues, even if that is against your conscience.) Keep in mind, though, that what you give is how much you will ultimately receive back in the form of your job. And if you are a teacher, parent, or organization that has an issue with TDC having an issue with it's union-supporters, we're always happy to help you understand that an organization is not always a "one-sided" organization. If it is truly an exclusive club with members solely due to the issue of their unions support, we would all welcome a conversation with that organization concerning the merits of opposing unions. But if it is not about unions, and if you know for a fact that this organization has a policy that opposes unions, and your position is aligned to mine, this might not be the place to find other organizations that will support you and your position. We offer services to many organizations on a regular basis. And if you find other organizations with similar views and policies to those of TDC, please let us know. We are always willing to discuss these issues. And again, I reiterate, please do not attack other

KOLKATA: For the first time, an Indian school textbook is being used in the U.S. for teaching mathematics. As part of the Global Mathematics Project (GMP) conducted by the Council on the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (COAP), the American Council for Education (ACE), P.K. Singh, a mathematics teacher from the Delhi Central School, taught in the U.S. to prepare Indian students for the GMP. While at the US for this project along with his students, Mr. Singh introduced a set of mathematical methods which are not normally used in U.S. schools.Mr. Singh, who is also the founder and president of Vigyan Bhartiya Sanskriti Anusandhan Kendra, shared his experiences of teaching mathematics in the US during a workshop at the New York Math Club on Friday. He told TOI: "I have been teaching math for more than 30-years in schools in Punjab where I have been able to show how mathematics is used in India. In addition, I know how to teach it in U.S. too. When I came to the U.S. at the end of 2012, I have learnt several basic principles which are not usually taught in U.S. schools. I wanted to share my experience of teaching math in the U.S to students and the general public here as part of the Global Mathematics Project.The American Council for Education and ACE agreed to work together to produce this textbook in cooperation with Vigyan Bhartiya Sanskriti Anusandhan Kendra, an education organization based in the U.S."Our experience on GMP has provided us with some insights and suggestions. Some of the most important things we learnt are that teachers in the U.S. and India must cooperate. Teachers in one country must have teachers in the other country to train each other. In addition, there must be a clear line of communication – from the teacher to the student. Also, teacher's books and materials must be in U.S. dollars. We also talked about the need to develop new research, and how India can continue to expand its education sector."The new Indian textbook has been approved by the ACE and has been sent to Vigyan Bhartiya Sanskriti Anusandhan Kendra for development."I am quite excited that this textbook has been approved by ACE and has been sent to Vigyan Bhartiya Sanskriti Anusandhan Kendra for development and the final version of it is due early next year. They have worked on this from the beginning. It is going to be a great collaboration for India and the U.S.," said Mr. Singh.The U.S. version of the textbook will be published by The Council on the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (COAP). "The content of this textbook will also be used in Indian schools, through teacher education programs and as a teaching tool in the academic discipline of mathematics," said Mr. Singh.The textbook will be available to teachers on various websites of Vigyan Bhartiya Sanskriti Anusandhan Kendra and the Council on the Accreditation of Educator Preparation along with some other education organizations. There are also some publications by the organization that will make this textbook available to students in the U.S. "A small portion of the textbook has been translated and we have sent that to the Indian version. I am not certain if that's going to be included as part of the final release of the book, but that is my hope," said Mr. Singh.The book is being adapted to U.S. English language. "It is based on the Indian Mathematics in English version and some other Indian textbooks as well. The basic mathematics and some interesting questions from the textbook will be translated into English," said Mr. Singh.

This is one of those "I read it for the story" moments. In the mid 1980s, a small group of people were looking at the same problem and came up with the same solution and a few other things that, if you were a scientist with a small budget and a large idea, would be very interesting for a good story. The problem comes from a very basic question about whether there is a connection between the rate of change of the weather and atmospheric carbon dioxide. Here is the paper for some background: Kotov , J. D-M. et al. (1986) Does the Atmospheric Climate Model Run on a Computer Get More True than False Temperatures? Atmospheric Science Letters, 10(3), 585-589. Basically, the model runs were set at 2-3% (or less) and it found, in their words, it was "no better than chance". They had one other interesting fact to add: the actual atmospheric CO2 content didn't respond at all to their choice of model, except for the fact that it went up around the equator (see here for more). Their paper was published in Air Science and Technology: A Quarterly Review, no. 1 and their data set they used comes from the US. In this paper, Kotov looked at how different models varied with variations in atmospheric carbon dioxide content. The problem, in this case, was how to handle the fact that climate is actually a global system (not just local) so there can be no simple linear trend in the variation of either CO2 or climate. The models could simulate the whole system and so it's hard to know what is likely to be happening to CO2. For the global climate, the models that did best were ones which could capture the whole world, i.e. in this case the global climate response. The other models could only model part of the world, in this case the North American and Australian regions (Figure 1A), but even then they didn't do quite as well. Figure 1. The average simulated climate response of the seven models investigated by Kotov in his paper, (A) Northern Hemisphere and (B) Southern Hemisphere, (from Kotov, 1986). They did get a number of interesting results, notably that the North American continent, although there was less variation in the response, had a larger trend due to the lack of data. The South was a bit more variable and the southern parts of the Antarctic got a bit more sensitive. They weren't so pleased about that, though and pointed this out, saying: We believe that the lack of global trend for the continental portion of the climate system indicates that it has not yet been accurately modeled; that the sensitivity of the global climate to the global carbon dioxide content is unknown; and that the variability of the response of these regions may have to be further explored. The paper was published in the prestigious journal Atmospheric Science Letters. If you think about it, this isn't an entirely new problem. After all, they ran the models a few percent higher for a little while and found that the climate actually got warmer. Why is that important? Well, consider that the Earth's average temperature is about 16.5°C; an increase of 1°C causes that temperature to rise by about 2.2°C. It's the difference between that and the 0.6°C observed in recent times. That is almost the same as half a degree. A change of 2.2°C, let alone half a degree, would make the average temperature in Europe warmer than it is now. So, the models that Kotov looked at simulated the rise of CO2 and they got it to go up, in real life, but with the model that got it to increase most quickly, it went up very slowly and with a lag of weeks or months. That's a bit of a head scratcher, though, isn't it? In fact, to the best of my knowledge, no one before Kotov had even tried to get an idea of whether there was a problem with the trend in climate, whether or not the observed increase was more than just noise in the data. It's hard to believe that no one else had tried before him. Even if it wasn't possible to run large numbers of climate simulations, one way of testing whether there was a problem would be to run one with a large enough variation, say in the range of 20 to 90% of the global range of temperatures, such that all of global climate would change, but that would still show a global increase in temperature if the variations were large. There isn't a lot of data for this, but I'm certain, by the way, that other scientists have tried a variation on this scale, i.e. have done a simulation using a much larger range of variation for climate than just the one which Kotov looked at. So there are some hints

How does it feel to be a man? The latest research on men's feelings about masculinity suggests it's a surprisingly nuanced question. And a recent survey of 4,068 men and women ages 26 to 65 reveals that most men and women agree that being a man is important in their lives. But when it comes to the ways in which they identify with the male gender, researchers found no obvious gender divide. According to the poll, men said they thought of themselves as "firm and reliable," "strong and confident," and "assertive," while women said they identified more with the words "caring" and "compassionate." Men also reported having more positive feelings about their bodies than women, with a majority saying they are "very thin" or "very muscular." They were also significantly more likely to be enthusiastic about their bodies in general, and to be averse to comments about appearance and weight. The study was published in the journal Man and Woman in the Social Environment, based on data collected as part of the ongoing International Women's Survey of Men and Masculinities. In recent years, the U.S. has taken on a national focus on the gender issues facing men, and many researchers have noted that men's feelings about their gender have been understudied or ignored. "Most people assume that the two genders are different, yet men and women report very similar beliefs about their gender roles, their values, and their self-perceptions," say a joint statement from the study's researchers. "This research demonstrates that both men and women share similar notions of their masculinity, but with women's perceptions of their masculinity showing less variance." According to the researchers, this is the first study to assess what men think about themselves in relation to masculinity and other attitudes about men. "We have the data that we needed to begin to understand these things, and that is what's so fascinating. Most people assume that the two genders are different, yet men and women report very similar beliefs about their gender roles, their values, and their self-perceptions, which is what's so fascinating," says sociologist and co-author of the study J.P. Rushton, a professor at Louisiana State University. Rushton and his co-authors also hope the survey, which polled 4,068 men and women in three countries, will add context to existing research on how American society and politics have become more equitable, and more progressive, for women. "We're starting to hear voices of men now in conversations about women in government and politics — it used to be all men, and it used to be all men. As we start to hear voices of men, we'll start to see an acceptance, and more and more men, and women start to move in the direction of what we were expecting," says Rushton. While some men do identify with the term "man" more broadly than others — some men say they consider themselves to be "feminine" — most people polled said their gender would fit into both categories, with men and women who said they saw their own gender as masculine roughly as equally likely to identify as "masculine" as those who identify only with their body's physical features, as well as those who identified as "feminine" or who said they were neither "masculine" nor "feminine." But while both men and women said that gender defined them, the gender of those who identified with both words — which the researchers used interchangeably — was largely unchanged from 1999 to 2013 — between 33 percent and 34 percent of self-identified men, and between 28 percent and 29 percent of self-identified women. The researchers believe their findings have profound implications for men's psychological well-being. Noting previous research on the positive emotional effects of masculinity, Rushton says men who are less interested in and more critical of their gender roles tend to be at greater risk of depression. But for those who identify as "masculine" but do not adhere to this image, these findings show a potential upside to less negative responses to gender roles. "People may be less satisfied with their own gender," says Rushton. "I think that would be something we would look for in our studies." Rushton adds that despite their apparent similarities to women, men feel comfortable with expressing more female-like traits that could make them feel more "masculine" than their gender labels suggest. For example, the study found that when asked to choose between two genders, half of men said they thought of themselves as "feminine" and half said they think of themselves as "masculine." The researchers say this gender overlap may be one reason why Americans were more likely to identify as male than female last year, according to the Pew Research Center. The researchers also speculate about the possible reasons behind the different ways in which men and women identified with their genders. For example, they theorize that some men may identify with their gender based

On Monday, the Supreme Court gave the final say over the state's "heartbeat" abortion law. The four justices split, as usual, about what the law does--or does not--do and the question before them today is whether the law will force abortion clinics to close down or go underground. In some ways, this issue is more complicated than the "two-thirds majority" ruling that the Court issued in March in Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt, which found that a Texas legislature had acted intentionally and purposefully to place severe restrictions on abortion access. The Texas law requires clinics to meet the building standards of ambulatory surgical centers and it puts a 72-hour waiting period on all abortions after the first trimester. The law also would require the clinics to have admitting privileges at a hospital within 30 miles--a step that many abortion rights advocates have deemed unnecessary since the vast majority of clinics already have hospital privileges. But there is also a broader question here regarding women's health. The Court in Whole Woman's Health also found that Texas's restrictions on abortion rights were designed to be especially damaging to women who had earlier miscarriages or who faced a severe fetal abnormality. The Texas law explicitly allows for any kind of abortion--including an induced abortion in which a doctor performs an "intact dilation of the cervix." These factors, which the Court has previously found to be relevant to the abortion restrictions, are not so relevant here. There is no question that women in Texas who undergo an abortion after a dilation abortion experience severe pain. In the same legal opinion that struck down Texas's law, Justice Anthony Kennedy wrote: In the end, the record in this case confirms that the pain of the abortion procedure can and does result in serious injury to a woman's emotional, physical, and mental health.... Even the best trained professional cannot ensure the emotional safety of women suffering such excruciating pain. As for the question of whether the state's law would make abortion clinics more dangerous for women to practice, the majority opinion in Whole Woman's Health has already dealt with that. In a concurrence written by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor--the majority author of the court's previous abortion rights decisions--the justices wrote: "Because of the nature of the surgery at issue, the likelihood of complication cannot be ruled out. In our experience, in-hospital dilation is very difficult, and the medical community's understanding of the surgery can be sketchy. Moreover, it is unlikely that a doctor performing the procedure for the first time would be competent to counsel her patient through the complications, either." To its credit, the court did not try to come to a "settled view" on what the new law might mean for abortion. Instead, it said that the law does the following: Requires abortion clinics to meet the building standards of ambulatory surgical centers...This requirement does not impose an undue burden on either the doctor or the patient. The requirements in the Act are minimal, and it requires a doctor to perform a very easy procedure. The patient cannot say that the doctor has subjected her to a significant delay or a significant inconvenience. The requirements do not violate the fundamental constitutional right of informed consent. The requirements do not prevent a doctor, in the course of carrying out his or her medical task, from communicating with a pregnant woman about the nature of the medical procedure, providing the woman with information about alternatives, and suggesting a course of treatment. While it may not eliminate the risk of abortions to women undergoing any kind of procedure, the decision today does signal that the Supreme Court will not tolerate the sort of surgical procedures that clinics must employ to provide abortions. As for what a decision by Justice Elena Kagan could mean for Texas' abortion law, the court could have a lot to say in March. In March, the court is scheduled to rule on whether Texas lawmakers have violated the 14th Amendment's ban on laws that place an "undue burden" on women's constitutionally protected right to choose abortion. If the Texas law is the sort of law that could raise red flags for the Supreme Court, the justices could be a lot more aggressive in striking it down if Justice Kagan agrees with the plaintiffs and strikes down Texas's restrictive law.

Citra is a free and open source software implementation of a modern CPU called the "Haswell" architecture. It is distributed under the GNU General Public License (GPL) and it includes a GPU backend. The software can be downloaded from its official website. Citra is currently supported on: Ubuntu Linux OS X 10.9 (Mavericks) OS X 10.10 (Yosemite) Windows 7 Windows 8.1 Windows 8 Windows 10 (Creators Update) Ubuntu Linux is supported on: Raspberry Pi 2 and 3 Windows 10 A full list of supported CPUs, supported GPUs, and versions can be found on the Citra website. Installing Citra The official package is available in Canonical's official repositories. You can install it by typing the following command: sudo apt install citra The software includes the graphical software viewer and the kernel. You will be prompted to install the "Pip tool". The software depends on the following packages. Ensure that your system is adequately configured to use this software. Dependencies for the graphical software viewer: libX11-dev - x11-server libX11-devel - x11-server-devel cairo - Xvfb and SDL2 frameworks libgl1-mesa-dev - Mesa OpenGL 3.3 development headers libgl1-mesa-dri - Mesa OpenGL 3.3 driver for Direct3D 10/11 libgl1-mesa-glx - Mesa OpenGL 3.3 driver for OpenGL ES libglib-dev - glib emulation library libglib3-dev - Glib library version 3.2.2 libcairo2-dev - Cairo library libglu1-mesa - Xvfb libxcb-randr-dev - Xvfb X11-libs - libX11, libX11-devel and libXvfb-devel The list above is subject to change and Citra is constantly changing and expanding. Always ensure you have updated your dependencies. If the list above does not list your dependencies, it means you must install them later. Citra's command line interface To start using Citra, open a terminal and type: citra-console The console interface allows you to use the Citra command line interface to interact with the Linux kernel. The console interface includes all of the standard Citra commands. It includes a number of options which can be added to the Citra command, for example: citra-console --help usage: citra-console [-h] [-C] COMMAND[-A] [-d] [-F] [--version] [options] Options: -h, --help show this help message and exit -C, --config COMMAND CURRENT CONFIGURATION -d, --default COMMAND CURRENT CURRENT MANUAL CONFIG -F, --force COMMAND CURRENT MANUAL FORCING -a, --auto ASSUME AUTO -r, --roles ASSUME ROLE ASSUME -l, --languages LIST THE LANGUAGES YOU WANT TO USE -S, --system SETTINGS FOR SYSTEM USAGE -a, --auto ASSUME AUTO -r, --roles ASSUME ROLE ASSUME To use the Citra command line interface, you will need to have some knowledge of Linux shell scripting. Many commands use bash syntax when they can be expressed in shell script syntax. Common Citra commands Citra's command line interface has many common commands you can use when building a Linux environment for Citra. Here is a list of some of these commands: help : print a short explanation of a command : print a short explanation of a command version : print the release version of Citra : print the release version of Citra show : list all available Citra command line interface commands : list all available Citra command line interface commands source : run the given command in a Linux-shell environment : run the given command in a Linux-shell environment unpack : extract a program or program configuration files and its dependencies : extract a program or program configuration files and its dependencies install : install a local copy of a dependency-package : install a local copy of a dependency-package remove: remove a local copy of a dependency-package Building a Linux environment for Citra Citra is distributed in a very basic GNU/Linux kernel build system, which makes it possible to assemble an environment for Citra. This section will show you how to get your environment up-to-speed. First

If your life is anything like my, you've been looking for that one thing that makes you feel special. No matter how many options you consider, you find there's only one that you can get excited about – that one thing that makes you feel special and worthy of being valued, respected, and loved. You may know this thing, but you probably aren't yet proud of it. Being an "A-List Bachelor" is no more special than being a "Wives'/Girlfriend" and "Bride/Groom" or a "Sibling Group" or even "Parent Group". It's time to get started. I want you to get some of the things you are proud of into a bucket. Take the most important one, and take it to your heart, and let's share your A+ status with the world… together. A+ List Of Gifts That Make You Proud

What a shame that you're not my husband! I've heard so much nonsense about a wife not being able to keep a man, but I think you make a mistake in your thinking. You are the one that needs to prove yourself worthy of my love. I'm not looking for someone to take on the whole house cleaning as if you're a maid...or the whole household management duties. I'm looking for a person I can count on, a partner, a lover. I think you've made it clear that you can be that partner. ~N.I.K. "I wish that I had someone who I could share that with. Someone that loves and respects me as much as I love and respects him... And if I think there is only one way that I can share this wonderful connection with someone, I think the same way...If there is only one person who could share this love with me, then I will find that person. I want this thing that I have with him to be like a diamond ring, something that will have a beautiful sparkle that makes it shine from the inside; a special necklace that has an endless source of beauty that brings him happiness and happiness with me.. And with that...I'm pretty much begging you to get together with me! Please come with me, to spend this wonderful time together and share each other's lives." ~N.I.K.

H.R. 3610 (112th) was a bill in the United States Congress. A bill must be passed by both the House and Senate in identical form and then be signed by the President to become law. This bill was introduced in the 112th Congress, which met from Jan 5, 2011 to Jan 3, 2013. Legislation not enacted by the end of a Congress is cleared from the books. How to cite this information. We recommend the following MLA-formatted citation when using the information you see here in academic work: GovTrack.us. (2018). H.R. 3610 — 112th Congress: Hire Early, Hire Often Act of 2012. Retrieved from https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/112/hr3610 "H.R. 3610 — 112th Congress: Hire Early, Hire Often Act of 2012." www.GovTrack.us. 2012. September 27, 2018 <https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/112/hr3610> Hire Early, Hire Often Act of 2012, H.R. 3610, 112th Cong.. {{cite web |url=https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/112/hr3610 |title=H.R. 3610 ( 112th) |accessdate=September 27, 2018 |author=112th Congress (2012) |date=June 14, 2012 |work=Legislation |publisher=GovTrack.us |quote=Hire Early, Hire Often Act of 2012 }} show another citation format: MLA APA Blue Book Wikipedia Template Where is this information from? GovTrack automatically collects legislative information from a variety of governmental and non-governmental sources. This page is sourced primarily from Congress.gov, the official portal of the United States Congress. Congress.gov is generally updated one day after events occur, and so legislative activity shown here may be one day behind. Data via the congress project.

As we go down the list of nominees for the 2014 Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Edition, we have some new names. In addition to last year's top-selling model Kylie McNeill, there's former Miss Florida Tara Conner, who has a similar look to what Rihanna wore while modeling for Sports Illustrated and is on a mission to spread the word of the magazine and model in the nude. And then there's the amazing Kate Upton, one of the hottest women in the world at the moment who's modeled in many issues of SI in the past. She had an interview with SI's Swimsuit Issue, and, I kid you not, it was a nude! Upton explains: "I never thought about modeling in a swimsuit before. And then it just seemed natural – because the way it works in the swimsuit industry is a lot of the models are naked… I think it's important to show the world what beauty can be like if you focus on it and you think about it and you make decisions for it, and you have confidence in it. And that's kind of what I do." "It's also a great opportunity to showcase women's bodies that traditionally may be under represented," Upton concluded. "I've felt that I don't have the same opportunities that other beautiful women have… To kind of shine a light and show the world how different a woman can be with just her body." We're not sure if it's the way she dresses, her attitude, or just her great sense of humor, but Kate looks like the perfect fit for some SI Swimsuit Edition covers. Do you agree with Kate? Comment below and tell us why you believe she's one of the top 25 hot models of all time! [Photo Credit: Getty Images]

A New Jersey police chief says a teenager from Jersey City made a threatening phone call to the city's mayor on Sunday morning.  "During the call, the suspect made an allegation of attempted murder concerning the mayor," Jersey City Police Chief Mark Peters said Tuesday after the teen turned 16. Peters said Jersey City police were called to the 18th Street Bridge in Bergen County around 11 a.m. Sunday for a report of a "suspicious person," not a threat. He said the teen was not armed and had no criminal record. Peters said while investigating, officers found a cell phone and several receipts belonging to the teen. When he was given a search warrant, officers found several items inside the teenager's bedroom and an unspecified amount of marijuana, he said. The teenager was charged with criminal possession of marijuana and endangering the welfare of a child, the chief said. He said the investigation is ongoing. Peters said he did not know the teen's age, though his phone had a profile photo for a person at the time of the call. Mayor-elect Steve Fulop, who will take office Tuesday, said he met Tuesday night with Jersey City police, who agreed to hold the suspect for the mayor's approval. Fulop said that would take place Wednesday at Bergen County Court in Freehold. The mayor-elect said the phone call could raise serious concerns about "security" in the city. "We had a guy who had threatened to kill the mayor in Jersey City," Fulop said. He said there are strict security measures in place in the city. "It's just very unnerving that the first place that a potential threat should be reported is a police department." Hudson County Sheriff's Office spokesman Jim McCarthy said the department and its detectives are investigating a separate call Sunday morning reporting that a group of people shot at a truck. He said the call came in as a false alarm, but when officers responded, they found two people, including one with a gunshot wound, who appeared to be intoxicated. They were taken to the hospital with non-life threatening injuries to their torso or limbs, McCarthy said. He said police believe that the incident may be related to the Sunday night incident. McCarthy said this was the second shooting of a vehicle suspected of being driven by an intoxicated person at the Bergen County Fairgrounds in one weekend, both in Ocean County. "The last incident was reported here during the Fourth of July weekend," he said. "The perpetrator left the scene on foot in this incident."

When there are two sides, there's a war on. What follows are the quotes from the man who wrote the best-selling book that has changed the war on drugs, turned an entire national conversation from criminalization to legalization, and changed the fortunes of his most ardent critics, the police. Cops, stop your bullshit! (I have to go now, but you should read it!) by Chuck Baldwin What do you do when you witness the unspeakable? When the blood of an innocent child breaks the silence, when the mother cries out for justice, when the city screams for an end to mass incarceration? When you see what is happening as your police take the life of a young man. At 4:30 a.m. on Nov. 14, 2013, the two Albuquerque SWAT officers who had entered the room where 23-year-old Daniel Zamudio and his friend, Marlon Vasquez, were sitting, guns raised, shot their way through the door, killing both men. An autopsy showed that the men had been shot at least 10 times, perhaps as many as 15 -- all from behind. The police said they feared for the lives of the two terrified, unarmed people inside. But on Dec. 6, the Albuquerque Police Department, citing a judge's order, released the medical police report on Zamudio that showed he was unarmed when his friend ran at him with a knife, and the officers fired five shots, killing him within six seconds. This is the first time that the department has released the details from this incident. It's the only time that the police have been transparent about police shootings. But, as the medical report from the shooting of Zamudio says, he was not, and could not have been, armed. Why were these "officers" so terrified? That is a question that needs to be answered by the people -- the Albuquerque people -- who have been fighting for a long time to change what's happening in local police departments. If these men were armed and dangerous, that's a completely different matter. When confronted with someone wielding a knife, an AR-15 assault rifle or a handgun, Albuquerque Police Department members would fire first. But the fact that it was unarmed men killed at the door is the reason that the police can be so quick to deploy their firearms. The men in handcuffs Here's what the police found in Zamudio's apartment. The officers had found this room completely empty. There were no drugs, no weapons, no evidence of a crime. And there was no reason for the men to be handcuffed and locked in the hallway, in this spot on the floor. It seemed odd to handcuff the two young men inside their own apartment in the predawn darkness with no sign of a break-in. But this was not odd -- it was standard procedure. All across the country, cities and police departments routinely perform door to door searches of homes without any warrant, probable cause, or reason for a search. The only justification for these searches is that police are worried that people are hiding weapons. But if you're in your residence when police knock on your door at 4:30 a.m., the most they are really looking for is to find drugs. These officers had no reason to suspect that the men they shot were armed, at least not until they shot them, and then started firing again. These officers also had no reason to shoot Marlon -- not that they would have found anything illegal in his home or car, which he was walking out of before they fired at him. It was a senseless act of violence not just on both sides -- it is a senseless act of violence on our criminal justice system. It is impossible to be shocked by this video, because it has been in the news every day for the past month. But the Albuquerque police chief's decision to release the officers' bodycam footage after a court order -- a decision I and others criticized -- reflects a disturbing tendency among law enforcement in the United States -- and it reflects a disturbing shift in culture in the country. We are moving toward a climate of law enforcement that will only protect people if they can be shown to pose a danger. That climate is leading to the murder of more of our fellow citizens by police than by all other forms of violence combined. Albuquerque police have also changed since the incident, and that's the important thing for us to remember. The Albuquerque police have changed, and this is a great sign. Police are responding to social media with humor -- their first response to the shooting was to announce that they were giving out free cigars. That's good, but the real question is: Why would you shoot and kill two men who were trying to protect their own lives? The same question was asked of the officer who shot and killed

It's just an example Hello, just an example, because I wanted to see if this is something that does actually work or not. My goal is to make a script which performs a scan, but the output is a list of nodes which are "connected" to each other with n nodes, where n is 1,3,5,...,15 (as many as are possible), as you can see, I chose n = 15, because that is enough for me, it works for me and I do have a bit of experience with the format of a scan. The example is not that much complex (as compared to my more ambitious scripts) but it does work. The script is just running through and reading each line, printing the node names that are connected to the nodes and then writing out a text file with this information, in this way you can look into the whole scan as you wish. In addition to that you can see the same nodes are scanned a few times and then written out as text again. The following screenshot shows how I generated the file with a script like this in the same directory as the scan (the node list itself is not visible):

This is what Donald Trump's presidency looks like when the American system of checks and balances is taken for granted. Trump's first move was to appoint and fire senior officials. Trump, a billionaire whose company has done business with foreign governments, and whose net worth is unknown, apparently lacked the necessary security clearances. He fired a law enforcement official (Mark Halperin) who was investigating him and he has asked the attorney general to fire the special counsel now in charge of the investigation. That move is unlikely to succeed. It is no coincidence that the actions reflect the kind of authoritarian personality that has infected Trump's transition team and whose actions are now reflected in the government at large. That is what Trump's own words about Russian President Vladimir Putin mean for this nation. Trump's first action was appointing Steve Bannon as his campaign chief executive and chief strategist. This decision was based on the premise that his instincts as a political operative were superior to his experience in the mainstream Republican establishment. The president-elect is following in the footsteps of Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney who gave Bannon the key job heading his campaign's analytics operation as he was looking for a way to win the nomination. The chief strategist is the one that Trump talks most about with his closest advisers. Trump sees little distinction between them and Bannon is not to be trusted, but the president-elect is also impressed with him. But then Trump went a step further. Bannon said in an interview that he was going to be his "wingman." He had a role in bringing Trump's campaign message to the mainstream media and the Republican Party. Now it appears that will be his role inside the White House. Trump appointed as the head of his National Security Council the former Wall Street attorney Michael Flynn, who lied about meeting with the Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak prior to Trump's inauguration, and subsequently was forced to resign as Trump's national security adviser. He also chose Steve Bannon to be the White House chief strategist, but he recently admitted in an interview that he had also told Flynn about the plan to fire FBI Director James Comey without consulting Vice President Mike Pence. Trump is going to need to rely on his chief strategist if he is to make progress on issues like healthcare reform and repealing the Affordable Care Act, two major fronts in the battle against the Democrats in Congress. Trump has also fired Robert S. Mueller III as special counsel investigating his campaign team's ties with the Russians and a host of financial transactions by Trump and his associates for which they have been caught up. It might be a legal maneuver, but it would be a political one. Trump's reaction to the news is predictable. Instead of being grateful for the president who is taking a huge, important step in uniting the country and keeping it in charge of its own destiny, Trump tweeted "RESIST," adding "Fired FBI Director James Comey will be replaced by someone who will do a far better job, bringing back the spirit and prestige of the FBI." Trump's action and behavior were predictable from the moment he took office. He will use his new authority to advance his political and personal interests. To be a leader worth the title he will have to put aside his political ambitions and concentrate on the responsibilities and work of being commander in chief to get the country back moving and on track to the goals of its founding fathers, the men and women who built America.

The number of people killed by drivers under the influence of cannabis was found to be more than double that of those killed by alcohol, a study has found. Researchers from the University of Sydney found that drivers aged between 18 and 32 years old were over five-times more likely to experience a cannabis-related fatality than drivers aged 15-24 years old. "Youngsters often view cannabis as a harmless substance, yet it has the potential to be lethal to drivers," the study said. "The increased fatality risk from cannabis is significant and should be considered in any policy measures aimed at reducing cannabis-driving-related deaths." The findings came after a study found cannabis drivers were seven times more likely then those who had drunk alcohol to collide with a pedestrian. Drivers found to be under the influence of cannabis were also more than twice as likely to lose control.

How to set up a VPN connection What is a VPN?  A Virtual Private Network is a digital tunnel that allows you to access online resources over the Internet anonymously. This helps keep your private information hidden.  When you use a VPN, websites, online services, and people around the world, use a different IP address to connect to you. The IP address provided by your Internet Service Provider (ISP) can be used to track what websites you visit, track what Internet activities you perform, etc. If your ISP collects this information or uses it to track your behavior, it could be considered as cyber stalking or harassment.  Here at SurfEasy, our VPN servers use a unique and secure encryption protocol to let you access the Internet securely. SurfEasy uses these servers in Australia to protect your privacy.  SurfEasy uses PIA for its VPN application. It's a open cryptographic standard developed by Open Whisper Systems (OWS). It's designed to be flexible, easy to install, and secure. SurfEasy also supports multiple languages, including Japanese.  Before you use a VPN, you need to learn a few things about what the VPN is and how it works. You can also learn more about IP addresses and DNS. VPN traffic goes through a lot of Tor Exit nodes and Tor users would not have Tor. This could also include sites that are associated with Tor such as sites that promote sexual predators. There are also many other reasons why you would not want to use a Tor exit VPN. For example, we are not responsible for any IP addresses you use when you connect to our servers!  SurfEasy has a Tor exit option. This means you can browse the internet anonymously while on SurfEasy's VPN servers. If you use VPN software on your Android phone or computer you are also using a Tor exit.  Using a Tor exit helps protect you from the internet predators, sexual predators, and government snoopers. What is a VPN IP address?  When you set up a VPN connection you must choose a unique IP address for your connection. This is the IP address you are using when you connect to the VPN server.  A VPN IP address can have a significant impact on how you are tracked. A VPN IP address is not the same as the IP address of your ISP which provides you access to the network. Your VPN IP address is not the same as the IP address of the VPN server that we connect to. For example you can use a VPN IP address that's different from any other IP address for our server.

I'm sitting in the kitchen of my apartment, which is full of books, maps, and various knickknacks. After two hours or so sitting, I'm tired and my eyes are watery. There's something different about the room, but I find myself unable to put my finger on exactly what it is. Then, out of nowhere, a pair of glasses appear on my counter. "These are really good," I tell the man, who is wearing a suit, an apron, and a mustache. "You have got to try them." Then I show him my room—three shelves of books, a dozen maps on top of each other, a dozen knickknacks like a giant backpack. He holds his hand up and takes a swipe. "I like your room, too. It reminds me of your home." The room itself has some resemblance to my own house—its patterned tiles and rugs, the chairs I use, the books and movies I keep in my house. In the kitchen, however, my house has been replaced by something a little unexpected. What you see is only my imagination, a house that never existed. I live on a property that is owned by a company called Trava House, which bought the property three years ago for a reported $15 million. For the last three years, I have resided here among a collection of people I call "Projects." These are people who have received $5 million to build some kind of architectural experiment; they call themselves "Circles of Influence." When I arrived, in 2012, they spent $5.7 million; this year, they spent $9.9 million, for a total of $21 million. At this point, I can't tell where the money will come from to finish building a house out in the desert. It may come from some kind of "open-source" project, or they'll borrow it from the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development. Or maybe they'll use the money to create a kind of community center. I'm in my apartment with two other people who live here: an artist named Daniel (he prefers his friends and family to only use their first names), who has a huge book collection; and an architect named William. They have been living here at Project Trava House for four years and are now living through every stage of construction. It's kind of like being in a traveling circus and hoping to escape that circus one day. I first came to Project Trava House with Daniel in 2012. Daniel had received his master's thesis about an architect he had met at the Architectural Center, and this had sparked a friendship that led to Daniel working on Project Trava House on his own. William was an architect who was in a position to do so. (William is one of dozens of prominent architects in New York City who do all of their client work in Trava House's studio.) Together, they founded Project Trava House, a community project whose goal is to create a house—any house—in the desert, in exchange for about $1 million a year of funding from HUD. It's like a small-scale utopian experiment, and there's a sort of science behind it, to be sure, but there's also a lot of free-flowing optimism, like when Project Trava House gets to work its magic on an unsuspecting neighbor (if not on them). The project has been criticized for the way it has re-invented the concept of sustainability, as well as the fact that it has been incredibly expensive. The project is located at 3600 East 7th Street, and it requires about a dozen people to run and staff the house for any given week. The group of developers and architects at Project Trava House has some interesting ideas about the way we move around in the world and how architects should do some of that, and some less interesting ideas about the way architects should just accept the consequences of a certain type of architecture. The group seems to believe that the construction of a large structure should result in an "artificial" environment—something that is "artificial," but not very good. (In case you're thinking: "Oh god, artificial! Can't that hurt someone who wants to find the perfect space?" Yes, it can; but I'd argue that it doesn't.) I also don't think that the group is well-suited to dealing with certain aspects of the city and urbanism. It may be a group of smart people who have made their way in the world through their skills and hard work with computers, but it's also a group of people who, I assume, have been living a lot of our lives indoors. If you've ever driven a car that didn't have a driver, you have some insight into what I'm talking about here. We might not have lived all our lives in apartments, but we've lived a lot of our lives inside buildings. The

The people have to accept change and have to be ready to change, said Mark Levin. That's an interesting statement. What does it really mean? Levin says that "all that's needed is a new president," with a new Supreme Court justice, and that everything else can be worked out later. I'm not sure I agree with the latter statement at all. I think that the American experiment in radical change would have had its first major test in America with a Republican president. We'd need to confront and overcome the cultural, political and philosophical challenge to the nation's founding that would come with a GOP president, and even then there's no guarantee that everything would be fine. There are limits, but they are all well outlined by the Constitution and the checks and balances built into that document. The people would not take the chance. I disagree. Most of the time, you do not need a change in an incumbent president in order to have a radical change. The change that needs to be made is within the Congress itself. The people need to understand that they are the center of this nation's governance and should be expected to use the power they enjoy to change that governance. This year Republicans are going to get the opportunity to do just that. Let's hope they seize it and see this through.

(CNN) A group of U.S. scientists says that their data from the Hubble Space Telescope prove it: Ice covers more area on Earth's surface than previously thought. Scientists said the new discovery means that the oceans cover about one-quarter of the planet's surface, as opposed to previous estimates of 70% or more, according to a report in the journal Nature Advances . They added that this new ice coverage represents more than 100 million square kilometers more than previously estimated. Previous estimates, which covered only half of the planet, were based on satellite imagery from the late 1980s, CNN affiliate KCEN reported. Scientists had suspected that ice in the seas covered only about 10% of the Earth's surface. The new data may mean that sea levels have been rising at an unprecedented rate, causing the ice to shrink, according to a statement from the National Snow and Ice Data Center that accompanies the study on its website. It added that ice melt is the main driver behind the rise in sea levels. The study "adds a little more uncertainty to our long-term forecasts," said Christopher Rupkey, director of environmental economics and policy research at the Environmental Management Institute (EMI), a Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Berkeley, California-based research organization that published the study. NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland, operates Hubble as part of an Astrophysics System Observatory (ASO) program. The discovery follows another recently announced ice cover discovery by the ASO group that led to the conclusion -- supported by the same study -- that the world's oceans have covered about 25% of the Earth's surface. The scientists were studying NASA's twin Hubble Space Telescope images to gain information about the Earth's climate. This is the latest in more discoveries of ice and water in the waters of the ocean. The Hubble photographs showed that the water of the oceans covers about 1% of the Earth's surface. The latest finding may mean that global sea levels are rising at an unprecedented rate, raising questions including how fast ice melting might cause sea levels to rise, according to Rupkey. The researchers calculated that the total ice covered in the oceans is equivalent to the area of the entire Greenland Ice Sheet.

A new ad from former GOP vice presidential nominee Sarah Palin and her campaign will be running in Nevada's Clark County ahead of next week's caucuses in the state, a county official and the local GOP chairman confirmed Tuesday. Palin's campaign will run an ad featuring a video featuring a child in rural eastern Nevada telling of his own story, as well as one of his mother raising their children in poverty in that county. "This is part of a larger ad we've done in a number of different locations nationwide: a child talking about what his mother does to make ends meet and how she raised him and how his mother raised him and how they all know the pain you have going on today and how we all stand together to change the world," said Brian Murray, chairman of the Clark County Republican Party and a deputy for Gov. Brian Sandoval (R). That ad has already aired in Reno, as well as the Las Vegas area, Murray said, which is why it will run in Clark County. "It's a positive thing because it's talking about a message about the future and trying to encourage people not to stay on the status quo," Murray said. Palin endorsed former Texas Gov. Rick Perry and Sen. Ted Cruz Rafael (Ted) Edward CruzBredesen says he won't back Schumer for Senate Dem leader Webb: The new mob: Anti-American Dems Ignored Latino vote will be key in future elections MORE (R-Texas) in the wake of Perry's departure from the race, and she will be back in the campaign in coming days if she does decide to run again for the White House. She has also been weighing in on the GOP presidential race. After the party's primary in New Hampshire, she called Donald Trump Donald John TrumpTrump: Dems playing destructive 'con game' with Kavanaugh Several Yale Law classmates who backed Kavanaugh call for misconduct investigation Freedom Caucus calls on Rosenstein to testify or resign MORE "a cancer on conservatism." "I think it's an opportunity to reach people because the Republican Party, we've never run away from our principles. We have never run to the right," Murray said, suggesting that the new ad is part of her ongoing effort to reach a broader audience with a clear message of economic responsibility. Palin and Perry have a long history in the state, with Perry serving as lieutenant governor in the 1990s and Palin co-hosting a radio show on the Perry administration's radio network. Both have been criticized for being insufficiently conservative, but Palin's endorsement of Trump has given her a boost in the polls there. The former Alaska governor is expected to appear on stage with the GOP nominee at a rally in Pahrump on Thursday.

Pineapple Sauce You can't beat the flavour of this classic and beloved Indian curry. With the crunchy, orange and sweet flavours of pineapple, this is just the ticket! The sauce is made of ingredients like kiwis, coriander, cumin and cardamom. A classic family recipe. Ingredients (Serves 6): 1 cup mangoes, peeled and finely chopped 1 can (25 oz or 750 ml) tomatoes 1 tablespoon turmeric 2 cups water 2 tablespoons sugar 1 tablespoon coriander seeds 1 teaspoon paprika 1 teaspoon ground cumin or cardamom Method Cut the tomatoes into small bits. Saute the onions, ginger and garlic in some oil until they start to brown. Add the onions, tomatoes and spices. Mix them together well. Add water to make it even thickest. Simmer the tomato paste for 8-10 minutes (for more heat) then add the cooked kiwi and simmer it for another 2-3 minutes. Meanwhile, in pan heat oil, add the crushed tomatoes, turmeric, coriander seeds and cumin. Saute on a medium flame for a couple of minutes and then add the water. Let it boil over a medium heat. Add a little salt and sugar, cover and keep simmering. Stir it regularly, or else it will be salty. When the tomatoes and water has evaporated and turn it off. Now add the mangoes and cover and keep simmering. Let the mixture boil about 5 minutes and then strain it well and add. Add the turmeric powder and mix it well. Curry is ready! You need about 30 to 45 minutes or more to make it the perfect texture. Serve it with rice or with chapati. Tips & Ideas Don't use canned tomatoes, especially in this curry recipe. Choose fresh ones whenever possible. The spices mentioned here are for the main spicy ingredients, you can add fresh chilies to the dish for a bit different flavour. You can keep the sauce chilled and serve it over rice and chapati, or serve it with rotis or naan. Pineapple (Pisang). This recipe was originally published on the blog of my dear friend Arun Kuriyan. Visit her blog here

I'm not sure what happened to all of my posts, but I was so busy working on the book for the last year that I didn't have any time to write anything for this blog. I did write a whole post about how to make a good recipe video, so you should keep that in mind. So after a couple years of living in New York City and cooking at home, I have finally found time to focus on writing a book about the food I grow and cook: Sweet Dishes: From My Kitchen to Yours. As a child, my mom taught me everything she knew about cooking – that it's about using the right spices, the cooking time and temperature, the amount of sugar needed for just the right sweetness. When I was in college, when I worked in restaurants like Chez Panisse and the Spotted Pig, I learned everything – that it's about knowing your food, taking good care of your vegetables, that we all deserve to eat our best dish whenever we are having a party for Thanksgiving or some other big occasion. But most importantly, I learned what I should be doing in order to cook and eat food I love to my fullest and enjoy every bite that comes from my kitchen. Today, I'm going to share my tips and tricks for cooking with my hands. 1. Make your chopping board and knife sharp… …and get good at cutting and eating food A simple rule that I think can make a huge difference is using an equally sharp knife to cut your vegetables, while using a different knife to chop your food. When it comes to chopping, it doesn't matter if you have used your food knife on a vegetable before or if you bought a new one (that's what I did) – it doesn't do any good for your knife if your knife isn't sharp. Once you feel comfortable with your food knives, practice by chopping some vegetables with them. It's not rocket science… just keep learning. If you can't find sharp food knives, at least get yourself a cutting board that has nice sharp edges. It will also help you cut vegetables safely with them and will help you learn where your food knives and chopping board are on the chopping board. 2. Keep your food clean I'm a huge believer that food should be properly stored. You're not just saving a few minutes here and there, by placing all your kitchen trash where it can be easily retrieved; you're not only throwing away food that's not coming out right, you're also throwing out a lot of food that could have gone to good use. The kitchen is a very busy place and we usually have to clean out our sink every week or so. When we don't, it ends up overflowing with food. Also, as the weather gets warmer, it's not uncommon to see food going bad in a few days, even if you bought fresh produce. It's not that it makes any sense to keep rotten food in your refrigerator and freeze it instead, but I really like seeing how the food looks before it disappears forever. It makes me feel a bit better about what I put in my body! That is a promise! 3. Get a good cutting board I love my Bosch Classic Bento Board because it has a cutting surface of soft wood pieces and a metal tray. It comes with a great cutting surface… especially if you're going to use your kitchen knives. As with my other boards, don't be shy to ask for a high-quality board if you see one that's not right for your budget. You may just get lucky one day that you see a board that's really high quality! 4. Use disposable containers It's very simple. If I eat out at home and the ingredients I buy that contain a lot of ingredients that take longer to wash before I use them are all glass, i.e. pots and pans, glass containers, or disposable containers, I don't want to be doing the math when deciding which glass container to use to fill my glass cup, or how many dishes I use in one trip. For the same reason, if I'm going to prepare a variety of dishes and use a glass container that might not even be broken or dirty, I don't want to be wondering which container will work the best to clean my pots, pans, or glasses. If the ingredient is glass, I'm okay using non-glazed ceramic plates, even if they are slightly stained or scratched. I don't care. 5. Use utensils and knives that are pre-cut to the perfect size I'm really serious about this one. My old favorite, the 1.5-inch wide (or larger) chopsticks from the grocery store, will keep for years and years. And I'll use them. But if I'm going to prepare a dish with a lot of ingredients that have a tendency to break when handled (think fresh vegetables or fresh seafood), I don't want to be struggling with tiny chopsticks all

A few things I did when playing with the new release I wanted to test my new release on a few things. I wanted to see how it worked to load and save files as an admin (i.e. a user/group that has write access to the server and is able to create files) and I wanted to see how it worked to create a new user/group at the same time, i.e. a user/group that does not have write access to the server and can only create files. So I created three separate environments:  test-domain (the machine with Ubuntu, the installation files and everything else I needed was on the machine) (the machine with Ubuntu, the installation files and everything else I needed was on the machine) test-user (the user with write rights to and the server) (the user with write rights to and the server) test-machine (an empty, empty VM, I just made one folder with the configuration files and started working with the setup package)  As a user I went to the local machine (test-machine): 1. I typed: sudo apt-get update 2. I pressed enter 3. I tried to start the Ubuntu server from the server command line sudo service ubuntu start Nothing happened.  4. I pressed ENTER and rebooted the server (or did something similar) Note. That was on the machine with the installation files and everything else I needed was in it. On the test-user server I had only the server configuration file. No installation files and the files that allow me to start the server at boot. Now I wanted to use the new release and test it to see how it worked. I started up the test-domain machine (with the Ubuntu server at boot, not the test-user one) and did sudo service test-server start but the server failed to start.  I tried to start the test-domain server again. This time with: sudo service test-domain start and it was started. I started another virtual machine (on test-server), typed the install command for the user/group creation and got "could not get the user/group id for this user" at boot. I did sudo useradd --home-dir /var/lib/nginx/www/home/test-domain --exclude http://localhost  This created the user/group test-user and I was able to create a user/group at the same time.  For a while I continued with my test-user experiment and it all worked fine. I got everything I needed and installed my application. After a while I found a problem and after some investigation found out that the problem is this: My installation files are on the test-domain system (I just made one folder with the contents) and my installation is set up for single user in a non standard install.  So my application is not installed properly. It doesn't work for a user with local access to the server and needs to be installed in the other way around.  I'm using this environment for this very reason:  I want to be able to test the new release locally, without needing to go to the Ubuntu server and download everything. The only thing that needed to be changed was the configuration files (in the package files folder) and the location of the server configuration.  But then a few days ago I did sudo service nginx start and the new release just stopped working (for me). So I did sudo service nginx stop  and the new release stopped working too (for me). I'm not the first person to have problems with this new release.  My advice is: If you are using the server configuration file (the one with the /etc/nginx/conf.d/nginx.conf file) try to use the test-domains server, create user/group accounts and have them installed that way. and have them installed that way. If you just have to install the application for some single user do that too but have it installed on the test-domain system.  The reason the installation files are not used by the test-domain server is it is so you can install the latest versions without having to download the install script for every new release release.

In an interview with The Boston Globe, Senator Ted Cruz (R-TX) defended his stance on marriage equality with one clear message: "I believe in traditional marriage … as an orthodox Christian." "I truly think marriage is defined in the Bible, it's defined in the Book of Genesis as between one man and one woman," he noted. "Marriage is defined in the New Testament in Matthew 19:4, 'You shall love the sister as yourself.' The New Testament is full of Scripture that talks about loving people, supporting them, defending them and loving one another, and I think there's nothing in that passage of Scripture that calls for the recognition of gays and lesbians." The Bible does refer to one man and one woman being in wedlock, Cruz asserted. "In New Testament times and throughout the New Testament, Jesus teaches love for those who don't have a certain faith, whether that faith is Jewish, whether it is Gentiles, whether it's atheists, whether it's others," he added. "The point is, I do not believe this is inconsistent with orthodox Christian teaching." Cruz also cited his Christian faith as being what led him into politics and he explained why he did not believe gay marriage was a threat to traditional marriage. Cruz's comments come just a day after his running mate Mike Pence said he believes same-sex couples should have the same marriage rights as heterosexual families.

The number of homeless people sleeping rough in the UK has risen to its highest level for 11 years amid continued cuts to council budgets, a leading homelessness charity has warned. The National Alliance to End Homelessness (NAEH) said it was concerned by a trend towards increasing numbers of single adults with no children staying overnight in their homes. The charity said the rise in rough sleepers - who often have mental health, or other problems - was being made worse, in part, by cuts to local council budgets and a long-running national crisis over low levels of affordable accommodation. The Naeh said it was concerned that more and more people were finding themselves living in their own homes and having to live on a "very low income" as a result of the current economic climate. "The cuts to council tax benefit and housing benefit that has taken place have had an impact on the amount of income that comes from council tax, which makes people even more reluctant to move out of their home once the freeze or cut ends," said Naeh housing spokesman Kevin Stewart. Mr Stewart said some of the "dreadful" experiences he knew of "could not have ever happened under the last government". In the past three months, for example, a father who had been out of work for 12 years was sleeping rough for the first time in his life. "This could never have happened under the last government. It's a completely different picture now," he said. "There's clearly more people than at the height of the last recession; it's a very worrying one for people who were at the end of their tether in terms of money." He said the problem was not solved by housing benefit and council tax benefit cuts, saying that more could be done to increase the number of homeless people living independently in their own properties rather than in temporary accommodation. The issue is causing major consternation among the government, with Prime Minister David Cameron facing increasing pressure to tackle the issue. The latest government consultation on reforming homelessness - which resulted in "treaty" proposals before the May election - has resulted in a raft of reforms aimed at helping people avoid homelessness.
