A lot of people who are not familiar with JVM internals still seem to think that the JVM just runs its own Java process with an interpreter. This is not the case. Although the JVM is the first application, it is certainly not the last. What you have in this article are a few of the last applications to run on the JVM. In my opinion, what you find here are the last of the few "good old days". These applications are not perfect, but they demonstrate the evolution of Java applications over time, and they show the development methodology that is used in the JVMs today. This methodology is not new, but it has changed a lot. In the next sections, I'll have a look at a few of the last programs running on the JVM. The first section will focus on some of the most advanced JVMs of the time—the J2SE ones (e.g. Sun and Oracle products). The following articles will focus on the development methodology used in the early years of the Java language itself, e.g. the early JetBrains products. In every article of this series, I'll try to explain the background behind the application, and hopefully, even convince the reader, if necessary, to give a look into the source code. The last Java programming applications In the first part of this series, we explored the evolution of the Java ecosystem and how it is used today. I'm gonna tell you a lot of stories, starting from the very beginning, and then, through the whole Java development lifecycle: writing the code, testing it, making bugs fixed, optimizing the code, deploying it. It is definitely more challenging to do so, and it has many more details, but the purpose is the same. It is all a part of the continuous process of improvement in Java. J2SE first, then Java SE The history of the Java virtual machine is, however, a bit more complicated. When the first programming languages such as FORTRAN and COBOL were developed, the notion of an "executable file" had not been introduced yet. Java, by the way, was originally named "Coc" (Cobwebs) and was written as a language for the operating system Cobol in the 60s. Later, in the early 70s, the company who would go on to develop the Java world-wide, Sun Microsystems (later Oracle, and now Oracle Corporation), called their new language "Java". So we have the two versions of the JVM, JVM 1 and JVM 2, both in the "public domain". Both versions were designed not only to run the JCL-based programming languages, but also a few other types of programs, such as shell scripts, graphics editors and other applications used for general purpose programming. There were two major issues with these implementations: firstly, they were hard to compile and run on modern CPUs. And secondly, they were big and bulky—over 200 kilobytes (KB) for JVM 1, and over 400 KB for that of 2. The problem was that the new JVM versions were huge (in all implementations, around 4,000 KB). This made it hard (if not impossible) to move them into smaller, faster and/or cheaper CPUs. Because it had to be able to run any number of smaller applications, and because most of these applications had only been run once, the JVM 2 had to be really small. It had to compress everything, and also compress the source code. However, even though there are some smaller JVM implementations, they are very old—in the first two years of its existence, it was used only by the Java virtual machine, and most of the implementations are no longer supported by Oracle. Because of these issues, the JVM's development was a challenge. It took a long time and a lot of effort for the JVM to be able to run more and more types of applications. And even now, many of these applications still run on top of the JVM—but very, very slowly. For example, Java applications today will run a lot slower because most of them will require the presence of the JVM to execute and compile them. However, there are some applications today that are compiled directly into the JVM. These might be some of the most interesting programs in the Java world, or it might be some of the most useless programs ever. There are a few things that I think are worth telling you about the JVM from the beginning. Some of them are well and obvious, while others might not be immediately apparent. Let's start with the obvious one: The JVM is really really slow! Yes. And by "really really" I don't mean that it runs at maximum clock-rate. The JVM is really really slow. Really. Slow. This is really big. This is only what you get

Rafael dos Anjos is still training, but is not close to a return. The Brazilian lightweight champion was scheduled to make the long flight up to Orlando from his native Brazil but was forced to cancel due to the Hurricane Irma. Dos Anjos is expected to make his return in early December once the conditions die down a bit and be in the clear from his injury but still wants the UFC to get him back on a date. Dos Anjos told Sportradar he will meet with USADA and look to fight in December. "The most important thing is to be 100 percent healthy now and prepare for a big fight on December 4, 6 and 8 in Las Vegas," dos Anjos said. He admitted that he hadn't spoken to anyone in the UFC regarding an immediate return. "In January I will have another round for the fight that's on next year and I'll meet with [UFC president] Dana White directly. Maybe in the beginning of next year." In his absence, UFC welterweight Nate Diaz has taken over against Eddie Alvarez and in his first fight against Nate Diaz he got the best of the champion and put the former champion on the shelf. Diaz-Alvarez 2 was not a great fight to begin with but Alvarez did a good job against Diaz and has come home with both belt and the interim lightweight title of the division. Alvarez believes dos Anjos would be a big threat to his belt and is confident dos Anjos would take him down and beat him in the ground. Dos Anjos has said he isn't concerned about a return from injury and is focused on the December 4 fight with Eddie Alvarez.

[NOTE: I had not done any real analysis on this so I'm basing this on what it says on the T-Mobile site. It's not exactly easy if you want to figure out T-Mobile's subsidy vs. cash value for prepaid.] "We believe in the tremendous value prepaid customers bring to customers. We're going to continue to build strong prepaid business that offers customers a strong value proposition and we're putting all of that in place for the new year," T-Mobile CTO Neville Ray said at the T-Mobile Un-Carrier 10X Summit in Fort Worth, Texas. T-Mobile's prepaid business has been on a good run all year, adding nearly 100,000 new customers each weekend. But with the T-Mobile Un-Carrier 10X initiative getting rolling, T-Mobile is moving to a prepaid model. The new model is known as Value Plan. Here's how it works: "You pay $30 / month for a phone and use it on our Prepaid Plan," Ray said. "Once you have 100 minutes, you'll get it back by paying 30 minutes the following month. It's like having your own phone network and unlimited data." What this means is that customers can get a phone for the same price as the high end iPhone, and then turn around and charge them $30 if they want to use it for calling and texting. T-Mobile's prepaid business is now one of the fastest growing consumer smartphone offerings. So this new model is a great way to get customers who usually aren't likely the best customer support out of their phones. It also keeps down the cost of the smartphones. "We're going to give our customers, our prepaid network customers, an option to be able to upgrade their phone in the near-term, and keep their phones on the network and on the bill cycle and also be able to switch phone carriers," Ray said, "and do all that over 30 months at no cost to our subscribers." We have a detailed review of T-Mobile's Prepaid Plans here.

There's just one problem! How to know if you are or are not a "real" Muslim (and not some sort of shirk)? According to the shari'ah, you've got some big questions to answer: "Do you consider yourself a Muslim?" The answer depends on your beliefs, and there are three kinds of Muslims in the world, one of which is "true" (tasawwuf), the second is "believed" (istahaad), and the last is a "fake" (kafir). Of these three, only the genuine ones are real Muslims in the eyes of the shari'ah. Is one of the three types genuine, and thus a Muslim? No, that's just "kufr" (unbelief). The first type: "I am a Muslim." Or, if you're a muslim, you're a "true" one and therefore a "true Muslim." And there's really no difference between true and true. The second type: "I'm a Muslim, but not at all. Some people call me a fake Muslim (kafir)." That's just "in order to justify his sinful conduct." The third kind: "I'm a Muslim, but in the form or shape of a shaheed." This is called (takfir), "the perversion (zahir and shirk)" of the Prophet (peace be upon him)." So…who will you be in the eyes of the shari'ah? As for the second question… I think that the answer depends upon your view of the Qur'an and the Sunnah. If you believe the Qur'an and Sunnah are perfect and perfect and perfect, then you will be a Muslim, as we all should. The problem is, you'll end up being a fake one. The problem for the person who will become a genuine Muslim… The second one is more difficult to understand, because it depends upon whether you believe in the shari'ah. If you do, then you will just be a Muslim of a few other characteristics. If you believe the Qur'an (and its narrators) are perfect, there is little difference between a real and a "fake" one. And since the Qur'an is the final authority in all matters and it is the best of guidance for all people, it is legitimate for you to believe and act upon it. But, if you think the Qur'an is imperfect and therefore can be flawed, then you think you'll also be a "fake" Muslim. Therefore, your view of the Qur'an will determine whether you are or are not a genuine Muslim. But there's a difference. So why can't we just follow what we believe in? We can see from the Qur'an that the Qur'an is based upon knowledge of the Qur'an! So if you know from the Qur'an that you should be a real Muslim… and it's based upon knowledge and you know from the Qur'an the "real" version, then that's going to have no difference from you being a fake Muslim. But why can't we just follow what is "observed" in the Qur'an or from the Sunnah, and ignore what we believe in? Because what we believe in matters, and that's what makes up our religion that we call shari'ah (that's what the word shari'ah means — meaning the law), and shari'ah makes up the core belief of true Islam. And the core belief is a core belief about the religion based on an actual, verifiable, authentic source (the Qur'an and Sunnah, for example): We say: There is no god but Allah and Mohammed is the messenger of Allah. The Sunnah is the life of the Prophet. It is the "proof" of the faith (tafsir). As such, we must believe in it, and must take it as the absolute word of Allah, and all "revelations" from it. The core belief in the Prophet (peace be upon him) and his religion is the truth regarding Allah, so it is the core belief of true Islam. What other belief can we bring into it that is not "observed"? The reason we have the "official" or "official" interpretation (i.e. the "most correct" one) of the Qur'an is as such: It was revealed to the Prophet by God… so it should be taken as the Word of God and not "observed" as it is. This is why it is taken "as is" with no attempt to alter the message in any way whatsoever, and

For an overview of plasma rifle models in all games, see plasma rifle. The plasma pistol is a weapon in Fallout 3. Contents show] Background Edit A variation of the plasma rifle, its plasma energy is a potent weapon. It is typically only used against robots, but has been used as a defensive measure against radscorpions, ghouls, mutated brutes, super mutants and super mutant brutes.[1] Characteristics Edit The plasma pistol possesses the same effects as the plasma rifle, except that the plasma has a slower rate of fire and deals half as much damage. However, its lack of recoil and the more efficient ammo it uses allows for a much longer effective range. Like the plasma rifle, plasma pistols are relatively lightweight, especially at higher levels, making the pistol a viable long-range weapon, though still less than the rifle. The U.S. government will pay $12.9 million to settle a lawsuit brought by the owners of a Washington, D.C.-area yoga studio that accused agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation of conspiring to extort them with false accusations of criminal activity. Yoga Studio, in Reston, Virginia, has a "No-Nose Policy." This means that customers must wear their own noses to join the studio for class. The studio's attorney, Paul Kedrosky, said his client was subjected to FBI harassment during its litigation. "The FBI targeted and intimidated my client," Kedrosky said. FBI spokeswoman Laura Eimiller said the agency is prohibited from discussing specifics of ongoing investigations. But she said the bureau is "actively working" with its law enforcement partners in seeking ways to encourage "responsible business conduct." The investigation into Yoga Studio was not the only one brought by federal authorities against a yoga studio in the Northern Virginia area. Last spring, a similar lawsuit was brought against a studio in Sterling in Loudoun County. In that case, a judge dismissed all counts, according to the American Civil Liberties Union, which represented the Sterling studio. Federal authorities have pursued a number of business practices related to yoga and spiritual groups in the past decade, as well as investigations into alleged criminal activities by spiritual groups and individuals at yoga studios. A 2010 Department of Interior report on religious liberty, which focused specifically on religious and spiritual organizations, was the first government study of the practices of yogis, or as they are called, namaskar, since the 1990s. The report noted that the practice had been "abruptly and negatively impacted" by the practice of yoga poses known as ashtanga and vinyasa, particularly the use of these practices by yoga studios. The report called the practice "dangerously invasive" to the body and called for stricter enforcement of restrictions on yoga studio permits and "special regulations" for such companies for the purpose of protecting against "violations of federal or state law." The report noted that in Washington, D.C., the "use of yoga poses by yogis" and "the teaching of yoga to minors" require permit application and approval by law enforcement, "which creates a barrier to the practice among a very small number of individuals who should be able to practice and obtain permits." The Interior Department report's recommendations to law enforcement in the District of Columbia and Prince William County, Virginia, were to "prohibit all criminal activity and criminal activity by yogis," and "not permit any person or business to be or to conduct businesses, activities, or conduct business that is, as to a particular yoga studio, criminal related." A 2007 letter to Yoga Studio owner Alysia Pappas from the U.S. attorney in the Eastern District of Virginia and the FBI's Richmond field office said in part: "Beginning March 22 and continuing through April 4, 2007, and during that specific period of time, your business was the subject of a wide range of investigations in relation to criminal activity, including but not limited to … (Criminal Infiltrating) and wire fraud." In his filing in U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia on Thursday, Kedrosky claimed that his clients were "effectively targeted and harassed" with a variety of tactics. These tactics included, Kedrosky alleged, "harassment, threats, intimidation, violence and physical harm." Kedrosky said the FBI took the investigation into Yoga Studio "very seriously" and "investigated thoroughly." "Based on the evidence and our findings and evidence presented at trial, the government has found that this case was brought out of a desire by the FBI's Virginia field office to protect its operations," Pappas' attorney, Robert O'Neill, said of the settlement. The court filing says that since the April 2006 settlement, Yoga Studio has received no money from the Department of Justice. Pappas' attorney wrote that she agreed to the settlement in order to get back in the yoga business and regain her reputation at the class level. Pappas, who had been certified in yoga and hatha yoga, sued the FBI, the Eastern District of Virginia and the Richmond field office in a federal lawsuit. The Eastern District of Virginia claimed in a motion to dismiss the lawsuit that a "vast amount of evidence" did not support claims involving extortion. It said no evidence supported the conspiracy theory asserted in the complaint: that Yoga Studio's members posed for nude photographs, that customers were extorted to pay for the services of an undercover agent, and that yoga staff were threatened with arrest or prosecution if nude photographs were taken. The U.S. attorney's office in Arlington filed a opposition to the motion to dismiss, stating in part that Yoga Studio's activities and conduct had resulted in "harassment and intimidation of the people who run yoga studios

Rudy Giuliani said on Wednesday that Hillary Clinton and her supporters want to turn the United States into Venezuela. The former New York City mayor made the remark while criticizing the former secretary of state on Fox News's "Fox & Friends." "She needs to realize that [Bernie] Sanders supporters are sick and tired of being told what the rules are, and she needs to give them a few more rules," Giuliani said. "The Sanders campaign, we have a different attitude. Not only am I supporting her against him, she needs to give me rules. She doesn't give them to me, and I don't give them to her." Giuliani added that Clinton "fights hard against socialism" — a reference to Sanders' support for a socialist model to overhaul the country's education system. He added that she didn't understand what social welfare means or why it's important. "The system is failing a lot of Americans," Giuliani said. "And it must be changed because what it is is a big part of American culture and it needs to be changed because you can't make a change without changing what's there."

When the first images of the Samsung Galaxy S8 were released in June 2016, I was eager for the best flagship smartphone I'd ever seen. My interest was not shared by everyone around me, but this was an important phone for Samsung to unveil that marked the beginning of what would become a five-year streak of great smartphones for the company. The Galaxy S8 brought many of the original Galaxy S features to a new generation of smartphone and brought Samsung's own software features to the forefront of the Android phone ecosystem. Since then, the S8 has been a hit, and in this article we're taking a deeper look at the Galaxy S8, including a look at two different batteries and a look at the Samsung Galaxy S8 battery replacement program, which we'll cover in our full review. The Samsung Galaxy S8 is the phone everyone is talking about. What is the Samsung Galaxy S8? What does it do, and how does it compare to its competition? Let's find out. 1. The Galaxy S8 is a big phone To me, the Galaxy S8 is the best phone that Samsung has ever made. If you compare it with the Galaxy S7 Edge, you'll see that its bigger screen size means that there is more content available and better images and video. The size of the device is impressive, and the new Galaxy Note 8 makes some interesting hardware decisions that make this display as bright and vivid as possible. And the Infinity Display with its larger bezels still looks great. But the S8, at 5.8 inches, is also larger than the iPhone 7 Plus, which is 5.5 inches; the Google Pixel XL, which is 5.0; the iPhone 7, which is 4.7; and the LG G6, which is 4.8. I was especially surprised that the S8 is almost as big as Apple's iPhone X, which is 6.8 inches, and that the S8 is just over 12 percent bigger than the Samsung Galaxy Note7. There are two more noticeable differences between the S8 and the newer iPhone X and Note 8. One is curved, curved edges, which makes the glass on the corners much more resistant to breakage, though again, this is only a cosmetic difference. The other is a metal body that feels sturdy and well-made. This metal body is covered in Gorilla Glass 5 that's super resistant to fingerprint smudges. Unlike the glass, the metal is super smooth and feels very comfortable to use. There have been some complaints about scratches, but if you're used to a more durable body, it's not noticeable at all. I also found the S8 to be more comfortable to hold in general. I think the S8 has a better curved touch-screen, which is something I love about the iPhone X but I found disappointing on the previous Pixel phones. The S8's display is also easier to view on one's face, which is great for a person with large eyes and long ears and nose. One thing I did find annoying, though, is the S8's tendency to slide on the smooth, metallic backing of the phone when it's placed on a surface. This seems odd but not actually a problem. The phone feels great on the outside, though. All in all, I love the design of the Samsung Galaxy S8 and I have no doubt that it will appeal to many. This video explains how to use the S8 in a pinch. https://t.co/XRqW3XzNrH pic.twitter.com/QjJY6tXxHc — Stephen Tulloch (@stephentulloch) December 1, 2017 2. All your Galaxy S8 phones will be unlocked and able to work on other carriers The Samsung Galaxy S8 can be used on any carrier, even Sprint. You can buy the unlocked device, so there's no need to buy a Galaxy S9 to use it on Verizon. You simply need to set up the activation and your phone will be on an unlimited data plan. You also won't need a data plan if you sign up for the Samsung Galaxy Prime service. You can pay by month or go all out and pay $20 for the full year of service. That means it will cost you a lot less and you can use your phone whenever you want without being tied to any one plan or plan provider. The Samsung Galaxy S8 has been announced for $769 on contract, but you can get the same smartphone with no contract without paying a monthly fee. The Samsung Galaxy S8 will be on AT&T and T-Mobile for $50 down and $20 per month or $200 down for 24 months. All other carriers except AT&T and T-Mobile will allow you to buy the unlocked device with no contract. You can sign up for unlimited data on all carriers with the Samsung

A group of about 2,000 Muslim women marched this morning in the capital city of Jakarta and held up banners with the slogans "Allah is Great" and "This is our future." The event, which was the first one of its kind in Indonesia and took place at the historic Haji Ali Dang Bugra mosque in the capital's outskirts, was held to commemorate the start of Ramadan, one of the holiest seasons in Muslim tradition. The event also coincided with World Economic Forum, an annual meeting of the world's biggest businesses and governments. "This is not the first time that we've gathered. We've always gathered together and shared stories and issues," said Adi Faria, a 26-year-old Muslim woman and one of the organizers of the event. The women shouted to the crowds gathered in front of the mosque that "if Allah was great, we would be great as well." "The whole world is suffering, and we need to do our best on our own and not rely on anyone, including Islam or the government." The women marched towards the National Palace in front of the prime minister's residence and held up banners reading "Freedom of opinion. Equality for women." A majority of the crowd appeared to be young and the event was attended by a number government officials. Faria also said she felt grateful for the government's support on the issue of women's rights. "I can understand the government's reluctance to have issues related to religion. [But] I believe that Indonesia is stronger because of Islam," she added. Despite the government's support, it was not immediately clear when the march would take place again. Faria said the event was meant to be symbolic and could change nothing in the lives of Muslim women in the country. The Muslim Women's Association (TAPEM) was also invited by the government to host a similar event earlier this week, but organizers refused to participate, according to Reuters. Photo: TAPEM/Facebook

The new generation of mobile devices is the hottest topic right now, but there are still no signs that there is anyone in the market that plans to make a success of the phone market. On the other hand, there exist those who believe that there are several reasons for this situation: they believe that the market is a big "screw loose" that needs "reinforcing" and therefore have a theory that the only way is to sell phones directly to the people. Those of us that are passionate about this idea do not accept these assumptions and instead prefer to propose the following idea: that we might just have a "screw loose" that needs "reinforcement": the mobile market. A phone is a gadget that lets you communicate with your friends around the world, whether in real time, or through the transfer of a video file. No matter how far or how cheap technology gets: it is still your phone that you have with you at all times. It has a screen and a tiny piece of hardware at its heart. As the number of contacts grows by the minute, so the need for an ever-slightly more powerful phone increases. The "courage" part comes from the fact that you cannot sell a phone to others. In the end, you are the only one who has access to the phone you have. In a few short years more and more people with smartphones will come to see their phones as just another gadget – and the same as a personal computer or camera: something that you carry with you, that can be used for doing something or kept in the pocket. And, of course, you will pay for them – which is not much if you consider the time, effort, and trouble that you will find in doing so. And the fact that you may have no way of buying or renting new phones doesn't make the situation better for anyone. On the contrary: that will make the situation much worse. There you have it. The reason why we think that the mobile market needs "reinforcement". In a world dominated by Facebook, there are already a number of new mobile apps that take advantage of the platform. Apps can work on multiple platforms, like smartphones, tablets and desktop computers, and are able to make a profit out of the network effect. However, if you can't actually talk with your friends, get the latest information or share photographs at will, this is a non-starter. With the mobile market only going up, the number of people using apps grows. Eventually this crowd will reach a tipping point, when Facebook starts seeing its first profits. It may be difficult for them to convince their users that they are creating profits, when everyone still has a simple personal computer and a large collection of photos. The next time Facebook needs a new business model – maybe after they buy or merge with some other social app – there will be plenty of users ready to jump on board if the new company has a really impressive new service to offer. Or at least, that will be the case if people aren't able to share anything over the phone anymore. A lot of people will find a new way to stay connected, which is exactly what Facebook has been doing. When mobile users lose their access to the internet, the effect will be much stronger than you know. That is, a lot of people will be disconnected and Facebook will benefit a lot from this. But we cannot be sure that every single one will do the same. For example, there are a lot of parents with kids – they are very likely to find a new way to keep them connected outside of the family. Even though social networks were started for children, a lot of people use them for their parents, to keep in touch or, better, because they are curious and want to learn more about what their kids say in their sleep. Maybe the last few months we have seen how the internet is disappearing from the lives of a lot of people. As a result, a lot of people have started using the internet as a way to learn about new and exciting technologies. That is, if you can still access the internet, you probably are also interested in computers or science in general. The only way of getting a lot of people to stay connected is the only plan that has a chance – if it's not just another one of the Facebook services that offers to you some really good perks to do the same thing over the web. Of course, there are many other apps that, to a lesser degree, compete with Facebook. But they are basically trying to solve a different problem. The main problem that all apps face is the fact that the people that you are talking with are not going to use the internet themselves. It's too slow, they know that their friends, family or colleagues are more productive on their device – and are going to use those devices anyway, so they can't wait to use those services again. So it's clear that the only strategy that will gain traction, is one

Django's template engine, known simply as django.template , provides some handy language constructs for making your template files easier to read, write, and maintain. Among these constructs, we have template inheritance. When a template inherits from a parent template, it adds additional constraints to that parent template, and it also removes some. These features are designed to make your template programs faster and easier to maintain. We use the concept of inheritance because template inheritance is a very powerful way to make templates more efficient and readable at the same time. Let's say a template for a list of customers has all possible values, and the following line is added: print_list(view) Since this template has the full set of available choices, it can be simplified into a single line of code to generate HTML: def print_list(view): print "#{view.name}: #{view.list.size}" print ' ' print view.viewname You can view this template by using the following URL in your browser: It's possible for all of the template files in these views to inherit the attributes of the parent views, meaning that each of this views' nested templates can use an array-based syntax to override the attributes of one of the parent templates. In this case, it would look something like this: from template.view import show_list from myapp.models import Customer from template.list import print_list # All print_list templates in the template hierarchy will inherit a template_name # attribute, which contains the name of the view inherited from # template parents . The default value for # this attribute is " myapp/customers/list.html#my-list-view " print_list( show_list ( view = show_list )) A more complex example, showing three levels of inheritance, is shown below: # Each new template inherits an additional template_name attribute to its parent # template. # The default value for this attribute is " myapp/customers/list.html#my-list " class CustomerList ( TemplateList ): model = Customer def show ( self , * args , ** kwargs ): print '

Customer: #{self.model.name}

' print view . viewname Note that while template inheritance is very powerful and handy, it also has a downside. Because template inheritance does not hide the template hierarchy, the fact that a template inherits from parent templates means that any templates that have already been generated can no longer be displayed by those views; if you want to display a view that already generated a template, you must render it with a different name . You may also find that this is a problem if you want to include a view that is part of a nested directory into your site. Templates can also use regular expressions in their file names, so that they can match the names of parent templates. To demonstrate this, the following view is included in the template hierarchy of the app: from template.view import show_list from myapp.models import Customer from template.list import print_list # All print_list templates in the template hierarchy will inherit # a template_name attribute, which contains the name of the template # inherited from template parents . The default value for this # attribute is " myapp/customers/list.html#my-list-view " print_list( show_list ( " #{customer.name} " )) # A nested template with a template name of "customer_list.html#customer_list-list" is allowed # because it inherits from "customer_list.html#customer_list". print_list( ' #{parent.name} ' ) # You can't include a nested template in a list view as it inherits # from nested-list , which doesn't include the nested template name. print_list( show_list ( nested_list . viewname )) If template inheritance were applied to the above example, show_list would be able to print the name of the customer because the show_list template inherits from template parents / nested_list . This is an example of the limitations of inheritance: as of Django 1.7, only attributes will be inherited from parent templates, not methods on them. If you want to get some more control over how template inheritance works, you can use the template_has_attribute and template_has_method methods. Both of these methods return True , indicating that either parent.has_method(X) or template.has_attribute(X) is present in the parent template. template_has_method works the same way as template inheritance, but it checks the parent template for a has_method method and returns True if one is present. template_has_attribute is a similar utility that also checks the parent for an

Image caption The BBC's Panorama programme revealed claims of abuse and exploitation in Rotherham The BBC is to give a further $55m (£38m) to fund its investigation into child sexual exploitation in Rotherham, the broadcaster has announced. The amount of the investment and what it will be spent on will not be announced until later, but it is understood the money will be spent to fund additional staff. The money will not go towards the £90m Rotherham abuse and trafficking scandal. It will instead be spent on programmes and initiatives to tackle child sexual exploitation, including children's voices. The BBC's Panorama programme last month exposed allegations of widespread abuse in the city. The programme accused the town's children's services of turning a blind eye to "the scale and nature of serious abuse". 'Tackling and understanding' Image copyright PA The BBC's Panorama programme revealed the scale of abuse in Rotherham Earlier the BBC said it would not be pursuing other legal action, but it said it would "work with the Attorney General and our editorial processes to address any future issues raised relating to the way in which the BBC handled the Rotherham abuse stories". This followed a request from the Home Office for the BBC to "co-operate fully" with their investigation. BBC Director-general Tony Hall told MPs the broadcaster had to "acknowledge that when it comes to dealing with any issue like this the risk of any story is the story itself can be damaging to a corporation's reputation". He announced the funding would also be used to "tackle and understand, both in-house and with outside experts", the complex nature of child sexual exploitation across the UK, and to fund the creation of a new project. The new project, which could be launched later this year, could be renamed "A Child, A Child." The new money will also be used in the future to pay for "all necessary legal costs", but Mr Hall said that funding is not a requirement for this purpose. The BBC's announcement comes amid a new police inquiry into child sexual exploitation by Asian gangs, and a "national conversation" around how public bodies and organisations protect children.

From the looks of it, it's been a long, busy year for the National League MVP race. Just days after Miguel Cabrera won the award, it's been Jose Altuve's turn to go head-to-head with Aaron Judge. The Detroit Tigers first baseman, who is up for the Silver Slugger award, is going up against the New York Yankees' right fielder. The two are off to an inauspicious start. Ahead in the voting is Judge, who is leading the MVP race at 42.3 percent compared to Altuve's 23.1. Judge has led in each of the first 10 races, with several of the voters choosing Judge in just their first ballots. He also has led in every year in the first 10 races. Altuve also leads at 43.6 percent, while teammate George Springer is second at 23.2. It's the first time in history an MVP has been chosen in his first ballot. The biggest story, however, is that Altuve has already been named an All-Star starter at the third time that he's pitched since his arrival in Houston the season before. He is pitching in his second All-Star Game and this time, he is slated to take the mound as the team's third starter. "It's just a great honor to pitch in an All-Star Game again, especially from your teammates, especially the fans," Altuve said as he warmed up before Friday's game. "To be the starter, I'm very grateful and I love it." Other players to start an All-Star Game before Altuve are Roger Clemens (2000), Paul Molitor (2001), Dennis Martinez (1999) and Roy Halladay (2012). This is the eighth All-Star appearance for the 23-year-old Altuve, who will be making his 15th career start at Wrigley Field Sunday. Overall, Altuve has started for the Astros in 10 games, including four this season. "As a young player, I've watched a few and they seem to grow on you. One thing about Jose is he's always ready for any challenge," Astros manager A.J. Hinch said. "I'm sure he thinks that about this, too, I'm sure he thinks the MVP for me is a real possibility. I have a lot of confidence in this kid, even for the first time to an All-Star Game." Hinch did say he's a little worried about a possible injury in his starting lineup, which is set to be trimmed to 24 from the 25 starting spots. "Just think about it this season when you've got [James] Shields out there and [Michael] Pineda. I'm a little worried we might have a little problem there, even without Altuve. That's the thing with our starting rotation we've got a pretty deep group," Hinch said. "You know, I'm kind of a conservative kind of guy, but if we can have everybody available, it would be nice." Cabrera will be honored at the All-Star celebration in Cincinnati, Ohio. He will wear the Venezuelan national team jersey he wore when he earned the 2012 World Series MVP. With the Astros, Cabrera has been a two-time Silver Slugger winner (2015, 2016), four-time All-Star (2010-15), seven-time Gold Glove winner (2009-2013), seven-time Silver Slugger (2006-09) and six-time All-Star.

Trouble in the family? You are, to some, the devil. Or, at least, you're one of Satan's chosen. In The Curse Of St. Anne, William Golding, whose novels (The Lord Of The Rings, Jeeves and Wooster, etc.) informed our childhood's imagination, describes some of the worst of this trope – or at least is probably responsible for it. Advertisement "Many of them had the most violent and wicked character of all the English," Golding writes, apparently trying to make a distinction between "good" and "evil" here. "We are to assume that there is no other sort of English except the 'bad English'… But perhaps they are good, for the people are happy." Golding then goes on to describe some of those individuals with some real violence – which, obviously, is what evil has been all about throughout human history. I suppose it's possible to read Golding's book as a sort of fantasy novel, but it also seems to me it's just a lot of stuff about a lot of very bad people, and they are, as we have come to expect from Golding, very angry people. (They are also quite bloody.) It would be great to say that this is a novel of redemption – after all, the book opens in an almost apocalyptic way, with a "great catastrophe" and a "war of Armageddon" – and that Golding's main concern throughout the entire thing is to make his characters more sympathetic, but I honestly doubt that's what he was getting at. I think he was basically just trying to get some perspective about the nature of violence and evil, and what can be done to stop it. "We are taught what is evil and what is good in the schools," Golding writes near the end, "but we do not learn what is evil…" Advertisement I do wonder though, if it's possible in our world, with today's technology and knowledge, that some of these things could be different than they have been in the past. I wonder what would have happened had someone not decided that "killing and lying" was more important than "humanity and tolerance"? I wonder if people would be more willing to forgive if people understood why they felt the way they did. I wonder if our understanding would grow if, when a young woman kills her husband, she says, after the fact, "Maybe I wasn't strong enough," or if a doctor says that when he sees a patient "there are some things we just have to put behind us" – if, say, we were more willing to listen and to forgive our friends and loved ones for their mistakes than just to blame them. It seems like a pretty obvious thing to say in 2015, but I bet it's an alien concept to people in 1600 or 1800. Advertisement [via The Guardian] Via Boing Boing.

Roughly half of Americans do not feel safe at work or with friends; 43% report being fearful of "violent or serious crime." The survey by the American National Election Studies found that 61% of adults have suffered some type of mental health problem, and half report that they know someone else that feels they have suffered from a mental illness. In America today, if people cannot access mental health care, then many will not access the medical treatment they need until they are in a worse state of mental health for themselves than they were when they were first diagnosed. Because of this, it has become increasingly important within the medical field to develop solutions that can help people who have mental health problems access appropriate and effective care. The Affordable Care Act (ACA) addresses this problem by establishing new guidelines for the care of people with mental health problems. However, these guidelines are not designed to address the full spectrum of the treatment that people with mental health problems require in order for them to get and remain well. Therefore, the goal of the National Service to Prevent Suicide project is to create a set of guidelines that will help physicians and health care systems create more appropriate care. The project is being led by the National Research Council, a private, nonprofit, and nonpartisan body that advises the US government on matters of government policy and scientific research. The project is the result of a partnership between the American National University and the Harvard Medical School. This project offers several unique resources to researchers interested in exploring the relationship between mental health and work and social support, and how these issues influence health behavior. Project website: www.nsppsych.org  Project Summary: The National Service to Prevent Suicide (National Suicide Prevention Lifeline) provides the following resources to help individuals experiencing depression, anger, hopelessness, thoughts of suicide, or suicidal ideation: National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-TALK (8255) National Suicide Prevention Lifeline is a toll-free national phone and text service that offers immediate crisis intervention and crisis counseling to anyone 18 years or older who may be feeling suicidal, feels trapped by an immediate crisis situation, fears a suicide attempt, or is concerned for friends or family. The Lifeline was established to enhance the quality of life for individuals throughout the United States and is especially designed to connect people in need with local mental health care. The Depression, Anxiety, and Suicide (DAS) Study: DAS is a longitudinal study of the impact of the national Depression, Anxiety, and Suicide (DAS) Study on suicidal ideation, depression, functioning, and health outcomes among Americans aged 18–24. DAS is conducted by the National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS). More information at http://www.cdc.gov/nchs/das/index.html  The National Study of Youth Risk Behavior (NSYRB): NSYRB provides comprehensive national data on youths' risk behaviors with the goal of decreasing risk in communities and preventing future suicide. NSYRB collects this data through in-depth interviews with school-aged youth by trained peer-researchers to identify risk factors—including family environments (including whether parents or other relatives view, treat, or support teens), the physical environment of a community (e.g., the presence of playgrounds and schools) and neighborhood conditions (e.g., the presence of gangs, gangs as neighbors and neighbors, the presence of gangs near or in school and neighborhoods, and peer-rated risk behaviors)—as well as their individual outcomes, specifically their suicidal ideation, feelings of hopelessness, and suicide attempts. All participants who had had a suicide attempt in the past or in the last 60 days are included in the NSYRB study. More information at http://www.hhs.gov/ocr/pdf/nsyrb.pdf

Praise be to Allaah. In fiqh some scholars are of the view that one should say "there is no taharah for the one who does what is haraam, even though there are many blessings of Allaah on whoever does that. Shaykh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyah (may Allaah have mercy on him) said: There is no blame on anyone who does a wrong action, and there is no harm on that person when he repents. Rather, the one who repents may see a blessing on himself after repenting. End quote from Irwa' al-Mufrad (2/285) and Tuhfat al-Akhlaar (5/286). He (may Allaah have mercy on him) also said: This was confirmed by al-Haafiz Ibn Hajar who said in Kitab al-Maghazi (4/185): the Messenger of Allaah (peace and blessings of Allaah be upon him) said: "The person who repents (after doing something that is a sin) will see the fruits of that in his life, and he will be blessed with that (good) fortune."[i] There is a difference in views whether the one who repents of this action will see a blessing therefrom or not, and this must be investigated for fiqh, because some of the scholars are of the view that it is not appropriate for the one who repents to say "There is no taharah" when he repents of it, because this is a concession and an excuse offered by the one who repents, and no such thing is possible, except that he will not go astray from the right path or be defeated. And we know the Shaytaan can be defeated with him, and in most cases he knows well what to do. Thus if he repents of it, then his path will certainly be straightened, and he will be shielded from the evils that come upon him. But if he is defeated, he will have to face the trials that come to people who sin. This point is confirmed in Saheeh Muslim (4/637) and it was also revealed in Saheeh Muslim (5/5536) and in Saheeh Muslim (5/6525) regarding the person who sinned, in both of which the person who repents was warned, and so that person did not go astray, and there is no sin on that person. This is also the view of Abu Haneefah (may Allaah have mercy on him) in his Sunan, in which he says: The one who repents after doing an action that is a sin, will not go astray, while if there is a sin and he does not repent (of it), it means that he has transgressed, but if he does not do what is wrong, then this is not a sin. End quote from Tareekh Al-Khateeb Fataawa 'ala al-Fiqhiyyah (30/7). The one who repents of the wrong action is not to be blamed or shamed after his repentance is complete. Shaykh Ibn 'Uthaymeen (may Allaah have mercy on him) was asked: 1) I have heard that the one who repents is not to be blamed or shamed after his repentance by others, or by the one who says to him: "Shame upon you. Repent! It was good news to you." Is it permissible to say to him that what he has done was a serious sin by itself and that he should repent until it is forgotten and he will not do it again, but not do anything wrong after he has done the wrong but not before? 2) I have also heard that the one who repents of the wrong action is not to be blamed or shamed after his repentance, or when he says: "This is a very serious matter. Repent!" Is it permissible to say to him that whatever he has done was a sin by itself, until it is forgotten and he no longer does it? Forbid: What he repents of will be forgotten and the evil done by him will be forgotten because Allaah will not keep what is done until it is forgotten, but the sin will remain from the one who did that action to the one who repents of doing it. Allaah has put it in His Book to seek forgiveness of Allaah, and we hope for His forgiveness. You should pray on behalf of one who repents in order to seek forgiveness for him, because this is a noble deed. And Allah knows best.

By By Paul Iddon Jun 5, 2013 in Environment A Chinese fisherman rescued a group of four humpback whales that washed ashore in the eastern province of Zhejiang. According to local reports, more than 700 whales were discovered stranded in Zhejiang's Xishuangbanna city just last month. The rescued animals had been spotted in the waters off of a man-made island that apparently was being put to use as a sea wall. When the whales were found, the fishing boat driver of the group attempted to get them on board, but was also reportedly grabbed. Local reports said the fisherman was forced to swim to shore after the whales grabbed him. Local media said that some locals then caught up to the fisherman and asked him to come down from the island, but the fisherman reportedly became belligerent and refused. The boat also reportedly lost control and capsized. The fishermen then managed to swim to shore and were eventually retrieved by a local police station which is said to have taken action quickly. Local media reports stated that the rescue operation took about an hour while the whales remained on shore. The local fishing vessels were reportedly also alerted and arrived at the scene to offer help. The rescued animals were then taken aboard for rehabilitation. According to The whale found this weekend in the waters around a Chinese island had to be taken by boat because it swam on land, it has been claimed.According to Zheng Jiulin, an official at the Zhejiang Conservation and Research Center, more than 700 whales were found stranded in Zhejiang's Xishuangbanna city just last month.The rescued animals had been spotted in the waters off of a man-made island that apparently was being put to use as a sea wall. When the whales were found, the fishing boat driver of the group attempted to get them on board, but was also reportedly grabbed.Local reports said that the fisherman was forced to swim to shore after the whales grabbed him.Local media said that the rescue operation took about an hour while the whales remained on shore.The local fishing vessels were reportedly also alerted and arrived at the scene to offer help.The rescued animals were then taken aboard for rehabilitation. I want to play a game with you, I want to play our game, I want you and I alone to choose what happens next, to decide if and how it is you will live again. You have the power.  The only thing that will stop you is you.  Choose the game. Your choices and actions will alter the game.  Choose your path. The path you take matters As does your future, so do your choices and actions.  Choose your path and the world will change.  Choose your path and the game is ours to play. ...And the one to play?  I just realized I need more words!  No. I am afraid that the words are all the world can provide. I want you to stop. I love you, but not this way. I want you to think of a way to bring us together.  We've been looking for a way back together and we've found it...  The game is now open. We are not yet ready to play, still. A few things I want to clear up:  This is my first game. This is the first game that I have ever made, and that I think I should ever make. I'm an artist. This game is not for everyone. I make videogames, and they are designed for a few things: fun, fast, and often very dirty. This game is designed for those people.  I want to use whatever artistic talent I have, to make this game as fun and exciting as I can. My games are not, by nature, perfect, so I expect ours to be, too. As in reality.  A few other things:  I am an atheist. I am a fan of science fiction, horror, and other things that can be thought of as the dark side of everything. I'm not much of a painter. I have no desire to be a rock star. I'm currently trying to live and work full time so I can finish this game. We're an indie game development collective. I am not paid for this game. I am being paid for it. And finally... the title of this game is "I will live through your choices." Yes. Your choices. I will live through them.

CAMERA ARSENAL: There are no questions that the world is changing. It's certainly true that there's less of it. But the world is changing. It is changing at a far more rapid rate — about ten to twenty-times as fast at a minimum — than was generally imagined in the 18thcentury. So if we're really going to be ready for all of the stuff we know we're going to be facing in the far future, it's going to take a lot more than a new generation of rockets. We don't need, nor do we have, the technological expertise for a return to the rockets of the 1960s. And even if we could launch them all again they would need to be much bigger than the first ones, with many more times the capacity. So how do we get the world ready for it — which is to say, for all of the stuff that's not like the rockets of the 1960s. And I think we're about ready for it. Here's what I think the world needs to do: 1) It needs to have more and better computers, on every continent. The Internet now reaches around the globe, with most nations now having computers of some variety. The question then is: to what extent will the Internet and the computers that power it grow at the same rate. And the answer to that question is: very likely at a rate that far surpasses our projections. A single computer today makes far more information available than all the computers ever made in the history of the world. How will you get everybody using the Internet with less than half a per cent of the world's computers, computers of the kind that we're talking about? You can't. The question at this point ought to be: what will be the effect of this rapid doubling of the availability of our most important information technology? It will be a truly revolutionary effect, and will change the world in profound ways in ways that few of us have ever imagined. 2) It needs to have computers able to learn. This is a bit of a surprise. After all, the first computers were made to program themselves. A lot of people thought I was going through puberty when I started with computers. But I've always thought that you learn by doing. If I were a good programmer I wouldn't be here. If I were a good musician I wouldn't be playing the piano, I'd be teaching. If I could write good software code, not that anybody understands programming, but if I could write good software code for other people to write, I think that would be enough to get by. I've discovered since then that actually learning computer programming is not the primary purpose of a computer. Its primary purpose is understanding how computers work. And the key to understanding how computers work is getting a lot of people to pay attention to how computers work. Now, there are two ways to do this. You can make a computer that understands it all — that will always know everything. This is a dream of pretty much everybody and pretty much all the time. But you could never hope to do this. The reality of our planet is that it is always changing. You can't stop a new asteroid from hitting it, or stop a change in the temperature of a region of the earth (the climate) from getting worse. You need computers that understand what's happening around them. The first computer to start doing this was one built by Alan Turing, a British mathematician, back in the 1940s. It was not a particularly good computer, because it ran at about 8th (or 2nd) rate of the best computers of that era. But it was a very early computer. It gave us a little more understanding of our planet's atmosphere, as well as giving us a small taste of the way computers might work some day. After World War II Turing got together two of his old computer friends — Alan Kay and Bill Joy — and they formed a company and built a better and better computer. It's a bit hard to say exactly how this second computer started working, because so much came later. But we know that after working on the "Turing Machine," their computers had a way of recognizing patterns that other computers could not. A good example of this is the way computers work in their search engines. For example, Wikipedia is a search engine. It's not a search engine, in the way we use the word, in the conventional sense. But what it does is it looks up the information it needs in a huge volume of data. And that data is, at least as much as anyone can tell, written in code, in the computer code that runs it. So Wikipedia is looking up the Internet. When the Turing machine was constructed, when Turing was working on it, the way it searched the data

While those areas are undoubtedly highly important to society as a whole, as these areas are traditionally regarded by the American people as the area of private, family life where privacy and individual responsibility flourish as a counter balance to the pressures of modern public life, the intrusion into such areas by public authorities and law enforcement officials is no greater than is necessary in order to maintain order. In addition, for the most part, the public has a legitimate interest in the regulation of adult persons' private activities in such areas for the purpose of preserving the orderly and safe functioning of the society or for the prevention of criminal activity by such persons. The right to freedom of expression is a personal right from the individual's point of view, but it is a universal right which belongs to every citizen of this civilization. We also agree with the Court of Appeal that the offense against the person provision is a denial of due process of law by providing that the provisions shall not apply where the publication was for the purpose of teaching the morals of lawful sexual conduct. In that case, the defendant was charged with violating section 261 for making an obscene publication, but the court decided that the obscenity provision was unconstitutional because it provided a different standard of justification for obscenity than was provided for obscenity of general type. The case did not deal with the question whether the Legislature has an inherent right to impose such requirements on public officials and law enforcement officers. In a new effort to curb what is perceived as an excessive number of children being vaccinated, the City of Berkeley passed legislation Wednesday to implement an "underage vaccination exemption" policy for students, but only to the degree allowed by California law. Councilwoman Kate Harrison, who introduced the measure, said there should be some parental discretion as the city deals with an increasing number of unvaccinated children. As of June 1, 49 of the city's 73 elementary schools had no children fully vaccinated, Harrison said. The bill, AB 375, was unanimously approved in a 9-0 vote, the first time an ordinance has been introduced to address how children — and their families, in particular — should be affected by state law. Vaccination exemptions Under state law, students who have reached a certain age and parental consent should be allowed to sign a form indicating they do not wish to be fully immunized against preventable diseases. But parents need not sign a form to exempt children from school, according to city spokesman Dan Mogulof. There is an exemption for religious reasons and for medical reasons that are not related to immunization. "There's an exemption form that can be signed by a parent, but it can't really go much further," Mogulof said. Under state law, parents can opt to not vaccinate kids who are not fully vaccinated. Under state law, parents can opt to not vaccinate kids who are not fully vaccinated. "All kids should be fully vaccinated," Harrison said, adding that parents can also choose not to send their children to the elementary school. "It really depends on the parent and the child," Harrison said. "I just think it's a good idea to give parents that option." In her new legislation, Harrison said parents may opt to let their children opt out of the state-mandated vaccination requirements. "This ordinance is intended just to give parents more wiggle room," Moulton said, when asked if the parents have the power to make their children opt out. "It's our opinion that the law is not being enforced consistently." The exemption for medical reasons is for "medical indications that involve the prevention or treatment of the health of the child. The law only applies to immunization requirements for kids up to age two unless otherwise specified by the California Department of Public Health," a department spokesperson said in a Jan. 15 letter to Councilwoman Margarette Mondragon. Underage exemptions A second bill, AB 511 — also unanimously approved — expands the law to give parents the flexibility to let their children opt out of immunization at school, according to Harrison, who said this is needed because the district is currently trying "to reach out and ensure that all students can be safely immunized." Harrison said the City Council will discuss the second bill at its Jan. 21 meeting. "This bill has been brought up by a lot of parents, both parents of kids (who are) at school — including my own daughter," Harrison said. Mixed reaction Under her legislation, Harrison also seeks to increase financial aid and increase the number of full-time teacher assistants by giving parents that option as well. Councilwoman Kate Harrison introduced the legislation to give students greater choice about vaccinations. In California, children have to be at least two years of age to be fully vaccinated. According to the California Department of Public Health, there are 23 vaccine-preventable diseases: 21 communicable diseases and five noncommunicable diseases. All communicable diseases need a specific vaccine for people of certain age groups, including: chicken pox, measles, mumps, rubella, polio and varicella (chicken pox). A few days ago, we were lucky enough to catch up with some of the game's developers at Gamescom 2014. The team behind the sci-fi strategy game, No Man's Sky, gave us a sneak peak into the procedurally generated, space adventure. For this interview, we've managed to get the team's creative director Sean Murray a quick peek at the upcoming game's early development, and what he's already expecting from the project. During the interview, we get to find out the basics about the game, what we can look forward to most in the near future, and our opinion on how players can expect to spend their time when not playing the game.
I'm going to do this, it's my career, he told the crowd. "My dream is to see all of you in the United States Congress. My vote is going to be very, very important."

A team of researchers led by the University of Arizona has uncovered a previously overlooked link between the immune system and the ability to perceive visual input. It could open up new avenues for developing more effective treatments for autoimmune diseases and neurological disorders, the team said. The research was published online in Science on May 27. The other authors were Zhen-Yan Chen, a visiting scholar at UA's Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences; Jiao-Li Li, the department's first author; and Zhongwei Zhou, the department faculty member and study co-author from the University of Pittsburgh School of Dentistry. The study was focused on an underlying biochemical protein that controls the activity of a part of the immune system called the T-cell receptor. When the protein is disrupted, T cells, a type of white blood cell, attack other cells in the body, causing inflammation. People who are predisposed to autoimmune diseases and are predisposed to neurological disorders are more likely to have a defective T-cell receptor, the team noted. They then set out to investigate whether this defect was linked with the ability to identify colors and patterns. When people are exposed only to black-and-white images, they have a tendency to forget what color the image is, the team found. However, when they are shown two different pictures: a black-and-white image with green dots and one with red dots, the subjects are able to identify which color and which pattern is occurring, the team found. The researchers further determined that such patients had impaired color and pattern perception. The scientists were able to identify the underlying cause of impaired color and pattern perception by identifying specific neurons in the visual cortex in the mouse's eye, that respond to light. They were also able to stimulate the neurons in a living mouse brain and observe the results via optogenetics, the same gene expression approach that the researchers used. They found that when the researchers stimulated the neurons with light, the subjects were shown a sequence of alternating green and red dots. In contrast, when the team stimulated any other neuron in the visual cortex the mice did not recognize the color or pattern and did not show any of the desired behaviors. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging, they also observed that the neurons that control colored perception are highly active in the prefrontal cortex — another brain region which is highly active during visual processing. "We have discovered for the first time that impaired color and pattern recognition in humans is linked to the dysfunction of the T-cell receptor in the prefrontal cortex," Chen explained. "This may be an important new target to target for developing effective treatments for neurodegenerative conditions." This study illustrates the importance of studying T cells to establish the basis for diseases that involve the immune system, said Zhou, an associate professor of neuroscience and the department's first author. However, as this project was funded by the NIH's National Eye Institute, the results were not released at the time of the publication. About this neuroscience research article Funding: This project was funded by the Rohn Endowment: Research Network on Neuroscience to Promote Human Health. Source: L.A. Abstract Chromatin immunoreception is essential for normal color recognition The visual system provides a comprehensive information processing and visual control system for humans. T cells play an important role during the development and maintenance of these visual systems, in particular in the development of normal color vision. Despite the central role of the T-cell system in central visual system function, remarkably little is known

The New York Times is an increasingly significant part of Rupert Murdoch's empire. But in a long interview with the paper's executive editor Dean Baquet, The Times's editors are careful to say they can't be expected to always toe the company line. The interview focuses on the rise of Murdoch's 21st Century Fox, but the exchange also includes Baquet and Baquet's own editorial opinions, which include backing from The Times's editorial page writer Stephen Holden. Baquet says his personal politics are irrelevant to his job, and he says he does not have a "viewbook" about what journalism should write about. He also mentions that he's not currently working with his wife at the paper, with her working as White House reporter to the administration. But he says he plans to work more closely with her after he leaves at the end of January, and he makes it clear that he plans to make the paper and its journalism a higher priority. And Baquet says The Times is becoming an online media company through a partnership with AOL. For more on Baquet's interview, click here.  (Photo via Shutterstock)

A woman who says she was repeatedly harassed by her husband is suing his employer. (WSYX/WTTE) CALIFORNIA (CBS13) — A California woman has filed a lawsuit against her husband's employer for not doing more to save her life. Kira Lantz says that on December 24, 2015 while she visited the doctor, her husband David began repeatedly masturbating and assaulting her. Her doctor called police after the couple was seen "kissing all over each other," according to the lawsuit. The doctors determined Kira was in a life-threatening state and the couple's marriage was in jeopardy. Kira says as a result of the abuse, she had three major surgeries in December, 2015 because she had lost too much blood. She was admitted to the hospital on November 19 after her husband was called to the home and told she was unconscious because she wasn't breathing. When police arrived, David admitted the abuse began in April of 2015 when his wife began complaining about back pain. On August 6, 2015, she complained that she was tired, but he told her to rest because he'd been cleaning her car, according to the lawsuit. Police say on March 23, 2016 their daughter called police about noise and her father "made a disparaging remark and then pushed her back and hit her on the side of her head while she was on the ground." Kira says she was sent to Children's Hospital after their daughter complained about a bloody diaper. On August 22, 2016, she told doctors in their final note that she was afraid he would hurt her again, but he replied he did it "with affection," which is a violation of the court order. According to the lawsuit, David has been terminated from his job and he was in jail awaiting custody negotiations for her and her daughter. He allegedly told her, "You're a piece of sh*t," during a confrontation at a local restaurant at one point in October 2016. Kira claims the abuse is continuing and he has threatened to "break her legs" on at least two occasions.

For a lot of years, the name "the Simpsons" simply referred to the animated television show, but now it's beginning to refer to an actual book. Just a couple of short years after the release of The Simpsons Movie, and just a few short years after the release of the animated television series, the book called The Simpsons: The Complete Collection has finally become a physical object. In fact, it's so good that it's actually more entertaining than the original film. Let that fact sink in a bit: a book of the Simpsons that's better than the movie. It's one of the best things that's happened in a long, long time, folks. We're going to start by saying that this isn't the book anyone would necessarily want in their collection. While it does include everything from Bart to Homer to the whole of the Planet of the Apes, the book only contains twenty-two volumes. And this particular release doesn't really focus on all 26 seasons of the television show, as many might have guessed. So in theory, The Simpsons: The Complete Collection is also the perfect companion to The Simpsons: The Movie. Okay, that probably isn't saying a whole lot, but it probably should be, because if there's one thing that will ensure that you've always been able to enjoy the wonderful television series The Simpsons, it's being able to enjoy multiple iterations of the same book. The complete collection goes through the entire series chronologically, though it leaves out the animated television show's finale episode and the series finale episode of the animated television series. Now, what I really like about The Simpsons: The Complete Collection is that it also includes the animated television series' pilot and the animated television series' first episode, for some reason. It's actually kind of cool to get multiple sources in order, and knowing that there are additional episodes not on the collection is great, too. The Simpsons: The Complete Collection is a great book, and it's available for purchase right now. The series is also available in its original form available now on DVD. I'm glad that there is a book out there that includes all 26 seasons of the series, with the pilot and the first episode. The book even makes more sense now that we know that it's not exactly a definitive guide to every episode of the show, as we can now be sure that this was the same show that was a hit for 21 years.
