I thought it would be important to take a closer look at the performance of the three most recent "high profile" players at UFC 182. Jon Jones, Glover Teixeira and Vitor Belfort were the top 3 ranked fighters at that time and all made this year's event into their most notable UFC win. Jon Jones While that was the biggest win, Jones' next two appearances as the co-main event of a card or even in the same bout should always be noted. Prior to UFC 182, Jones had never been finished in 16 years and was still regarded as the most dominant man in American MMA. For most everyone outside the UFC, Jones' first appearance on FOX would be a big moment and one of the biggest of the year. His next fight would go on to be his biggest pay-per-view of the year against Daniel Cormier. He was coming off a close decision loss in UFC 182 and the first loss in the UFC since 2007. It would be his last win in the Octagon in two years. Jones ended up getting rocked on the feet in the second round and Cormier came away with the unanimous decision win. It would end up being a record-setting fight on Fox Sports 1 after the fight ended with 20 million viewers tuned into the fight, the largest audience for a UFC Fight Night fight on a cable or network television network that night. As such, it's the most watched fight of 2015 behind UFC 189. In spite of that, Jones' performance at 182 should be considered the moment where the narrative changed: he became the man with the belt, not necessarily the best but the guy to beat. It was a performance so dominant on so many levels that almost nobody can come back from after it. After a slow start, Jones seemed to regain the confidence that had been lost with a quick submission of former heavyweight champion Vitali Klitschko at UFC on FX 8 two weeks prior. It would go on to be the most dominant performance by an undisputed champion since Michael Bisping at UFC 184 when he demolished Antonio Silva to win the belt. The question is will Jones be back? That'll be the big question. Glover Teixeira When you think of Glover's career right now you probably picture the most exciting fighter to grace the UFC since Jones. In a year where he knocked out Roy Nelson in the first round of his last fight, Glover was on a path to unifying the light heavyweight championship with a win over Chael Sonnen in September. His win over Sonnen at UFC 181 cemented the narrative: Glover is the most exciting fighter to ever compete in the UFC. On that evening, he became the UFC heavyweight champion as Chael Sonnen's title reign was vacated following his own loss. Teixeira's performance versus Sonnen at UFC 181 left us asking more questions than it answered. Can he come into Jones' rematch with a fresh mind and fresh body? Will he have the cardio to beat Jones, the ability to outbox the champion. Will he be able to do anything besides what he was capable of in the first round at Madison Square Garden? When it was over, it was clear that this guy was very much on the rise and he wasn't done there. For those who were skeptical about his ability prior to his fight against Silva, it now seems like his potential to be a star was right there in front of him. And, with the success of his last win, he now has a legitimate chance to get the title. Vitor Belfort The fight against Chael Sonnen in Brazil was no mean feat for Vitor, as it seemed even more daunting than it was in the lead-up to the fight. He made a quick turnaround to UFC 182 to face Anderson Silva, a man who was on a 14 fight winning streak in the UFC at this point. It was clear by the final day of 2013 that UFC 182 was going to be one of the most anticipated fights in years. The main event between Chael Sonnen and Anderson Silva went under the lights and was probably the best fight of the year. Silva was able to hold his own the whole night; he did what no man had ever done before in the modern era by knocking Chael Sonnen out in the second round. It was like the two were destined to fight in that moment. The crowd got louder and louder with each missed kick by Anderson Silva or missed leg kick by Chael Sonnen as their momentum grew. It wasn't until the fourth round when Silva finally was able to finish Sonnen. For most people watching it, Silva finally got his chance to "retire" on his own terms. It wasn't really clear that he wanted to retire until he did, but it was the first time since being stripped of the belt that he truly gave it his "All-Out Effort" and the fans got to see him do what he was capable of as

A little boy's love of "Doctor Who" has brought him to London to perform at the new Doctor Who Experience, the UK's first theme park based on the popular British show. "The new 'The Doctor Who Experience' is something really special," Paul McCartney, a member of the Beatles who performed on stage at the theme park attraction before it opened to the public last week, told The Guardian. "The kids love it. It's got a real warmth and they love it, and I think that's really important. The audience don't just have to be Doctor Who fans to like it. It can give them a different point of view." The five-story attraction houses a replica of Doctor's TARDIS, home to a "living" Doctor and a robot companion, and features exhibits in costume and with props that can be taken home for viewing. McCartney's guest appearance at the park, just two blocks from Wembley Stadium in central London, is his second in a week. On Friday, Lennon played a gig at an amphitheater outside the venue that was part of London Calling: A Concert for Africa. The show was part of the Global Citizen Festival. He also played a short show at an exhibition about the Beatles' songs and recorded music with Bob Dylan and Jeff Beck. The singer's visit to "The Doctor Who Experience" marks the second time he has paid homage to the pop music icon since the death of John Lennon last month. Lennon performed his final song, "Imagine," at a concert in New York shortly after McCartney died in New York.

(CNN) Police in Germany are seeking to find a 31-year-old man who was spotted on surveillance footage last month as he tried to hide from them from an unrelated burglary investigation, a police spokesman told CNN. Police have been searching for the man since the discovery of his backpack, in the same small village where a woman and two young girls were killed in a home invasion, a police spokesman told CNN. The man appeared at the beginning of November "with little clothes and a backpack and a large backpack over his shoulder," police spokesman Stefan Redlich said. The man was seen "invisible" between the hours of midnight and four a.m. with a backpack "which indicated the person was hiding from a burglary investigation," Redlich told CNN. His backpack was found early Wednesday at a train station in the village of Heilbronn near Berlin. Read More

This is how my last year at the University of California started: It was August. A month of fall classes before the beginning of the spring semesters. I was in my third quarter – and I was already feeling overwhelmed and lost. A freshman at the school was in my class and, like me, he was struggling to fit in. I felt awkward. I was a little more confident than him – but I wasn't quite getting there. He was my TA and his name was Ryan. He was shy, introverted, and very focused on his studies. He never really talked to me, but I still found him fascinating; he seemed to be making sense of a lot in his life. (I'm pretty sure he was having some sort of emotional crisis and he was on top of it; I was just happy to have caught him in class.) We did everything together, from study sessions to class quizzes. We were so in sync, we rarely talked to each other. But Ryan was different; he was a year older than me, and I wasn't sure about him. His first year at the school had been the worst I had ever experienced. I started doing my best to forget to care about him, ignoring his words and his actions. But one day, he started to say things that made me look at myself in a totally different way. His words were full of passion and energy. There was a great spark to every conversation, and I knew it was his passion that kept us connected throughout the day. It became more than just a friend – it was love. I'm pretty sure I was totally surprised when that love began to blossom. I remember he was in my office during a class lecture. He had been struggling for so long with academic difficulty. I didn't know what it was about his ability to focus he really enjoyed – but I wanted to find out. I wanted to be that student that Ryan admired. I wanted to be one of those exceptional students that he was reading about in his class material. How could I not think about that? During our studying sessions we always found ourselves in conversation with each other. Ryan was always very intelligent and he was always interested in learning things. As I tried getting him to share more information about himself and learn more about his personal interests, I discovered that we were both very much interested in life – which was something that I always wanted to be. At first, I started to make excuses to go out of class to hang out with my roommate, but things didn't go that well. He was so interested in his work that I could barely manage to keep up. But eventually, we both found time to come over and talk about our dreams. We both agreed we wanted to continue our studies and we talked about how we wanted to keep going. I was always excited at the prospect of my future as an academic and I had all of those same goals. But to get there, I needed to be patient. Ryan was excited and he was eager because he knew that his studying would pay off in the future. He believed that the hard work that he put in would lead to things going his way. But I wasn't sure. After talking with Ryan about his future – he was eager because his future had become a reality for him. He was now a student who had a place to live, a car to drive and an allowance to save. He told me over the phone, "Mona, I feel like I can live, so, why can't I start now?" As he was telling me this, we were outside, talking about a different topic. Suddenly, he broke the conversation off to go back inside to talk to me. He came back and was ready to share more of himself…but I didn't hear a word he said. I could hear his heart breaking, waiting for his words. Eventually, he came back outside and told me that he was worried. He wanted to come over and talk more, but I told him I needed some time, because, as he says, he wouldn't be here with me if I didn't wait for him. Ryan had given up trying to convince me in his heart that he could go back and still pursue his dream. This is the story of a young man with a dream who gave up. I'm not saying that Ryan didn't work hard his first year at the school. But at the end of the day, he put his full focus and energy into his studies – and everything else else took a back seat. When he came home for fall break, it was as if he had finally reached his destination. It was almost like he had achieved his goals of getting a degree and starting a career – and now he was just trying to save some money to make sure we had a down payment for our own

You can choose to download our iOS or Android app. If you have a Windows PC, we also have a Chrome app . The App is provided Free of Charge to those in the EU. What Is the Law? European data protection laws do not apply to the United Kingdom. If you are not in the EU and you use our APIs in the United States, you need to comply with the laws of the US. In many states, the law prohibits unfair competition or consumer-shopping practices, so we ask all our users to take reasonable steps to avoid these types of illegal practices. Many of our APIs are offered in the US, which means that the API users are often required to obtain additional permissions, such as the rights to take and use photos, or to send content directly to our cloud servers. If you are in the EU, we also have a Privacy Policy which explains the rights that you have, when doing business in the EU and the rights you can exercise in the EU and when doing business in the US. We only offer these APIs to our customers in the EU. If you are in the EU, or in any country without a privacy law that applies to your data, please choose to accept this privacy policy.

For a good couple of decades people have been getting their heads handed to them on social media by an angry group calling themselves "the Men's Rights Movement." The MRM is a loose collection of websites and forums that are dedicated to attacking women for all manner of alleged wrongs. The "core" of the movement is a misogynistic belief in the idea that it's inherently good for a woman to be dominated by a man, even if she's abusive or threatening. One of the most famous examples is MRA's insistence that it's perfectly normal for women to be physically and verbally raped by their boyfriends. While the idea is often presented to us as a matter of self-defense, it's far more nuanced than that. While it's perfectly reasonable for women to feel violated in some situation, these sorts of situations aren't necessarily the sort of things that merit physical punishment. Rape culture is a culture that teaches and condones rape as a legitimate form of sexual assault, and women are the ones who, by default, are the targets of that culture. The notion that they should retaliate when being physically and verbally raped is absurd. It's a little surprising that a man's rights activist would be concerned about "rape culture" when men have been using rape as a weapon against women for decades. So what is the MRM doing about this? The movement is an outgrowth of anti-feminist culture within geek culture and online. The origins of the MRA can be traced to early "manosphere" blogs and message boards, where misogynist and often explicitly antisocial behaviors were encouraged by their commenters. That culture grew out of the men's rights movement's focus on the alleged victimization of women. There's a lot of overlap with the Gamergate movement which started because of similarly "misogynist" ideas about how video games are hurting women. As many people in that movement knew full well, it was designed as a means of attacking feminist critics of gaming. That movement has grown by leaps and bounds since Gamergate started, and I would imagine it is now even more closely tied to men's rights activists. Many of the people who post on the "men's rights" pages have very strong views on how the relationship between video games and equality is a joke and should be dismantled. One of their biggest claims is that video games are inherently sexist and misogynistic. As with their ideas about feminism, they think that video games are a cultural force that women have exploited in order to gain power over men. There is a very particular strain within the male gamer population that views video games as inherently degrading and harmful to women, and the belief that video games promote a culture of rape culture is used as justification for these negative values about video games. The movement has a history of being very successful at recruiting women to their cause, despite the fact that they also attract both men and women in equal numbers. It's worth noting in this context that there are a lot of "traditional" male-dominated geek culture sites, and that many of those are now run by women who are attracted to the movement because they recognize the toxic misogynistic elements within it. There will always be misogynistic people in geek culture, but there is no denying the fact that the male-dominated geek culture (which includes the "manosphere" as a major part of that culture) has a problem with its misogyny. It must be confronted and tackled aggressively if the entire community is going to avoid further damage. However, we still need to look at this from a different angle. The problem with a subset of men within geek culture is not that they are misogynists but that they are anti-feminist. They're not anti-women, they're anti- feminism. It's this part of the male population which is the primary focus for the various "men's rights" groups that make up the movement. The men's rights movement wants nothing more than to dismantle women's rights and privilege in all forms – from work to the bedroom. That is what they will do until they have their way.

I've finally finished the first part (that was my goal). At this point, I've got something that is about 50% complete. The next step is to get it finished and polished. I also have some new ideas for the project, to update the game when new features are added and to try to add more content while also making it more balanced.  For the first part of the game, I've just added all the basic components of gameplay that should be present in a game. The game should have a single player and multiple modes/layers, such as multiplayer and story mode, but for now I just used the single player. The game should play as you might expect from a Mario video game, where you're trying to avoid obstacles and hit coins to beat goals which will increase your star count.  I'll keep updating as I finish the game.  As a final note, the graphics aren't really original or well drawn, but I wanted them to be simple enough to start from. I hope you can appreciate the effort I've put into them, as nothing good comes out of mediocre graphics.  Here are some screenshots:

There is more and more talk about why the United States isn't leading on global climate change. The new administration is moving in the opposite direction. One idea, which won't change anything in the short term but does have the potential to move the world in the correct direction, revolves around a small country that is trying to cut emissions and become less dependent on foreign fossil fuel imports. "On a scale of one to ten, the Maldives is a ten," explains Daniel Baumann of Columbia University's Earth Institute. He notes that the Maldives government has cut its emissions of carbon dioxide by 60 percent since 2000, largely in response to a 2009 law that required its citizens to reduce carbon emissions. "A couple years later, they increased them a little bit, and they've stayed there ever since," he says. Baumann's office, part of Columbia's Earth Institute's environmental program, has just published a paper based on that country's efforts to reduce its carbon emissions. Its findings will be published online this week in the journal Science Advances. For Baumann and his Columbia colleague, Robert Jackson, there is more to the story than that. "Even within the Maldives," they write, "there is a sense that the country's government and people can actually accomplish what they need to do to protect the climate, especially over the long term. The main lesson has to do with the local politics, the need for political will and political space, and the power of the people." The Maldives' experience can serve as a counterpoint to the current debate around climate change in the U.S. The study is one of a number of analyses to help put the current state of the environment in context, and to help the world's political leaders and other decision makers make better sense of what's at stake. Baumann, who is also a senior fellow at the Earth Institute, is one of the founders of that initiative, in which he serves as director. Climate change has already hit Maldives hard. Since 2012, temperatures in the country have been more than a degree Celsius higher than during the years of the 2000s global-warming peak. And the country, with small but well-developed coastline, is vulnerable to sea level rise. It is also one of the world's most densely populated islands that already hosts some of the world's most vulnerable communities—which includes many in the Maldives. "The Maldives has a very strong sense of community and identity," says Baumann, who is also the co-director of Columbia's Climate Change Institute. "It's a pretty fragile situation." The new study shows that Maldivians can make real progress if political will is maintained over time. At the same time, the country is making real progress. It has recently launched an extensive program to reduce carbon emissions by nearly 90 percent over the next 20 years. That's much more ambitious than many other countries, though there is still room for improvement. Currently, the Maldives has just about 5 percent of the world's renewable renewable energy potential, compared to 25 percent in the U.S. To be sure, carbon emissions are a big worry in the country and elsewhere, according to the authors of the study. But the authors also suggest that in the long term, a low-carbon climate-protection strategy might be more important for the future than cutting greenhouse gas emissions from fossil fuels. "We are much more optimistic about the potential to reduce greenhouse gas emissions than the world has been led to believe," Baumann says.

Dublin police have appealed to people who know anyone who was involved in an incident involving a semi-automatic rifle last night at Dún Laoghaire-Rathdown Town Hall. There have been reports that a man had brought the weapon into the city centre, where he was reportedly shot dead by police. "Someone had brought the firearm to the Dún Laoghaire Garda station at approximately 8PM, the following evening," said the officer in charge. "It is believed that this is not a gun but a semi-automatic rifle. "The location is not being disclosed at this time." "It is believed that this is not a gun but a semi-automatic rifle. The location is not being disclosed at this time." The man has been shot dead by gardai It is believed the weapon had been previously used in dissident republican killings. There are a range of questions that need to be sought, the officer added. "Firstly, we are trying to establish if this firearm was not used by dissident republicans; there have been quite a number of shootings in the last couple of days and there have been fatalities," he said. "Secondly, is this a self-inflicted issue, and will the person have been under the influence of alcohol? "Thirdly, is this a case of robbery, or just a case of an individual who was in the public domain using an object which he possessed illegally? " It has been alleged that the weapon was a semi-automatic rifle and was taken from the car of a member of the PSNI in the Dala Street area. The Gardai were alerted to the incident when a call was received saying an automatic rifle had just been seen being used in an altercation on the ground floor of the Garda station. Gardai also told motorists to avoid the area. Gardai received two shots as the suspected gunman opened fire on patrol. "He was shot while the offender was on the run," said a source. "He was not wearing police uniform, he was carrying the firearm in a bag. "We expect there could be more shots." Gardaí are now searching for a man described as medium-built. They say there were witnesses to the incident and they wish to speak to them. Anyone with information who wishes to contact gardai can call the Incident Room on 1800 666111, or any Garda station.

(CNN) In the midst of the most intense debate ever over the nation's defense budget, President Donald Trump tweeted that he was asking the Pentagon to reduce the military's long-term readiness by 5%. In fact, he was asking the Pentagon to "get to work," according to Lt. Gen. Herbert Carlisle, head of the US Air Force. "There are a number of things that I think we could do in the short term and a number of things that I think we could do in the long term in order to both reduce our budget and have an impact that I hope will help us not just in the short term but also not only in the long term and certainly will benefit in the long term," Carlisle said. "So there's a lot of things that we could do and that's exactly what I was talking about, whether it's reducing the readiness period or some other way." But Trump insisted at a news conference in Paris alongside French President Emmanuel Macron on Thursday that he still plans to ask for a larger budget to make up for the reductions he wanted to make to the defense budget over the last seven years. Trump was in Paris to attend the Group of 20 summit. In a series of tweets, Trump wrote he was calling for a "big boost for our military," as he continues his push to slash spending and reorganize the defense budget. "The United States must greatly strengthen and expand its nuclear capability until such time as the world comes to its senses regarding nukes," Trump tweeted. "Being respectful of other countries' systems at all times is not a bad thing, but it is not smart." "United States must greatly strengthen and expand its nuclear capability until such time as the world comes to its senses regarding nukes," Trump tweeted. "Being respectful of other countries' systems at all times is not a bad thing, but it is not smart." Trump also said he and Secretary of Defense James Mattis met recently to discuss "how to get the full cost of our vast military build-up in order to be truly sustainable." Asked at the news conference if the money for the military will actually increase, Trump said, "Yes." Trump said the military will be getting the money from the Department of Defense budget, which as of 2011 was about $583 billion, including $52 billion for the Pentagon. Trump said he has spoken with the "top generals" of the Department of Defense, and that Mattis will probably report to him. He pointed to a 2013 Washington Post story that he said was very accurate, and he said that the generals were telling him this, and he said, "They don't like the numbers that they're coming in at." But in fact, Carlisle said Thursday at a Pentagon news briefing, "I can tell you that both the Secretary of Defense and the National Security Council have a very open conversation with the Department of Defense to talk about what the cost of the United States military is on the front end, and to talk about the long term." Earlier, Trump had tweeted: "I will be asking Congress to fully approve President Trump's $54 billion dollar plan for modernizing our military." I will be asking Congress to fully approve the $54 billion dollar plan for modernizing the U.S. military. #DefendU.S. — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 23, 2017 He continued, "There will be many different costs involved in our tremendous military needs. But these costs will be paid for by those who truly need them. Our goal is clear: to get the cost down so we can protect our people and make our defence powerful again!" His statements to The Hill were consistent with the comments the President made in France on Thursday, where he said "the greatest threat and the greatest challenge that we face as a nation is a global threat." Trump has taken many stands in the last month, seemingly all at odds with the Republican Party's longstanding defense of the $600 billion national security budget he inherited from President Barack Obama. Trump has suggested he wants to spend more on the military. He has also called for a $110 billion increase in defense spending. Trump wants to increase non-direct military spending, such as the Coast Guard, Navy, and nuclear weapons, at a much faster rate. The President has even told his generals to come up with new ideas on how to pay for their budget increases, including cutting the State Department's budget. But Trump's plan isn't going over well with the military, according to his new White House budget chief, Mick Mulvaney. "You know, I know that that number's a number that the president likes to cite on a regular basis or once in a while. But I just haven't seen it anywhere, have you?" Mulvaney asked reporters on Sunday about the President's number. Mulvaney was speaking with reporters in the back row

What is the problem with being self-sufficient? Well, let's start with how we perceive success and failure and the ability to get into relationships with other people. Most of us feel like we are in a struggle. In our culture, being alone can still have a powerful psychological impact. A study conducted by the Yale School of Medicine showed that loneliness causes people to show more aggressive and antisocial behaviour in certain situations, because they feel they have to assert power over others (or "suck it up" in a derogatory quote). In the same study, people who reported being lonely were more likely to act aggressively towards colleagues and to act on their negative emotions more easily. Studies also show that the lack of friends or other relationships can cause people to become less helpful. An increase in positive and trusting relationship styles can bring people to be more helpful to each other, meaning that they can solve problems together. Research suggests that a lack of contact can even cause you to change in social behaviour. In one study, when asked to rate the importance of each of 10 social behaviours, people's social attitudes and behaviour were assessed as negative when they lived alone, but positive when living with friends or close acquaintances. People living alone, on the other hand, had a negative attitude to family, but positive attitudes to friends. They liked family, but did not interact with them much. When people have a lack of friends, they also have less chance to be involved in the life of the community around them, which is crucial in the modern world. Living in social isolation can also cause people to miss out on social encounters and friendships and can affect people's sense of self. Being a successful solo person, you will likely also lack social awareness, a crucial survival trait. The researchers at the University of British Columbia asked people with disabilities to read three stories. Participants were then shown photographs of their friends and family. Only those who were able to communicate verbally had the ability to learn from these personal pictures. While these people were not able to learn about the photos, the ability to do so helped them to build a more in-depth knowledge of their families. What was also interesting was that participants in a separate group read about the photos before watching the video, where everyone was the same. No one knew who their friends' family members were because they had no personal pictures to communicate with. They were also given a list of the words used by their friends' friends. The results showed that the words used to describe their personal photographs became more accurate as the situation improved. As we have seen, loneliness and lack of friends are closely entwined and affect each other. This is why it is important to seek relationships with people with whom we can share interests, as well as support services. Also, be aware that social isolation is a symptom that signals greater problem. Try to find out if you have these symptoms before you attempt to leave your personal world and find another one, where things are more stable. And that is it for today's post. Next week we shall be exploring the symptoms and symptoms of loneliness, as well as how being self-sufficient could improve your well-being! I want to thank my reader for making me do this! Here's another link, if you have a moment: http://self-sufficient.info/symptoms-of.html Enjoy your day. Advertisements

Caught between the Scylla and Charybdis of a rapidly collapsing economy and massive social upheaval, the leaders of the Greek government and the EU have shown an appalling inability to act in an orderly fashion. They have shown a failure to recognize the gravity of the situation. — Alexander Graf Lambsdorff, former German Chancellor, in an interview with Business Insider, April 8, 2015 "It's clear that the Greek government is paralyzed. The European Commission has no influence, but the European Central Bank does. They're trying to come up with a deal with the Greeks and they have some basic guidelines: They have to get back to the negotiating table soon, in time for a European Council meeting in December or January, and they have two choices: they can do the deal or they can let Greece leave the euro zone. If Greece leaves, Greece could be in very much trouble. If it stays in, Greece could have a very difficult time in the future and it would have to rebrand and re-enter the world economy very, very slowly, without significant amounts of borrowing." — George W. Bush, U.S. president in an interview with Bloomberg News, April 8, 2015 That's a warning from the former U.S. president and architect of the American economic experiment to the current Greek government. "Europe will not solve an issue like Greece if the leaders there are not prepared to take serious leadership. And the problem is not Greece — it's Europe." With President Barack Obama's approval ratings sitting below 42% in polls in Greece, with a growing unemployment rate of 22%, and with economic experts such as the European Commission's chief economist Martin Ravallion arguing that Greece cannot possibly be allowed to leave the euro zone, the United States' two foremost political leaders have found themselves the subjects of renewed criticism and criticism. What does it say about U.S. politicians if the former U.S. president seems unable to help steer the ship of state when faced with such an overwhelming crisis? Does it send a signal that, despite being the world's largest economy, Washington has no idea what to do when it comes to economic management? A brief history of Greek leaders to illustrate the difficulties of Washington's approach to Greece's bailout: Former Greek Prime Minister George Papandreou, elected in January 2005, had a record of managing Greece under harsh austerity. He lost the 2009 election to Alexis Tsipras, who came to power in January 2015. Papandreou's party, "Coalite for a New Era" (CoNE), had been in office for 24 years. His coalition government had been involved in a series of unpopular measures since 2010, including tax increases, pension cuts, cutbacks in social services, and reforms of national security and judiciary. Papandreou had faced repeated criticism of his management of Greece, which included the 2008 global financial crisis, an economic slowdown that was almost universally blamed on the policies of the previous government of the "Troika" in Athens — the European Central Bank, European Commission and International Monetary Fund. After the death of former prime Minister George Papandreou in April 2012, Greek voters went to the polls for a general election. Polling stations opened at 7:00 a.m. that November day and lasted into the wee hours. There were no media coverage or projections. Voters went to the voting booths with the knowledge that their country had entered a new phase of political and economic chaos, and that they had the difficult job of deciding whether the country was on the verge of civil war or the path toward democracy. Greeks came out in droves to vote in Greece's first general election since the end of World War II. In all of Greece's post-World War II elections, turnout had never exceeded 62%. The official turnout was 72%, but there was a much larger turnout of 67% of Greek males and 75% of young people. Turnout in the general election was the highest recorded in Greece's modern history. The vote was in favor of radical, anti-establishment parties, the Syriza, Podemos and the Democratic Left. The new government immediately embarked on a program to "restore public trust and confidence from the financial markets" and "to put an end to the political uncertainty that was leading to a deterioration of the economy" (as the Financial Times reported). The Greek government began cutting salaries and pensions. But before the cuts went into place, Greece's creditors, including the European Union, the European Central Bank and the International Monetary Fund, cut all loans to Greece by the equivalent of 80% or more. Greece, still in shock from the global financial crisis, needed to borrow $27.5 billion to pay for the new spending programs. The Greek financial sector, which still had some $170 billion on its books at the time of the new austerity measures were unable to refinance and repay the new loans. So the crisis continued into 2013. Greek public spending fell by 12% in 2015 alone, bringing the amount of debt in

"If I had a camera," he continues, "and I wanted to take a photograph, I couldn't take one right through the head. As soon as the shot starts, it starts going down. One of the photographers involved in Sunday's shooting says the footage he reviewed showed that Williams had not been able to see anyone on the sidewalk when he was shot. "There is no evidence that this shooting was a suicide," says Jonathan Blake, an Associated Press photographer. "It was a brutal, brutal act," he says, noting that the first two bullets to Williams's body missed, and that both victims fell on the ground. "It was a murder." This video shot by an AFP journalist shows police officers responding to the crime scene. The officer in the driver's seat had only been on the job two days, and had only been in the station at about 11:45 p.m., when he was dispatched after arriving on the scene. He was the third officer to arrive on the scene. Blake believes that Williams might have had a gun, or at least had a gun with him. In addition to the three-officer team, a third person, an elderly woman, was also called on. It took police about 45 minutes to respond to the crime scene. He adds that the man and the elderly woman were taken directly from the scene. "What was done, as far as our investigation is concerned, is as good as it gets," he says. The woman, identified as 89-year-old Delfina Mares, was also taken home at the scene, and was being interviewed by investigators yesterday. Mares told reporters that she was returning home from her yard across the street from the home where the shooting took place when she turned around and saw a man with a gun in his hand. She then ran to the area where she believed it was going to happen and confronted the man while she held it for him. "I told him, 'You are not going to do this,' " she told reporters."I asked him to put down his gun but he didn't." She added that the gun looked like a pistol but a different brand. This video shot by an AFP journalist shows police officers responding to the crime scene. The man shot, identified as 59-year-old Charles Short, was killed upon arrival at the hospital. A short time later, another man was arrested. A spokesperson for St. Louis County Police, which includes Ferguson, said that another man, 45-year-old Tyrone Harris, was detained on Friday night at a nearby auto repair shop in connection with the shooting, and charged with armed criminal action after police found a pistol on him. "I am not going to say anything else, because I'm the prosecutor and there's a process. We're going through court tomorrow, and I'm going to be involved with the legal aspects of the case," says Ferguson prosecutor Bob McCulloch. "But to me, the bottom line is this: This is a murder weapon. ... No matter what the circumstances are, if you have an assault weapon as an assault weapon and it is designed for that purpose, you can kill somebody." "If I was in this office, and I saw a man with a gun or someone who was carrying a gun, who looked like a threat to me, and we were responding to some call, I certainly would have tried to subdue and detain that person." The prosecutor is preparing for a grand jury meeting on August 16 and 23, at which time he'll decide whether or not to bring charges against anyone involved in the shooting. "They can indict a cop," he adds. "It's an indictment of a lack of respect for the law." Ferguson Police Chief Thomas Jackson is due before the grand jury on August 15. This week, Jackson promised that the department would release the name of the officer who shot the suspects in order to show the public the officer's character. The world is slowly starting to wake up to how big of a problem climate change has become. The UN has called for a "moral and political awakening" by the 21st century, while the World Bank has predicted that global warming could cause more than 6 million premature deaths by the end of the century. However, it doesn't look like we are going to make much of a difference. The UN is getting more and more desperate as they can't take the situation any longer and are calling to do something about it. Climate Scientists Warn Of 'Risky' And 'Highly Dangerous' Effects Of Global Warming At a meeting about 'the future of the human race', hosted by the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, former US President, Jimmy Carter, warns that climate change is the most threatening to humanity. He says that if we don't stop this now, more people will die. As it turns out he isn't the first person to warn of this effect. In 2009, NASA's top climate scientist said that with climate change, "the likelihood of one person's life being destroyed by a category 5 hurricane could quadruple, by 2100." If that's the case, then we are definitely not going to stop this anytime soon. There's even a group of NASA scientists who are calling for an 'extreme weather' warning system (that's what it sounds like – a system where people can alert about extreme weather conditions). On top of that, there will be a lot of severe weather conditions in the future. One of these could even be "category 5," or even a Category 6. The UN's chief of peacekeeping mission for the Balkans, Nicholas Haysom, gave his own warning earlier this year saying that the Balkans region is highly susceptible to climate change because of its harsh weather and natural disasters. On top of this, the UN is trying their best to prevent it. In the last few years they've been trying to find a way to create a global agreement on keeping global warming under 2°C. However, this year the climate group agreed to do it through individual nations, rather than trying to reach an international agreement. Global Warming May Cause More Than 6 Million Delayed Menses By 2100 One of the reasons why we aren't likely to stop climate change is because it's happening all around us now. Sooner or later, climate change is going to reach a critical point. We are already seeing more and more extreme weather events as our planet warms due to global warming. Some estimates suggest that global warming could cause more than 6 million women in the northern hemisphere to postpone their periods throughout their life. Unfortunately for those women, some of the more severe weather events can disrupt their menstrual cycles, causing them to get stuck in a state of amenorrhea.

A new law would allow the state to seize and destroy firearms used by the Texas terrorist who shot up a Prophet Muhammad cartoon contest in Texas, according to new documents obtained by Breitbart News. Texas Governor Greg Abbott signed the bill on Monday afternoon, according to the Texas Tribune. The new law is similar to a law passed in April by the Pennsylvania legislature. The new law would allow the Texas Attorney General to seize firearms if the person involved in a crime poses "a significant risk of violence" or is a "fugitive from justice." The act of terrorism would be considered an aggravating circumstance in the application of the law to seize a firearm. The new law also expands the definition of who could be designated as a "fugitive from justice." Under the new law, anyone can now be placed in the state's custody if they are a "person who has been discharged from the custody of the U.S. Armed Forces as a result of a dishonorable discharge, any felony conviction, or juvenile arrest related to domestic violence or crimes of violence, or who has been convicted in any other jurisdiction of an offense that, if committed in Texas, would constitute a felony." The new law also adds two new circumstances where firearms can be seized. Federal law already allows the government to seize an individual's firearms as part of a criminal investigation, even if that individual is alleged to have no connection to the violent act. Breitbart News reported in April on a separate Texas law which allows the state to seize firearms without an indictment. One of the primary purposes of this law is to allow state bureaucrats to destroy firearms that are not wanted in a firearm control situation. On Saturday, a shooter with apparent ties to the Muslim Brotherhood attempted to hold the Prophet Muhammad cartoon contest in Garland, Texas. The event would have been held in an open-air gallery, and the shooters apparently had other motives. One of the gunmen who shot up the event had posted online statements espousing support for Al Qaeda, ISIS, and other Islamist extremist groups, Breitbart News reported at the time. Texas State Senator Glenn Hegar (R-Katy) was also among the legislators who fought vigorously in favor of the law. Hegar's push for the new law drew fire from other lawmakers, who argued that the move would actually increase the number of weapons falling under the State's control. At least one Republican lawmaker, State Senator David Simpson (R-Longview), spoke out against the attempt by Hegar to push the new law through, Breitbart reported. Simpson told the Texas Tribune, "I'm not in favor of giving the government authority to tell me I cannot own a gun. I disagree with that," adding, "It's not about gun control, it's about gun control if they feel like there are too many guns under the gun." Simpson is part of a group of state senators who fought to protect the gun industry by ensuring their manufacturers' profits never hit the state budget. The new law would help to protect businesses by making it easier to protect their own product lines. The Texas Tribune thanks its sponsors. Become one.

Tottenham Hotspur striker Harry Kane has been named the Barclays Player of the Month for October. The 24-year-old scored 10 goals to power Spurs to fourth place in the Premier League table and a third consecutive win - all under Mauricio Pochettino. His 10 Premier League goals have made him the ninth highest goal scorer in the competition, behind City strikers Sergio Aguero (20) and Gabriel Jesus (14). But it is Kane's exploits against Watford in the Premier League on Tuesday evening that has made headlines. It was a tale of two goals, as he missed a good chance before shooting too high from a tight angle for David Nugent to palm away from close range. But then, with his side two goals behind, he grabbed his side's third goal with a lovely dinked finish against the Hornets. His six goals in October means he is now just one behind Manchester United's Manchester City captain Vincent Kompany, who also had six goals in the league. Harry Kane became the ninth different Premier League player to win Player of the Month award (last player to win it was Chelsea striker Didier Drogba - May 2006) Spurs' five victories in October - including a 3-1 win over Everton - has seen Kane come of age this season Harry Kane became the ninth different Premier League player to win Player of the Month award (last player to win it was Chelsea striker Didier Drogba - May 2006) Kane has scored two league goals in three successive Premier League games after getting just two Premier League goals in his last 14 games (also Oct 2013)

If you want the fastest possible way to move your mouse, you'd think it would be the one that's most accurate. But it turns out that some mice—especially those used by gamers—are getting much faster than your average mouse, thanks to technologies that can track more than one point at once. An Intel researcher, who's been quietly working on a similar project that's been known about for some time, has presented a paper at the Usenix Security conference. His invention is called Multi-Point Motion Tracking and it's the subject of a demo in this year's DARPA Cyber Grand Challenge. MPMT can track multiple points in real time with up to five feet of separation, says Craig Williams, the researcher who's led the effort. That means you can, in effect, track multiple objects in a virtual space without sacrificing quality performance. "What we're trying to achieve is a way to have a single point that is tracked for an extended period of time [and] to achieve an accurate and repeatable motion tracking in the virtual environment," said Williams. "What we can do in this demonstration is get a point-to-point motion tracking that covers a very large distance by having the same point-to-point motion tracking in more than five feet, but in a space that is very small." As a result, Williams says MPMT can be used to achieve better precision or even, in the near future, give a virtual avatar the ability to "walk" on a surface. And that kind of power might just be what's needed to turn gaming into a reality. Intel worked with a number of experts in the field to ensure the accuracy of the technology, Williams says. One of the key challenges in achieving this was reducing the error inherent in tracking multiple points at the same time. For example when a shooter moves from point A to point B, what matters is where they end up, not what they do to end up there. The way to do that is to keep track of the position of each of the individual points of action, in addition to keeping track of where every single one of those points intersects with an object. And you can make all sorts of things happen in a three-dimensional space: The key to this is to be able to have objects that are different in color, size and even texture. Using multiple points to keep track of that variety is another challenge, but one that will be overcome if the technology works the way Intel says it will, Williams said. He's already shown off some examples of how this technology might be used in the future. "If all the points in the environment are the same color, it's no problem in three dimensions and I can point to those points. It's the texture and color and size differences that I'm having difficulty with in those environments," he said, adding, "We did some very basic computer vision based modeling and actually a very simple tracking. We could not capture that information and that's where the work has come from." Williams, who's been working on his research for the past three years, has some ideas how his technology might eventually be used. The first is to make a device like the Microsoft Kinect for Xbox that would allow gamers to control and move an in-game avatar physically in real space, without having to use a mouse to track multiple points at the same time. He's also working on a device that he's calling the Multi-Point Sensory System that could be used to track multiple body parts at the same time. "One of the challenges that we faced in this project was that the tracking speed needed to be sufficient and to track more than one point at the same time we needed to have the ability to use motion sensors in a very high degree of accuracy," explained Williams. "So right now the MPMT tracking can only track one point per motion sensor. But I think there is a big opportunity to explore how many extra sensors can be used, how much accuracy can be provided, how many spatial configurations can be established, and using those sensors in three dimensions we may be able to provide very high resolution, very high accuracy tracking that is actually able to track many more things at the same time than a standard tracking device." Intel plans to reveal more details soon about Multi-Point Motion Tracking and other related technologies that might become part of the future of gaming, Williams says. "I think in terms of the games that we'll be designing for gaming, I think the future of gaming is going to be a combination of what people call virtual reality and augmented reality," Williams said. "The reality here is that in virtual reality the player can't move their body. You might think about putting on a glove or a hat or putting on a headset, but you can't really move your body." "So the reality here is that in virtual reality the player can't move their body." Craig Williams, lead researcher on MPMT

The idea behind the new, improved and even smarter Corgi is to create a pet that loves you more than it hates you. Our mission? Create a dog that can do what you want and feel good about every step along the way. Each Corgi is carefully crafted to be a uniquely tailored fit for any and every unique personality. Corgios are hand sculpted and individually hand fitted to each corgi. Our goal is to create the ultimate combination of style and function. Each and Every corgi is meticulously crafted as if we are walking down the red carpet for the Oscars! A unique piece of art and an essential addition to anyone's collection. Corgis are a modern dog breed that were originally bred for herding sheep. These large dogs (around 14 inches tall) are also bred for their beauty and grace. They are now an increasingly popular pet due to many health and welfare benefits, a pet that is beautiful whether you have dark or light eyes, and a dog that will never growl. Corgis are now one of the most popular small breeds in America. This is due to many of the benefits they offer like their ability to be house trained, loving and loyal to their owners, and can be groomed however you please. In addition, people of all ages and backgrounds will find the dogs to be truly fun - there are so many different ways they can add character to your life.

A new survey claims that more and more women are now using the app to find long-term romantic matches. It comes as a survey claimed more and more female members are using the dating app dating apps to find love The survey, from OkCupid, says the number of female users of Match.com has also increased in the last five years. It found that the most popular matches are for women aged 25-34. The survey also claims that most users are using apps as a way to 'do things with people they find interesting'. The report also claims that men were more likely to use the app to 'connect' with women - but they are also more likely to use the app as a 'partnership tool'. OkCupid told MailOnline: 'Women and men are finding different things attractive in the world, and they're coming up with new ways to find them. 'So there is definitely a need for these tools, and we believe that's also why they are still growing despite all the great apps available.' 'We believe that for a few decades, we'll see more and more women using the app, but maybe not on the same scale as other apps like Tinder. 'Men have had more success than women in using apps with a high number of active users, and we believe it's because these apps are all designed for the same kind of user – that's for users with high frequency needs.
