I've got a lot to say about this book but I do think I'll start with one sentence from the back cover… You are about to enter the amazing world of The Book of Life. If you are an American and do not know at least a little about the amazing world of Kabbalah or have no idea what Kabbalah is this book is for you! But I think this book is a good read for anyone! The book begins with the idea that the entire world is "a book", every person has a "book", everyone is "out there". The book is the "big" and "small" worlds, each person's book has a special purpose, and each book has a special "meaning". This book is the "Book of Life". Each person's book is like the universe, and each book is like a person, and each person's book is like the sun. This is something that the author has brought to his art from his experience growing up in this world where everything is "in a book". The book world is the idea of the book, and everyone in it is there to help you learn about them. This book is full of stories from many different areas of the world about people, places, and things that will give you new insight into the world you live in. I was really surprised by some of them but my favorite one was about the first time I saw Buddha before we were in his monastery. He did not look like an average human being but I knew right then and there that he was something different, something special. I know of many people who have never seen him before but this particular one did and they know something magical about him. Many of the stories are centered around Kabbalah, Judaism, and magic and Kabbalah is a special way of looking at a very different part of our lives. It involves the inner workings of creation, the soul, nature, consciousness, angels, spirits, and the nature of creation itself. This book is so different than other books I have read about Kabbalah. Every story is different. One story can relate to another story, this one does not or there are times when it relates to another story in a new way but does not do so in a different way. One story might be about a particular place, another about specific people, or it might be about other aspects of the universe. This book can make a difference in the things people focus on or don't focus on in my opinion because it is not something that is easily categorized. You could say that what this book offers is an "inner journey" or inner learning which I really appreciated that this book does not fall into the genre that I would call a "religious book" and doesn't follow the rules for many religious books I have read. You can read this book on your own time but you are sure to find it informative if not enlightening. I felt like I didn't know anything about the topic of Kabbalah but the books after this one gave me an even deeper understanding. I know we are living in a culture that thinks about spirituality like we do with religion and Kabbalah has a lot of things that we can read about and absorb. The whole world is full of wisdom and the world is our book. I was really shocked at one of the stories that I was surprised by. It is about a man who is born blind. He is born with a severe eye disease when he is eight weeks old. His vision becomes impaired and he cannot see more than 10 feet ahead of him. He feels like he has a mind of its own but he cannot do anything about it, and he does not know how to explain it to others (until the day when he finds out he has a son who can see all around him. When his son is born his eyes are miraculously healed without surgery). One of the main things that attracted me to this book was the way that Kabbalah relates to the person who is blind. It shows how a person's mind can change through the miracle of God. It seems so unbelievable that this could really happen, but we can see in a child, even if he cannot see any farther than his hands, that God may be able to heal a person's blindness and allow the blind individual to do amazing things. I found this amazing book to be very educational. There wasn't so much in terms of language that was difficult to learn; I just read what seemed like the book itself, and I think that it did a good job of making me think about things in my own life and how I thought I had to change. It also really got to me and made me think. I was not really familiar with the book but it showed me things about the world about which I was already more familiar but I also learned things about myself that have never made it into my brain. I think The Book

The first thing that I can say about this review is that I am not very impressed by it. To start off, my experience with GQ is largely limited to online shopping. On the days I did do physical purchases I was fairly surprised with how bad of a job they seem to do. With that said, let's move on to the actual review of the product. Packaging: When opening the container I noticed that it came sealed. The whole thing was packed up nicely and the box had a pretty cool design on it. The top part of the box gave me the look of a giant pair of sunglasses, which I thought was pretty cool. I didn't really see a reason to open the bottle though, because of the obvious flaws I found in the product. So I left it on the shelf to get a closer look at the bottle itself. The bottle itself looks a good bit different than my usual sunglasses, I wouldn't say that it's completely different, but it has a unique look to it. It also feels pretty nice and well constructed. The main feature that makes the bottle different than a standard sunglasses is that it feels like a pair of sunglasses for everyday use. For someone who wears glasses on a daily basis, this would be great to help them look decent without compromising the quality of their prescription lenses. That being said, the lens itself wasn't going to be much of an improvement over my existing eyeshadows. It isn't going to give them an extra 3 or 4mm for one. When opening up the tube it's easy to see that there aren't any instructions inside. No printed writing to tell you if you have applied it correctly. That being said it is quite obvious how to properly apply it. You have to use a dampened sponge to dab off the top and bottom of your eyeshadow with some sort of misting consistency and then you run it through. I applied and followed the label directions to a tee. The results were nice and they didn't seem to look too patchy in the tube, but there were areas where it looked patchy. I did find that, overall, that the coverage was alright. I know that this eyeshadow has the words "luminous" and "rich" stamped on it, but the coverage was not really that impressive. On my arm, it didn't really reach all the way to the crease. I think that I would have liked it to have done better due to my dark circles at the time. It was still ok, but it may have to do with my under eye bags. Performance: Packaging: 4.5/10 This product is pretty solid. It has some nice packaging, it comes with a nice glossy, clear top that looks a bit like a pair of shades and does not look as though it will be damaged in transit. The product is sealed in a pretty standard plastic tube. There isn't a lot of product to go around, which is kind of a shame. The tubes are small, so they're not going to last too long in general. The application of the shade was fairly easy though and did not require a lot of effort. There could have been a bit more product in the tubes because of it, but even so I think that's a tiny bit of a pity. Application: 9.5/10 Overall I think that this eyeshadow is a good product. It is a bit on the thicker side, but does offer quite a bit of coverage. When you blend this shade it does not come out of your eyes as patchy as one would like them to, but it will appear patchy in a way that may be noticeable if you apply the right amount. The formula on these eyeshadows is a combination of really good pigmentation, as well as a natural shimmer to it. You can see the natural shimmer more clearly than the pigments are. While the glitter is a bit noticeable when blended out, it is not as bad as it was in the tube. It's more of a very subtle touch than something you would notice when you're looking in a mirror. The coverage is great however and I wouldn't call it patchy. The overall application goes fairly smoothly. It seems like I can do a good job with this product if I use a lot of effort in blending it out. It's a bit of a pain with these more sheer shades as you need to go down in the intensity of the shimmer and get better coverage. As expected, it didn't do too well on my dark circles and my eye area actually looked a bit patchy during application the best I could judge. So I think that blending it out is definitely a better option. The texture however isn't anything to write home about. It's a bit like a gel, but a gel that's probably not going to stick to the skin very well and that feels and smells a bit like the inside of a perfume bottle

If you go to any American music festival, chances are you'll find someone in a homemade bib, as they are called, singing from the crowd. If such a performer turns up during a festival in Belgium, however, it's not their fault; they are literally performing from the crowd. A team of international musicians formed at the same time as the festival, who have been called the bib-bearers. They form their part of their project through a process called 'bibbeating'. This means they run down the festival grounds yelling their songs to get people to join them. They make their presence known before the final bands play. They use their body and voice to give a clear message to the crowd, and to keep their audience awake and thinking. Bibbearers are so popular the festival organisers have had to adapt, allowing them to sing from the crowd too. The team, which have been travelling the world, make their presence known earlier in their performance to get the crowd as inked with the words 'we've been together for 24 hours'. At the end, the final band performs in front of the bib bearers, who hold a massive sign to the crowd. At this festival, the bib bearers were given a big stage and the team held a sign that read 'we sang 24 hours' in the middle of the stage. This allowed the bib bearers to come full circle, coming to the end of their performance and giving the audience an even clearer message - that they were really in the same band, as they all had 24 hours together at the same time. It was a perfect end to a perfect show. Bibbearers are not all about the songs though. The bib bearers are also known for singing messages from the audience. A bib bearer at this one in New York, for example, sang this message of solidarity "We will get through this". It is also not the first time they have performed at the same festival - they have performed at festivals in Austria, Canada, Germany, Japan, and the United States. They also hold their own shows during festivals in these countries.

A day after the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) officially confirmed Russia has applied to join the treaty-based treaty-making bodies, India, India on Monday announced it will support Russian application to join the WIPO. © REUTERS / Sergey Ilnitsky Russia's UN Diplomacy a Big Success - Putin WIPO's General Council is expected to set a date for the vote. While it hasn't been formally agreed, the move will see Russia, a country which has historically been an ally of India, becoming a member of the treaty-based international organisations. "India has always supported Russia in its efforts to strengthen international law. We believe that joining the World Intellectual Property Organisation will improve our bilateral relations. India will support Russia's application and look forward to further expanding mutual cooperation," Minister of State (Independent Charge) for Commerce & Industry Nirmala Sitharaman said as reported by IANS. The move comes soon after Russia's diplomatic mission in India said that India's support for the move would "bring about positive outcomes" for international law and development. The treaty-based WTO, which is made up of 34 member countries and China, which itself is a signatory of the treaty, has been at loggerheads with the United States, which is not a member, over the way it interprets international trade norms. The dispute arose after U.S. Trade Representative Michael Froman in 2011 told the WIPO's members that the United States was not seeking to replace WTO membership but would work to expand its participation, with the aim of creating a more level playing field between countries. On that count, India has also stood by Russia. "We take note of the U.S. administration's official statement in favor of WTO membership for Russia. This should help to pave the way for the future development of WIPO. India-Russia cooperation and cooperation in the WTO will definitely help us to further our development," India's Deputy Minister of State (Independent Charge) for Trade, Satellite Services and Shipping, K.T. Mohanty said in a statement.

For the past three years, the Federal Reserve has used an interest rate of just 0.25 percent to fund financial companies that do business in the US. Most of this money has gone into buying assets — essentially, US government bonds — that are bought and sold by hedge funds, private equity companies, and other money market speculators. But in July, President Barack Obama used his executive authority to change how the Fed lends to financial companies. The Fed's $85 billion-a-month fund would pay interest only on deposits (i.e. savings accounts) that are made in the fund. The Federal Reserve's two million member banks will no longer have access to the fund and will not get the Fed's interest payments to be used for lending services. Banks will get only a fraction of their deposits through the new interest rate for their deposits. It's a huge blow to the US banking system, that's for sure. It's a shame that the bank bailout, or financial derivatives reform, is not an immediate priority for the White House. It's a shame that in an era of austerity, the Obama administration is forcing the private sector to subsidize an entire industry that generates jobs for some of the poorest people in America. But is this the real problem? Or do the actions of the president matter more? Banks have been trying for years to get rid of the fed funds rate as a way to make it cheaper for them to make loans. This is partly a result of the Fed's efforts to keep rates low — to ensure that it doesn't force banks to make risky loans that might blow up. But in addition, it has become increasingly clear that there is only one way banks make loans: by creating credit. These loans are then used to buy assets — usually commercial real estate. For banks, this is a big payoff — it means that if they want to maintain control of the American economy, they need to control the US credit market. The idea was that by making commercial real estate more difficult to buy, banks would have less incentive to make risky loans to new borrowers. But the Fed is now cutting off the supply of funds that banks can create. The Fed's action has a large impact on asset prices. People who can't get deposits are worried and sell off their stocks and bonds. This pushes the prices up, and those who can now afford stocks and real estate see their values go up. But everyone else (who can afford to hold cash, as well as other assets) sees prices fall — causing them to sell off their stocks as well. So the Fed is making a huge difference in how the American economy functions. But it is also making a huge difference in the amount of wealth the American middle class receives through their savings accounts. The Fed's action is forcing bank depositors and bank shareholders to start to worry, and these financial market players will decide that it's time to hold off on a big purchase. Their fears are justified: the Fed's recent actions are pushing US stocks lower. There is certainly a case that the Federal Reserve should do more. Banks don't need a rate of interest for a few months of credit to fund their operations. As we've written, the Fed doesn't have to set the interest rate below the natural rate of interest; it simply decides to do so when it believes that inflation is low enough. And in the long run, if the US central bank does raise interest rates, financial investors will adjust. What's happening now may not get fixed as quickly as the Fed would like, but it's not the end of the world. And it may not be the end of the economy. But there will come a point where the Fed has to decide whether it wants to support an economy that is losing more than 5 million Americans each month and is being decimated by job loss. Is it worth forcing the American worker to carry financial debt he doesn't need if there is some chance that his job will be lost tomorrow? Is it worth using inflation (which the Fed doesn't want to do because it would force it to raise rates) as an excuse to cut rates if wages are stagnant and workers are losing their jobs? And for this reason, a lot of economic policy wonks are saying that it's time for the Fed to raise rates.

The most famous (and hated) of British monarchs by all but a handful of his subjects, George III was an imposing figure, one of only three British male Heads of State (along with George IV and James VI) until the birth of Queen Elizabeth II in 1952. Born in 1757 to a wealthy British family, George III believed he was destined to follow in the footsteps of his father in politics and government. His mother died in childbirth, and he was soon sent to the prestigious East India Company School where he studied military strategy under Admiral Lord Nelson. Upon leaving the British military, when he was 22, he traveled to the American colonies, where he learned to grow and smoke tobacco, and to be an expert in navigation. ADVERTISEMENT Thanks for watching! Visit Website In 1780, at the age of 26, he was elected king's adviser on ships (a position which saw him spend hours studying maps and surveying for naval engagements), then, in 1786, he was made second in charge of the East India Company. In 1789 he married Elizabeth Mountbatten, the wealthy daughter of Lord Mountbatten, the head of the British government, and they had six sons between 1789 and 1792; George III grew up with his two younger brothers, William III (1791–1814), and George IV (1793–1860), both of whom would grow to rule the British realm from their grandfather's position as king. As the son of two monarchs, George III was heir apparent, and he proved himself as a great and ambitious administrator. He founded the House of Hanover in 1791, the first foreign power to reside in the royal capital of London, and made sure the new kingdom could afford both a royal palace and the most advanced naval fleets in Europe. A favorite son, he won the public's goodwill by establishing a system of state religion, encouraging British immigrants to become citizens, building the first public library in the British Isles, and establishing the modern British postal service. He was also a great patron of art, design, sports, dancing, and drama, and his son and grandsons became prominent members of all three of these fields. George III had several mistresses, two of whom, including the first English woman painter, John Constable, became popular celebrities. When his elder son Prince George, only fourteen at the time, was killed in a duel by a member of the American revolutionaries in 1781, George III was widely condemned for his role in what many historians now regard as a foolish and unnecessary battle. Still, when he died in 1799, his kingdom seemed secure. He was succeeded by his grandson, King George IV and his favorite son, George V, which made the era known as the 'Golden Age' of the British monarch. ADVERTISEMENT Thanks for watching! Visit Website

The following is a guest post by James Meehan, who is the CEO of the National Catholic Reporter and the editor, along with Tom De Wever, of the Catholic News Service. In an op-ed published on April 12th, The Wall Street Journal's Bret Stephens attacked Pope Francis' advocacy of "the idea of mercy." He called, "one of the pope's most controversial views, mercy, is being undermined in the Catholic Church—by the leaders of its hierarchy, and, for that matter, by the church's own bishops." To explain and amplify my argument for why mercy was important in the life of Jesus, I have come here to offer the following reflections on his words. I have chosen to use the same phrase used by St. Francis of Assisi in the Sermon on the Mount to describe Jesus in Revelation, "God's Goodness manifested." I have used both the Latin word for mercy and the English word "mercy" because both have historical origin as the English translation of the Latin word, merce, which appears in several well-known biblical texts, but especially in Leviticus, where it is used in the Hebrew Bible, the New Testament, and the Book of Revelation from the Catholic Church. This usage comes to us from the Greek word, kataki. While the Hebrew word for it is in the singular, while the Latin is in the plural. Kataki means "the offering of God for our sins" [1] and when translated correctly, both are the same word. In the Greek and Latin, a verb must be found to translate the word, though. The translators of Revelation have not simply translated the word kataki for mercy—they have changed the meaning of the word itself. Jesus Christ is the offering, merchein katakyon, which in Greek means the offering, mercy of God. Christ is the one who offers mercy for us, his only begotten Son, to offer us the fullness of God. The Word of God is "that mercy, the which God hath before ordained, to be received by faith. [2]" That mercy is indeed given, not of men, but rather by God. It is God himself that gives mercy, who is mercy itself, "who also quickeneth [katakos] the dead, and calleth to the things which are above, even him that sitteth upon the throne, who is in heaven" (Rev. 3:17). God has not only "mercy" for his people, but mercy for all men. This is the mercy of God revealed in his only begotten Son. The word merciful, in Greek, means "loving." A mercy for an instant but a merciful God over time. "For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life." [3] In this passage of Scripture, Jesus is calling God, who is merciful, a loving Father. What is the Church's attitude toward the word of God? This scripture describes it. And he told them, "I am the voice of one sent forth from the Father, with the words 'Go, and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit,' and teaching them that they may be blessed. [4] As if to say, "What has been given to Father does not belong to your children until they are born." The Church has a special and different relationship with the mercy of God. To be merciful means to be loving. We must, therefore, be merciful toward our church through love and the teachings we share. In the early church, even as they spoke of God as a Father who gave himself in love for all men, they expressed a strong sense of justice for them. "O how richly they are, but how unjustly impoverished!" [5] They held the Church to be "our Mother, Who for us men and women, who for us Christ's Body, is our Mother" (Mt. 10:4). Today, however, we hear a similar call from St. Francis when he says we should "be merciful to everyone, just as a merciful Father loves the children he has given and not the people he has given them to." [6] That does not mean to be indifferent to the sins of others—on the contrary, it means to love them, to "be kind to all men." What is the Church's attitude toward the mercy of God? The Catholic Church has not only a special relationship with the mercy of God—it is the mercy itself. "It is not the man who is most directly merciful, but God who is most directly merciful. And in His own way God is

You know how in a romantic comedy, the bride and her suitors arrive in the middle of the night to surprise the groomsman, just in time to be woken up by the sounds and smells of his bed? In a post-apocalyptic world, these same characters would probably arrive to welcome a certain someone they're in love with, while she's away. A couple in Russia took to Facebook to inform their Facebook friends that they'd arrived at their destination at dawn because the weather's perfect. The event has since been dubbed the "Sleeping Beauty" problem after the image of a princess and her husband coming to a sleeping beauty's rescue.  Advertisement The idea for the joke began when a couple in the Russian city of Ulan-Ude shared the image on their Facebook page. Although it's technically a joke, the photo has since been viewed more than 13,000 times, and in less than three days, it's gone viral. The joke isn't going unnoticed, however. The photo was also picked up by other social media outlets, like The Daily Dot and The Huffington Post, but has also been shared on a variety of forums and forums around the web. Advertisement This new type of post-apocalyptic romance is a very weird thing to have a lot of followers for, as you'd expect. Some users are also not in on the joke.

The White House on Monday was asked to respond to President Barack Obama's claim in his weekly radio and news magazine address that America needs to "rebuild" its military before it's too late to prevent another 9/11-style attack. Obama, who was in California this weekend for a Democratic fundraiser, discussed his new proposals for curbing gun violence following last month's terrorist attacks in Paris that killed 129 people along with French President Francois Hollande. In the address — broadcast on Friday — Obama also blasted the Republican-controlled Congress, arguing at one point that "it cannot be that some of our military, some of our most precious resources, are not even being used to keep us safe." "We're not allowed to kill people any longer because we don't want to kill people. We have to rebuild our military," Obama said in the address. "We haven't used the military to keep us safe. We have to rebuild it." He added the following statement: If we're serious about defending ourselves and our allies, we've got to do more to support local law enforcement, and ensure they have the tools they need to investigate, disrupt and catch violent terrorists before they strike. White House press secretary Josh Earnest responded Monday to Obama's statement. "I don't know where the president was going with that particular piece of rhetoric," Earnest said. "I think it would be helpful if we had it laid out for him, or if someone could give him an update as to what was actually being done by the military, given to local law enforcement, as to what it's looking like and what kind of threat there actually is from ISIL and from other extremist elements." Earnest said the president was simply talking about the cost of war in terms of lost lives. "You heard the president talk about how he wants to restore our military capabilities, and I think he's exactly correct. It's not because he thinks that military capabilities are always necessary," Earnest said. "I think a little bit of context is needed. When he talks about the costs of fighting and preventing another terrorist attack, he's not talking about just military costs. He's talking about the costs of having those kinds of attacks happening anywhere, anywhere in the world." The Obama administration has been taking a cautious approach to the Islamic State group as it continues to lose territory to the fighters. The group's territory in Iraq has shrunk to less than 50 miles from the capital Baghdad, and a United Nations report released in August said that ISIS's leaders have abandoned their Iraqi stronghold because of attacks mounted by the Iraqi government. Obama did, however, warn the group, which has also claimed the attack in Paris on the satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, about "the dangers of terrorism." "We will not be intimidated or dissuaded by despicable attempts to target innocents. We will stop you. Period," Obama said on Friday at the end of his speech in San Francisco. "The entire American government is working as hard as we can to protect the American people. And we will continue to do it." Fox News' Jennifer Griffin, Bill Mears and The Associated Press contributed to this report.

This is part two of one interview with former Vice President Joe Biden. In the first part of this interview, published January 15, Vice President Biden talked about his decision to step out of the 2016 presidential race. This interview, published today, is a follow-up to our first one, published November 11, 2016. Presidential historian Arthur Schlesinger Jr. said in 1992: "In politics of any kind, there comes a moment when the party has gone too far the other way." This time, it's no wonder Democrats and former President Barack Obama are facing significant internal pressure in the Democratic Party to distance themselves from former vice president Joe Biden, now a U.S. senator from Delaware. That being said, there are some significant reasons not to distance the left from Biden. Indeed, if Biden were ever to run for president, he would likely run in the Democratic primary. While we still prefer Clinton as the candidate of the left in this election, this might actually serve Democratic interests for the party. The current Democratic Party leadership will not make a "Joe Biden" candidacy possible—and if they did, it would not be a very good sign for the party. In order to defeat Donald Trump, Democratic leaders will need to keep as much distance as possible so that they would have a way to take him down after the election in 2020. Therefore, the current Democratic leaders need a strong and charismatic candidate to take on Trump, and a guy like Biden might be this candidate. For his part, Biden still sees a way to reach out to Trump's base and win with these issues. His most important message is not just about Trump, but about an America-first economic policy centered on free trade. "If you have a president willing to say to the people who he doesn't know who 'you're going to be left standing after I'm gone,' that's a pretty powerful message," he told the Wall Street Journal. This would be a key part of how Biden's presidency would succeed, not just in rebranding the right and the Democratic Party from Hillary Clinton to Bernie Sanders to Elizabeth Warren, but in showing the country that change is still possible. But as the former vice president said "There's an enormous amount of anger [among] white working-class voters that has to be managed and harnessed. A large role that I see myself playing is taking that anger out to where it's about jobs." Biden will go up against the Democratic Party establishment on his left, who have largely aligned behind Clinton and, according to a Politico/Morning Consult polling report, are more "likely than not" to oppose his candidacy. In addition, Biden will go up against former President Barack Obama, who seems uninterested in running for his former job, which may be in part why he's making no effort at rebranding after the 2016 elections. Nevertheless, Biden is one of the most popular Democrats in the country, is a popular speaker, and he's just gotten some new momentum in his reelection bid in Delaware. His endorsement by the former Massachusetts Governor and fellow Democrat, and longtime party member and former United Nations Ambassador, Deval Patrick, has proven very popular, and as a result there are many Democrats who are interested in finding a way to keep Biden in the fold. That being said, the current state of the Democratic Party means there may not be a real chance for Biden to win the nomination, but he might not be out of the game for long if he were to run. What does Biden want to do in the United States political scene once he retired? There's definitely some overlap in his priorities when he ran for the U.S. Senate against incumbent Richard Blumenthal, for the New Hampshire seat. Both Biden and Blumenthal are also big supporters of the American Health Care Act, which could give them some clout within the Democratic Party should Biden decide to run for president someday.

A group headed by U.S. billionaire businessman and Republican megadonor Charles Koch wants to influence the 2016 campaign by promoting a pro-free market message, particularly to younger voters, according to documents filed with the Federal Election Commission. A memo from one of the group's top officials to other top officials, filed Friday with the FEC, lays out a policy of "economic freedom agenda" for future campaigns. The initiative is a nod to the Koch's own economic freedom policy, which has led the donor network's political operation to develop a more centrist strategy in recent years. It could be a signal that the libertarian wing of the conservative movement is poised to take on higher-profile roles in national politics. The group, called Freedom Partners, is headed by senior vice-presidential candidate Tim Phillips, who was recently appointed by Koch to be president of Americans for Prosperity-Florida, a super PAC that's spent much of the past decade on the state and national stage. The plan appears to be part of a broader push under the Trump administration to bring conservative ideology under the direct control of Republicans, as the GOP tries to regain its footing and regain voter support after its failed bid to repeal the Affordable Care Act. "Trump campaigned and promised to repeal and replace ObamaCare. The public deserves a president who can deliver on that promise. The Republicans now have a chance to show the public the power of conservative principles and deliver on that promise," said Koch network vice-president for policy Marjorie Dannenfelser. The memo, signed by Phillips and distributed to Koch network officials from across the country, was first reported by Politico and The Wall Street Journal. The plan calls for the groups involved in the initiative to "create a daily campaign that will help Americans understand why the freedom agenda is the best for their families." One of its key policy objectives is the promotion of the free enterprise system, particularly for millennials. In particular, it wants to promote "economic Freedom Index scores" that measure the U.S. economy by looking at "economic freedom index rankings," "pro-growth economic policies" and "pro-market policies." The measure will be updated periodically, and will likely measure where the world's rich and poor countries stand. It also highlights the growth in the number of millionaires in the U.S. "For us, the index is a great way to understand what is happening in the world with our economy," Phillips said in an interview. "It's an objective and quantitative measure that allows us to understand which countries have the most free enterprise," he said referring to nations with low government regulations. Freedom Partners is also hoping to focus its efforts on the "right-to-work" bill, which was voted down in the Wisconsin Senate this week. Freedom Partners would support efforts to "make certain that right to work is included in any major national economic legislation," the memo says. The group intends to use the Freedom Index to build "a network of like-minded organizations and individuals who believe in economic freedom and believe it is good." "We intend to support and build this network to influence future legislation, to make sure that economic freedom is included as a principle in legislation and will advocate across the country for economic freedom," the memo says. The group has been expanding its political outreach in recent weeks and now claims more than 80 affiliates around the country. The memo goes on to say that the campaign is "focused on engaging the millennial generation and building networks." Koch network officials did not immediately respond for comment Friday.

The first time I heard of the U.S. "War on Drugs", it was in the context of Nixon's "reefer madness" campaign. I was living in New York in the early 1980s, and when my roommate bought a bong out of the mail, the state police raided our apartment because the drug paraphernalia was too "hardcore." I was incredulous and furious. As an African American teenager, I was also disgusted by the way young people in the hood had been targeted by the police for their music, clothes, and hair. However, as a young black male living in the Bay Area in the 1980s, I had no idea how this war — which had been raging at that moment of my life — affected me. As I grew up in New York and later in Los Angeles, I grew increasingly frustrated with the "war on drugs." It seemed hopeless — no one seemed to have the answers. As a young man, I felt that the police, the government, and all of America's institutions had failed me, and that the system was racist, classist, and homophobic. As I entered graduate school in social work, I struggled to explain why I was so troubled by the drug war. I came to the realization that the war on drugs is not just an effort to get addicts into treatment and jail. As a working class gay male, the war on drugs is also about my experience of class. On the day my father came out of the closet, my grandfather told me that being gay is a disease that affects the black men who love him, and that I am the cause of it. A week later, my father came out of the closet, and the media portrayed my father as the tragic victim of his sexuality. I was shocked at the hypocrisy, and my frustration was compounded when I discovered that my boyfriend at the time, who is White, was also gay, and this fact had no impact on the "war on drugs." To understand my anger, I spent the summer after my father's second coming out in Jamaica in 1990, where I listened to music from the 1960s and 1970s to learn about the history of Jamaican Jamaican gay culture. I learned that the Black Panthers are gay, and that homosexuality had always been viewed with fear and suspicion. I learned that the British Empire's homophobia was fueled by the fear that homosexuality will make people "fiscally more efficient," which translates to more government money. I read about the rise of the LGBT Movement in Jamaica, and the way it became the first country to legalize same-sex marriage and recognize trans rights. Jamaica became the first country to recognize same sex marriage by the 1990s, and trans people in Jamaica have never felt stigmatized or discriminated against. Jamaica's law, called the Jamaican Human Rights Act, is also the first international human rights law to specifically address discrimination on the basis of gender identity. In 2009, with the backing from the Jamaican government, the Human Rights Campaign (HRC), the most powerful LGBT organization in the United States, came to Jamaica to tour the country and engage in a series of local dialogues. The HRC's visit sparked an unprecedented discussion between LGBTQ Jamaicans, people of color, the White community, and other Jamaicans. At the end of the trip, several people called a meeting in the Queen's Club for Change in Kingston that was hosted by the Community of Jamaica. Two days of talks and discussion led to resolutions to the following issues: End discrimination against gays and lesbians within the Jamaican society. Eliminate the criminal penalty for same sex relationships. This will end the practice of "repenting the crime," where many gay and lesbian couples in Jamaica would have to face the stigma of being branded criminals. (Jamaicans currently face the threat of being executed if found guilty of "sodomy.") Criminalize consensual gay sex and human trafficking. End the stigma surrounding HIV/AIDS Progressive Laws for Men, Better Education, Better Welfare: The government of Jamaica has taken concrete steps to support gay rights. Despite a very backward legal system, gay and lesbian couples can now legally marry, and the government has implemented laws that give civil rights to transgender people. In 2009 Jamaica enacted the most progressive law regarding gender identity in the Caribbean and the Western hemispheres. This law is called the Jamaican Human Rights Act and gives protection to gender nonconforming and transgender people. The law was signed by Governor Sheila Clark, Jamaica's first openly gay female governor. The Jamaican government has also given its backing to the international Pink Dot celebration. Pink Dot is a global movement that uses Pink Dot, a beach near Singapore, to promote peace and gender equality. With the new laws in place, the government has given its support to the International Gay and Lesbian Human Rights Conference (IGLHRC) in Kingston. The Jamaica Gays and Lesbians Union is one of the founding members

LUCKNOW: The state government has started a survey on crime against women , looking at the crimes committed by men against women and whether it is a problem. The survey will be conducted within a year.The UP home department, acting on a petition from a woman journalist, had initiated the survey in August 2014, following which the state government passed an ordinance, making provisions for the study. "We will do the survey within a year, once we get some more data," said a government official. The official said it was planned to have a team of officials in each district and also a team of women in each local police station to implement the study."The survey will not only take all kinds of reports on crimes against women from the women who have come to us and reported them, but will also survey cases that were not reported. They will also collect the names of the culprits of the crimes," he added.The petition, filed by Prashant Bhushan, also said that since law and order measures by the chief minister's office had not seen any positive impact, the state government should also conduct a survey.A senior state home department official said that with Uttar Pradesh and other states having more women, there was a need to look at crime against women. "At least 10,000 rapes were reported in the past one year alone, but only 20 FIRs were registered in the past one month in the state. We want to ask what are the reasons behind the low number of police stations being constructed in the state?"The official said even though the law and order department had started several initiatives to help women at risk of crime, the police personnel are also not on the same page and this also resulted in incidents of women being attacked."Asking whether rape is a crime would be like the police asking why only four FIRs were registered in a year," said Bhushan. A lawyer, who had filed the petition, contended, "The survey will not only ask why are there fewer police stations, but also the number of such rape cases." He said the chief minister's office was taking the issue seriously and it was an attempt to create awareness among women about crime and how they need to take protection from it.

The state's highest court has rejected the argument by the state's attorney general that a law prohibiting transgender individuals from using public restrooms that align with their gender identity is required to comply with the U.S. Constitution. Earlier this month, Attorney General Maura Healey launched an aggressive public relations campaign urging the public and businesses to comply with Massachusetts' bathroom law, which imposes penalties of up to $500 or jail time for refusing to accommodate transgender people who seek to enter restrooms that match their gender identity. On Tuesday, Healey filed two separate lawsuits against a local grocery store chain and a woman's group seeking to invalidate the legislation. "The Massachusetts Constitution prohibits government from imposing gender-based discrimination ... on any person or business," Chief Justice Leigh Saufley wrote in one of the first two decisions rejecting the arguments from the attorney general. The state's Constitution "has been interpreted to protect against public policies that penalize private conduct," she wrote. Advertisement But in a second decision, Saufley turned down Healey's request to issue a preliminary injunction in her first suit. Get Fast Forward in your inbox: Forget yesterday's news. Get what you need today in this early-morning email. Sign Up Thank you for signing up! Sign up for more newsletters here The women's group had made similar complaints against Healey and the attorney general's office. The group had tried unsuccessfully to force the secretary of public safety's office to stop enforcing the state's law prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sex in employment. The office agreed to stop enforcing the law against the supermarket chain and its parent corporation in a settlement reached last year. Healey's office has said the law protects women and children from sexual predators seeking private areas where they could molest them. The law was enacted after legislators heard complaints from women of what they said were a disproportionate number of reports of sexual assault in women's restrooms and dressing rooms by men who were seeking to harass them. But a judge dismissed Healey's lawsuit against the Boston chapter of the National Organization for Women, calling the attorney general's argument "ludicrous." Advertisement Judge Robert B. King said Healey's office "has never advanced a legitimate interest in this case." He declined to issue an injunction, finding that Hisaley had not met her burden to show the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits of their cases. "If you're going to make the argument that this is needed to protect women, then you must have evidence that the law is necessary to protect those women," King said. "And I haven't seen anything to suggest that any of the cases that you've named to be violators should be put in a situation where they are likely to be vulnerable to harm." Healey's office has said the law protects women and children from sexual predators seeking private areas where they could molest them. The governor issued a statement calling the rulings a "victory for privacy and public safety." The attorney general is "in court trying to rewrite Massachusetts' bathroom regulations by the back door," the statement noted. David Scharfenberg can be reached at david.scharfenberg@globe.com

The two biggest US tech companies, Google and Facebook, have come under fire for paying "hundreds of millions" of dollars to US law-enforcement agencies, reports revealed this week. The National Security Agency and FBI are reportedly among the companies that have reportedly paid for access to people's personal data through the so-called Prism program. But Google is widely considered the most powerful of the two firms, partly because Google provides information to users on how to access the company's own services without compromising personal data. It was last month that the Guardian revealed how the government used data from the company's data centres to track the movements of tens of millions of citizens without a warrant. And after the revelations earlier in March were made, it emerged that the US National Security Agency (NSA), also known as the "Big Brother" or "Big Sister" of the US, had been paying more than $800 million (£450 million) of taxpayer money per year to a secret data-mining company, apparently exclusively working for the spy agency. The news broke last month and, thanks mostly to a leak from NSA whistleblower Edward Snowden, made the headlines. Facebook, meanwhile, paid $10 million (£6.5 million) to the NSA between 2011 and 2013 to make sure the internet giant was not targeted by terrorists because it uses its own servers to store user data. The Guardian claims the $10 million payment included an additional $2.3 million (£1.3 million) that was a "direct contribution from the US government". A separate payment of $600,000 (£386,837) in July 2012 followed the initial "contribution" that brought the total amount to $11 million (£7.4 million). But the latest reports suggest that the total figure may be much, much higher. According to the Wall Street Journal, US government agencies have come under pressure to disclose the details of the surveillance and law-enforcement agencies have also reportedly requested to spend more time in the company's data centres. "The amount they spend on these services is astonishing," one former government official said. "It's a billion-dollar industry, it's not rocket science." But while Google and Facebook are able to afford to hire more staff, the firms have come under harsh criticism after a number of scandals involving government access to data through their services. A report in 2010 revealed that the NSA used a program called Boundless Informant to track the emails of tens of millions of users across Facebook, Google and Yahoo for the agency. It also emerged that the data-mining company had conducted surveillance on private relationships between American citizens and a range of companies in order to give the spy agency insight into how to best target suspected terrorists. In the wake of the deadly attacks in the French capital by jihadists, France's largest Muslim group has demanded an end to "hatred" but said it remained "confident" police would crack down on a rising tide of homegrown terrorism. "No one likes a terrorist, but no one can justify [terror]," said spokesman Kam el-Chantiry. He added: "We cannot allow ourselves to be driven by hate to commit attacks against people whose faces we have already seen." France, currently home to about 5 million Muslims, has suffered a series of attacks by Islamist militants this year, including suicide bombings in Paris on Friday that left 130 people dead. Get The Times of Israel's Daily Edition by email and never miss our top stories Free Sign Up The violence has coincided with the arrival of tens of thousands of migrants fleeing war-ravaged Syria, with some of them heading to France, seeking asylum. Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve is expected on Friday to announce plans for tougher checks on those seeking asylum from Syria, where several jihadists are believed to have trained and fought. The group Muslim Star, which describes itself as "the largest umbrella organization of Muslims in France," said on Tuesday it was worried, but not shocked, about terrorism. The group's leader, Grand Imam Hassane Meschaoui, urged Muslims to cooperate with anti-terror forces in France. "It's obvious that it is the nature of the times, but we are certain that our brothers will continue their fight and will prevail!" he said in a statement. "France has been a target in the past of several attacks in which Muslim citizens fought at the side of terrorists," said Meschaoui, who heads the Grand Mosque of Paris (La Marseillaise). "We are also certain that we are going to face a rising tide of attacks in the near future," he added. He also said that France needed to be more discriminating in the ways it selects refugees "to ensure not only the security of [the] citizens but also the religious identity of our young people." Many Muslim groups in France have repeatedly urged authorities to be more accommodating of migrants, as well as to do more to fight Islamophobia. On Tuesday, Meschaoui also addressed a rally in support of French President Francois Hollande. "It's very painful that they are calling him an Islamist. He is not, he's a president. He has made sacrifices for every citizen in the country. He is responsible to all of us, Muslims as individuals and Muslims as a community," Meschaoui said. "He has declared jihad to save France," he said of Hollande, who has come under fire from far-right and nationalist groups for being too cozy with the Muslim community. He also addressed the issue of security. "It's very clear that we're going to face an increase in terrorist threats and that our country's security is very fragile," he said. "The war on terror doesn't just take place on the front lines. The entire world, our brothers and sisters in Syria, Iraq, Libya, Afghanistan, Cameroon, Palestine, Eritrea and Somalia all need to work harder against terrorism and we need to make sure that we're part of the solution rather than the problem." Meschaoui was speaking in support of an anti-terrorism law that would allow authorities to track and punish French citizens who travel to fight abroad to join Islamist fighters, including in Syria. The proposed law would give the authorities sweeping powers to monitor citizens and to revoke passports. The proposed legislation comes as France continues to battle its deadliest terror attacks since World War II. The attacks, claimed by the so-called Islamic State group, began late in the day on Friday with a suicide bombing at the Stade de France sports stadium. Two attacks followed within a week, the first at the office of the satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo and the second in an attack on the Jewish supermarket in Paris. The French authorities identified the two suspected terrorists as radicalized French nationals, who had links to Islamic State jihadists in Syria. One of the two attackers was shot by security forces and killed. On Saturday, two assailants, one from Morocco and the other from Algeria, killed a police officer and a civilian outside the city of Montrouge and injured 11 people in a possible reprisal for Friday's attack in Paris. In the city of Tours on Sunday, about 30 people were wounded as two attackers opened firing on a police station on Thursday night, injuring four people. France has suffered over 100 terror attacks so far this year, of which 86 have been by jihadists.

HUNTSVILLE, Alabama – The City of Huntsville recently took the first step toward putting solar panels on its water main system. The move will eliminate nearly $3 million in operating expenses for the system and provide a new source of funding for the city's aging infrastructure. Plans for the system are estimated at $2.3 million and will bring energy to Huntsville homes and businesses, the mayor has said. That funding will pay for approximately 65 percent of the upfront costs, including installation, financing and regulatory fees, and can be used for projects within the Greater Huntsville Water Company boundary, according to an August 2 news release from the Huntsville Utilities Agency. It is important to note that the city of Huntsville still needs to obtain approval from the city council to install solar panels on utility poles. The energy generated from the system will be used to provide electricity to city buildings, said the release. The city is funding the project with $225,000 in matching funds from city utilities, the release said. The remaining $1.6 million will come from a "community development fund," the release stated. (The mayor has said he will use some of that money to start working on his city's new police headquarters.) The release also stated that city of Huntsville employees and contractors will be using panels and other equipment to keep an eye on the service lines. City utility spokesman Bill Jones said this is the city's first use of renewable energy to power municipal utility projects. He said previous projects have included solar panels on the roof of the city fire station and solar panels on the exterior of the city offices. "We've had some success at putting panels on utility poles," he said. "The next step will be to install them on the poles around the city." The city, along with the Greater Huntsville Water Company, are working together on the project, Jones said. "We're excited about it." The water main project is scheduled to be completed sometime between late June and early July, Jones added. The news release and the announcement made to the media came in Huntsville City Council's Tuesday night meeting. The topic of the meeting revolved around the city's "Sustainable Energy and Greening" plan, a long-term sustainability goals statement. According to the release: The plan is a long-term strategic vision for the City's future. It lays out a long-term vision for sustainability that will be implemented in multiple disciplines, from land-use and permitting to municipal operations and building codes to community services. The plan calls for the development of sustainable infrastructure, strategies and strategies that address and mitigate the effects of increased urbanization and rapid demographic change, such as a greater reliance on automobiles. It seeks to create a more sustainable environment for residents, businesses, the arts and the natural environment, such as by reducing reliance on solid, fossil fuel-based fuel energy sources and creating more sustainable transportation options. It also seeks to minimize the impact of the energy supply and use by all levels of city government, and will help to ensure that energy sources that benefit community members are used by the city. According to the release, the city has a goal of sourcing 90 percent of its electricity from renewable green energy sources by 2050. Currently, it sources about 20 percent of its electricity from electricity from renewable sources. But it is unclear if the new system announced Tuesday will meet that goal, Jones said. The city has long wanted to develop more renewable sources of energy to help meet energy sustainability goals, Jones said. For example, the city was able to acquire 50 acres of land south of U.S. 60 that is currently undeveloped. That land will allow the city to develop a 50 million square foot city complex. Once completed, the city will have 4,900 multifamily units from which to draw energy. The city has also discussed the possibility of converting the U.S. 60 bridge over the Mobile River into a pedestrian and bicycle access corridor, Jones said. To learn more about the new plan for the city's renewable energy portfolio, check out the announcement on the city's website, cityofhuntsville.com. The Huntsville Water Company is the city's electric utility. As a subsidiary company of the Huntsville Utilities Agency, the company has been in business since 1925 and serves approximately 35,000 customers, including approximately 7,000 in the City of Huntsville and approximately 16,000 in Madison County. The Greater Huntsville Water Company provides water and wastewater service on the City of Huntsville and Madison County boundaries in the Greater Huntsville area. It is one of the largest water and wastewater utilities in North America.

A Florida man who got rid of a bag full of cocaine and heroin that he thought was a Halloween decoration instead found 15 grams of meth and a half-gram of cocaine. Police found the heroin and meth while searching a car that had just passed through the Port St. Lucie area. They say 33-year-old Juan Carlos Rodriguez-Ruiz, a construction worker from Fort Pierce, was in possession of a container full of drugs in his truck. Police say this isn't a criminal case, but a drug task force operation. And they say it's not uncommon for cops to find the items in the cars of drug dealers. Port St. Lucie police say they're trying to keep the operation a little closer to home -- with patrols, at least once a week.

Killer whale calves on the coast of Canada's east coast have been spotted for the first time since 2015, according to a team of scientists from the British Columbia Ministry of Environment and Parks, the Canadian Wildlife Service and the University of British Columbia. The researchers released photos taken by an underwater robot called SeaX-MP-2, which operated in the waters of the Gulf of Georgia, the Gulf of Georgia Bight and the Canadian Arctic Coast. BONUS: A Giant Killer Whale Breaks Through the Waves at the Miami Beach Pier The team says that in the past six months, they've seen "some of the very rare, young black and white orcas born at an unusually young age, and they appear to have been in good health." They also say that the whales showed strong mother-calf social bonds, which "may offer insight as to why the animals' numbers are currently still declining." "The findings are important," said Dr. Michael Smith, one of the team members. "We've seen these animals at lower numbers for many years, and we need to understand just how important these orcas are to our fisheries."

In an article titled, "Can It Be Done?", he writes:  It's actually much easier to write the whole thing this way. Write a very small function. (At most, about one line in length.) Write a very compact method. This will make it easier for you to move the function onto a separate line. And, even better, if you're a good programmer, you'll be able to move it into a separate function or method, leaving just the method as an outermost call, so that the whole thing looks like one step. So don't try to do the whole thing this way. But if you're an advanced programmer, maybe try doing an outermost method first and then doing a step. After that you will be a lot more comfortable doing it this way. It's not difficult to understand the implications, but I was surprised by how often people write this way. (Is it because it's easier?) So I figured I should write an article explaining it, because I think this is a topic that should be explained, and because it's fun to see how it can be done wrong, but it's much more elegant to write the way you write it when you want to. OK. Lets start from the top: First, lets consider some very simple function that calculates the x% of each row and the y% of each column. Let's call this function p , where p is the x% and p^ is the y% : function p%(x, y) if x < 0 return -x elseif x > 0 return x * (1/x) / y else return 0 end We can now generate a nice table using the p% function, which can easily be found here: function p%(x, y) rows = {"A"=>2, "B"=>1.4, "C"=>.9}, cols = {"A"=>2.4, "B"=>1.25, "C"=>.3}} print "%dx: %dt", p%(x,y,1) end What I want to do now, is create a small function that takes each row and produces the corresponding column: function pcol(r1, r2) if r1 == 0 then r1 = r2 end if r1 > 0 then return row(r2, #r1) end if r2 < 0 then return col(r1, #r1) end length = pcol(:row(1,:col(1,:row(2,:col(2,:col(1,:)))))), 2) end The first thing I want to do is understand how to call the row function, even though the resulting table appears quite long. Here's how I would start with my own implementation, without knowing anything about the inner workings of row . function pcol([row_a, col_a]) p.row(row_a, col_a) end That's fine. But how do I call row that doesn't take an argument? function row(row_a, col_a) if col_a > 0 then row_a[col_a] + row_a[col_a-1] * col_a end end That might be OK, but I might as well be able to pass by value so that I could make rows just as big as my original, non-row functions. Then I come across the following code. I don't seem to be able to use an outermost call like pcol . To see why, consider a table a . b is the column in table a: table.a table.b I use the b column in my pcol call to calculate the y% column: pcol(:row(1,:col(1,:row(2,:col(1,:))))) This is certainly not the most elegant way to call row , since it has to start off with two outermost calls! The correct way to call row is actually to create a function that works as row itself, without the need to start off with three callers. The idea is to start off as a simple outermost call like pcol , then create a function for each column in table a . If you have to use the outermost call, you're probably asking for trouble. You don't need to know whether or not you can pass that argument to the inner calls, only that you can use a method on the same callable object. Let's create these inner calls now, so that we can use them in our pcol call. We first create another function called row_contents on the call to pcol with an argument for the output column: row_contents(#x) row_cont

Trevor Timm The year is 2011. The first-person-shooter genre, the one where you use your brain, not your guns, to take down all-comers, is booming. On the other side of the pond, Call of Duty: World at War is coming out. It's a sequel to the game that revolutionized the first-person shooter. The best shooter in history, it's still the best. In both cases, the original shooters have spawned a number of imitators, which make the original look like a bad movie. But with Call of Duty 2, the sequel to the best FPS of all time, the developers have created more than a better follow-up. They've created an evolution of the genre—a sequel to the greatest ever. The sequel to Call of Duty 2 is the year's most successful game. By any measure, it is a revolutionary blockbuster. The graphics are stunning. There are three protagonists, all unique and engaging, and their decisions affect how the game unfolds. In the space of about 20 minutes, you can experience a variety of emotions. The plot turns on the actions of a single character, but the game's narrative twists and turns so frequently (and so expertly, in comparison to other video games) that you lose track of who's the hero and who's the villain. The multiplayer is also spectacularly designed and engaging. All the different weapons make for different types of gameplay. Every multiplayer match feels like a different puzzle to solve. If a game's plot and setting are its key selling points, then Call of Duty 2 manages to sell those strengths to one's mind, body, and soul very well. The plot, by the way, is as much of an original idea as its gameplay. (That first game ended, not with victory, but with an epilogue of betrayal—and, most often, death.) This sequel keeps you guessing about who the hero is. The villain is as interesting (and as evil as ever) as the hero. And that's just the first game. Call of Duty 2 is a sprawling, multi-character tale set in the world of the First Gulf War. The characters are all memorable, which is a great accomplishment. Even the ones who don't get too much screen time get enough of it: the gruff-talking sniper that seems to know exactly when and where to shoot to kill, the silent, stoic sniper that is often the first to spot the sniper, the guy in an Israeli tank (a tank that has more guns than a Volkswagen bug). The only one we didn't see at all was the smart-mouthed computer genius, and his role was cut way, way short. It wouldn't have been surprising.

A group of five men are recovering from bullet wounds following a shooting Thursday on the South Side of Chicago. NBC 5's Natalie Martinez reports (Published Friday, May 21, 2015) A group of five men are recovering from bullet wounds following reports of gunshots at a barber shop at 6401 N. Sheffield Ave. in the city's North Austin neighborhood on the South Side. Officials at Advocate Illinois Mason Medical Center said all five males are in stable condition and that they were shot in the head, left shoulder and upper back. One was grazed in the head by a bullet. Chicago police detectives are investigating the shooting, which was reported at about 5:30 p.m. The men, age 16, 17, 25, 28 and 43, were walking to the shop, where all attend North Austin High School, when they were confronted by a group of men in a white car, police said. The driver, who has not been identified, pulled out a gun and began firing, striking the five men. "People were in the barber shop when they heard gunshots and a car drive by so they ran out," said one of the victims. "Everybody was crying. One of the guys that was shot had a big hole in his head." He added that the car also sped away as they walked outside the shop. The driver took off after the shooting.

LONDON, May 8 (Reuters) - The price of petrol and diesel prices may fall later this summer due to the high UK government subsidies given to fuel retailers, the Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis (IEEFA) said on Thursday. A customer pays for an oil pump outside a petrol station in Harrogate March 24 last year. REUTERS/Toby Melville The U.S.-based think tank said in a report that fuel retailers will have a lower profit margin but higher revenues as subsidy costs are passed on to customers. "We expect the retail fuel price to fall by around 2.8 pounds per litre in July due to a combination of lower refinery costs and fuel subsidy costs," the report said. While prices for home heating are likely to rise following the reduction in subsidies in April 2015, the IEEFA forecast that petrol and diesel car prices will average $1.11 per litre in the summer this year, down from the $1.26/litre they were at this time last year. A report published earlier this year said the government would cut fuel duty by about 70 percent from 2020 in an effort to help drive down the price of fuel.

There's only one person you should worry about: yourself. That's what a new experiment out of Yale suggests. Researchers asked participants to think back on an activity in their lives, and then rate how much stress they felt from it. After doing so, the experimenters then ran a second experiment on how much stress participants felt afterward. When people gave themselves an ultimatum, they felt significantly less stress at the end. In some cases, the stress they felt was actually lowered. Meanwhile, when people forced themselves to respond on time, their stress levels spiked. That's the case for people who asked for help, too. The most severe ultimatums didn't work the best: They were followed by increased stress; in these cases, the participants ended up feeling less stressed after the ultimatum. Advertisement "The results of this experiment lend credence to the belief that ultimatums of any kind tend to have greater negative effects on the recipient, on self or on others," the researchers concluded. "Such ultimatums tend to exacerbate existing psychological problems and/or drive an increase in current psychological problems." It's important to note that this doesn't mean people were intentionally trying to cause stress. This is how psychological research works, so we don't know that in the study specifically. But the idea that taking on an ultimatum was the first step toward increasing stress and anxiety just makes sense. To give people advice on how to deal with stress (other than not taking requests), the authors recommend telling friends and lovers you'll take one last job offer (on an earlier date) before announcing if you've taken another. Advertisement All images: University of Arizona / University of Utah

Spencer Platt/Getty Images Former President Bill Clinton made headlines on Thursday morning after saying in a fundraising appeal that, since he exited the Oval Office last Friday, "everything's changed in this country." The news wasn't all positive for the current president, though; he added that he thought Trump's agenda would "destroy our country." "Trump's team's vision for our country is an impossible mission—one that will put us back 25 years on the pathway to the most unequal, most unfair economy and society in the world," Clinton said. "The people who live there deserve the things I was elected to protect and protect our nation deserves that. Everything's changed in this country since I left." Advertisement  "The election of Donald Trump has created a national emergency," Clinton added. "I will do everything I can to support our former president and work to protect the progress we've made and to make the world a better place for our kids and grandchildren, to do what I can to help him carry on that good work when he becomes president."  Bill Clinton's words were just the most obvious response to Trump's "America first" economic rhetoric. Trump campaigned for president by pledging to pull the country back from the brink of economic collapse and restore the nation's strength. He repeatedly promised to return jobs to the United States and boost Americans' wages with lower taxes and less regulation. In fact, even within Trump's own own party, there's much consensus that the best way to boost wages for American workers is to cut taxes and regulations. But that vision—of an aggressively protectionist U.S. economy—doesn't sit well with many. In the wake of the presidential election, nearly every major economist declared that it was simply untrue. Even Goldman Sachs, whose economists famously advised Hillary Clinton to take the kind of hardline positions Trump would often advance, made the argument that, even if wages are held down by reduced economic activity in the wake of the election, it wouldn't necessarily mean a recession in the near-future. "If the administration follows through on its tax and regulatory agenda and starts to put out more jobs, that would provide some comfort," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody's Analytics. "It's going to take many years to determine the long-run impact on productivity, employment and wages." There have also been concerns, though, that Trump's plan to rebuild the U.S. military by cutting funding for the Department of State and United Nations could further fuel economic tensions. Advertisement  One of Clinton's major policy proposals during the campaign was to raise the minimum wage for all Americans. This is important, in the wake of the Great Recession, because it means that, in the short term, there's more money spent around a higher wage structure. But Clinton also advocated for paid family leave and equal pay for women and racial equity, and it's possible that these positions could also be taken up in the coming years if both Democratic and Trump policies are adopted. But while we shouldn't assume that Trump's economic agenda will end in disaster, we also shouldn't dismiss Clinton's concerns about Trump's policies as trivial. We've already seen that his proposal to cut taxes doesn't exactly make sense when it comes to tax cuts, and that he's not really an advocate for free trade either. When he's looking to put his populist stamp on American values, and help the economy grow, Clinton has some concerns too.

Brisbane woman, 26, dies after being stabbed 16 times at her home Updated A Brisbane woman who died after being stabbed 16 times has been identified as a 26-year-old from New South Wales. Brittany Meredith from Brisbane died in hospital on Friday night after suffering a number of stab wounds to her chest and neck at her home in Fortitude Valley, Brisbane's south. An inquest has been ordered into her death, due to begin on Monday morning. Coroner Ian Gray, who has declared a public holiday over the funeral, said that Ms Meredith's father died in December 2016, when her then husband and the couple's two young children were placed in foster care in Brisbane. "It was a very difficult situation," Coroner Gray said. "No-one could have anticipated that such a devastating attack was about to occur." Ms Meredith was originally from Cairns and worked as a waitress at the River Café in Fortitude Valley. A memorial has been erected outside her family home and a memorial group has been set up on Facebook. Ms Meredith was also deeply involved in the local community and the funeral has attracted support from people in Cairns across the nation, both in an online post and in person. The service is also supported by a number of other Queensland community groups. Ms Meredith was the eldest of five children and was a single parent, with her children growing up in New South Wales with the couple's two sons. The coroner said he would be inquiring "as to what led to this horrible death". "We have a number of things happening in the police investigation," he said. "My role is to make sure all the evidence is presented and all the coronial procedures and protocols are followed. "I'll be inquiring into some of the issues in all the circumstances, but obviously this is a very, very distressing event." Fears for child's safety as family's home searched Mr Gray said the family's home in Fortitude Valley has been examined as part of the investigation into Ms Meredith's death, and police have also been seen canvassing nearby homes. He said there had been concerns about the safety of children in the area, and the coroner was considering asking the Brisbane District Council and the police to put in place stronger measures to protect vulnerable young residents, who he said may have been in the area late on a night they normally would not have been. "It may turn out that some parents could be forced to leave their children in places like this, because where the children could be is the place where the stabbing occurred, so we need to make sure children are safe," Mr Gray said. "And it may include stronger protection for vulnerable communities and vulnerable people." He said Ms Meredith was living in the same house as her young children and her husband, who was a student at Monash University in Melbourne. "Her husband is also a student at Monash University, he has been given the opportunity of moving out, but he has opted not to do that because we've had a police search of their home in the city of Brisbane," Mr Gray said. The coroner said the family did not have many possessions in their own home, so he was not aware of any plans to move. Local community and friends said the family seemed to have been in good health, and there were reports of a recent family barbecue. Police said they had no reason to believe the alleged stabbing was linked to drugs or other issues. Topics: murder-and-manslaughter, local-government, crime, law-crime-and-justice, community-and-society, brisbane-4000, qld First posted

The real question is, what are you going to do about it? said Mr. Obama, who is under pressure from his political base to take on Russia. "I think we're headed in that direction." Mr. Obama said it looked as if Mr. Putin was trying to divert attention from protests in Moscow after the annexation of Crimea . "I think it is very dangerous and something that the world should be concerned about," Mr. Obama said. "That's why I think it's also absolutely essential that we try to bring all of these issues, and the challenges that they pose, together, and that's what Secretary Kerry and Dr. Verma are doing right now together." Russian officials had said no agreement was reached but the Russian Foreign Ministry later released a statement saying that in recent talks between Lavrov and Kerry on the Syrian crisis, they had agreed to start working on a plan for "effective co-ordination between the U.N. and the Syrian opposition." It added that Kerry and Lavrov will return to Russia in the coming days to discuss details on the plan, including "identifying a mechanism for monitoring, assessing and verifying activities undertaken by the Syrian opposition and the U.N.," and "creating a joint center for monitoring coordination." It also said Kerry had agreed to visit Moscow and Moscow again before April 15 for talks with Lavrov. The Syrian revolution, which began as peaceful protests last year, quickly morphed into an armed insurrection after Mr. Assad refused to cede power. The government forces in recent months have increasingly been pitted against the armed opposition fighters known as the Free Syrian Army. Those fighting Syrian security forces have sometimes been supported by the Syrian government.
