On the first day Mr. Kerry left the country, British Parliament debated whether to allow him immunity like those from other countries like Syria or Libya , where his son is serving a jail sentence for plotting against the British government. One lawmaker, Mark Pritchard, said Mr. Kerry's continued travel suggested there was a "big problem" with a proposed intelligence and legal system in the Middle East. "He's going from place to place and he has all these other issues to address," Mr. Pritchard warned. While some politicians may be considering how to treat Mr. Kerry because of his involvement in the Syrian negotiations, they have stopped short of calling for his removal from his job. "What we're considering is if any of those people can become legitimate representatives, is he eligible," said the British foreign minister, William Hague . Russian officials said Mr. Kerry was in Moscow on the first day of three days of talks with Lavrov but did not respond to a request for comment about any discussions on his future. It is not clear whether Washington would seek to suspend Mr. Kerry once the Syria talks conclude. The United States and its friends believe that Mr. Kerry, a former chief negotiator for both President Bill Clinton and President George W. Bush , is one of the few diplomats they hold in high regard. In public appearances since leaving Syria last Friday, Mr. Kerry has expressed hope that talks would not be abandoned and that the United States and its allies would soon be able to work together to find a political solution. But many officials, including Mr. Kerry's Republican critics, are wary, given Mr. Kerry's strong interest in establishing dialogue with Syria's government and being seen as an honest broker. He has been working with the Syrian opposition since he returned from Syria two years ago after his son was arrested by the Syrian security services. Photo If the Syrian government continues to ignore demands for free elections, some officials in Washington say, Mr. Kerry may be asked to return to the region. On Wednesday, the Turkish Foreign Minister, Ahmet Davutoglu, said that Mr. Kerry and his Russian counterpart, Sergey V. Lavrov, agreed in Istanbul "on the need to continue efforts toward an agreement, and to continue contacts and consultations on the Syrian crisis." When you see it, you know it's a bad story. At some point in all these weeks, I'm sure that a journalist will ask me if, when I'm done with the book I'm working on, I'd like to do a TV version instead. I'm sure my first reaction will be, "Yes!" and I guess, yes: I really want to see how a television show from me and my co-writer and co-producer Lauren Oliver would translate to television. But I'm also certain that, whether I write it, produce it or direct it myself, I'm going to find a host of objections to any such project—a host of objections that, when we're done, have not yet been put under scrutiny. Here are the biggest of these objections, in no particular order: 1. It's about a movie. A lot of movies get adapted. I watched The Godfather five years ago. I'll admit that when I found out that Michael Corleone was actually named Marlon Brando, I thought, "Oh, my God, did anyone write a screenplay about that?!" I was right. That movie adaptation was done by someone named David Mamet. And that was a very good film. I liked it just fine. Like most Americans, I'm a little put off by the whole thing, of course, but I was at least glad that the movie wasn't about Brando, just Michael. I've seen a lot of films. And I know that for a book about a movie, it'd be a very bad idea to start telling people what the movie was about, because if you try to put Brando, Marlon Brando and the Godfather in the same sentence and get them to agree it's all one big movie, that doesn't help anyone to understand what the movie is about. It gets confusing. 2. It's about the Vietnam War, really. Oh, the War. It's just like that. When it comes to the War, no one but David Mamet and Mike Nichols, who wrote the screenplay, has much of an opinion. For instance, when it comes to the Vietnam War, there's no such thing as the "realism" of the War. They only have one version called "the War" and that's the version that the American public has been fed—and, incidentally, that's the version that the book is about. Why would a good writer take the time to write a book about a subject you know well? For what purpose? Why not spend the time to simply write the book? Because of all the objections that this is all Vietnam, of all the objections that the book is only about Vietnam—we'll get to that. 3. It's not a novel. We've all seen the movies. We know the plot. The thing that's most important in a book is the plot. The thing that's most important about a movie—and it's something you should have in mind when you're writing a book, too—is that it's not a work of art, that there's something more than entertainment in it. If you know anything about movies, you know that the first act is usually not the best part of a movie. A great movie is when you get hooked by the first act, when the story moves faster than the movie stops moving in the second act—and that's what a good story is. You can see this very neatly in a novel. Take a book that begins with a beautiful opening paragraph—"The book was being brought by an elderly lady in a wheelchair," or thereabouts. In fact, you could put the first line of nearly any novel into a screenplay: "The boy opened the book." What happens then? Most of the dialogue in that novel is meaningless—"The man looked surprised when he saw what she was carrying" or "The woman looked up at the little blue sky and smiled." This is not because there's anything more in the novel than boredom. It's because the plot is so terrible that there's nothing interesting to say while you're reading the book. It's really only the first hundred pages. There's only one reason to write a novel: not so that you can do the movie. It's important to do books—and movies—for the reason that you find interesting. So even if a screenplay about an episode of The West Wing might be a good movie, you have to resist the temptation to copy the first chapter of that book, to think that the rest can be found in this first scene. 4. The movie is in English, and you're going to have to translate it. One of the big complaints about movies is that they are just too complicated to translate and that people who love movies, just love them in English anyway so there's no reason to force them to listen

In August, the New York Times published a story on a mysterious new group called Global Witness, that had a reputation for exposing corporate excess. Their findings, the story stated, supported the suspicion of many that the global economic system was in tatters. By the following day, after spending just a few minutes digging into the group, the Times had called them "a fringe group that is more interested in media attention than in transparency". In fact, there were few articles about Global Witness that weren't about their corporate critics, the financial industry, or the political establishment. If there's a reason why the media is quick to denounce NGOs, it's that they have the power of the state behind it. A few dollars in their pocket from an NGO (or a billionaire) could make the difference between a newspaper article about how to get rich, or how your kids get sick. But there is a counter-narrative being pushed across countries with the help of a new organisation called the Fund for Investigative Journalism (Fij) – it's a campaign to restore the balance between government, business and civil society. It's a campaign that we can take our part in, because we are the beneficiaries of the system. By the way, the Fij website says they have a $3.7m (Dh18 million) budget, yet the list of backers is limited and a lot of this money isn't being used. The rest is going towards funding local NGOs, which provides them with new opportunities to tackle the problems, as well as the opportunity to help governments, NGOs and other interested parties solve those problems directly. Last week, the Fij invited me to join them, and the next day, I was on my way to Berlin. I was greeted by a man on a motorbike who introduced himself as Michael. He showed me around the office and gave me an overview of what Fij does. Here are five lessons I learned from Michael. 1. Funders are not stupid In the office, I met another Fij Board member, Anne Sargent, a young, attractive Frenchwoman whom I initially got along well with. For starters, she seemed to know a lot more about the problems Fij dealt with than I did. There were a couple of Fij staffers at her table, too. They looked like researchers rather than consultants, perhaps due to budget cuts, and their knowledge and experience seemed to be extensive. The Fij staffers were happy to answer any of my questions. But they also seemed to know what I had in mind and tried to steer me away from areas where I might get stuck. For instance, they wanted me to focus on what I should know about the corruption problem in Angola and Mozambique, even though the topic was on my mind already – there was nothing in the room that would have convinced me. 2. Don't trust the media: they will always be biased I met a few times with a bunch of lawyers; another Fij board member met me at the offices of the Legal Services for Sierra Leone. The latter one wanted to give me a primer on legal aid, pointing out that the Fij had helped build it out. But as I was trying to find out what it cost to use legal aid in Sierra Leone, he suddenly wanted me to stop. "No need to stop," he said, "The Fij is trying to fix that too, we can fix it together with you." I said I was interested in finding out how legal aid programs worked in Africa, not just learning the basics. I explained to him that the Fij was doing this, but we couldn't do it alone. I tried to get an answer, but I had a feeling he was avoiding the topic. The other Fij staffers didn't know what to tell me either. If I was a freelance researcher, they would have been more willing to give me some time to learn the ins and outs of legal aid, but they are public relations experts who also are trying to shape the public opinion regarding aid. It's not just the NGO they work for that is pushing them to tell the same story (see: The New York Times). 3. A lot of research goes into the media, which can get corrupted I met with reporters from the Times, and several from the Guardian, who assured me they were on my side with regards to Global Witness. I also met with local journalists who are working on the issue. When I got back home, they told me they were getting the same answers from other reporters as well, even though they had the same sources of information. In other words, the media have a lot of influence on the information that we are getting. And the information is never objective. As soon as you mention the names of the companies and the people behind them, it's all too much. For example, Global Witness investigated companies involved with the Mozambican government-owned electricity

The video will start in 8 Cancel Get daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email Hundreds of residents in a rural Co Galway area have been offered emergency accommodation as the weather continues to get colder. Residents of the town of Doon, County Mayo, have been told they will be relocated to a temporary shelter in a rural location as the temperature falls. It is unclear whether the move is connected to the storm that is expected to hit Ireland early on Saturday. More than 100 people are said to be being offered emergency accommodation in Doon as the cold front approaches. The Co Down Telegraph reports that the move was being made by the Regional Support Services in a bid to help residents stay warm as the temperature falls. The news agency also quotes a Donegal County Council spokeswoman as saying that the move is "part of a weather alert system for all the areas in south Mayo", in relation to the anticipated temperature fall. The move is in addition to the 10,000 emergency accommodation offered by Donegal County Council so far this winter. The spokeswoman's comments were made to the Donegal Register on Tuesday morning. (Image: David Butler) Earlier this week, the State Emergency Operations Committee (SEOC) warned that extreme cold, high winds and low pressure systems are forecast to affect the north eastern parts of the country on Saturday. Gardaí have urged people to take the necessary precautions during the night, with warnings that there could be a mixture of rain and snow, especially in rural areas. This morning a large part of the Co Louth coast was closed off by a gale force wind storm. The National Ambulance Service earlier said it had recorded four medical calls for the storm. One fell victim to a fall, while another person was treated for a laceration that was not serious.

Bike Lanes on Broadway Street We've been hearing a lot about bike lanes on Broadway. The main street between South Lake Union and South Duwamish is one of the busiest streets in the city. Broadway runs from the waterfront southward, through Pioneer Square, to Denny Triangle. It's one of Seattle's main thoroughfares, a commercial artery. At its busiest, the street brings in 80,000 cars each weekday. Now the Seattle Department of Transportation (SDOT) is looking at expanding bike lanes by adding bike-only lanes and narrowing the streets. A recent story in the Seattle Weekly discusses the City's process for planning and design, but we still don't have any details. This is a complicated undertaking. Bike lanes are a controversial topic in Seattle. A lot of the issues we're raising are the same as issues around bicycle parking and sidewalks. And SDOT is not new to cycling. The agency has been running bike infrastructure for decades, and has been building roads and rail lines for the better part of that time. If things go smoothly, bicycle infrastructure could be in place for this summer's opening of the Fremont Bridge. Here's a map from SDOT showing the street reconstruction and expansion, and the city's long history of bike infrastructure. The SDOT website has no information about the streets on the list, other than the ones marked "conceptual," and where possible, they were used in the planning process. No one who has studied bicycle infrastructure in the city is surprised. Here's one example: On Broadway, the city plans to add a protected bike lane alongside the existing "one-way" bike lane, called the "bus right of way." The bus lane is in good condition, and the bike lane would be an obvious and good option. SDOT's plan also includes widening the two parking lanes and turning lanes on Broadway from two to four lanes, but that has not been implemented, and it's unclear how big the change would be. How SDOT Plans to Increase Safety for Cyclists SDOT does a very good job of describing the types of safety improvements that they will propose to make, but they have some vague goals: Add more cycle tracks to the busy road. SDOT notes that cyclists on Broadway have very low visibility and lack safety features such as a bike box or raised curbs (which are essential for cyclists who ride with the flow of traffic). SDOT would add bicycle signals to the bike lanes which would be activated by motorists to allow a cyclist to proceed through the intersection safely. SDOT notes that cyclists on Broadway have very low visibility and lack safety features such as a bike box or raised curbs (which are essential for cyclists who ride with the flow of traffic). SDOT would add bicycle signals to the bike lanes which would be activated by motorists to allow a cyclist to proceed through the intersection safely. Add more bicycle traffic signals. SDOT notes that this is one of the most urgent issues for Broadway cyclists. Bicyclists who can't see intersections (including cyclists who are walking) need to be able to signal safely during stops and turns. SDOT notes that this is one of the most urgent issues for Broadway cyclists. Bicyclists who can't see intersections (including cyclists who are walking) need to be able to signal safely during stops and turns. Extend and improve pedestrian crossings. SDOT would extend and improve the existing pedestrian crossing at East Pine to make it a safer option for bicyclists and pedestrians. The City also recently published a report on Broadway bike crashes, and found cyclists made up a good chunk of victims. SDOT's plan could go a long way toward reducing cyclist injuries. At the most basic level, bike lanes make it safer to share the road with cars. On the streets where SDOT wants to build bike lanes, there are already two-lane boulevards, making it easier for cyclists to turn left from an intersection. The city also notes that bike lanes provide a great experience for cyclists and non-cyclists. A cyclist on Broadway may see no cars, but traffic in and around the neighborhood does. "It's a very active street, with a lot of travel lanes and an increasing number of pedestrians," says Megan Koester of the City's Office of Transportation and Workplace Development. "It's a huge transportation corridor. Many people use it for their commute to downtown as well as for all their other transportation needs, including a lot of people who ride their bikes." So, on Broadway, the city will build a new bike lane and add two traffic signals to help cyclists flow up to the next intersection safely. It may also look at adding bus stops on the block that will be impacted by the street reconstruction and widening. But bike lanes don't fix all of the problems people report. People biking near the intersection of Broadway and Pine tell Koester that when buses pull up onto Pine, they have to stay where

Image copyright Getty Images Image caption South Korean men wait to march in a parade during a military-sponsored event in Seoul in June 2013 A conservative member of Korea's parliament has suggested that the country take in Muslim refugees. In a survey of local residents, Kim Chul-soo of the Korea Solidarity Party (KSP) said some people in the country would "fear that Islamic societies will be worse than the North". More than 10,000 South Koreans have fled to the North for better prospects. The latest migrant crisis is expected to worsen tensions on the divided peninsula. North Korea has carried out several nuclear tests this year, most recently in January. South Korea and the US blame the regime for the test, although Pyongyang insists it was in self-defence and a test of its short-range missiles. The UN has imposed new sanctions on North Korea over the nuclear test in North Korea's third nuclear test in February. Earlier this week, Pyongyang threatened to carry out a further nuclear test "sooner or later" following threats to kill American citizens in retaliation for the new sanctions. Last week North Korea withdrew its ambassador to South Korea in protest at plans to tighten anti-dumping sanctions over its exports of cheap products. Mr Kim's comments were made in an interview on the US channel MSNBC, the Yonhap news agency reports. Image copyright Getty Images Image caption A US-backed military exercise, Foal Eagle 2012, involved US and South Korean servicemen taking part in joint exercises between the two counties in early 2012 In his opinion, the North's religious authorities "are more strict than their counterparts in the North", he said, without providing further details. "In the North, you're supposed to pray two hours a day," he added. "In the Muslim countries it's more likely they might spend up to 40 minutes in prayer." Asked how it could be possible if "the state rules every single aspect of life," the KSP member said: "The authorities would be less intrusive than the ruling party in the North, and the citizens would be more liberalised, so there would be less discrimination." His comments were also made during an interview with Fox News. Asked whether he supported a potential evacuation, he answered "Yes, of course". South Korea currently takes in about 20,000 refugees per year. South Korea's Unification Ministry said on Tuesday that the number of such refugees had risen by 6,000 to almost 50,000 so far this year. The US defence secretary, Chuck Hagel, said on Tuesday that the US would consider allowing South Korea to take in more refugees, Reuters reports. Earlier this month, North Korea blocked entry visas for 50 people - the largest immigration crackdown in the country's history. However, in November the UN said it would give new asylum applicants the right to work, so they can provide for their families.

Trevor Harris has played a lot of football for the Carolina Panthers in recent years. "I haven't been to a game since 2011," Harris said. In 2011, Harris missed all of training camp and was just beginning to get acclimated to the NFL. Since then, he's been Carolina's starter at right tackle, and has been the team's second team right tackle on many occasions. Harris' journey to the NFL has been unique, but at the end of the day, he just wants to play football and is looking forward to the upcoming season. "Obviously, the hardest part is the first game," Harris said. "You get to a new league, a new city with all the new players, and you don't get a lot of sleep on the plane. It's a little bit of a whirlwind. And obviously you want to get out on the field, so we'll see what the rest of the season has to be like and let the fans know." Harris' first year in the NFL as a rookie was not great. He started two games, but his play has taken a turn for the better since then. "I've been working like the team wanted me to," Harris said. "Obviously the coaches do their best, but we've also got to come out here and go out and practice hard and put the times on the board, and see what we get out of them. The last couple of years, they've kind of let me loose, and it's just up to me to keep it up to the standards they said I've set." Harris is not concerned about being an early cut, even if the Panthers are looking for a player at their desired position. "I don't worry about that," Harris said. "I know what I have to do to be successful. It's just about competing, and showing these guys the respect they have as leaders in the locker room, and keeping those standards high. They're all big in there. They want to play. It's just a matter of showing them the respect they're looking for." You can follow me on Twitter @LeviDamien or email me at levi@sportsguychallenge.com

Mauricio Pochettino wants to stay at White Hart Lane, despite the club's struggles this season. Tottenham captain Dele Alli has expressed a desire to sign a new deal at Tottenham. The 19-year-old England international has scored nine goals this season in 46 appearances and, while he has been handed a new long-term contract, Alli has also been offered an extension with the club. It is understood that Alli wants to join a club like Chelsea or Manchester City in the summer and will be prepared to stay at Spurs for another season at least. Dyche wants more creativity in his team Tottenham have struggled to put a consistent run together this season and now face a fight to reach the top four ahead of Saturday's North London derby against Watford. Alli has been at Tottenham since the age of 14 and has become a regular starter for the club. The fact that he has been offered a new contract means there is little interest from other clubs to prise him away. "I really like it here," Alli said after the 2-0 win over Tottenham at West Brom on Monday. "It's a very well-oiled machine, a lot of people know me. Tottenham are a great club to be at, and I love it here, and for me to stay at Tottenham, it would be fantastic. "But I am 21 now and there is always that next step, and I am very happy here playing my football, and hopefully one day I can stay and play with the best players in the world." Meanwhile, Tottenham are weighing up plans for a new sporting director to take charge of the club's transfer business over the summer transfer window. Mauricio Pochettino, the manager, has already overseen significant investment in Tottenham's youth system by bringing in Harry Winks, Vincent Janssen and Etienne Capoue, with Pochettino wanting to take further risks with incoming transfers. Tottenham have also sold players this month including Paulinho, the Brazilian midfielder, to Shanghai Shenhua but that is not what Pochettino wants to see happen. "When our business in the transfer market stops and we have to look for talent, I want this to be done after a new manager comes in, a new vision and with a new board," Pochettino said on Monday. "I want a new sporting director, a new head of recruitment to be responsible for that and take the responsibility of picking players."

It was as if a big hand was placed on my shoulder, he said while trying to hold back tears. "I just couldn't believe it. I could barely believe it and as my mind started racing, my legs started to shake. But the coach stayed on me, and the next day he came in with the team and I was able to get back into the team. That was my first championship and to become a champion in the city and as an individual, in my first game, was special. To have that type of support and the community surrounding the program, has allowed me to grow as a person and learn and grow as a college player." But the city has seen something else — a huge shift in how players are treated. Many athletes are not the type to brag about winning the title. The city is also not a town for trophies — a big trophy was not the goal for the city last season, but that will change in the coming years. "For me, going home to my mom and dad is the first thing," Hines said. "For me, my kids are the No. 1 thing first, for them to see a piece of me going back to them and saying I had a better season. If I do not have a piece of me going back to them, it would be sad." For now, he is focusing on the next step — getting the right pieces together to compete for the Rose Bowl. "I'd just love to help my team win," he said. "We're a very talented team that's come together as a team and a group as a group. We all know we're not the best players in the country, but if we get our work done and work hard, we're going to beat anybody in this country and go to the final [Rose Bowl]." He has seen that team and that bond start to grow. After a game against Cal Poly, Hines noticed what was happening at practice when he got back to the complex in Santa Clara. "Everyone was super focused and working together," he said. "That's what it's all about. There was no egos, there was no drama. Just trying to win the game, but a group effort and everyone working together. What a great group of athletes and I've just seen a really great group of guys grow." He also has seen the city come to embrace it. "I've been there several times now, and seeing the number of people coming and really being into it, and the support from everyone from players to parents, that's the most important thing to me," he said. "I'm a part of the city and if I can get the support and the love from anyone, then I'm happy." He and the team will not be doing any more media interviews this week — Hines wants to focus on the rest of the season and focusing on preparing for UCF this weekend. And that's just fine with all of his teammates on defense. "To see that [Hines] has made some great strides and gotten into this position on his own that we have, it definitely brings a lot of confidence," said defensive lineman Andrew Moore. "He's definitely made great strides and we certainly support him."

The "P" in the name isn't just for show. The "Practical Inventor" brand was first introduced during the height of the Industrial Revolution, and made famous by inventors such as Henry Ford, who popularized the name by naming his cars after his inventions. The company's mission was to provide inexpensive, durable, and high-quality tools for the working inventor. It was a product that was in direct competition with the then-biggest names in the industry: W. A. P. toolmakers, Remington, and Hamilton Steel. The company was founded in 1874 and made a name for itself by releasing the first model of a pocket-sized pocket-wrench with a rotating socket. The design made it easy to apply a wrench to the wrong side of any object. The company also created tools for tinkerers. The company's founders were avid mechanics with a penchant for tinkering with machines. Today the company still makes a wide variety of precision tools such as the T-square and rotary screwdrivers. The company ceased operations in 1982, and then merged with the company, which had been called the "Inventor Tools Company," after they merged, which had been called the "Ain't I Great" Tool Company, after they merged. The name of the new company was changed to the "Engine Repair Company." In 1996 the company was bought out by the private equity firm, Blackstone, who went on to purchase all sorts of industrial companies. A brand like "Practical Inventor" is destined to live to see another century. You can find the company's tools at almost any hardware store or DIY community. The tools are available in a variety of materials including aluminum, steel, stainless steel, copper, brass, and brass and copper alloys. What was the company's best quality tool?

Cannabis users are using a chemical in one of the world's most potent recreational drugs more often than before, a report has argued."While the illicit drug market has grown considerably in recent years, and some argue that the market can only be contained with the use of stricter legislation, there has been no increase in the incidence of cannabis use to date," says the study.The report, conducted by The Global Drug Survey ( GDS ), says use of tetrahydrocannabinol ( tetrahydrocannabinol, THC) has stayed steady in recent years: "It is therefore important to assess whether the rate of use has increased among regular users."The survey says that it found nearly 20 to 25 percent of people aged between 18 and 64 have used cannabis within the last 30 days, but use has held steady and many of those who have used cannabis in the past year have not done so since 2011.This is consistent with past studies where surveys have shown around the same rate of regular use. However, in 2016, the World Health Organization reported that between the ages of 15 and 24, the annual percentage of people who had used cannabis was found to be 3.5 percent, and in countries with a greater prevalence of cannabis use, that percentage is even higher (see Figure for data sources).While this increase in use among regular users has led to some concern that the drug could become harder to access, the results of the GDS report suggest otherwise. The report notes that while illicit drug markets may increase in potency and some countries may see changes to public health services, the use of highly potent illicit drugs such as THC or heroin remain "high" and stable over time."There has been little evidence so far that regular cannabis use has increased, but when considering changes such as changes in law, new policies, and the perception of risk, the level of risk may have increased in some ways," said Dr. David Nutt, the chair of the GDS.The GDS researchers interviewed 1,521 adults in 28 countries in 2014. The majority of all surveyed respondents said they would not want to smoke cannabis on a regular basis - 62.7 percent - but did report using the drug on a monthly or annual basis in 30.9 percent of the cases, and on a daily basis in 1.2 percent of cases. This is higher than the use rates from previous surveys that found around 12 percent of adults reported the use of cannabis on a monthly or annual basis, and around 15 percent reported cannabis use on a daily basis.Most of those adults who said they used cannabis in the past month were male (78.6 percent), aged between 18 and 24 years (63.9 percent), from the Americas (44.9 percent) and Europe (31.4 percent). More than a quarter of all people interviewed said they had used the drug at least once during their entire lifespan. The prevalence of frequent use, usually of one high dose or higher, was less than half the survey's estimate of around 1.7 percent, and it was only around .5 percent in many countries.According to GDS co-director Dr. David Nutt, it is too early to tell whether this recent uptick in use will make the legal cannabis industry flourish in the future."While the legal cannabis market in most countries is currently still tiny - with only 2 percent of the global market now - the continued high levels of use and high risk profile of this group suggests that the legal cannabis industry remains in its earliest stages of growth, and as a result, it's difficult to extrapolate any clear predictions of the future of the industry," said Dr. Nutt.The study also said that, "while the current availability of high potency cannabis poses problems for some users, it is highly unlikely that a change in laws and public attitudes is to blame for the increasing use of cannabis.""These findings demonstrate that increased availability of highly potent cannabis is not associated with increased use among the general population of young people across all 28 countries," said Dr. Andrew Grulich, the lead author of the findings. "The findings of the recent study are consistent with those of previous research on this topic: that there is little evidence from the available evidence to suggest an influence of legislation on the levels of use by young people."

The official account said that more than two dozen members of the military were on the ground in northern Tikrit. It would be the most direct American intervention in Iraq since the United States began its battle to oust Saddam Hussein from power in 2003. It was not immediately clear what military assets the American military might be using in the operation. But Iraqi security officials said American warplanes were in flight Thursday, and Iraqi officials had been briefed on the operation through the night. The officials were not authorized to discuss the mission publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity. Two of the officials said Iraqi troops, backed by American advisers, had retaken control of the airport in northern Tikrit and that helicopters were flying overhead. One of the officials said the operation was still under way and that it could take six to 10 days. The officials spoke on the condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the information. Kurdish officials in northern Iraq, meanwhile, said they had captured the village of Dikwa in the vicinity of the airport. Kurdish officials had said that a number of villages in the area had fallen to Kurdish fighters, though none had been taken by American planes. "We are dealing with ISIS now, not with Baghdad or Washington," said Jabar Yawar, the deputy head of Syria's Kurdish P.Y.P. party. "Kurds will take Dikwa. I say with all our force and weapons, not with American planes, it will soon be in our hands."

By Richard Thomas As of March 7, the IRS has a backlog of more than $7.7 million in refunds due to individuals who received returns that it says are incomplete or fraudulent. Those refunds were being paid out by an IRS computer program that failed to detect, track, or process billions of taxpayers' returns over the last 30 to 40 years, according to the agency and some government auditors. Auditors found that more than a third of all individual tax returns filed since 1977 showed inconsistencies and errors, such as false or invalid information, or other problems, such as tax refunds that don't match what the government owed taxpayers. Auditors said the IRS computer program was supposed to send the returns to the appropriate refunds unit, known as Unit 8. That unit has been "virtually vacant" since 2011, officials said. When taxpayers complain that they were victimized by a software problem, the agency typically sends them a letter and a letter of offer of a settlement — but no money, according to interviews and other documents reviewed by NBC News. The agency's offer of a settlement is generally between $500 and $10,000. The problem is compounded by the fact that some taxpayers have sent letters claiming that they were victims of computer glitches when in actuality the IRS may have sent a more expensive tax refund because of the computer glitch — and possibly no money to begin with. According to two audits, more than a third of tax returns filed since 1977 — 36.6 million — showed inconsistencies and errors. As of March 7, those taxpayers owe a total of more than $7.7 million in unpaid taxes. The IRS claims to have paid more than $6 million to customers of the software glitch identified by government auditors. But the agency has not fully recovered from the glitch. Taxpayers still owe $4.4 million from an October 2013 "computer glitch" that caused more than two million erroneous refunds to be mailed to innocent taxpayers. "As a result of Unit 8's lack of progress, over two million individuals will owe tax on their 2015 tax returns, and the agency remains in default of its obligations," according to a report by the Treasury's Inspector General for tax administration. "Additionally, over $11.6 billion of federal tax refunds could be under-collected because of this mismatch between taxpayer's actual tax liability and the government's actual tax liability." The Treasury inspector general's office recommended that the IRS adopt new procedures, such as a new system with real-time data access, to catch the fraudulent and incomplete returns and refund issues. "Although we find significant shortcomings in our current tax refund procedures, we have a responsibility to follow through on that recommendation," Steven T. Miller, who is acting commissioner at the time of the audit, said in a statement. "The IRS is committed to fixing mistakes as fast as we can." But as of March 7, the IRS already hasn't fully remedied problems identified by auditors for an additional $5.9 million of tax refunds worth nearly $7 million that taxpayers who are eligible to receive a refund, but haven't yet sent the IRS a letter saying they've done so, or that a refund has not been automatically applied for, owe. Taxpayers who fail to send in their refunds may be eligible to file an objection with the IRS, which will delay the processing, or file suit against the IRS, which can force the court to find in their favor in order to collect the refund or to make some other financial provision for the taxpayer, such as paying the back taxes — which can go toward offsetting the cost of the dispute. The Treasury Inspector General's office said that as of December, the IRS had processed more than 2.2 million refund objections "that have had the potential to impede refunds in collection," and more than 600,000 suits that had been "potentially injurious to IRS collections." The IRS disputes that the backlog of tax refund complaints is as large as the audit suggests. "The overall tax processing backlog in the United States is approximately $2 billion. But as stated in a prior OIG presentation, this represents approximately 17.9 million individuals who have submitted complaints regarding their returns," Miller said. According to Miller, the backlog was due to two primary cause, first, is "that individuals have failed to return their tax-return forms voluntarily from 1983 through 2011, and second, is a backlog from a software technology failure that caused the IRS to process millions of returned returns incorrectly." But Treasury Inspector General, Michael E. Thorndike, said in January 2013 that the IRS software error had been "substantially addressed" a few months ago and that the agency had found ways to avoid sending those returns back to customers unless the individuals were told the IRS had already processed the return. The agency's software glitches began early last year when the IRS computer department began using a system to send automated mail, letters,

From the section Gillingham have joined Premier League newcomers Wigan in rejecting a bid from Premier League champions Manchester City but will stand firm on their valuation of midfielder Luke Murphy on loan. Murphy, 20, had been offered to Wigan as part of the deal for former Manchester City defender Richard Dunne. The Latics had been willing to pay around £300,000 for the youngster and offer him a place in the club's senior squad. And while the deal for Dunne has been completed, they will still hold on to the midfielder as they push through an overhaul of their squad. The Latics have also had a bid for Ipswich defender Richard Tonge and Bolton striker Mark Howard rejected.

The Canadian Press  TORONTO - The head of Canada's largest pension plan says the Ontario Retirement Pension Plan must do more to encourage participation, saying the new province's retirement system is better when it is viewed through a "grinder's lens." "I'm very sensitive to the fact that this will be a challenge for a variety of reasons," John Corbett, CEO of the Ontario Employees Retirement Income Security Trust, told reporters Tuesday, noting retirees and employees with pension plans have had a hard time coming to terms with the change. "There are two different types of retirees -- ones that have a fixed benefit and ones that are going to receive a benefit based on the assets they place in their [pension] account," he added. "People need to think about how they are going to make that transition in their lifetime as well as how much they are likely to need to retire." The changes, which take effect May 1, 2017, allow some workers to start withdrawing from a defined benefit plan when they turn age 65, up from 65 in 2016. Currently, there are no requirements for workers to leave their full paycheque before age 65, except for Ontario's new defined benefit plans. If people decide to withdraw too much, then they will lose their full pension -- which now amounts to about C$26,000 ($21,600) a year per retiree, compared to under $18,000 for those with a defined contribution plan. If people withdraw too little, they will only lose half of the pensions they have been promised. Ontario is making its changes with the goal of reducing the number of retirees paying into the state pension plan, by about 2,600. Corbett said pensions in Ontario are "in a good place" considering the change but he wants to see those benefits "come in a package that actually encourages people to participate in the pension plan." In Ontario, the pension plan is operated jointly by the government and the three biggest provincially owned pension funds. Ontario Finance Minister Charles Sousa and Corbett were both in Toronto on Tuesday at the release of a report about retirement incomes and the OEP, in which the two noted their government's determination to make sure people are able to keep collecting benefits when they retire. "We really felt we needed to do a better job of communicating the benefits of being part of this plan and actually taking advantage of a solid retiree pension plan," Sousa said. Corbett, meanwhile, expressed sadness after hearing the news about the OEP's dwindling numbers of retirees. "For some people, the plan is more important than their retirement," he said. "People need to decide if this is something that matters to them."

The man who has been the leading proponent of the radical Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) was today branded a shill by an ally that claims he 'cannot be trusted'. Talks between Britain and the US are set to begin tomorrow and are believed to be aimed at making it easier for business to set up shop across the Atlantic. But the president of the EU's business lobby group, the EEF, said on Tuesday that business leaders had been given 'no choice' between the rival approaches – which he said were not 'at odds' with each other. President of the European Economic and Social Committee (EESC), Jean Claude Juncker (left) has said he does not believe TTIP will 'have disastrous consequences' for Britain And Jean-Claude Juncker, the commission president who has spearheaded the drive to bring the deal into force by the end of next year, also dismissed concerns it may cause Britain to pay more to Brussels. Speaking at a press conference in Brussels, Mr Juncker said it was 'obvious that the UK is, to a certain extent, dependent on the rest of the EU.' But he added: 'This is not a contradiction – there is no conflict.' After days of claims in the media that the EU and US could pull out of the talks by Friday as there is too much of a risk of an embarrassing defeat, Mr Juncker said: 'Let me be very clear: the negotiations between the two governments will not be possible tomorrow [Friday] if the other side wants to put in motion this ultimatum. 'The two sides are not at odds with each other – the negotiating team of the EU and the US, and the negotiators on the other side, do respect each other, are good friends, and the negotiations will go on.' Under the proposals, the European Commission – which is charged with overseeing TTIP – would have two years to conclude its own talks rather than being forced into one with the US, and it would be able to amend its proposals at any time. But critics have said that could allow multinationals to influence the final pact in a way that would make it unfair to the UK and other countries. On Tuesday, Business Secretary Sajid Javid said: 'While I fully acknowledge the challenges ahead, I am absolutely confident we can deliver a good deal for Britain – no matter how complex.' The EU has insisted it will not pull out as a result of the TTIP talks – as claimed by the Daily Mail and other newspapers – saying the proposed pact would 'ensure a level playing field for European businesses'. President of the European Economic and Social Committee Jean-Claude Juncker (left) said his group 'obviously respected' the US. But the EESC is in fierce dispute with the US over TTIP, with Mr Juncker (right) and EU Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager in an acrimonious split over the deal The move was condemned by the UK, which is facing a fresh backlash after the Mail reported allegations that Sir Ivan Rogers was 'seriously compromised' in the role before he took over as head of the UK's intelligence service. Sir Ivan, 61, the former head of MI6 and GCHQ, recently warned that the EU risked being 'run by the unelected'. He said EU leaders have 'little understanding of the way a civil society works' and have been 'slow to listen' to civil society groups. This month, the EU launched a probe into a series of alleged leaks by senior officials to a German paper and claimed Mr Juncker has already been accused or sacked by German politicians and MEPs for his role in negotiating the deal. It claimed that if leaks to German newspapers the New York Times and the Washington Post did not 'seriously affect the negotiation process', then Mr Juncker had 'no room to criticize the US authorities'. Mr Juncker took a swipe at the Daily Mail's 'unfair' reporting of him and accused the paper's reporter of 'making up facts'. 'I'm not surprised that the British press is making up some facts in order to attack somebody,' he said. And he warned it would be 'difficult to trust the EU if there is no mutual respect between its member states'. Mr Juncker (pictured with the US president yesterday) told reporters he supported his trade commissioner in his efforts to 'fight corruption' Mr Juncker insisted on Tuesday that the TTIP negotiations with US were 'at all hours of the day' and that he had been in talks with a wide range of American businesses, including Google and FedEx. He insisted that 'this is an entirely serious negotiation', adding: 'I can only be optimistic.' The US Trade Representative, Michael Froman, has also been accused of 'blandly lying' to French journalists about the

By Robert Romano With all the noise over the President's planned executive action on immigration, the mainstream media have a hard time getting into a conversation on the issue, since there appears to be little to no interest from the American people in the matter. But there are plenty of people who would like to talk about immigration and the president's executive orders, even if it's as a talking point. That's true even though most Americans don't think the President should be able to do that at all to the law-abiding citizens in America. In a May 15-April 22 survey by the Pew Research Center, 59 percent of respondents say the president should have the right to do whatever he wants when it comes to immigration and the economy. But that number was almost the same level — 58 percent — when the same question was asked in December. And in January 2014, the same group of respondents said the president should be able to make that decision, while just 36 percent said the opposite. But it's the president's action to the people of this country that the issue is concerned. Here are some stats, courtesy of the Pew Research Center, that are worth looking at, if only as an example of where the American people would like to see immigration go. — A majority of Republicans think more needs to be done to reduce immigration, but the same amount of people say immigrants should not be allowed to become citizens before being naturalized. — Almost three-fourths (72 percent) of Americans say "there should be a law that prevents immigrants from receiving citizenship," even when asked by whom they want it to be applied. Only 45 percent said they wanted a law that would provide for the same effect without mentioning legal immigrants. — Overall, Republicans are slightly more apt than Democrats to say immigrants who are already citizens should be allowed to become citizens. Among Republicans, 63 percent say that, but among Democrats, the numbers are flipped: 64 percent say immigrants should have to leave to become citizens. — The number of Americans who believe legal immigrants don't contribute economically is up 13 points, from 45 percent in 2009 to 59 percent in 2016. But with the same group, 45 percent is still higher, indicating the fact that they can't even come close to paying into the economy. — Democrats and independents have become more supportive of admitting more legal immigrants, but they still oppose doing so even more, 62 percent to 55 percent. — There remain strong, albeit less widespread opinions that immigrants are driving down American wages and that foreign workers are a drain on the economy. Fifty-one percent say immigrants are a "cost to U.S. workers; lower wages; take jobs away from U.S. workers," and 35 percent say immigration benefits the economy more than "the American workers." — There are big demographic differences between Republicans and Democrats on immigration and what a president should do about it. While 83 percent of Republicans say the president should stop illegal immigration as long as it doesn't threaten American jobs, only 48 percent of Democrats agree with that assertion. Seventy-nine percent of Republicans support a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants, compared with 64 percent of Democrats. Now, the president is unlikely to do anything about immigration as he moves forward with executive actions on deportation relief and on increasing the number of federal employees to work on immigration, but there is a lot of public outcry over the issue. What people think should happen and what should be done, even though it's not a popular position, should be discussed. Robert Romano is the senior editor of Americans for Limited Government.

LONDON (Reuters) - More than 3.5 million people are believed to have been affected by a cyber attack that hit businesses and media companies across the globe last month, putting their network security at risk, according to a report released on Thursday. A man walks past a sign displaying the Google logo outside the new Google Store on 5th Avenue in New York's Herald Square June 6, 2012. REUTERS/Mike Segar The research, conducted by the Institute for Critical Infrastructure Technology think-tank, also warned of the risk of future attacks as organizations move to "hybrid" security models that include a mixture of traditional approaches and automated ones. Cyber attacks have become a major problem for the world's business community, and the cost is expected to reach hundreds of billions of dollars each year by 2025 due to the complexity and sophistication of them, the ICT report said. It highlighted the increasing use of "hybrid" security, which is one approach that combines traditional approaches with automation tools, such as intrusion detection systems, intrusion prevention and prevention systems, computer forensic analysis and automated attacks that rely on machine learning to find weaknesses. "Hybrid security offers a cost-effective solution to organizations that have decided to incorporate more sophisticated approaches," said Adam Levin, the founder and director of the ICT foundation. "The traditional security model includes a mix of manual security controls (such as user passwords) and automation, so that attackers may gain access but are never successful in executing a destructive attack." A man sits next to signs displaying an image of Google's logo outside the new Google Store on 5th Avenue in New York's Herald Square June 6, 2012. REUTERS/Mike Segar But the hybrid approach, which has been piloted in the UK and Canada, is still being tested in other countries. "Organizations are seeing the opportunity, but are having challenges scaling it up. The challenge is that no-one is quite sure on what the best path to take is," Levin said. He said in the United Kingdom, attackers could not simply compromise individual sites; they had to "steal" them from other companies or be "piggybacked" on their website hosting company's servers. U.S. President Barack Obama called for new cybersecurity regulations this month, and a congressional commission is set to make recommendations for a national cybersecurity strategy.

Our research has demonstrated the impact of our new policy on driving. We've shown that there's a major safety gain. We've got the largest study we've gone through of this, said Dr. Christopher M. O'Connell, the lead author of the study published this week in the American Journal of Public Health. The new policy, which was announced as the start of a five-year pilot project that will provide $1.6 billion to address the concerns of highway, road safety, and pollution researchers who called for federal funding for roadside emissions-control programs. Fettner, chief executive of the American Highway Safety Association and chairman of a highway research group that has been pushing for more highway safety testing to be done on real driving scenarios, including at highway speed.

A Texas judge has cleared the way for the state's ban on same-sex marriage to take full effect. (Reuters) A Texas judge has cleared the way for the state's ban on same-sex marriage to take full effect. (Reuters) The Obama administration is asking a federal judge in Texas that has blocked a Texas gay-marriage ban to decide whether to extend the protections afforded to same-sex couples under the federal Defense of Marriage Act and the equal-protection clause of the Constitution to gay-marriage states that have passed such laws. U.S. Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. asked U.S. District Judge Orlando Garcia of Corpus Christi to grant a preliminary injunction Thursday, to prevent the state from enforcing the 2013 law banning gay marriage and also pending a decision about Texas's lawsuit against the Obama administration. He also asked Garcia to decide if same-sex couples have the right to marry in those states. "This is not just about Texas," Holder wrote in the motion. "We are all bound together by our rights derived from our respective constitutions and laws." As of Thursday morning, same-sex marriages are legal in 17 states, including Massachusetts and California. Garcia rejected Texas's arguments in 2012 that it is barred from enforcing the state's gay marriage ban. Texas Attorney General Greg Abbott, a Republican, has said the Obama administration would ignore a court order that says Texas was in contempt of court if it took further steps to allow gay marriages in defiance of the court's decision. Abbott said Thursday that federal authorities were trying to "extort" Texas by threatening to shut down the federal government if the state ignores its court decision. "To further punish Texas and force the State to violate basic constitutional liberties is intolerable under any circumstances," Abbott said. The case could mark the first time the U.S. Supreme Court reviews a state law banning same-sex marriage, and the high court could take up the case by next month.  A man holds a rainbow flag as he celebrates with others after the U.S. Senate voted to advance Bill (PHOTO: Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg via Getty Images) Justice Department officials acknowledged that they are hoping Garcia will grant the injunction. But when asked what the government hopes to gain by fighting in court, rather than through Congress, the officials said nothing is off the table. "We expect this case to go to the Supreme Court," said Deputy Assistant Attorney General Matthew Axelrod, who oversees the federal government's LGBT-rights programs. Axelrod acknowledged the government is likely taking the case to the Supreme Court for the first time. While Texas has already begun taking the lead in the state's suit before the 4th Circuit Court of Appeals this week, that court has jurisdiction over the case because Texas is a district court. "When the appeals court reviews any challenge to a state law, the 4th Court of Appeals can decide whether to review it — just as it took the opportunity in the wake of our decision on marriage equality to review several state challenge to same-sex marriage bans, and declined to review challenges to marriage bans in Idaho and Utah as well," the Justice Department said in its motion. An attorney for Texas said he is skeptical. Michael H. Weinstein said the Obama administration's letter is not a legally binding decision and that his office will file a response in court. "There remains very great skepticism that the administration's legal analysis is anything more than a threat," said Weinstein, president of the Gay and Lesbian Advocates & Defenders and lead attorney representing the Texas plaintiffs in the case. Garcia has indicated during a hearing in February that his ruling against Texas will be upheld, noting Texas was given a reprieve from the legal fight if lawmakers took similar action in the state. A spokesman for Garcia's office, Bill Rausch, declined to comment.

From: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8LZl9XKg1cI&feature=youtu.be  From: 'Dr. Robert E. O'Reilly, Ph.D., N.D., and co-author, "How to Talk to Your Child About the Truth"  As an American mother I grew up with a strong desire to find the truth, when I could not find it even when the facts pointed me in any direction. I was taught to ignore those around me who tried to persuade me otherwise. I remember my father trying to tell me a story about a car accident that almost killed my mother and my younger sister and her best friend. But he told me it was a hoax, that my mother couldn't have survived the accident. The story kept coming back to me, but I wouldn't have any idea what to do, I had no doubt that what the other side was saying was not true, the details were wrong. As children we are especially vulnerable to the lies we believe to be factual because we do not have a strong sense of responsibility or empathy.  A few years later, my husband and I discovered a book, "The Big Lie," for a few dollars in the library, written by a man who claimed he had invented the lie and could tell it from facts. The book was filled with errors, half-truths, distorted versions of events and it seemed as though each chapter was told in a different tone on each page! It was frightening because in the first few pages he claimed, for example, that his book, "The Great Santini Fraud," (published in 1973) provided proof that the moon landing was a hoax by showing images of alleged landing sites that did not match the photographs taken after the landing. The photographs he provided did not prove this.  After reading "The Santini Fraud" my husband and I talked for over three hours trying to persuade the author that he was wrong. One of the things that really made a profound difference was when my husband told the author that his evidence for the existence of Jesus Christ had never been proven and was in fact a fraud. For the first time in several years the author admitted that his book was, in fact, a fraud. It took less than two minutes for the truth to hit home: Christ never died on the cross and the Bible he quoted in its chapters was written as a result of centuries of human error!  What I have talked to my daughter about as she grows up, I have talked about with my family, for we are all susceptible to misinformation. All of us love to believe the impossible. We are also susceptible to the stories that the media tell us about ourselves. I have heard many stories about my mother, my sister, my sister (who has no memory of it), my father and my husband that don't conform to what we know to be true.  What are you taught when you hear the lies of the media? Many of us are not taught about the truth in education, science or the Bible, nor about how to know the truth. In truth, it might be even worse, we are not taught how to know what to believe and that there should be a choice available to us to make up our own minds. When someone tells you that a politician is a racist, or you are told that the earth is flat, or "your doctor" is not really a doctor but a person who sells a product you can buy, the media is not telling you the truth. Those who push these ideas are often not the people you really want to be thinking of. There is a tremendous disconnect between what you have been taught to believe and how it affects you and how you behave. We often cannot tell who is telling us the truth and who is telling us what we want to hear.  The more you hear what they want to hear, the more likely you are to believe them. You can try to be more selective of the information you receive and you can also try to understand the difference between what is true or false. If we ignore what we are told about the world, we will have no problem believing what they wish to believe. But we may find ourselves in a difficult situation because we will not have the same level of knowledge that we have once had.  One way or another we will still be held responsible for making up our minds and choosing to act from our own convictions, not from media stereotypes.  "The most effective way of making a point when you are on the outside of a crowd of people is to keep your audience far enough apart from you to be beyond personal criticism, just far enough apart to give you the freedom of association." - Robert B. Pinsky, "Saying No"  "I am not here with you for your money; I come alone. I have something to say that I want said. The only thing I ask of you is that you do not listen with your ears

Hacking is in, the NSA's former chief of staff Keith Alexander told an audience at the University of Texas in Austin on Monday. "The question is not how do we stop it, as much as how do we defend against it." The U.S. government is becoming a "cyber security" first responder, rather than just an "information security" one, a role once dominated by the NSA. "You just never know what will happen," Alexander told the audience of IT security professionals, as reported by ProPublica, the New York Times, the Center for Investigative Reporting, and Bloomberg Businessweek. This is a significant shift in a decade-and-a-half of the United States becoming an information security first responder by way of the NSA. The change, Alexander said, was necessary, he explained, because the US has become the victim of massive, sophisticated hacking and cyber espionage campaigns. There is a "very robust commercial" and "state-sponsored" Russian cyber espionage campaign "that is penetrating all of the critical infrastructure sectors of the country. We have seen a lot of the cyber attacks that go after nuclear weapons and pipelines, we have seen a lot of the cyber attacks that go after our elections," he said. "I think one of the biggest challenges we face … is figuring out how to protect our own infrastructure from such attacks." This is, perhaps, the first time we've heard the NSA be so forthright about how its mission has changed in the last couple of years. In the years since the Snowden revelations, NSA analysts have said that they believe the Russian threat is far from over, though their capabilities have. "We need to prepare for them [Russian hacking]," Alexander said. The NSA is not just concerned with cyber security against "state-sponsored" hackers. They've long seen themselves as part of a global information security arm of the U.S. government and the military. But that was the NSA. It's the NSA now fighting the cyberwar on, not just foreign governments like Russia, or even foreign cyber groups. It's the NSA and the intelligence community, at the forefront of both the NSA's "intelligence gathering and cyber offensive." On Monday's conference call with reporters afterwards, NSA spokesman Vanee Vines confirmed this new role, calling that a "new emphasis" for the agency—a role "consistent with our focus on protecting the nation against cyber threats from foreign actors, including those that target government entities." Last week the White House announced it would spend nearly $1 billion to help make the NSA and other intelligence agencies more agile and capable. It also said the budget would be more than doubled to the maximum level allowed by law for the spy agency. Alexander and the other top NSA officials will now have another $21 billion to spend. The NSA has previously been criticized for what experts call poor organization on cybersecurity operations. The office that is responsible for the country's cyber threat information—the Office of the Director of National Intelligence—was set up only years ago, but doesn't have sufficient resources to take on the cyber threat. "It's a mess at every level," former NSA head Keith Alexander told a Washington security conference last year. "No one has the capacity right now," he said. When asked if it was easy to do a single successful attack on the United States, Alexander replied, "Not at all." But Alexander's announcement on Monday was more like a press conference than a statement, with only one actual question (more on that below). The questioner was David Rivkin, a Washington lawyer who now serves on the President's National Security Advisory Board, which advises the White House on the threats and challenges that cybersecurity poses. ProPublica asked what the NSA was doing to protect critical infrastructure. In response to this question, Vines again clarified: The NSA is currently looking for new ways to protect critical infrastructure. This will include looking at what more our workforce can learn about cyber and its methods and how the NSA can more effectively defend and protect critical infrastructure. Our intelligence community has done significant research on cyber security and has identified vulnerabilities in government systems. The NSA is working on integrating cyber defense efforts at the agency and with the intelligence community. This integrated, multi-disciplinary effort will help ensure our nation can better defend its critical infrastructure. Vines said that some of the research is already on defense lines, but more will be done as the agency "further evolves to address the increasingly complex cyber threats we face." Another question, ProPublica asked of Alexander, was about the NSA's role in the Trump transition team. Alexander said he had no involvement with Trump's transition, but added the same kind of public outreach that has been done for prior presidential nominees. He said the NSA is "engaging in the normal, non-controversial interactions that we've done with many presidential candidates." However, he noted that he has not met his boss, President elect

When we decided to release this game we made certain assumptions: 1) we knew the engine would only be as good as the game's performance. 2) we knew we would need a powerful machine to test and optimize our game. Well we are happy to report that the game is running on our PC build of DirectX®11.2 with the frame rate up to 60 FPS with the following settings: 1920×1080 1280×800 1024×768 1024×600 1024×576 1024×464 The resolution options are as follows: 1280×1024 1680×1050 1920×1200 2048×1536 2K In addition, we ran at a quality setting of "High" and ran the game on medium graphics resolution. If our PC is capable of running this game then the GPU should be able to do so as well but, as always, we are always learning and testing. As you can see, the game runs smooth at 60 FPS with the resolution set to all-in-one. As you can also see in the framerate charts, the game does not look bad at it's native resolution of 1920×1080. What you can see in the top left, and what is shown in most cases of our reviews, is the difference between 60 FPS and 60 FPS on the same settings as you can see in this screenshot: The second screenshot is the same test but done with medium graphics. You can see even more detail visible in the game in this case.

Newly released court documents and an email trail reveal a close relationship between former FBI Director James Comey and a "former close associate of Mueller's" and reveal how high the Obama Justice Department pressured Special Counsel Mueller to terminate the FBI's investigation into former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. Fawny Newsome, a former reporter for The Wall Street Journal, wrote an open letter to FBI Director James Comey after the former Comey had already concluded an investigation of the Hillary Clinton investigation for which Newsome was a key source. This letter was released to the public by a conservative group and the FBI in June of 2017. In the open letter, Newsome details the "close connections" Comey had with James Kallstrom, a man who he refers to as his "close associate and friend". In addition to having a criminal history, Kallstrom was married to the daughter of Bill Clinton's assistant, James McDougal, who was convicted on 12 counts of fraud and conspiracy for the misappropriation of funds in the Whitewater Savings & Loan. McDougal's lawyer used to serve as Deputy Attorney General James Comey's personal attorney. In the case of the Whitewater investigation, Comey and Mueller used McDougal as a witness to ensure that a case of fraud was not brought in the case. Kallstrom also had a relationship with Mueller who was his legal counsel at the time he was hired by the FBI following his retirement from McKinsey Global. Newsome describes how the FBI "seemed to favor" Kallstrom as an investigator and that he felt Kallstrom was "a good guy, who would take care of my client and be straightforward." On July 4, 2013, shortly after Clinton sent and received over 13,000 emails from her private email server on the subject of Chelsea Clinton's wedding with Marc Mezvinsky, former Attorney General Eric Holder called Comey and told him to end the Clinton investigation, saying, "the American people deserve to get the full and complete facts immediately. This is the way we always handle matters that involve national security, and especially when it involves the top two national security officials." Comey, according to the email trail uncovered by Breitbart News with the help of a Freedom of Information Act request, had also discussed this new and "sizable" investigation with Kallstrom at a dinner and at a memorial dinner to former Attorney General Eric Holder in 2015. Newsome describes how after Comey started the investigation, he was approached by Kallstrom in December and offered a "very important job." Newsome said after Comey had "reached out" to him in a number of meetings in his early days at the FBI, he had made it clear to his friend that he did not want any sort of "interference" in the investigation. In his open letter, Newsome detailed how he had written and called his own resignation letter to Comey and then was offered the job at the FBI "right away". Newsome did not know how a large investigation like this came to being, but said that Comey "had no qualms about pushing me" to do so. "It was clear early on that the investigations were going to involve the Clintons and their close cohorts. The investigation was far different than the initial investigations into my colleague Michael Flynn. In the end I think Mr. Comey made the right decision to let the [investigation] go," Newsome wrote. During his tenure as FBI director, Comey investigated Hillary Clinton's private email server, both while she was Secretary of State and thereafter. He also sent two letters to Congress at the end of his term which were highly critical of Clinton. He had the power to bring criminal charges, but did not do so. "Comey had the authority to bring charges against Mrs. Clinton, but did not," Breitbart News Senior Editor-at-Large Peter Schweizer said at the time of Comey's decision. "I want no political appointee to decide that the law does not apply to him." According to Newsome's open letter, he went from calling Comey his friend, to an FBI Director who was "very close" to the Clintons and who would not only end the Clinton investigation, but also make them pay a very high price for it. He was told by "James Comey" in March of 2016 that he "had a lot of work to do and needed to go to New York, and he asked me to stay…I had to tell my team that I would be travelling to New York, and I told them I needed time to think about it." In addition, he said that on March 22, he was taken from the FBI headquarters at FBI Headquarters to the "Gathering Place" at FBI Field Office in Washington D.C. where "the senior officials to whom I had reported were gathered. They briefed me on the Clinton investigation. I was told if I was there that day that I had to go and do the interview." Newsome

1. We are all aware of the incredible beauty of our planet, our oceans, and the vast and varied landscapes that comprise its lands. It is only natural, then, to wonder what it will be like when our own bodies are transformed into a more pristine environment. 2. That's what these amazing artists from the Philippines have done. Through the sheer power of their creativity and skill, they have built a model that looks absolutely gorgeous. The results are pretty much like an accurate depiction of what Earth will look like in the not-too-distant future. 3. You'd never guess that these gorgeous drawings were a work of science fiction. After all, what is a drawing but a flat image with dimensions equal to a few percent of the real world? You'll also notice how many of the curves in this model do not really conform to reality. It's an intriguing idea that gives us a chance to contemplate how we might live with our bodies in the future. 4. They have created a world that looks a lot like our own, but at the same time does not resemble it in any sort of detail. This is the reality of a future that we can never see. Imagine Earth turned into a virtual planetarium—a virtual universe in which we explore the worlds of other civilizations from throughout the universe. 5. So are we going to be able to live in the world that is imagined in these drawings? It would not be impossible. One of the best places to look at how the planet will look like in the not-too-distant future is the work of scientists like Carl Sagan, a scientist who was so concerned with these issues that he wrote this wonderful foreword to this book: "If our imagination is ever to do the job we are trying to do in searching for intelligent life out there on another planet, perhaps a picture is worth more than a thousand words. This planet would seem to hold many unique possibilities for human life, but even with all our resources, we will not be able to get there, no matter how hard we look." What did you think of this? Tell us in the comments below.

In late 2015, a new generation of Android smartphone debuted in China. At that time, the iPhone 6 and its accompanying iPhone 6 Plus were available in China. However, Chinese phone manufacturers quickly caught on with the feature, as they realized that China's smartphone market shares were declining and they needed an alternative to the iPhone and iPhone Plus. That alternative was the Android system. And the Android system was quickly adopted in China and then worldwide. Chinese brands like Huawei, ZTE, Xiaomi and TCL soon began offering Android smartphones in China. As the Android smartphone market grew and Chinese brands began offering Android smartphones, sales were so successful that those smartphones quickly expanded internationally. China has always had a very good mobile market and many Chinese brands such as Huawei, Lenovo, Samsung, Oppo and Sony also saw strong sales with the Android smartphones. Huawei introduced the Mate 9 in early 2016 with a large 6-inch display at a premium price. A few years passed as Chinese brands such as Samsung, ZTE, Oppo, Motorola and Xiaomi introduced more affordable Android smartphones. It seems as now that the Android ecosystem is very well established, and Chinese brands have started to introduce more affordable phones, and the Chinese OEMs are also selling their smartphones abroad. In recent months, Chinese manufacturers have introduced smartphones ranging from entry level to mid-level, such as the Mi5 and Mi5 mini. Huawei has also introduced the Ascend Mate 8 Pro and the Ascend P7 Lite. Xiaomi introduced the Redmi Note 4s with Android 6.0 Marshmallow. In March 2017, China's biggest manufacturer, Huawei, launched its own flagship, the Ascend Mate 8 to compete with the Xiaomi Redmi Note 4s and Apple iPhone 7 Plus. In April 2017, LG launched the G6, followed by the G6 Pro in June. Meanwhile, Samsung launched the Galaxy S8 and Galaxy S8 Plus. Meanwhile, Motorola (with its new lineup including Moto Z) launched smartphones like Moto Z Max, Moto G5s Plus, Moto G5 Plus, Moto Z Play and Moto Z Play Droid. And Lenovo introduced the Lenovo Phab 2 Pro. In the past, Chinese brands have also launched entry-level to mid-range smartphones such as the Huawei MediaPad 7 Vogue, Xiaomi Redmi Note 4s, OnePlus 3, Xiaomi Redmi Note 4 Pro, Mi 5s, Xiaomi Redmi Note 4, Huawei Redmi Note 5 and the Motorola Moto G5 Plus. Chinese brands also launched budget-focused smartphones such as the Xiaomi Redmi Note 4, Mi Max 2, Mi Max 3 and the Mi Max 2 Lite, among others. China is quickly becoming a very important market for global technology companies. As global companies such as Huawei and Lenovo have expanded their presence in China and others such as Oppo, ZTE, Google and others have also started developing their presence in the country, it becomes even more important for global companies to offer more affordable products in China. As Chinese companies are launching Android smartphones at cheaper prices, it becomes even easier for global companies to offer smartphones for cheaper prices to Chinese consumers.
