And I would be surprised if Chinese smartphone companies do not continue to further roll out cheaper offerings.

Ticket sales were disappointing at the box office yesterday (Dec. 29) as "Avengers: Age Of Ultron" and "The LEGO Movie" missed estimates, sending the day's box office tally to $94 million. According to Disney, "Age Of Ultron" earned $18.7 million in ticket sales on the domestic number, compared to $24.4 million for the previous "Avenger" in 2015. "Lucy" made $15.5 million, while "The LEGO Movie" earned $12.6 million in ticket sales. Also read: This Is How Hollywood Is Ruining 'Lucy' And 'Frozen' Again (Report) "Lucy" made a respectable $11.25 million in ticket sales in its second weekend in wide appeal, while "Frozen" made $9.8 million for its second frame in all of theatres. "The Lego Movie" earned $3.9 million in second-weekend sales, while "Age Of Ultron" earned $2.7 million and "Frozen" earned $2.6 million for fourth place in weekend numbers. Opening week box office numbers have been sluggish for Hollywood, with only six films having taken in more than $100 million in the opening weekend. "The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 3," "Captain America: The Winter Soldier" and "Ant-Man" topped the charts, giving industry watchers hope for the summer season. Also read: How 'Captain America: The Winter Soldier' and 'Ant-Man' Are Rebounding in Overseas Domestics The box office tumbled to $15.6 billion in 2014, with $8.8 billion coming from North America alone. Globally, it was the worst year ever. After a month of awards season, Disney also reported that "La La Land" has made $60 million domestically and $154 million abroad from three territories, including the U.K, Germany, Russia and Italy, while the musical has earned $724.6 million worldwide thus far. "Frozen" took in another $50.8 million in the U.S. and Canada, bringing its worldwide gross to more than $1.06 billion. Also read: Why 'Avengers: Age Of Ultron' and 'Guardians 2': A Postcard from the Silver Screen The studio has reported that "Zootopia" has made $739.7 million domestically and $1.08 billion internationally since its May 15 debut. The animated picture is earning $536 million at the worldwide box office, putting it right in the top five films at the worldwide box office for the 2016 season, making it the most successful film of this year, according to Walt Disney.

In the late 1940s British soldiers with the Royal Army Medical Corps (RAMC) began a programme of sterilisation, in a bid to rid the male troops of the most undesirable female characteristics, like small breasts and high-cheekbonedness. Today, that sterilisation policy remains controversial, because the military's record on treating the female prisoners is, shall we say, less than stellar. But what of those soldiers who were sterilised? Could there be health consequences? And what about the women who are still alive? Have we learned our lesson? According to Mary Robinson, a historian of medicine at the University of Manchester: "Sterilisation is the only form of forced contraceptive that we have a record of. The practice of forcible sterilisation became legal in Britain in 1956. Prior to then, the practice was illegal and the medical profession tended to condemn it. A few medical commentators have voiced their opposition. Many others have taken a neutral position. The Royal British Legion in London recently made two women available as speakers at a symposium [in December 2016] about their experiences." When we ask the soldiers we interview how their sterilisation as soldiers affected them later in life, for example through pregnancy or a mental health problem, a number of replies inevitably come back. They have endured the consequences of a sterilisation which they never intended. The process of forced sterilisation The medical professionals who participated in forcing soldiers into sterilisation programmes often believed that the soldiers would make a good father. "Sterilisation was a way of controlling birth rates," wrote Dr R S Welsing, a medical consultant during the Third World War. "The aim was to make sure that the new generations were not too large. The idea was that all of Britain would go sterile." It was thought that the British army would be able to stop the problem of population growth through strict regulations on sex relations and birth control. It would also be possible, many believed, to prevent the sexualisation of women. This was not so, however: the troops still had sex – with the consent, sometimes, of military superiors and even the soldiers themselves. "The practice of forcing soldiers to undergo sterilisation was a form of female genital mutilation in the same way as female circumcision was a form of male genital mutilation," says Robinson. Women who underwent sterilisation were commonly seen as 'disorders' or 'sexual deviants'. The practice became politically unpopular, but it didn't lead the sterilised soldiers to commit suicide. Instead, the effect on their health was seen as being negative in itself. "The practice was regarded as an effective method of making males behave with less aggression during sex," says Robinson. "They would have been encouraged to seek out a woman for intercourse with more regularity." The impact on women's mental health can be seen in the case of Margaret Ann. The Army Medical Service refused her request to have a second child, thinking it would make her mood less volatile in future. Margaret Ann died in 1962 at the end of her army period. "She was suffering from severe post-partum depression that caused severe anxiety and fear," says Robinson. Margaret Ann's children were raised by different mothers, never knowing that their mother suffered from what was commonly considered a psychological health condition. "They thought she had a breakdown and they were quite happy for the children to have different fathers." In another case, a soldier's girlfriend asked to be sterilised so that she could have a second baby, on the grounds that her second pregnancy had been difficult for her. The Army Medical Service refused the request. Margaret Ann's daughters grew up without knowing of their mother's mental health problems. Margaret Ann's suicide Despite the medical service's reservations, the sterilisation programme continued, after Margaret Ann went on a hunger strike. She threw herself out of a fifth-floor window, before being arrested and rushed to a psychiatric hospital. She hanged herself in the wards. Today, her cause of death is not considered to be a suicide – she left a note, which describes her suicide as a result of her "wonderful and happy experience of a second pregnancy". In some ways, she was lucky, as the Army Medical Service agreed to carry out her sterilisation. In 1948, the same year Margaret Ann committed suicide, the same group of British physicians – the Royal College of Surgeons – had recommended a medical sterilisation of all servicemen. Instead of going ahead with this plan, the doctors went on to argue that the procedure should be left to women. The British government, however, opposed this. In 1969, Margaret Ann's family was successful in making a Supreme Court ruling that the decision shouldn't be legally binding. In the end, Margaret Ann's death affected just a small number of soldiers. Those who were sterilized suffered in their personal, physical and mental health, as did the soldiers who were not. Today, Margaret Ann's case still raises the issues about women

A few years ago, I spent a year in North Carolina working in the local law enforcement field. In that position, I was able to get to know the local people and their values. The common thread I learned was they were concerned about the quality of public schools and the quality of their local schools. Since then, school choice has exploded across the country. States like Georgia, Florida, North Carolina, and Virginia have passed legislation to allow parents to use public money to send their children to private schools, and a handful of other states have taken it a step further, with "choice" mandates that give parents more flexibility with how their children are taught, or what schools they send their children to. North Carolinians, on average, spend roughly the same amount of money per child on public education as other states. What sets us apart is the relative percentage of children in high poverty. In 2014, more than 20 percent of kids in North Carolina were living in poverty, compared to 13.4 percent nationwide. Of the nation's top 10 high economic schools, only two of them were located in North Carolina. This is very telling. If North Carolinians aren't providing the best public school option in our state, where is the problem? The average household in North Carolina has $50,000 in disposable income, compared to $33,000 nationally. Most of this is attributable to the wages lost from manufacturing, and those are projected to grow in number and size. In this economy, we need an economy where, if you work hard, you have a chance to get ahead. We need a workforce that is prepared for the jobs that are coming in the future. That begins with good public schools, and this is why we need to make the choices and provide more opportunities for parents. As we continue to grow as a state, we need to be making smarter, more informed decisions about what services we need, where we can deliver those services, and how we can make the state's priorities a top priority in terms of funding its public schools, whether it is preschool education, the K-12 school system, or early education and education. It's also worth noting this week that the state's Public Facilities Commission, which licenses the state's airports, also voted to cut funding by about $100 million on a budget of nearly $12 billion for the next fiscal year. That decision comes on the heels of a federal court ruling that the airports would be subject to the Affordable Care Act. In this economy, we need to be making smarter, more informed decisions about what services we need, where we can deliver those services, and how we can make the state's priorities a top priority in terms of funding its public schools, whether it is preschool education, the K-12 school system, or early education and education. A recent state report found that North Carolina spends about $10,000 per pupil per year on education, a percentage that is about the same as the state of California, though North Carolina gets slightly less than three times the amount of money per child than California. This should be alarming to people who are working to make sure our public schools are funded. The federal government and the state of North Carolina both bear a shared responsibility to make sure all children have access to a quality education. We can do that, and all we need now is for the legislature to come together in a spirit of collaboration and compromise and work together on our shared goal.

There's now an official answer! The United Nations has released its list of the most dangerous cities in the world. Topping the list is Baghdad. The United Nations has released its list of the most dangerous cities in the world. Topping the list is Baghdad. Here's what the UN says: "The list shows cities that received UN-ranked 'most dangerous city' rankings for their overall safety for the fifth consecutive year in 2013. The list shows that the worst of the worst of the world continues to dominate in many ways." The report also gives some interesting nugget by nugget descriptions of the places on the list. I think the most striking comparison is the number of homicides registered by violent crimes in America compared with the murders reported in Iraq, where UN peacekeepers are being sent to stop a civil war. But here's the most important thing: The world is a much safer place today than it was in 2013, according to the 2013 Global Urban Violence Map. There were nearly as many murders worldwide in 2013 as there were just three years ago. I'm happy to be alive in 2013. (Via The Huffington Post, Image is a screen grab.)

This article is from the archive of our partner . If you are an American with internet access, and you go to Wikipedia, you may notice that your address is different than a person without access. On Thursday, Google started rolling out a software update that will remove the country-specific data from your account, meaning that you are no longer able to show up in a map under your birth country, or any of your current home states. Google says that its data was not accurate enough to give accurate results for its search results, which are based on an "online crowdsourced consensus." It has also been trying to improve the accuracy since June last year when Google issued a statement saying that it "did not maintain any records to provide geographic coverage or to allow for country-specific search queries." The change doesn't mean that users can't still see some of the results that they did before the change in July. However, a link to a page about a specific place on Wikipedia for a particular country is not going to show up for a person in, say, New York. Instead, a non-existent page about your country will appear. The change comes amidst a backlash against the company that is based in the U.S. over privacy and privacy issues. In September, Google released a statement apologizing to users after it decided to change the default search results to reflect the U.S. population by counting residents by ZIP code. Google didn't say why the changes were made, but many people believed the company was trying to promote more ads, which is illegal in the U.S. The change in search data for all users will take a week to fully work its way through Google's infrastructure. In the meantime, Google says that it is "notifying affected users and we are working hard to restore the correct data." This article is from the archive of our partner The Wire.

Ride of the Damned is a classic arcade game based in urban fantasy and set after a nuclear war in the world of Earth. The player takes control of the Damned, a mysterious gang that must rescue their loved one by any means necessary. Features Classic arcade style gameplay with challenging physics and the ability to create your own gameplay. Two separate worlds with multiple stages and hundreds of enemies. Over 45 different abilities to unleash on your enemies. Challenging puzzles with dozens of solutions to overcome. Complex enemy AI. A diverse cast of over 200 characters. Local co-op and online multi-player battles.  Note that I have been doing extensive playtesting the last couple of months (I have several full time jobs!), so expect to see a lot of tweaks and additions.

This content was published on October 13, 2017 12:03 PM Oct 13, 2017 - 12:03 The government has promised to raise the minimum wage to at least CHF7.55 an hour, but many workers want to see further improvements, including a new minimum wage for cantinas (Keystone) With Switzerland's economic growth slowly declining, the country's highest earners face one extra thing for their troubles – more taxation on their earnings. The federal government announced last month that it would raise Swiss wages by at least CHF7.55 an hour (CHF4.90 at the Swiss franc) per year for at least a decade. But in the latest move, the government also suggested that it would also take steps to raise the cost of living in Switzerland. A recent OECD report suggests that minimum wages are not the only way to curb income inequality in the country. There are proposals currently underway to make labour market flexibility and job training more attractive when it comes to hiring and firing. At present, employers cannot sack or fire workers for any reason other than illness or accident within a year of the incident. They can also choose from a number of mechanisms, which include: The loss of a paid holiday within 12 months A decrease in the income tax No automatic deduction of tax from wages A ban on deductions from employee salaries for pension contributions The creation of a new minimum wage for cantinas. A proposal was already introduced in 2012 and is expected to be extended at a later stage "The current labour market for employees is in many ways restrictive, particularly in the areas of employment stability and job security," a government report said in March 2016. As a consequence, workers with certain kinds of skills are often reluctant to change jobs. The report also suggests that workers with the right social skills should always be given priority for an entry into the labour market if they are offered a job. The same cannot be said for workers that are considered too dependent on their employers. However, Swiss workers do seem to be getting more flexibility. The OECD report suggests that an increase in the use of flexible worker contracts was responsible for the increasing rates of employee turnover. Switzerland's political decision making remains relatively decentralised, which means that most policies are up for discussion at local level, where decisions often don't play well with the business community. In addition, the public sector remains relatively inefficient and its share of Swiss employment is below that which is required to finance its social insurance contributions in the country. However, the government's decision to focus on social policy was also aimed at alleviating rising income inequality. According to the latest report from the OECD, a high "progressive social share" is a vital component of effective labour market policy. A progressive social share is defined not only by measures aimed at making employment more attractive, such as wage protection, job opportunities and training programs, but also by measures that facilitate workers' flexibility when searching for new employment. The government has promised its new rules will give more flexibility to workers and employers, by introducing a new system of social insurance for the canton. This is currently supported by an amendment to the Employment Act. The new Social Insurance and Compensation Act will go into effect by the end of 2018. A special fund will help the cantons that don't have the same level of insurance provisions as Switzerland. The amendment's supporters say that it will provide a fairer framework to address the social needs of different cantons. A spokesman for the parliament's centre-right Bloc-Eurondemans group said that this "will give the right balance between the interests of labour and those of social security and guarantee a strong and viable social safety net". According to the government, employers in Switzerland receive more than €4,000 per employee each year. The new system could result in some extra cash flowing into the pockets of workers and employers. The amendment was the result of a consultation with the canton of Valais, which proposed a minimum wage for cantonal workers and more flexibility for employment. However, many cantons will not be happy with the new regulations. "There are already many provisions that can help cantons meet these needs," said Andre Känel, minister for industrial and social development in Valais. But Switzerland is on the right track when it comes to the concept of a progressive social share. Switzerland has been struggling to ensure an equal share of jobs for women since the 20th century, as they were systematically less often chosen for higher positions in industry and the services sector than men. And while more recent developments such as the introduction of a minimum wage and the establishment of social security funds have led to substantial improvements in the gender wage gap, recent data have suggested that they are still too low. According to figures in the OECD's latest Work and Income Survey from 2015, a woman earns 8.5%

On March 10, 2014, the Russian Federal Drug Control Service (FSKN) and the Health Care Safety Research Institute (IHR-HHSR, NNU) published the results of a study on the prevalence of opiate dependence, non-medical use of opiates, and other drug addiction among children between the ages of 10 and 12 years in Russia. These results show not only that in Russia opiate dependence and non-medical use of opiates are not common, but also that most (75.1%) Russian children between the ages of 10 and 12 had already used opiates at least once. According to statistics from the FSKN, in Russia approximately one out of five children under the age of 18 is dependent on some kind of alcohol, and about one out of five children from the age of 15 is alcoholic. Furthermore, about one in five adolescents of 15-18 years has drug addictions and is at risk of drug use disorder (e.g., alcohol and opiate dependence or use of illegal drugs). In addition, over half (54.0%) of all adolescents at risk of drug use disorders come from lower socioeconomic economic groups. Of the Russian population, approximately one-third has been arrested for a drug-related crime at least once in their life. However, in children between the ages of 10 and 12, only one-third of the children had been arrested for a drug-related crime. The prevalence of drug use disorders (alcohol dependence, non-medical use of opiates, and other drug addiction) among children in Russia is higher than in other countries. For example, in the European Union, prevalence among 10-12 year olds ranges between 22.6 and 33.6% for alcohol dependence, 2.2 - 16.9% for non-medical use of opiates, and 0.8 - 8.8% for other drug addiction. In Russia, the prevalence ranges from 12.1 - 17.4%. These statistics suggest that Russia is a higher risk country compared to other European countries. The survey on opiate use and addiction among children found that there are a number of factors that influence the likelihood of opiate abuse and addiction in children. These include: drug consumption behaviour; the way the child learns to consume drugs; peer influence; the level of drug consumption exposure; the family context; childhood experiences and the child's perception of drugs. According to the results of the survey, the frequency of opiate abuse and addiction is relatively low in many Russian children younger than 15 years, whereas children between 15 and 18 years showed an overall higher prevalence of opiate use and addiction. In fact, only one out of every thousand children younger than 15 years in Russia used opiates, while one out of every two children between the ages of 15 and 18 years, use opiates. Although there are more studies on non-medical use of opiates and other drug use among Russian adolescent drug users, little is known about opiate use and addiction among this group. The Russian Drug Control Service (FSKN) and Health Care Safety Research Institute (IHR-HHSR, NNU) conducted the study on the prevalence of opiate dependence, non-medical use of opiates, and other drug addiction among children between the ages of 10 and 12 years in Russia. Results indicate the prevalence of opiate dependence in children is relatively low in Russia's population overall, although the prevalence of dependency in Russian children younger than 15 years is at the highest level. Moreover, the prevalence of opiate addiction among Russian children younger than 15 is higher than in other European countries. Some countries in Europe have relatively fewer opiate-dependent or other drug-addicted children than in Russia, but this cannot be considered as a main cause of high rates of opiate dependence and other drug addiction in Russia since Russian children use drugs in different ways.

On Sunday, after months of controversy, a group of black men, women and children are expected to march through downtown Seattle on Sunday to protest police brutality. Organizers from the Seattle chapter of Black Lives Matter say the event is a show of solidarity with those killed in the recent police shooting of Charleena Lyles. The event begins with a peaceful march and protest, and organizers plan to meet with leaders of the community who disagree with their message.

There are some good stories that are worth hearing from the first week of free agency. A week one starting pitcher who can throw in the low 90s and be a starter instead of a reliever and a top flight starting shortstop for the Chicago Cubs are examples of that. We could go for a guy like Yoan Moncada in free agency or Justin Turner for the Atlanta Braves or Zack Cozart for the Los Angeles Angels, or there might not be a guy on the free agent market but that doesn't mean he's not worth the gamble to acquire from another team. In each of the last six years there has been a couple of players on free agents from another team who ended up proving to be great signings. Some of those players are getting new contracts signed by the original team to which they came and some of them are signing new deals for smaller multi-year contracts and some of them are still players that are worth keeping around even though they are not guaranteed to be starters. The key is that free agent acquisitions from other teams aren't often successful. For example, in 2006, the Yankees acquired Jose Iglesias from the Atlanta Braves. In the 2008 offseason the Yankees signed Carlos Beltran and Carlos Gomez from the Cleveland Indians and acquired Mariano Rivera from the St. Louis Cardinals. In 2009, the Boston Red Sox signed David Ortiz and Pablo Sandoval to five year deals with one year team options. Then in 2010, the Chicago White Sox signed Melky Cabrera and Adam LaRoche to six year, $110 million deals. And so on and so forth. You could also add Carlos Beltran and Pablo Sandoval (twice), Jose Reyes and Robinson Cano, Shin-Soo Choo and Ben Zobrist. Some of the best free agents in baseball history were acquisitions from other teams but that is not really what we want for the Boston Red Sox at this stage in the rebuilding process. We can't afford to lose two good young players for nothing. They are not starters and there is not any guarantee that they can provide us with the production that we need. They are young kids, they're young players, they can produce in multiple ways, there are no guarantees, we can't always guess, there are no guarantees of what they will do, and they are young players and young players change. The best way to learn how not to draft them is when you have them. We can't wait to take advantage of an opportunity to draft players better, we can't wait to pay more than market value for a player that will most likely be a role player with an average to below average skill set at the end of a long career. We might not wait to get what we want with the Boston Red Sox and we might not get that player from another team, but we should at least know whether a certain free agent is a good option for the redo Red Sox and if they have the ability to play in Boston. If they are a good player the Celtics should draft them and they should be on the team right away but we should at least know what kind of player we want for this rebuild in Boston.

The city of Boston is set to award licenses to companies that will eventually launch the Boston Bikes program, which is scheduled to launch in April of next year. The city plans to have about 50 "bike corrals" at select locations around Boston where users can borrow bikes and lock them to the curb. The goal of the Boston Bikes program is to have 700 bikes on the streets by the end of 2015. Currently only 100 bikes are available for public use. Advertisement Bike corrals were first put in place on the Red Line in the 1970s by the city of Boston to provide safe, convenient and convenient spaces for people to borrow bikes from the transit system. The Boston Bikes corral for the Green Line will be more similar to what cyclists in other cities have experienced. In the past, a corral would typically have about 18 or 20 bikes in it for free to people like students, office workers, and other people who need bikes. According to the Boston city-designated Bikes website, the corrals are designed for commuters, cyclists and pedestrians. It cites some examples of recent bicycle corrals in other cities: "In Chicago, people use corrals like this when they want to take advantage of the new on-street bike-share, CTA, buses and trains are available, and they do not want to go out of their way to find a station that has an available bike rack. People also use corrals like this when trying to return their bikes after a ride in a transit system that has bike racks, such as the Washington region's Metrorail and CTA. When these corrals were first installed in Chicago they had around 20-25 stations where people could return their bicycle. Now corrals are so full that people can only use them if they are parked a maximum of 100 feet from one another, which makes them a perfect candidate for a bike corral." Advertisement So far, about 20 bike corrals in Boston have been opened by the city-designated Boston Bikes program. The cities of San Francisco, Austin, and Seattle have also opened corrals in recent years. The bike corrals in Boston will be similar in structure to similar programs in other cities. The corrals will have at least one bike with a lock and bike racks. The bikes will have a unique color scheme that will hopefully be memorable to the people around it. Bikes could be borrowed and locked in the corrals for 30 minutes per day. Bikes will be charged an annual fee based on the distance the bicycle is traveled. These bike corrals could be used for short-distance trips downtown, to the South End or downtown Boston. Advertisement The city has set up three different levels to award licenses to companies that build bike corrals. Currently there are two tiers which were awarded to a company called BikeRescue, whose corrals are located at the Museum of Science and Industry, MIT and the Boston Commons in downtown Boston. Another company, BikeHub Inc. Inc., was awarded a three-tier license for an existing corral at South Station that will open in time for Bike the Boston Marathon in April of 2014. Companies that received the first tier licenses must complete a design assessment, which assesses the need for the corrals in Boston. Then the companies will make certain modifications to their corrals to meet the requirements. A final inspection is given by the city if the changes haven't been made. Finally, the company must submit a plan to the city explaining their plans to implement bike corrals and provide plans to have all the necessary equipment and resources in place such as a locking mechanism. They are allowed only one year to be in use before the city must start issuing a ticket to the company to begin issuing a citation. To read the full grant agreement you can head here, and see the full list of companies that have received permits to open bike corrals can be found here. (Update: the three companies receiving third stage licenses for existing corrals are the Massachusetts Bicycle Racing Association, the Boston Cyclist Union Inc., and the MassBike Foundation). Advertisement In an email to the Globe, Massachusetts Department of Transportation engineer Mike Ross said that, based on initial test runs at South Station, those corrals are likely to require minimal modifications. It remains uncertain, however, whether the city can afford to put the extra $18,000 a year into operating those corrals for 60 months. "It's not the cost of the license, it's what that license fee would be," Ross said. "If we're going to dedicate the city money on this, that money should be put to use." But in addition to the time it would take to make the modifications, the bike corrals will also need to be purchased and stored at one of the corrals once they are opened up, Ross said.

After the first week I would estimate that our site gets close to a million visits per day. It goes through peak traffic on Mondays and Saturdays. I can see a few hundred thousand people visiting our site during the week, I'd say we're pretty well-known in the industry as well. I do a lot of other things online, but what we do on GIGABYTE.US is where the money is on. That being said, I've been at GIGABYTE on and off for almost seven years. Before the GIGABYTE.US project began, I was known around the internet as the guy who gave free video cards to various customers. I worked at a big retail store and I started a little online game store called Digital Chaos, but it didn't get very good reviews and I wound up giving most of the business to TuxGames in 2006 (the website wasn't up yet), which was where GIGABYTE.US is a spin-off from. Since then, I've been back to school to get my MBA and work as a product manager and developer. It was through my work as a product manager that I realized how much I had learned on my own online in the past. I knew how to optimize a page for pageviews but that didn't include what users did after they arrived in your page. There was something missing. The problem is that I have had little to no experience with games. I could get it on the phone and through a console, but that was it. One day I was browsing the web. I saw how people got around in the early days of the internet. They got around through mail orders. I decided to see what mail order sites were around in the old days too. At this time the internet was still very new, so there were still lots of websites and servers back then that people used back then. They'd use them to order stuff from the post office and sometimes they'd even send money that way. Back then it was usually fairly easy to get someone (preferably not you) to do something online. I figured that mail order was the best way to get in touch with the people that were actually making the game. I'd even read that a lot of these guys had their own websites. These guys wouldn't take the phone call you sent them on a walkie-talkie, so you had to go through mailing lists. This was how I first met Paul from Digital Chaos. He had his own personal website and it was all about buying game systems online. The next problem to solve Paul was one of those people that just wanted to give the players something new, something new and unique. I thought the mail order thing was a great idea, even if it was a pain in the ass, but this email was going to blow their minds. Then he did something that blew my mind and made me realize this whole idea of making a site where people could order something online was the answer. If it was going to work and not cause any serious problems, then it was worth a shot. Paul, my mentor and mentor in many ways, thought of my mail order service as part of our development plans, not a gimmick or something that we were doing to pad our profits or create some kind of free marketing (the other companies who did mail order didn't do that, they were like my competition here I think). That made me realize that it's our site that's going to sell what we sell and that it's only natural to ask for cash. All this lead me to believe that we are the first company to actually have a mail order service that lets people sell a game system online on a personal website. And then it happened. I got an email from GIGABYTE saying they were doing mail order and that the site was in the works. I immediately had to get in touch with Paul. I emailed him and said, "Hey Paul, I guess this is a little crazy and we can't really go live, but I'd like to do some eCommerce on the web and have you create something to handle the payments and all that kind of stuff. I want this to be your baby so I can be involved. I'm sure you have lots of cool ideas but I want to help you. Can we talk about this?" Paul had such a strong sense of what needed to be done that he made me a deal. I didn't have to pay him anywhere near what he was charging other companies at that time for the same sort of service, but he was going to make sure that our mail order process would work properly. That deal made all the difference. I still remember my first day online at GIGABYTE in January of 2007. It seemed like it was over night. My inbox was flooded. People who just saw my email were asking where the site was. I was overwhelmed with so many new things. When I came online I saw that the

Image copyright AP Image caption Mr Trump has repeatedly said China is using the US as a "penalty" or pawn in trade disputes US President-elect Donald Trump is a "dishonest liar" who would use tariffs to force his way into China's markets, China's official news agency has said. In an article, the Global Times said Mr Trump's promise to protect American jobs is a "farce". It also suggested Mr Trump's victory showed the US "is a banana republic" - a term that originated in the 1930s. Trump Tower is in the city of Shanghai. The New York developer won the election in Tuesday's US election. "From his [Mr Trump's] campaign, it should be obvious he is a cynical opportunist and a dishonourable man," the Global Times said. Citing a recent tweet by the president-elect stating he won the popular vote but lost the Electoral College, it suggested the US was "a one-man dictatorship". "China will also watch the changes in the US. Should he push the buttons to start a trade war, he'll immediately be branded as a puppet of the big US car companies and their Chinese rivals," the article added. Image copyright AP Image caption Mr Trump promised to label China a currency manipulator during the campaign The report also argued the global economy had lost its "socialist basis", adding: "The world's most powerful nation could lose its power." The article went on to say that Mr Trump's election was a "major blow for the whole free world". "His rise in the US elections should be clearly seen as a warning from the Chinese public to their own country." Mr Trump had repeatedly said he wanted to label China a currency manipulator while campaigning for president. But on Wednesday, China's foreign minister spokesman Geng Shuang said "China never attempts to 'deter' or 'prevent' other countries from freely managing their currencies". While the global economy has been growing steadily, many economists say many countries are slowing for the wrong reasons. On Tuesday, European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said trade between the EU and the US would get more difficult if Trump were to be elected. Mr Juncker said his countries would be "less competitive in the global economy and would see their economies shrink while the United States becomes even stronger". A spokeswoman for the European Commission warned that Mr Juncker's comments were not aimed at any US election party, but were aimed at countries in the European Union. A number of countries in the EU are also concerned about Mr Trump's plans to implement a "Buy American" policy and potentially impose tariffs on Chinese goods.

What would you do if a random person in a supermarket asked you to buy them a few litres of a cheap bottled water and then, instead of giving it back, the police pulled you away from the counter like a criminal and asked you to sign a blank piece of paper as evidence? What would you do if someone gave you a ticket for smoking a cigarette on the pavement? What if an elderly man tried to cross the street while holding a walkman in one hand and a glass with a bottle of cheap beer in the other hand? In most instances, if you're going to be ticketed for smoking or drink driving you're not going to go to court, you're going to go along with the ticket. But in Scotland, what most people don't believe is that the Scottish government can use the police to enforce a law when it didn't make them make it in the first place. I have worked in Scotland for 13 years, mainly in local government. There is a law in Scotland that if you're fined for a ticket you can be forced to cough up the fine. It has been used by the police to threaten petty offenders. For example, a couple I know were both given fines of £60 (£60 on each fine, per month) for littering. This is only a small taste of the abuse being inflicted upon the citizenry in Scotland. A recent report by the Scottish Parliament said that £1bn was lost the last 3 years of the Scottish Government as a result of the police not following up with people who'd been summonsed to court. This is £1bn which could have been used in services or social provision. But it's only for a few people who've been summonsed. And the report says that in some cases, the police refused to charge the people because they were homeless or didn't have the money. The whole system has been corrupted by the fear of being fined. These are just some of the examples of how Scottish government can use the police to enforce laws without making them. I think there's a case for all sorts of reforms to reduce the scale of policing in Scotland. But in this case it could actually be a case of a very bad law made good and a great injustice made worse. The police should not use police powers as a substitute for a good legal system The only way to change the situation is for Scotland's government to come and back the proposals of the Scottish Parliament. But Scotland only has 16 of the 53 devolved MPs. And the Scottish people have to take their decisions at an election. Some politicians in the UK have suggested that the Scottish people have to be asked to vote on this issue at the next election. This is to be expected. We have been through this in the rest of our island. People don't just vote for an individual councillor; they have to vote for their whole council or city council, etcetera, etcetera. But it is time for the UK government to back the Scottish Parliament, which has been putting forward these proposals for the past 18 months or so. The Westminster government has been talking tough on criminal justice reform and the police and prisons are now very underfunded. If Scotland cannot be trusted to set its own criminal law, then neither can it be trusted to fund criminal justice services. A police force that can't enforce the law is not a police force. That was not always the situation in Britain and in this country where you had civil servants making up their own laws and then having the rest of us enforce them. We have to rebuild the trust and the capacity of our police and the courts so that people know that there is genuine justice when they are breaking the law. Not all the time but when people are breaking the law. You might think that it is not too much to ask that when a person has been given a fixed penalty notice for parking on a footpath, that the police do a more robust checking on whether he or she has a genuine right to park there. If not, the police should not waste public money on this ticket. But because it is Scotland it is up to the Scottish Government to decide who they are going to send the parking notices to. It's not for an individual. A few months ago I had a taxi driver pull up in front of me in the street with a ticket under my numberplate. The man had told the police that we had been having phone conversations about whether I was a prostitute, and that he had written down my numberplate because he didn't want to go through this process again if we didn't actually know each other, so he needed an official document to prove this. I told the police that he had given me a numberplate and he told them that he had done so. That's his business, that's his car. But instead of taking no action he wrote a ticket under the passenger numberplate – this is ridiculous. So the police came round to the taxi and asked why I had signed this for his

The only way out of this mess is through the eyes of a small child. They are often the most vulnerable at the heart of a crisis because they are powerless to protect themselves. We all have an intrinsic need to be loved and loved as a child. It is the emotional connection that this basic need provides that can save us in a crisis. This is a hard truth. We can all sympathize with the little, helpless boy staring out at his world without a mother and father in sight. This post is not a call for pity or for pity politics—which have been used to delegitimize an argument for much of human history—but rather an indictment of a particular worldview that can be used to justify the death and misery inflicted on our children, often without any recognition of the damage of their existence. We need a new way to look at the world for our children. And it is not through the lens of an abstract system in an ivory tower. I am not defending the killing of children, and neither are my friends at NAP. The idea of killing a child is horrifying to most, but these same people are the first to defend the death of a person with any kind of disability, disease, trauma, aging, or severe pain. There is no question that the people who suffer the most pain and anguish in the lives of children are their caregivers—but not through "choice" but through physical and emotional abuse. "Let's not pretend that our kids have rights. They don't." This kind of attitude is a powerful weapon. It can be used to excuse child abuse and to justify the deaths of children with disabilities like Down Syndrome or Alzheimer's. They say that a child's right to live is more important than someone else's right to die. This "truly caring" is all too often used to justify child death. It takes a willful blindness to see how much misery is inflicted upon children, especially their helpless, broken-hearted, and often traumatized "little humans." It is a willful blindness that I am here to fight. What is neglect, abuse, and abuse of an older person? Disservice, abuse, and abuse of an older person is the result of a failure by a caregiver to adequately provide for a loved one. An older adult needs emotional, physical, and spiritual care as much as a child or teenager but they are still in need of care nonetheless. For this purpose, the term "disservice" refers to the acts of neglect or abuse of an older person. This definition takes into account the very real difference that older adults need in order to survive, and it is an important part of the concept of neglect. An elder's care—even if it is only "just" something you could offer to make your loved one feel better—is very much like love, and it is a very powerful thing. This is the crux of a great issue facing us: the age of care. Many older adults do not know how to care for their own needs. They get stuck in what many call the "care trap," where they are so overwhelmed that they have to rely on other adults for help. The problem is so bad that it is affecting thousands of people in nursing homes, retirement homes, and assisted living centers. In this sense, the term neglect may be applied to all people who are too frail to provide for themselves, but it is being used to describe the neglect of elders in our society more than any other age group. It is hard to explain to a child what neglect is without sounding callous, but in the context of our modern society it is a stark and devastating reality. So often, even those who do not understand what neglect is can easily see why it needs to be eliminated from nursing homes, retirement homes, and assisted living centers. This type of care is not about personal choice. It is about the social and economic system at work, where we must make a choice between paying for someone's survival and caring for ourselves. There are no other choices. We choose, not so much a caregiver's competence, but simply whether it is the right thing to do at the moment. If you or a friend are experiencing care issues at home or in another setting and wish to share your story, our helpline number is 1-800-950-7283. You may also submit a care complaint online. The bottom line is that we need a system that supports our need for care while at the same time allows us to be healthy adults with the time and energy to take care of ourselves. It is important to know that the choices we make will determine how much, if at all, our loved one will need of us—but we cannot be sure of that knowledge. We cannot wait for "healthcare," as much as we like to think of ourselves as free to make choices, and

Titanfall 2's servers are set to be back online by tomorrow. The original Titanfall was one of the first big name multiplayer shooters to introduce "buddy co-op" features, allowing a second player to jump in and take on an opposing trooper. Those kinds of systems are a big deal, and for fans of the previous game Titanfall 2 is a big game, with a ton to work through. Here's everything you need to know about Titanfall 2's new co-op features: What is the buddy system in Titanfall 2? Titanfall 2's Buddy System allows players to work with two other humans to take on enemy Titan pilots. How do the two human pilots cooperate? The two human pilots have an individual score, each. The two pilots have an individual score, each. They also work together in the same way humans would in regular multiplayer. By running into a Titan, or taking a Titan down with a group of players, the pilots will earn medals along the way. Will having buddy co-op work in some places? There are many different scenarios that will allow players to play either solo or with another human. The players can work together in free-for-alls, team deathmatches, or even other modes such as Last Titan Standing. How do players earn their buddy medals in Titanfall 2? Each pilot has an individual score, which is used to evaluate the teamwork. Players can earn medals by taking down enemies with a group of players, and by taking down an enemy Titan. In this way, players earn medals in different play styles to support their teammates in the field. How will Pilot Armor work? Titanfall 2 introduces new technology that improves pilots' ability to fly and survive in the field. Unlike most shooters, player health can be completely regenerated after being knocked out with a single hit, meaning players can be knocked out repeatedly and still be able to fly and have the ability to survive. Players also have new health-regen abilities called Armor Packs that can be used to refill their health over time. A couple of the new features in Titanfall 2: Grenade Launchers and Rocket Launchers Pilots can launch grenades (including mines) and rockets by pressing the X button. The Grenade Launcher has a maximum damage of 200, and rockets have a maximum damage of 300. Additionally, players with armor or shield can use these attacks in place of traditional attacks to help survive in the heat of battle. Titan Boost The Titan Boost has been improved: Pilot characters can now jump to a great height. When jumping, the Titan Boost will automatically start to slow the character just before impact, giving the pilots better positioning and positioning in a Titanfight. Once the pilot reaches the height they aimed for, they can quickly reach high surfaces by pressing the jump key again. These abilities can be useful during a titan fight when your teammates just need a little extra boost to reach a high surface quickly. GTA Online GTA Online has always had a good selection of co-op options, and now players are able to take on some of those modes with their buddies in the new Titanfall 2. If you want to take on a co-op match with your friends, there are two modes you can select: Heist and Bounty Hunter that is an online-only mode. If you haven't gotten the opportunity to try out either, check out this quick video demonstration: Co-op for GTA Online takes place in Heist and Bounty Hunter. Hip-Hop Hip-hop is the popular arcade game mode in GTA Online, and again this mode is able to be played with teammates. In both Heist and Bounty Hunter, there is a small drop zone that allows the players to take on an opposing faction during a gang battle. On the ground, each faction has unique abilities, and both teams will need to coordinate each of these abilities well if they want to survive a match. This is just a brief glimpse at some of the different modes Titanfall 2 has coming to the game. With two player co-op comes more options for co-op gameplay, and these are just the tip of the iceberg. Are you excited about co-op in Titanfall 2? What type of co-op modes are you hoping to unlock with the upcoming patch? Share your own Titanfall 2 co-op tips and tricks in the comments below! Source: EA

Frequently mentioned in the press, the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter (DSF) program appears to have some key weaknesses — specifically the cost and schedule. The problems are so pervasive and seemingly intractable — they appear in recent comments made by military commanders, military leaders, and senior lawmakers. That's a serious problem because the F-35 is set to become the American Air Force's first all-conventional fighters. It's projected to cost about $400 billion — about twice the cost of building the Lockheed Martin F-35 today. And yet the F-35's schedule and cost problems are the very things that will be cited by its supporters as reasons to cancel the plane before it is ever fully combat ready, even if there are technical problems. Some critics — including the Pentagon's own top weapons tester — have said the F-35's problems are so severe that it cannot be considered safe for combat, and that the Air Force should stop designing and buying them until the flaws are largely resolved. Advertisement And yet the Air Force's own director of operational test and evaluation (DOT&E), Lt. Gen. Chris Bogdan recently said that the F-35 has "some of the most robust testing programs you could possibly have." Get Ground Game in your inbox: Daily updates and analysis on national politics from James Pindell. Sign Up Thank you for signing up! Sign up for more newsletters here So how has the F-35's problems remained hidden from the public, and the Pentagon, for so long? For starters, some of the problems are hidden in the program's own figures about how many people will be flying the F-35 by 2015. According to a summary report by the Pentagon inspector general, the F-35 Joint Program Office (JPO), one of three agencies overseeing the program, was unable to provide full and accurate financial details on its F-35 program office budget from 2010 to 2012. Because the Navy and the Air Force are doing more testing of the stealthy F-22 and its potential adversaries, respectively, the report estimated that "further cost adjustments due to reduced testing will have a greater impact on the JPO's projected final aircraft budget." The report also noted "further testing to improve mission capabilities will also add to the expected cost increases." Advertisement This last caveat is crucial. While the F-35's problems have been clear to many who have looked at them closely, the Pentagon's own top defense tester, John Butterfield, suggested in May that "at least some testing and refinement" of the plane were not needed after all. For example, the Air Force's initial certification that the F-35D could serve in "night" air defense missions last December, Butterfield pointed out, is still based on initial flight data, when the plane still has to be tested. Bogdan took this to mean the Air Force needed to conduct a second flight test by October — and have it be judged in early November as "stable and performing." Butterfield concluded that the schedule "has not changed significantly in the last year." That echoes statements made a year ago, in which he told the Boston Globe, "What we've concluded in terms of what happens in the certification is that in the short run we have not increased the schedule significantly." Bogdan, for his part, has defended his comments on cost by arguing the "F-35 represents a new kind of airplane." He has said that no major design changes are required. "The challenge is not the design, it is actually flying," he said. Nevertheless, the Pentagon's inspector general, which released one of the reports in conjunction with an audit released in early December, noted that "the testing of the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter continues to be more difficult than expected, with problems associated with key systems and with software that has been not fully tested." Advertisement That was followed up by this statement from the DOD inspector general: "Joint strike fighter development was not designed to achieve near-reliable and repeatable developmental testing." This is the latest in a series of reports from the Pentagon inspector general that have raised serious concerns about problems with the F-35's design and production. Since its initial announcement in January 2008, the F-35 program has cost over $1 trillion and is predicted to cost more than $1 trillion over the next two decades. The Air Force has asked for another $20 billion to $30 billion in savings over that same period. Congress passed a spending bill that set aside about $8.5 billion for F-35 problems — a relatively small chunk of the over $600 billion that has been budgeted in the current fiscal year. The Air Force's F-35 program office, the Joint Program Office, has argued that some of most critical problems can be solved by redesigning its

The U.K. has to be on the cutting edge because, for now, it's the only country where it's possible. I've had a ton of people tell me this week that the U.K. (or Australia, or New Zealand, or South Africa, or so on) should get on the cutting edge of AI. I've had them go on as if there were nothing to learn, as if these technologies do not exist and aren't here to stay. Yet there are now a multitude of people trying to get the next generation of these technologies up, running, and working. It's still early days, the applications are incredibly complicated, and the technologies are very immature. However, from where I sit it looks like we should get on, and while there haven't been a lot of examples (yet) of where this has led, in a few years we could have a really disruptive technology that doesn't exist today. The problem is that it's all about the cost of the technology. Just as the cost of the technology used in electric cars has dropped from US$40,000 to $15,000, which has resulted from the massive cost reductions achieved (for now) through battery technology and innovation in electric car batteries, it looks like we could see the cost of AI coming down even further. While there are still a lot of issues that need to be worked out before this can happen, the bottom line is there are a ton of great engineers and innovators out there working on solving these issues. Just as there are great inventors who come up with amazing ideas and make money by making it happen, too. I think the most important thing here is to remember that these technologies are already here: the algorithms, algorithms, algorithms, algorithms. We have the technology today to create autonomous systems, and the cost is only increasing by just enough that the opportunity for success is there. That said, it's all about the cost. AI needs to be affordable enough so that it can be deployed at a lower cost. The technology just doesn't exist yet, but the economics of the space are already very promising. AI is only as good as its data. The data we create to build it is critical. It is the data that enables the machine learning algorithm to function, to discover novel behavior, and to optimize solutions. For AI technology to be successful, it has to be as easy to adopt as it needs to be difficult for the adversary to build an effective counter. The first and most important thing to do is to build a data ecosystem that makes it easy for people to use (in particular for startups), because that's what's going to drive the adoption. It sounds like a cliche, but it's actually not. This ecosystem needs to be made up of many very different players. There are two primary categories of players: developers and institutions. If you're a CEO or a CTO or someone involved in an AI startup, you're not going to be involved with any organizations that are not part of a development team. Those people need to be empowered to create the data, the problems, and the solutions. This means ensuring there are great tools, APIs for data and insights, and other kinds of tools to help developers, institutions, and startups develop their own AI algorithms, tools that make that data easily accessible. This also means a focus on getting the algorithms into users hands, ensuring they're quick to learn and adaptable. Developers are going to build the solutions. This is not surprising! We've got the hardware, the software and the people, it's just a matter of putting it all together. We need to make sure that organizations and software developers are going to be able to build systems that can tackle all the problems on the grid. We've got some great resources available to help achieve this. At the moment, at least, there really aren't a lot of solutions with the complexity needed to solve this problem. This is an enormous time and money commitment for developers. If anyone is willing to take that on and make the investment, I guarantee you can see an exponential increase in the adoption of these technologies. If you're an organization that can build these solutions and is willing to hire the best of the best (developers) and work tirelessly on the problem, I bet it's going to be very difficult to come up against any major organization with an AI solution that they won't be able to defeat. If you want to do AI right (and I think you do!), let developers do the hard parts. So in summary: we have the tech. It's just a matter of making it affordable enough that it can be deployed at a lower cost. Let's do that. — We've already written a bunch on AI, and while there are a few more books or articles we've written, there are more I want to put out there: here are a couple that I think are going to be huge hits:

Image copyright AP Image caption Mr Trump has been using the golf course in Scotland as a backdrop for his campaign American presidential hopeful Donald Trump has announced his Scottish partner, Aberdeen Golf Links in Ayrshire, will host the final round of the US Open. It comes as the businessman said he believed Scots would vote to stay in the UK, even though they were "much closer" to England. He is holding an event at the course on Friday before heading to Scotland. Last Friday, it was reported a letter from his Scottish solicitors would be delivered to Brexit Secretary David Davis this morning. The US Open, which was moved from the UK to New York last year, starts on Sunday. The organisers of events say they are "working hard to confirm venues and confirm dates for the 2018 event". The first round of the event, which includes the title at 13:00 local time (06:00 GMT), is being held in the afternoon. The British Open starts on Wednesday and Mr Trump is the favourite to win the tournament despite the strong protest from British golfers.

The FBI will be in contact with the U.S. Border Patrol later this week in Puerto Rico in order to determine if any suspected marijuana coming into the country as part of a drug interdiction on U.S. soil was being shipped through Puerto Rico, the Department of Justice's public affairs office confirmed to Reuters on Monday. In response to a Freedom of Information Act request for more details on the meeting, the Justice department said it is looking for additional information from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which is known to be increasing its presence in Puerto Rico as part of a mission to combat illegal immigration and drug trafficking. The news about an upcoming meeting could signal a major shift in approach in the U.S. government's approach to the island, which has for decades been ravaged by poverty and crime. The U.S. island territory has a very specific role in the drug war, which seeks to interdict shipments of marijuana and other drugs by law enforcement agencies such as the FBI to the mainland as a way to put a dent in the Mexican drug trade. While such seizures are typically very large, it's a relatively rare case where drugs would be interdicted directly from the U.S. mainland to Puerto Rico. It's also somewhat remarkable that the American public would be aware of such an event, according to Dan Riffle, the director of federal policies at the Marijuana Policy Project. In the past, the case of the interdiction itself has often become much more public, Riffle said, citing how the Department of Homeland Security, which was made aware of the incident, would often hold press conferences just to inform the public. This time, there will be no such announcement to the public. Riffle said that he doesn't expect the news to have an effect on the debate over the legalization of marijuana on the island. "I think the public will probably learn it isn't a big deal and there will be no big political change," Riffle said. "It really doesn't impact the island's ability to have marijuana access and use." Still, the DOJ's announcement will likely serve as a reminder about just how difficult it is to enforce the U.S. laws against growing and selling pot in Puerto Rico, where the police force is currently underfunded and understaffed. It also underlines a point of interest shared by the federal government and the island's governor, Alejandro Garcia Padilla, who is a longtime critic of the current approach of interdiction. "For those of you who have visited Puerto Rico, you should know that it is a huge challenge to arrest and convict people here," Garcia Padilla said in a statement issued after the Justice Department was made aware of the possible incident. Still, there could be some other effects that the news will bring the island's elected officials into a greater public spotlight. Riffle said that the fact that Puerto Rico's governor and the Trump administration will be discussing their shared goals on drug policy could potentially play out in favor of the mayor of San Juan saying that she will be working closely with the U.S. government when it comes to addressing drug policy in Puerto Rico. "I think that in this case there are some things Puerto Rico needs to think about," Riffle said. "On the one hand, it's important for them to know that their administration isn't ignoring people who are using drugs, that it has resources that are available, and that it will get to people who are using drugs."

DETROIT (Reuters) - Two Detroit police officers were charged on Friday with murder for shooting and killing an unarmed black man in July that triggered days of rioting, looting and arson in the city's poorest African-American neighborhoods. Rochelle Clark, 44, the mother of Marvin Orr (center) and mother of the suspect, Tanisha Anderson, holds a protest sign as she waits for the charges to be read in the Detroit police shooting death of Orr, in Detroit, Michigan on October 29, 2012. REUTERS/Rebecca Cook Owen Newman and Edward Mays, who are expected to be arraigned on Monday, have not addressed the charges before. The indictment, seen by Reuters on Friday night, alleges both officers "knowingly engaged in a scheme to commit murder." Newman and Mays face a maximum sentence of life in prison if convicted of first-degree murder, said Wayne County District Court Judge Cynthia Gray Hathaway. A court reporter confirmed that bail was set at $1 million from $200,000 for all two men. Police could not immediately be reached for comment. The incident drew national attention after footage showed Officer Edward Mays shooting Orr 13 times while he fled an arrest. He was captured minutes later and died the same day. In what prosecutors said was a ploy to justify their actions, both the Detroit Police Department and union representing officers at the time have denied Orr was resisting arrest. Orr's relatives have insisted they believe Orr was unarmed and was just trying to get away as his partner, Orman, tried taking his gun, which was found next to his body. The charges against Orr bring the total number of defendants in the case since July 25 to nine. Five of the nine defendants were initially charged on Thursday, though each eventually pleaded not guilty on each of the eight charges filed on Friday. On November 22, four officers - including Orman - were each convicted of assault and sentenced to probation or house arrest with electronic monitoring, after a judge said the incident was an assault on citizens rather than the police. Orr's family have said they still believe the officers committed a crime.

The White House on Monday issued a new policy directive outlining the steps it has taken in efforts to prevent gun violence in the United States as well as its plans to fight terrorism in the wake of the Islamic State's gruesome beheading of 21 Egyptian Christians. Speaking hours after a shooting, a statement from the White House said the administration had "made it a top priority to stop gun violence in this country, and to do this in a way that recognizes the unique risks faced by law enforcement officers and the families they serve." The directive, however, did not refer to guns as a threat to national security and is focused on preventing terrorism. The document did note the threat posed by domestic terrorism, including "acts of domestic terrorism," which include the killing of law enforcement officers or others, "criminal or unlawful threats" resulting in bodily harm or death, or those involving international terrorism. "Since 9/11, our nation has been united in supporting and protecting the rights of Americans to be able to protect themselves, to use firearms to protect their families, and to protect their communities," the directive says. "All Americans have an inherent right to feel safe in their homes and in their communities." JUST WATCHED Police: Man in U.S. over ISIS call from Egypt Replay More Videos ... MUST WATCH Police: Man in U.S. over ISIS call from Egypt 01:55 President Barack Obama said Saturday that the killing of a Christian Egyptian Coptic woman in an incident in northern California was a particularly "heinous" reminder of the need to confront the threat posed by extremists and the "evil they represent." "It's an outrage that this happened," Obama said. He acknowledged that the United States needed to do a better job of keeping guns out of the hands of known criminals and mentally unstable individuals. But he offered no public explanation for the policy directive and a U.S. official said it was not a response to the video showing the horrific murder of the Coptic Christians. "The White House is not commenting on specific videos," an administration official said. On Monday, it emerged that the video was posted on a social network used by a member of ISIS, a militant group based in the Sinai peninsula. The official said the administration did not have a direct link to the video, though "we do know that some extremist groups around the world have sought to depict what transpired as part of their recruitment campaigns, in their various languages," the official said. "They certainly will try to make clear that they're doing it for one reason, to attract attention," the official said. The killings have prompted protests worldwide and prompted the White House to ramp up counter-terrorism efforts both at home and abroad, including more U.S. airstrikes in Syria and Iraq. On Tuesday, Obama announced plans to create 10 new U.S. military drone bases. The new bases, including bases in South Carolina and Florida, will also help protect U.S. military personnel, embassies and other U.S. facilities in foreign countries to "make their own operations safer," said White House spokeswoman Caitlin Hayden. JUST WATCHED Coptic activist: 'This is about freedom, no matter your faith' Replay More Videos ... MUST WATCH Coptic activist: 'This is about freedom, no matter your faith' 02:02 But with ISIS claiming responsibility for the gruesome death of the Egyptian Christians, Obama's declaration of a "national emergency" on terror did not necessarily constitute an expansion in presidential authority. The Constitution's "special powers" allow the president to declare emergencies during an ongoing war for public protection, and to call to mobilize militia to protect citizens and U.S. interests, the U.S. State Department said. "A national emergency declared under any of the authorities listed in section 401(b)(2) may be invoked only by the President, or by the President's designee, for such period as he or she deems necessary to overcome an emergency declared by him or her or to protect the public safety," a statement from the State Department said. The White House said Obama was still reviewing how to protect U.S. citizens and American facilities worldwide after the video showing the slaying emerged in the aftermath of Saturday's massacre at a Coptic Catholic cathedral in Egypt. The White House has not identified the countries represented in the 10 new drone bases but officials are discussing other locations, some of which have been in the works for years and did not receive prior scrutiny, a U.S. official said. Officials indicated the U.S. was still in the process of identifying those countries, but said it would be "premature" to indicate whether any countries had been selected. Obama signed an executive order more than a week ago creating a special effort at the Department of Homeland Security and the Justice Department to prevent citizens from being radicalized.
