MEXICO CITY -- A Mexican man has been arrested on suspicion of raping a 19-year-old woman on the city's main shopping street on a weekend night. The victim, a college student, says she was followed by someone in an open car, and followed in a private motorbike. "I walked across the street and I was followed at speed (down Mexico City's main shopping avenue) in front of a hotel called 'Casa Marina' by an older man in a green BMW," she told reporters Monday, her nose bleeding from the attack. The victim says she was walking through the middle of the road on Friday in an open car to get to a friend's place when a man started following her as she ran to meet up with her friend. READ: Murder investigation into possible abduction and rape in Mexico "I decided to cross the road, and it was then he approached me. He had a black suitcase on his back. I felt afraid," the victim said. She says she tried to run, but she kept going at a much faster pace because she knew the path would take her to where her friend's apartment was. She says she was afraid to go back the other way, but decided to go through the pedestrian area instead. WATCH | Woman who said she was attacked on Mexico City's main avenue arrested The victim said she was attacked in front of a hotel called Casa Marina, on the main mall of Mexico City. The victim told reporters there was no surveillance camera in the area, and she believes her assailant might have been a stranger to everyone there. "I couldn't believe it when I saw the suitcase and the man following me. The attacker took control of both of my arms and I couldn't think straight," she said. WATCH: Man found guilty in Mexican student's rape She's now in the hospital with a broken nose and broken bones in her face and neck and is recovering. She says she can't go to work, and she will be on painkillers for the rest of the week. A nurse who saw the injuries told her the attacker is a foreigner. Authorities believe there may be more victims because the victim was followed from the Casa Marina hotel to the Plaza Moneris. She said she wasn't sure where the motorbike pulled her home and it's possible people have fled the scene. READ: 'I'm afraid to go back to my own apartment because I'm afraid to find the body': Mexico student Police are saying that the investigation doesn't seem to be related to terrorism, but that the investigation is currently in its early stages. The victim says she doesn't trust police who initially arrested the suspect. Police said they have launched an investigation into possible robbery or kidnapping and a possible hate crime. WATCH: What the 'Day of the Dead,' or Dia de los Muertos, really means This type of crime is extremely rare in Mexico City, according to Carlos Vazquez, head of municipal security. "It's a terrible crime, especially for a young female who might have a boyfriend, or maybe she's doing something she shouldn't do, or maybe she didn't get in her car or got in a car that wasn't her car. It's very much disturbing," Vazquez said. Municipal police said Monday this is the first case of its kind they've encountered. The victim said she met a man online and they met several times to have dinner. She said they've been seeing each other for a few months. The victim said she has a boyfriend and they are planning to get married, but she has decided not to go to a wedding because she's scared of what might happen. RELATED: Students say Mexico is becoming more dangerous The victim's family moved her to another apartment in the capital and they have to make a new plan for her as she spends every moment at the hospital. "She is going to stay with her parents, but I hope it's for one week so she can recover," the victim's cousin Maria del Carmen said. It's believed that a man was traveling with the victim in the car that night of the attack. Police have asked residents of the area to be on the lookout for the suspect. Meanwhile, the victim's parents are looking for help. They say she has a very bad feeling about what happened and they'll try to find and support each other in any way they can.

HONG KONG — It took five years for the latest government-initiated reforms, the latest crackdown from China's top diplomat, to finally reach Hong Kong's leaders. As it turns out, they're not all happy about it. On Tuesday, after nearly three weeks of negotiations, the Hong Kong government announced the details of two proposed national security laws that Beijing plans to push through with its local representatives before the end of the year. In essence, the laws would allow security authorities to monitor the activities of Hong Kong and Chinese citizens outside the city through broad powers of surveillance. Hong Kong, an autonomous place, has enjoyed significant autonomy in domestic policy making for the past 17 years. But the laws could severely limit the freedoms of the next Hong Kong leadership, and there's no guarantee that the new leadership would be willing to grant Beijing so much new power. After all, as the Chinese government has been increasingly aggressive toward the city in recent years, Hong Kong's government has become increasingly wary of its responsibilities, said James Leung, the head of law firm Kowloon S.C., which advocates free speech in Hong Kong. "This is just the latest step to push us back," Mr. Leung said. "Hong Kong has shown an increasingly defiant attitude over the last several years." In June 2008, for instance, China accused two high-profile Chinese human rights lawyers of working as foreign agents — a designation usually reserved for political activists — and sought their arrest. The Chinese authorities then detained the lawyers for more than 13 months, claiming that they were "under the control" of foreign agents. The detainees never denied they worked for lawyers, but Beijing denied that they actually were — at least publicly. "Hong Kong had a lot of people like [those lawyers] who stood up for the rights of human rights," said Leung. "Now, they're all in prison." The law that Mr. Leung describes would have a major impact in China. Beijing controls about 90% of Hong Kong's commerce, and the vast majority of its companies are Chinese government-owned, which limits the territory's ability to push back against Beijing. The law, by restricting the ability of government officials to monitor domestic activity, would further restrict the ability of Beijing to monitor foreign entities and individuals on Hong Kong soil — as well as the ability of Hong Kong people to see or communicate with mainland Chinese in any way they choose. And though the law doesn't explicitly mention the Chinese leadership or its members, it's impossible not to interpret it this way. Mr. Leung said the idea behind the law is that "politically sensitive information will be restricted," and that government activities would be "controlled or monitored." There's no indication in the statement from Hong Kong's government — issued on Tuesday and published only on Monday — that the laws are intended to monitor or control domestic political activity. But the wording is reminiscent of language the Chinese government has used in recent years when targeting the rights of Uighur refugees living in the region. In October last year, Beijing approved new national security laws that give security authorities more broad powers to monitor and surveil all citizens. Those authorities have broad discretion to grant people and organizations access to information about their personal affairs when deemed necessary. The new laws are currently undergoing public consultations. Hong Kong's government, meanwhile, has not been able to implement the laws until January, or so far anyway. It may be years before Hong Kong's legislation becomes fully implemented, Mr. Leung said. The two proposed national security laws, if approved, would come amid increasing tension between China and Hong Kong. First, there's the matter of Hong Kong's 2017 presidential election — which will play out with less drama now that a key Beijing-appointed committee has approved the candidates. The committee will select two of Hong Kong's three pro-Beijing candidates in the vote. (The other is one nominated by a major pro-democracy political party, which the committee chose not to include.) But Hong Kong's new pro-democracy chief executive, Leung Chun-ying, was not included in the committee's initial list. Some pro-democracy activists in Hong Kong were infuriated by that decision, calling it an attempt to remove Leung from the race. A day after he was excluded from the initial list, Leung was allowed to run for the top spot — a decision that sparked widespread protests across the city. The pro-democracy movement has held weekly demonstrations calling for Leung's removal, with over 4,000 people turning out each week, according to Hong Kong police. One of the leaders of that movement is Joshua Wong, a 17-year-old pro-democracy activist from student activist group Scholarism, who has just entered a new high school this fall. "The decision to exclude Leung Chun-ying is a big problem. … You can't just take away our rights without a fight

What was the reason for the attack upon us? asked one of his party-mates on Saturday. "Why did they attack us? These are questions I ask myself. We are at war. We are on the road to war." The first two rounds of the war against Isis-held Mosul were more or less a war of attrition on the ground, with Isis attacking Iraqi security forces in densely populated areas. When the Iraqi Special Forces and police managed to advance towards the eastern suburbs of the city, they were attacked from both sides, with the latter launching a powerful counter-attack. As the battle was underway, Isis reportedly launched a car bomb at the security forces, killing at least 15. Some of the victims were reportedly children, though many of the dead were believed to be Iraqi police or army. The army is trying to verify the figures. It was then that the city's residents began to flee to the countryside, where they were caught in the crossfire between the two sides. The government has been trying to enforce a heavy curfew since the militants' last assault on Mosul, after which locals were able to safely return. When the Iraqi forces tried to tighten the noose, they found few if any of their fellow citizens were willing to stay in the city. They were scared not of imminent death but of being locked up without food, medicine or blankets. "We had our own houses, cars, everything," said one Mosul resident. "Then Isis came and took them away." As Iraqi forces began to close in on the east side of the city, the city's residents began to fear a full-scale war would engulf them. While Isis's advance was halted over the weekend, the extremists still held the upper hand. "They have destroyed everything," said a Mosul resident who escaped the city. "Their snipers are everywhere. The streets are a war zone and they are ready to shoot at anyone and anything." One of his two sons went into the countryside with him, leaving their mother alone with their daughter. She was unable to flee with them because of the shelling of her house. Al-Zarqawi's successor, Abu Ayyub al-Masri, announces the creation of the Islamic State in Iraq (ISI). Reuters 3/40 2009 Still al-Qaeda-linked ISI claims responsibility for suicide bombings that killed 155 in Baghdad, as well as attacks in August and October killing 240, as President Obama announces troop withdrawal from Iraq in March. Getty Images 4/40 2010 Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi becomes head of ISI, at lowest ebb of Islamist militancy in Iraq, which sees last U.S. combat brigade depart. 5/40 2012 In Syria, protests (pictured here starting in Daree) have morphed into what president Assad labelled a "real war" with emergence of a coalition of forces opposed to Assad's regime. Syria group Jabhat al-Nusra are among rebel groups who refuse to join, denouncing it as a "conspiracy". Bombings targeting Shia areas, killing more than 500 people, spark fears of new sectarian conflict. Sunni Muslims stage protests across country against what they see as increasingly marginalisation by Shia-led government. AP 6/40 2013 Al-Baghdadi renames ISI as the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or Isis, as the group absorbs Syrian al-Nusra, gaining a foothold in Syria. In response, al-Qaeda chief Ayman al-Zawahiri (Bin Laden's successor) concerned about Isis' expansion orders that Isis be dissolved and ISI operations should be confined to Iraq. This order is rejected by al-Baghdadi. AFP 7/40 2014 - January Isis fighters capture the Iraqi cities of Fallujah and Ramadi, giving them base to launch slew of attacks further south. AP 8/40 2014 - June Isis declares itself the Caliphate, calling itself Islamic State (IS). The group captures Mosul, Iraq's second largest city; Tal Afar, just 93 miles from Syrian border; and the central Iraqi city of Tikrit. These advances sent shockwaves around the world. 9/40 2014 - June Around the same time Isis releases a video calling for western Muslims to join the Caliphate and fight, prompting new evaluations of extremists groups social media understanding. 10/40 2014 - June Isis take Baiji oil fields in Iraq - giving them access to huge amounts of possible revenue. The United Kingdom has joined the United States in urging its citizens not to go to Syria but if they do it should be for strictly humanitarian reasons, Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond said on Friday. Mr. Hammond was speaking at a meeting with the United States' ambassador to the United Kingdom David Miliband in London on Friday. "I am concerned that people who are interested in travelling to Syria to join the civil war there are doing so for purposes other than helping the people of Syria," Mr. Hammond said. Mr. Hammond said those who had left Britain to fight in Syria had not engaged, trained or given humanitarian aid to the Syrian people. "We hope the British people will do the rest of us a great favour and not get involved in that sort of nonsense," he said. Mr. Miliband said that Britain was also worried by reports that Syria has a chemical weapons program. "We have every reason to believe that Syria has some military capabilities, even if it cannot yet use them," he said. Britain has been taking steps to strengthen its defenses, including putting into place new military training courses. A year-long civil war in Syria began in March 2011 when the government of Prime Minister Hafez al-Assad was violently removed from power. At least 70,000 people have died. The conflict has also spilled over into neighboring Iraq.

Newton has a penchant for doing the unexpected, and even more so than he did this summer, with his second half surge in the MVP race. What do the Golden State Warriors do when they get a steal, an incredible basket, a moment of greatness or one of the most spectacular plays in playoff history? They do something extraordinary: They go for it again or take one of the best shots in recent NBA history. Golden State did just that late Saturday night, when the Warriors took advantage of a breakaway to take out the Denver Nuggets in double overtime and win the NBA Championship 105-99. It was the type of play that the Warriors do not often get, at least not on national TV. WATCH: Warriors defeat Nuggets on D-Wade's big shot The play may not have been the type of shot in the playoffs that gets the attention, but you can't really expect the Warriors to have a routine performance, can you? So when Curry took the ball from Curry and fired a ball that went in at the buzzer, it might have felt as if the Finals had turned into an exhibition. But there wasn't any pretense. The play was part of an eight-minute run of three consecutive Golden State buckets in the fourth quarter that set up that play that put the Warriors ahead 105-99. The Warriors led 109-102 with 1:06 left in the fourth on a 20-foot, fadeaway jumper by Andre Iguodala off of a pass from Klay Thompson with 7:24 left. Things didn't get any better for the Nuggets. In the following 1:20, the Warriors had an open-look 3-pointer from Curry's right hand, but Klay Thompson was knocked out of the game a few seconds later with an apparent leg injury. Iguodala missed a runner with 14.8 seconds to go, and the Warriors scored the final seven points of the period to win. It was the type of play that the Warriors do not often get, at least not on national TV. But you can't really expect the Warriors to have a routine performance, can you? So when Curry took the ball from Curry and fired a ball that went in at the buzzer, it might have felt as if the Finals had turned into an exhibition. But there wasn't any pretense. The play was part of an eight-minute run of three consecutive Golden State buckets in the fourth quarter that set up that play on a breakaway by Stephen Curry late in double overtime that tied the game at 105-105. What if the play had not been the steal and the 3-pointer was not the 3-pointer? That game would never have ended. It is just one of those crazy plays that happens in the NBA. Stephen Curry finished with 33 points on 10-20 shooting to lead the Warriors. For Denver, J.J. Hickson finished with 19 points while Ty Lawson had 17 for the Nuggets. What do you think of this play? Did the Warriors pull a prank by having Curry take the ball and play a two-man game on a fast break?

Polls from last week show that over 4 in 10 Americans believe the nation will be stronger should it ratify the treaty, but they are just three to four points more likely to vote yes than no, giving the campaign a slight edge in support from independents. If ratified, the treaty would represent a significant shift in power and jurisdiction from countries to the United States, potentially altering federal law, the rule of law and national security. The treaty will likely have to undergo public debates in the coming years as politicians across the United States discuss the implications of its provisions for domestic and international law. This week, our friends at the National Journal weighed in, noting the many benefits and potential downsides of ratifying the treaty. In addition to being a big deal for the United States, the treaty would allow America to more easily monitor the use of U.S. troops and resources in other nations. While it does not give the United States the power of force, it would give American citizens a clear idea of when and how their tax dollars and international aid to a foreign country ends. It would also require countries to make major transparency and accountability changes as well as provide an annual report to Congress on human rights and civil liberties. Here are some more facts from the article about the treaty. One of the most important parts of this treaty are its transparency provisions, which would require member nations to make public any information that may be used to investigate violations of human rights laws or other laws of the treaty's signatories. These provisions would allow members of the public to see exactly how the United States or other members are using funds appropriated by Congress and how a country in that country is performing on human rights. There is an added bonus for Americans: if it's ratified, the UN will no longer be responsible for administering the U.S. domestic human rights laws such as the Freedom of Access to Information act and the Electronic Communications Privacy Act. These laws are overseen by the U.S. government and will remain so under a ratified treaty. Another added benefit for Americans: under this treaty, American taxpayers will no longer have to provide human rights fund payments to a UN human rights body. Instead, Americans will be able to keep this money on their domestic financial assets and will then not have to pay taxes on the money earned from the transfer of funds. Ratifying this treaty will allow the United States military to have legal jurisdiction in some of these nations — the U.S. will no longer have to send troops from the United States to defend civilians in the country. And when a U.S. servicemember is hurt in foreign countries, including from the use of military force, the U.S. will no longer be responsible for paying medical bills. Another big reason to support Obama's decision to ratify this treaty is that it would allow the U.S. to better monitor aid and money that it helps with. Because so much of the money is fungible and the U.S. can keep track of how much of the money that goes to foreign countries is actually going to help those people, it will be easier to track and verify the use of military funds. In addition, ratifying the treaty will give American taxpayers better knowledge at a time when the world economy needs more transparency and accountability from government. The U.S. would be a better place to do business and for trade and investment, as American companies will no longer be held responsible if their countries violate human rights laws that they are expected to abide by. Here's an infographic to show you how a ratified UN treaty could affect American's law.

As the U.S. embarks on a military campaign against the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) militants, it needs a robust intelligence-gathering network that is strong enough to keep tabs on terrorist organizations operating in the West, President Obama said Wednesday. "We certainly need a very high level of cooperation, especially within Europe, between intelligence services, between military and civilian authorities, between law enforcement and regulatory agencies and business networks," the White House press secretary said during a news briefing at the White House. However, "we are not talking about 100,000 [officers] right now," Carney added, although that's a target the United States wants to achieve. According to the U.K. Guardian newspaper, a senior U.S. intelligence official says "the United States needs 50,000 to 100,000 active-duty intelligence personnel across Europe to monitor the continent's jihadist movement." According to a Pentagon report, the U.S. military is already on track to reach Obama's goal within the next three weeks. Carney said the U.S. is pursuing that effort through various avenues, including direct intelligence-sharing, partnering with foreign countries, and working in partnership with civil intelligence services. "So the bottom line is we need to have in place the proper intelligence infrastructure to deal with terrorists, just as we need to have the relevant capabilities in place to defend this nation, and all of the folks in the region," Carney said. U.S. officials say U.S. intelligence networks will be "vital," but they are also working on developing new strategies to counter the terrorist threat.

Somewhere in the world, a young woman is being raped on a daily basis in the name of God and Allah. That is precisely the view of a radical Muslim cleric in Bangladesh. This is the first time a non-majority religious organization has called for Islamic law to be applied in an Islamic country and the woman in question, an advocate for religious freedom, is being punished as a result. According to Bangladesh Observer, the victim, Mahfuzul Islam, is a member of the All Bangladesh Women's Front (ABWF), a group calling for a ban on Muslim marriages, the conversion of non-Muslims to Islam, and the death penalty for apostates. When asked why she doesn't submit to the husband's demands, Mahfuzul is said to have replied "In the name of Allah, I am not going to marry that man…and if I am going to submit to him, I am not going to submit to death penalty." It goes on to say that Islam gives "the man the right to decide what woman he wants to marry." However, when a Muslim man, married to a Hindu woman or a Christian woman, wants to marry a woman of another religion, such person is said to be "deviated" and "unbelieving," and "should be killed, tortured [or] thrown into hell." Mahfuzul's words are being used to justify Sharia law, which states that if a woman's husband does not find an acceptable match for her, then "he may kill her, or he may punish her, or he may divorce her, or he may enslave her, or he may force her into marriage." This is what the group is proposing in Bangladesh, but Mahfuzul and her fellow women's rights activists, according to Bangladeshi newspaper The Daily Star, are being labeled "deviant" and "unbelieving" by other Muslims due to their "lack of belief." To be fair, one doesn't have to be devout Muslim to call for Islamic law to be applied in the West in order to maintain the religious freedoms guaranteed by the Western legal system. In fact, in the Netherlands, the Islamic courts have ruled that a man, in the middle of a marriage when he becomes sick and desires to divorce his wife, can force the woman in question in front of the religious tribunal to agree to "woo the husband with an immaculate wife," or have her wife legally recognized as his property. But Bangladesh isn't a modern, modern country, and the fact remains that many Muslim women in that country who have spoken out against the atrocities of Islam are being subjected to brutal and brutal punishments in the name of the religion. And so, while her fellow activists and many Muslims may call in good faith for religious law to be applied to Bangladeshi law, one must wonder: if such laws had been in place in the United States, what would have happened to Mahfuzul Islam? Her life may have been a living hell, but she is not alone. A recent report from the U.S. State Department warned U.S. citizens in Bangladesh of "dangerous religious extremism." As a result, many Americans are afraid to venture to the Muslim-majority country. In response, Bangladesh's minister of information and broadcasting, Shahriar Alam, said recently during an English language interview in the country's English daily The Daily Star that Bangladeshis have "no problem" with Westerners or tourists visiting Islam's holiest cities in Mecca and Medina, but "we cannot allow people to visit the birthplace of the Prophet who married a 6-year-old and he died at 39." This comes from a man who is not only responsible for enforcing Sharia law but who has been promoting Islamic supremacist ideology since he was a child. He appears to be the perfect leader for Islam's extremist movements in Bangladesh, and he should be the one who would be held up as an example of what happens when women are victims of religious law.

It is with heavy hearts that we announce that the production of the fifth edition of Het is being delayed to October. This is entirely a personal decision. While we feel we can't bring Het to a completion and release a fifth edition before the season arrives, we are aware that some fans are eager for a fifth edition. We know that Het is very significant to the Twin Peaks community. We hope these news will please you all in some way. We are extremely grateful to all the fans who have already signed up for the fifth edition—even though there is still room—and we are thrilled that some new fans have registered. Our production team will be back at work as soon as we have an actual timeline for the upcoming season.

This is not my deck. It is what I learned through the last two seasons, playing against opponents who were so close to playing their best deck. I made some minor adjustments to the deck last night and I think it's better than ever! This deck is designed to punish your opponent for playing a non-legendary class like hunter or warrior by drawing them out, setting up big board clears, and destroying them. The deck focuses on two things: A) Making quick, aggressive plays, B) Building up a board with minions that help you finish the game quickly and efficiently, For A, this includes: -Fury Swipes and Charge, -Savage Roar, -Mountain Giant, -Killer Klown, -Bite, -Amani Berserker, -Dire Wolf Alpha, -Gang Up and Charge, -Charge, -Fury Swipes while facing aggro, -Kronroh, -Shield Slam, -Unstable Ghoul, -Kobold Geomancer, -Sunkeeper Tarim, -Argent Squire, The deck makes use of cards like Kill Command, Kill Command, and Deadly Poison to help clear out enemies out of the game. Against B, the deck relies on a mixture of minions and weapon cards to finish off and overwhelm your foes. To start off, let me say that I feel like this is one of the strongest and most fun decks I've ever played. Let me explain: First, I have to thank HEXTCGplayer.com that I've met them through their website and I feel like I've gotten to know them a lot more through this forum. They took the deck concept and ran with it and taught me quite a bit. Also, before my initial run, I had played a version of this Deck on the website where the deck had 6-8 minions on board at the beginning. After running a few matches and learning the deck and the combos, I noticed that I was never able to finish a game before my opponent drew their entire deck. I'm sure there must have been a good reason to do this, but I don't want to jump to any conclusions. The game is always changing and with an extremely high win rate of close to 55%, I am confident that they did it to punish you for playing the non-legendary class. Now that I've changed the list drastically, I have the following changes: -Removed 1 Deadly Poison -Removed Kill Command -Added Kill Command, 2 Shadowsteps -Added Acolyte of Pain -Updated card backs All of the above was done by me and I made sure to test and adjust each step I made. After the deck worked out, I then did a quick search to find other people who ran the deck and posted their thoughts. Since I am quite experienced, I decided to go up to 3 Shadowsteps, 2 Kill Command, 2 Acolyte of Pain, and 2 Arkenstone. Here my main changes to the list: -Removed a 2-drop -Removed Acolyte of Pain -Removed Kill Command -Removed 2 Kill Commands -Removed Arkenstone -Removed 2 Killer Knocks -Removed Acolyte of Pain -Removed Assassinate -Removed Shadowstep And this is how the deck looked after running all of my adjustments. I do realize that there may be more than one play you can make to optimize the deck for you. My advice then would be to adjust the core of the deck so that you are only playing one Kill Command. I hope you all enjoyed this deck and I wish you all the best. I'll update this deck as I play more games and adjust.

The most recent poll showed Trump at 33 percent — his worst showing yet. Many of his supporters are expressing a lack of confidence in the candidate's ability to lead the nation. "We've been talking about how bad he is and how terrible he is, and that's only after [Clinton and Trump] have been in office," says Della Valle, 44, a registered Republican who supports Trump. "They are just not ready." Others see more possibilities for Clinton's defeat. She has had her own bump, but not the kind Trump supporters cite. She would still defeat Trump, the majority of pollsters say. "She would probably be the worse person to be president, probably, by a long shot," says Patrick Caddell, an independent pundit widely published on network television. But Caddell and other forecasters — including the nonpartisan FiveThirtyEight political newsletter — do not think she would take the presidency. "Even in a world in which it's very close, she doesn't have a good shot in a landslide," Caddell says. In recent weeks, Clinton has had her highest-profile rallies and was the subject of a new ad from her running mate, Sen. Tim Kaine, D-Va., on television. But other Clinton events haven't boosted her popularity. A Monmouth University poll on April 7-11 found that just 16 percent of voters would be more likely to vote for a candidate who is viewed favorably by the news media. In a CNN/ORC International Poll two days earlier, just 11 percent said they felt a lot closer to casting their ballot for Clinton while 60 percent were leery of it. Her unfavorable numbers were even higher, at 41 percent. "The numbers that she's being tested in by the media are far, far higher than anything her numbers were prior to this campaign," says Larry Sabato, director of the Center for Politics at the University of Virginia. Trump and his aides have claimed that their rallies have drawn more people to the polls in recent weeks. But the polls do not support this claim. A Monmouth survey in late March found that the rallies that drew the most people to the polls weren't in swing states where Clinton often barnstorms: Georgia, Florida and North Carolina. Instead, the rallies that drew the highest poll numbers, like those by Trump and his own supporters, tend to be in states that he needs to win in order to win the presidency. The poll shows that Trump's supporters are not only disaffected with the Obama administration but also with the economy. In that same Monmouth poll, 50 percent of Trump supporters had an unfavorable view of the country's economy, compared to 33 percent who said favorable. In March, a Gallup poll found that 55 percent of those who voted for Trump in the Republican primaries viewed the economy negatively, while 30 percent were optimistic that the economy would improve in the future. "They're not looking for a better America," Caddell says of Trump's loyal supporters. "They want to see America succeed." At Trump's campaign rallies this week, supporters often express the same sentiments. "I'm a lifelong Democrat, but I voted for Donald Trump because he's a businessman and a man of action and he's got the experience, he's got the grit for this job and he's going to make good decisions," says John Anderson, 72, a retired truck driver wearing an America-themed cap and a T-shirt with his face on the back. Anderson is among many who say that a Clinton win could harm their lives. "The country that I live in is really going down the toilet," Anderson says, echoing a theme that many of the pollsters' interviews uncover. "It's a lot of people are getting poorer and the rest are getting poorer. And things are getting worse and worse."

The official website for the television anime adaptation of Ryo Akiyama 's Shokugeki no Soma manga revealed three new staff members on Sunday. Kazuaki Morita ( Shōnen Hollywood -The Movie- ') is directing the anime at Doga Kobo , and Takanori Asai ( Mobile Suit Gundam Seed , Shirobako , No. 6 ) is in charge of series scripts. Nobuhiro Kobayashi is supervising the series scripts. Akira Hiyama ( The Great Passage , Shōnen Hollywood ) is designing the characters. Nobuyuki Hayashi ( Kiznaiver , No. 6 ) is composing the music. The story revolves around the Yūha clan, which has five members of a superpowered family, the Soma family. The siblings of the Yūha clan are the youngest siblings in the entire clan, Sōma, Misha, and Kuromaru. They strive to inherit the position of the Yūha, which their parents and elder brother don't have. The story is set in Sōma's hometown, where the young Sōma is just beginning to grasp how to deal with the other kids in school.

On Saturday a large crowd of protesters turned out at the Republican debate in New Hampshire over the killing of James Foley by Islamic State militants. One of them was John McElroy, a freelance photojournalist from New York who had been reporting for CNN. Mr McElroy, who was wearing a CNN T-shirt that read "American Hero," was detained by State Department security after his press pass apparently was found at the event. The State Department, however, released a statement saying the journalist was not detained or prevented from getting on to a plane to go back to his home in New York City. It says that Mr McElroy was detained when he was about to be flown home. "However, he was not escorted to the airport. He was not asked to produce his credentials or undergo any security screening," the statement said. The statement went on to say that Mr McElroy had not broken any laws and that his press accreditation was valid. Mr McElroy has been working as a freelance correspondent since 2005 and has won awards for his work. At a speech at the debate on Saturday, Mr Trump said Mr McElroy was "very proud of his heritage." The President-elect said that "if somebody said it was not, they would have never picked him for the Middle East" - a reference to the conflict between the Palestinian Authority and Israel. "I want news media that represent our civilisation, not one that's got a different political viewpoint than a reporter from the other side." A White House press briefing later on Saturday was scheduled to be held by Mr Trump's press secretary, Sean Spicer. "The president expects to hear from the press corps. He expects to have a lively and robust briefing," Mr Spicer said.

MILO'S GIRLFRIEND CONFIRMED FOR SEX AS-SAULT (UPDATE) Tanya Gersh, the former boyfriend of Milo Yiannopoulos' former girlfriend, has confirmed to The Daily Beast that she was allegedly assaulted by Yiannopoulos and his friends in 2015.

Facing mounting allegations of rape against Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump, former Miss Universe Alicia Machado said she was "victimized" by Trump while he was in power, despite his claims on the campaign trail that he did not sexually assault her. "I was an innocent victim… He could have stopped it," Machado said in an appearance Sunday on CBS's "Face the Nation." "He should have said, 'She did not attack me.' I could have stopped it, but he chose not to. What were you thinking to run this pageant? I ran this pageant to be like America's beauty queen, I wanted to be like a super model, something like that. I wanted to break all records. When he saw me he smiled." On Friday, The Washington Post released audio and written descriptions of several women, who accused Trump of making inappropriate advances and unwanted sexual contact. Machado, an award-winning Miss Universe in 1996 at age 23, said Trump threatened to ruin her career after she refused his advances. "He just ripped [my] arm away from me," Machado said. "He was laughing. No, he was shaking, laughing. He just twisted my arm. It's like – I saw him moving all around in my body." Machado said that she thought Trump was on to another sex assault victim because the former reality TV star is not the type of person to attack people in public and said he has not been accused of anything like that before. "He's an arrogant, greedy man," Machado said. "He has that kind of body… He should not be a part of this organization." Machado also said she found Trump attractive and he invited her to his house. She was "in shock," she said, and thought, "'I cannot be raped by him or be a victim of him.'" Machado had earlier told CNN's Anderson Cooper that she did not "belive that he did not rape me" since "he already did a lot, in front of my eyes, and I was already humiliated."

A study published Monday in the Canadian Medical Association Journal reports that the number of patients visiting emergency departments in British Columbia will increase by over 5,100 per year to reach a record-high of more than 300,000 patients over the next 10 years. The study also predicts that this trend will continue in all provinces.

A Florida man who was charged with animal cruelty for killing a cat with a lawnmower, then driving several miles to kill the cat's owner was sentenced Thursday to a year of probation. William J. Haug was convicted May 7 after a month-long trial in Palm Beach County Circuit Court of one count of animal cruelty and two counts of driving with a suspended or revoked license in connection with the May 16, 2010, killing of a female bobcat on a residential street near Boca Raton. According to the Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office, Boca Raton police received reports that a man had fatally maimed his cat on a residential street in the village of Boca Raton. The owner told police the cat had clawed and beheaded itself in the yard of a home. He said he had placed the cat outside his home for several days and allowed it out into the yard several times a day so it would not be afraid. Police took the cat to a local animal clinic to be examined but the animal did not survive. Police learned that the cat had sustained numerous injuries consistent with being mauled by a large urban cat, an animal expert testified during trial. Boca Raton police, Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office and U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service officials conducted a six-month investigation of Haug. They found that his license had been suspended for a year in March 2010, the day before the killing of the bobcat. Under Florida law, a driver is prohibited from operating a motor vehicle on the road except when he or she is operating a motorcycle, moped, wheelchair, bicycle or vessel or transporting passengers for hire.

The U.S. Justice Department has—for the first time—made it illegal to lie repeatedly about your income in response to a federal tax assessment. The new rule, signed last month, does not apply to Social Security income and is a far cry from a "no income" campaign. But by making it illegal to lie with your income, the Obama administration was putting more power in the hands of ordinary citizens. Here's how it works: If the IRS asks for some information about where you work, you will have to respond honestly. If you falsely claim your income as "independent contractor" and don't work at all, you could be slapped with a hefty $3,000 fine and up to five years in prison. This is a major victory for taxpayers. Most of us have lived with the threat of this audit of our finances for as long as I have owned a mortgage. And even as we've fought for years to get it abolished or cut back for the sake of the taxpayer, not a single reform has been made. Taxpayers have already begun suing over this new law, but it still has to withstand a challenge before the U.S. Supreme Court. But with the Obama administration's encouragement, all this litigation could make a comeback. As a former mortgage attorney, I've become a bit of a tax policy wonk. I've always thought that people should be allowed to falsely claim certain types of income under the tax code, as long as it wasn't an attempt to hide some sort of criminal activity. After all, if someone is honest about having no income from any source, as they should be, that means they're being "innocent." And when people who are honest about their finances are also being "innocent" of tax avoidance, there is far less to worry about. Indeed, if honest taxpayers are the least of our problems, then what's the problem with tax avoidance? Why should anyone be worried about it?

It was a nice run - I don't know that people will want to watch it again just because of the incident, he said. Mr O'Neill said he did not want to press charges against Ms Kelly, saying he was "not going to start something like a witch-hunt". Ms Kelly, from Finglas, north Dublin, was last year awarded an OBE by the Queen. It would have been her first decoration when she was awarded the medal in 2002. She won a number of awards over several years before winning an MBE for services to the Irish film industry in 2013. The decision to award her an OBE was a significant one, as it recognised her work as a film producer, as well as her contributions to the Irish film industry. Ms Kelly had been due to retire from acting in Dublin on February 5, but the decision means that she will stay in the city up to her 75th birthday. Irish Independent

The new iPad has taken its place as the biggest-selling tablet for Apple, which is now on track to top iPad sales of its previous two iterations, the fourth-generation iPad and the second-generation iPad. At least that's what Macquarie Securities analyst Peter Misek says in his note to clients today, published after Apple's quarterly earnings call yesterday. According to his estimates, the new iPad was Apple's top selling product in the country in the month of April, selling more than one million units in the quarter. That's a significant leap from his earlier predictions in late February, when he said the new iPad would only sell about 350,000 units during the March quarter. It's worth noting that Apple doesn't break out iPhone sales by country, but MacQuarie says iPhone sales in April are off only about 2 percentage points from a year ago, suggesting Apple has still not lost its foothold on mobile. The iPad is the best-selling tablet Apple has ever sold, MacQuarie writes, but there's still room for growth. The company expects the new iPad to sell 200,000 units in Apple's remaining fiscal year, which begins in November. That leaves Apple ahead of its competitors in tablets, and still ahead of the industry, as long as demand doesn't start to slow. The company sold 12.5 million iPads in the March quarter, beating analyst expectations for 10 million units. But it was a pretty solid second quarter for tablets overall -- the sector only managed sales of 5 million in the March quarter, and 10 million in the April quarter. At the same time, sales of Macs dipped, while iPad sales continued to surge. Apple sold 9 million Macs in the quarter -- and 11.54 million since the new iPad was announced -- a jump of 2.2 million over the previous fiscal quarter. That's about the same amount it sold the previous June, and it suggests Apple had a solid second quarter overall on the back of surging demand.

The war has left millions of men, women, and children wounded and dead, including civilians who have been left homeless, while forcing hundreds of thousands of desperate refugees to seek new hope in other countries. In recent decades, the Russian economy has taken a hit from a collapsing ruble, which has been almost completely devalued against the dollar. Russia has also spent massive amounts of money supporting the regime of Bashar al-Assad, a man who has committed a long and brutal history of human rights abuses by using chemical weapons, as well as committing genocide against the Syrian people. #14 India India is a country which has been engaged in a deadly struggle for more than 100 years in the quest for independence, which has claimed the lives of over 5 million people, including an army of 20 million. However, one of the most notorious atrocities is the rape and sexual enslavement of millions of Indian women by British soldiers and colonial administrators. The rapes were motivated by an alleged policy that said "Indian women were fair game to be taken, killed, and raped as desired". The most gruesome fact of all? India's own army and police are still involved in these horrendous crimes today. What a disgrace. #13 Indonesia The country of Indonesia continues to be the second worst place on Earth in terms of human rights. The most extreme example of this is the continued imprisonment of over 200,000 Rohingya Muslims, ethnic Rohingya who have lived in the country for almost a century. This persecution is in part fueled by the violent ethnic cleansing of the state of Rakhine by the Burmese military, resulting in millions of refugees seeking new homes elsewhere. The mass rapes and crimes of torture continue to this very day, while Indonesia uses its diplomatic position to keep the global community in the dark about its complicity in these atrocities. #12 Syria The country that would probably be thought of as the worst country in the world by many Westerners is the Syrian nation. In less than 5 years, Syria has gone from being a peaceful country with a strong economy to an internationally recognized war torn tinderbox of an island. When the war began, it was fought with the backing of Russian military, diplomatic, financial, and financial elite. Today, this support is largely gone, and the same people that were once allied with Russia to prop up Syrian President Assad are now actively seeking him out in search of a blood bath to add to their long list of massacres. #11 Iran The Iranian people are the victims of a war that is no longer being fought for the benefit of one people. The Iranian nation is no longer the vibrant state that it once was, as its former ally Saudi Arabia has been allowed to exploit both its oil industry and its country's nuclear energy capabilities for economic gain. Iran's oil wealth is now largely used to sustain the Saudi monarchy's war machine and its own domestic repression. When the Arab Spring swept

We love it when we get to see our favorite celebrity models get down on our screens. But when that means sharing a nude body with the world, the results are always…unexpected. A new film from Director James L. Brooks shows just how out of control nude is when it hits screens. The film stars Naomi Watts, Jamie Lee Curtis, and Jamie Lynne Seinfield, and is a very adult dramedy based on the autobiography of Michael Crichton, who wrote the book, The Girl Who Was Plugged In. Brooks is known for his low-budget movies set in the 1980s, often starring the famous faces he's worked with before. The Girl Who Was Plugged in was shot on a shoestring budget, and has become the rare mainstream movie starring celebrities. Watts plays Amanda, trying to get away from her husband (Curtis) and her career in Hollywood to raise her daughter in L.A. We see Amanda go from her "normal" life as a stay-at-home mom to being a porn star on the set of a new sex film. In the end, Amanda finally meets her match with Pamela Lynn (Seinfield), who has a hard-on for Amanda. The rest of the cast consists of a plethora of familiar faces in supporting roles: Jamie Lee Curtis – Amanda's former modeling agent Mia Hansen-Love – Michael Crichton's wife Emilie De Ravin – the woman who plugs things into Amanda Nina Arden – a photographer who knows Amanda's secret Rory Fitzgerald – a producer trying to make a career out of their relationship Sally Lane – a high-end dominatrix Jamie Lynn Seinfield – Pamela Lynn's ex-girlfriend Jamie Lee Curtis is just as talented with her nudity as she is on screen. Watts' performance as Amanda really shows off her charisma. Curtis takes the role very seriously, and even gets in a few laughs as he and Watts both get embarrassed. The whole cast is great, too, and the chemistry between them is palpable. Even though The Girl Who Was Plugged In is a very adult film with nudity, it's not overtly sexual or violent. Instead, Brooks is trying to capture the tension between sex and privacy. And that's just what he does. The Girl Who Was Plugged In has gotten mixed reviews, but I feel like the more that you watch it, the more you see it for what it actually is. It's a fascinating and at times hilarious look at the ups and downs of sex and celebrity. Even Watts gives it her all, having to strip down to her lingerie and posing nude with Curtis. But, even though The Girl Who Was Plugged In is a movie with a lot of nudity, it also has a very low budget, and that makes for a very good way to show it off. It's so unique and different that I wanted to post it, and hopefully you'll enjoy it too. The Girl Who Was Plugged in opens on September 21st in U.S. theaters. We'll have more to share this week as the trailer begins rolling. Keep checking back! Follow me on Twitter @polarbearstv for daily updates on film and television, and photography whenever I post something new.

The New York Jets just cut their opening day practice squad, and it was a quiet day for the team. So this morning I put together a look at some of the players who showed up, and one name that stood out was right guard Willie Colon. Colon was signed as a free agent by the Jets last week. Last year he spent most of last season on the New Orleans Saints roster, splitting time between guard and tackle. There hasn't been any indication that he is a future starter for the Jets, but he's certainly something, and was a fan of the organization when he visited for meetings the day after the Jets signed him. He's a tough guy to take a shot at, even though he's only in his fourth year in the league. In three years he's only had three injuries: a broken jaw, a concussion and a shoulder and elbow injury, the latter of which he suffered this season. In college, Willie was a first round pick of the Chicago Bears, selected in the 3rd round of the 2010 draft. That was a long time ago. If the Jets need him, they can always bring him up at any point. The key is that he's a backup at this point in the game. He's got some familiarity with Mike Maccagnan, as both were teammates of years past in New Orleans, and they'd both been cut this month. In addition, Willie and Maccagnan were two of the assistant head coaches during Maccagnan's time with the 49ers, and both have connections to the Ravens as well. Colon does not have an extensive background as a backup, but what we'll see is how he handles the Jets' opening game against Houston, who are the No. 7 ranked rushing team this season. [UPDATE]: Willie Colon has been released.

A new survey of young people has found a link between atheism and violence, and has also found more people are identifying as atheist. The American Religious Identification Survey (ARIS) polled over 18,000 people in the US in 2011, to determine the religious leanings of young Americans. The results of the survey show that a significant portion of the young people surveyed are not religiously affiliated, with a significant rise since 2007. "The results reflect an emerging pattern in America — that young people in fact are having less religious affiliation and affiliation with a religion is declining as the percentage of the population that is nonreligious increases," said Dr. James Gross, director of the Center for the Study of Public Religion at the University of Oklahoma. The ARIS found that there are more than 23,800 young people who do not identify with any religion, while just over 5,600 are affiliated with a religion but have lost their faith. The survey also found that there are 5,200 fewer young people who identify as Christian than in 2007. The survey found that over one-third of the people surveyed identify as atheist, agnostic, humanist or skeptic, and over 10 percent are agnostic or atheist. According the American Atheists, the percentage of these groups has increased more than 200 percent since 2007. In 2001, only 0.38 percent of Americans identified as atheist. By 2011, that number had increased to 0.88 percent, and is expected to be much higher in 2015. "The increase in nonreligious Americans is largely due to increased recruitment from non-Christian backgrounds rather than to a general rise in non-belief," said Richard Wike, a researcher in the Institute for Studies. The results of the survey showed that over one-third of the people surveyed identify as Christian, and less than 5 percent of Americans identify as atheist, agnostic or humanist. In 2001, the survey found that only 1 percent of Americans didn't identify with a religion. The survey also found that young women report a much larger percentage of Christians, with about 40 percent identifying as Christian rather than as atheist, agnostic or humanist. The survey indicates a similar trend, with the percentage of young men who are religious compared to young women is growing. The ARIS found that 15 percent of young men identify as Christian, while just over 14 percent of young women identify as Christian. Despite the increase in the number of young people with non-religious beliefs, religious affiliation is still the most preferred group among the non-religious. The ARIS found that over three-quarters of the people who don't consider themselves religiously affiliated are religiously affiliated. The least commonly preferred group was atheists/agnostics/secular humanists, and "nothing in particular."

A former student of one of the world's leading Islamic schools says he was forced to marry a young Yazidi woman in Syria after he was caught having an affair with a married Christian. Hamza, who had studied at Al-Huda College in Kuala Lumpur, said he was initially happy to marry the Christian woman following her religious upbringing, then his former girlfriend began to pressure him not to "marry a Muslim". "I was young, I was happy to marry a Christian. I was so happy I can't express it," Hamza, who wished to remain anonymous, told The New Straits Times from an unspecified location in Malaysia. "After about a month I was getting a lot of threats. She (the woman his former girlfriend) told some people that if I didn't marry her that maybe my mother would leave me. "She said she would kill the woman if I did not go with her. "She told other people that you have to save your virginity, so she would go around telling Muslim girls not to have premarital sex so they had a better chance to marry." Mr Hamza, now 26, said he became increasingly worried after his former girlfriend went to her parents about the threats and the threats came true. "She has gone to her parents because her parents are very strict Christian... they refused to accept my relationship. "I had not been drinking, or doing any things I should not have been doing, that is why she thought something might have happened between me and her... but I believe I was innocent," he said. "When I called my parents, they told me I must get divorced from her." Mr Hamza said his former girlfriend then began to threaten him for the sake of her religion and after two months of being physically abused by his girlfriend, he decided to move to Syria, where he hopes to become a doctor and an expert in the field of Islamic education. "I did not want to stay here (in Malaysia). I was not really happy in Kuala Lumpur... so I said to myself I have to get a life and work, get a place to live here where they don't harass you as much. I hope I can save myself for a better future after this." The New Straits Times is unable to contact Hamza for his own safety. Hamza's story is just one of the many from Malaysia's Malaysian Islamic students' association in conflict with Islamic authorities in the area about where they do Islamic education, or what they are allowed to do after they complete their studies. But Mr Hamza's story is just the latest of many reported on the group this year and one of its members said Malaysia's government was failing the Muslim students by accepting their claims of religious persecution. The religious students association, part of the country's second Islamic political party, has claimed that it has been victim of intimidation by Islamist Malaysia's governing religious party. The government, however has maintained that the religious students association is not welcome in the country. It has said it is not accepting their claims that their rights are being infringed. "The Malaysians have decided not to recognise our situation, this is their decision and it's not for us to dictate to them," MCA president Mokhtar Hamzah said. "The problem is we have a very powerful Muslim majority in the country... and they have their ideas about Islamic teaching. "To be honest, it's hard to find anyone that will speak out for us." The government is now considering an ordinance, which will require teachers in Islamic religious classes or programmes to provide their own copies of Islam's holy books at government expense each time they are copied, reports The New Straits Times. Hamza, who now lives in a house with 14 other girls, said they had to leave Malaysia after the school threatened him if he did not get married. In Malaysia's Shariah law, if a Muslim male and a Muslim female are in a relationship and both have not consummated it, then both are not allowed to marry. "If a relationship develops into a marriage, the Shariah law says that person are no longer legally the other's husband," MCA representative Khairiza Farah said. "That can be disastrous for a couple who wants to keep the relationship intact." The government has since made it easier for couples to have their relationships recognised under Shariah law, by not allowing a court to approve a Shariah marriage if the couple does not have parental consent or if there was fraud involved. It is not clear how many marriages are going to take place under Shariah law in Malaysia. In February last year, two members the Muslim students association were arrested after an argument in which the pair claimed they had been the victims of "unintentional racism". One member, Muhammad Fazila Abdul Az

This is a very cool looking piece of technology to say the least. If this is the sort of product you have in mind, you might want to take a closer look at the price. You could add even more of these to the list - which includes the following: "Paintings of the dead" "Museums in which corpses remain" "Museums for the dead" "Museums for the living" "Museums for the deaf and hearing impaired" "Museums for the blind" "Museums for the handicapped" "Museums for young men" "Museums for young women" "Museums for the elderly" "Museums for the very old" "Museums for the physically handicapped" "Museums for the blind" "Museums for the deaf and hearing impaired" "Museums for the physical handicapped" "Museums for the physically handicapped" "Museums for the mentally handicapped" "Museums for the mentally retarded" "Museums for the intellectually handicapped" "Museums for the physically handicapped" "Museums dedicated to the disabled" These were just a small sampling of the hundreds of categories that could apply to a museum. As I mentioned above, the U.S. Supreme Court has held that these categories do not necessarily constitute a de jure (permanent) place of worship and thus would not qualify for taxpayer-funded tax exemptions. While we wait for an official ruling, there's little cause to despair. You can still get tax breaks for museums and other types of privately funded religious organizations, provided they don't receive financial support from the federal government at the expense of churches, religious organizations, and their adherents. We'll get to that in just a moment. So, without further ado, here's the tax-exempt list of the most common museums in America. The Religious Foundation of the United States (RFUL), whose leaders include the likes of Jerry Falwell (pictured above) and Pat Robertson , is known for its ability to get religious groups — such as museums and universities — to apply for tax-preferred status and give them the kind of tax-preferred status that can cost them millions. As my colleague John McCormick wrote in 2004: The federal government does not distinguish between churches and religious organizations. In fact, it does not really distinguish between churches and any other religious institution, except the Mormon church, by granting them tax-exempt status. . . . Churches and religious institutions are given tax-preferred status because they need special help from the government to pay for the buildings, programs, and other activities of a religious institution, and only tax-preference status allows the charitable organization to spend more. In his own words (on page 11 in his book Christianity 101 and again in another passage). [T]he church's ability to obtain tax-preferred status is granted on the understanding that it will continue to operate in the same way as it has in the past. It means that we continue to operate under a single set of rules that apply to all religious organizations. The church believes it is in the public interest to be recognized for its religious and charitable work because it helps to strengthen the religious community, builds strong schools, and builds strong families. To make a charitable donation, the church must prove its commitment to a charitable work under the rules of an organization of its type, that "provides financial assistance to a religious or nonreligious organization so that it may continue to operate." So, as you can see, the Christian Science Church — which is a bona fide religious organization and operates under its own rules of its own kind — qualifies and does qualify for a tax-preference charitable status. And that, I think, makes a certain amount of sense, even if the church's stated intent is to "build stronger families", "strengthen schools", "build strong schools", etc. We've come across other examples elsewhere of tax-preferred status for certain religious groups: The Lutheran Church – Missouri Synod (LCMS) has a charitable status for its educational activities. The church's mission statement and tax-preferred status are listed on the church's website. The United Church of Christ in Cleveland operates in a similar fashion. It claims it is not, and never has been, a religious organization, despite the fact that both the UCC's purpose statement and its tax-preference status are listed on its website. Instead, the church operates under the rules of a church (and not a religious organization). And just last month, a UCC church in Houston was given tax-preferred status after the IRS determined it was operating as a for-profit congregation instead of as a religious organization. This was a victory for the church, because under tax-preferred status an individual congregation is only able

What do you mean, I will not get a medal? she asked. "It is the biggest honor anyone can get. I am not just saying this because I am a princess from another country and have no connection to any country. We are so pleased to have found a local publisher in England, with an expert editor in the United States. In England, we are very fortunate to have a strong and active literary life. There is no other part of the country that can boast such an abundance of bookshops and book magazines in the right sizes, at a number of different and excellent prices. Not only are there local literary magazines and bookshops, but national magazines, as well. We, like you, are very interested in literary publishing, both new and older material. At The Literary Review, we strive to produce publications of all national origins, in all the literary genres, from first-person essays to reviews, poetry, fiction, history. Some of our recent pieces include: "The Literary History of the English Poetry Movement," a book review of the first volume of The Eameses' New Poems , and "The English Poems of William Wordsworth in Their Own Words, 1900-1910," a new collection of his best-known poems. The Literary Review will continue to strive to support and encourage good writing as it pertains to the British Literature and Arts. Our goal is to publish work of British Literature and Arts throughout the world.

The man who was at the centre of a national debate over Islamism claimed the Islamic State had been trying to recruit him since the summer. The 27-year-old appeared on Newsnight with Jeremy Paxman to talk about his recent departure from Islamic State (Isis). He said: "They have been trying to recruit me for the last two or three months." Paxman then asked if he "wanted to die in a fire fight with the Islamic state" before explaining that the British Government had recently announced that he was being deported. When the presenter asked whether he was surprised, he said: "I don't know if I was, to be honest. I was expecting it. "I've been in this for four years now and even in Syria I saw Islamic State members who were very aggressive towards people. I was expecting them to be a bit more patient and a bit more patient and not try to force people." The revelation comes after footage emerged on Tuesday appearing to show an Isis fighter beheading James Foley, the second American journalist to be killed by the extremist group in recent months. The British member of staff said his life-changing journey began in July 2014. He was living in Syria at the time with a fellow Briton - fellow journalist Steven Sotloff who reportedly had been shot in the neck and face. Read more He told the documentary presenter: "We were together in Aleppo… We were both going to take our cars to go back to the UK. We both wanted to get out of there. "We went out in the morning for lunch. We ate. We drove in the night. We thought we left together for Manchester." He went on to explain that he was able to leave Syria because he wasn't in a military unit fighting against the Syrian government - a point of confusion for the Foreign Office and other British officials who previously said he had been on a "high-level IS unit". The footage, which appears to have come from a recent news channel documentary, showed his former colleague sitting in an interrogation room with his head wrapped in a black cloth. The camera was moved inside the room and then a man speaking with a voice accent raised in an Arabic dialect speaks through the cloth. He said "you are one of the British citizens that was recently killed, right?" but was still unable to give the name. James, who has an adopted Scottish father and a mother from the US, said he was "very, very sorry" for the death of Mr Sotloff and his family as his family had forgiven him. "I'm very, very, very sorry for killing the man Steven Sotloff and for his family and I'm very, very sorry to have taken Steven's life," he said.

The first part was hard, but you have to go to the place, and that's what I've done since the age of 10. That's how former Manchester City midfielder Carlos Tevez describes his path to the club, where he became the club's top scorer after leaving his boyhood club, River Plate. "It was hard, but I didn't give up," he continued. "I worked hard and stayed until I was a professional. Now I feel like I'm here to stay, but maybe I'll go to another English club in the future. It could be Liverpool, Arsenal, Manchester United and others. "I'd like to be in this position for three or four years. I'm 34 now, and I feel like I'll be more useful for another six to eight years." The Argentine isn't the only Manchester City product whose ambitions could see him in a different country in the future. Tevez, who played for the club's youth teams, made his senior debut in the 2011-12 season following a successful loan spell. He did very well, scoring five goals in his first five league games, but he didn't break his current team-mate Sergio Agüero's team-leading strike record that remained in place at the time. Agüero has now gone on to win it twice this season, and Tevez has made clear he can't see himself replacing the Argentinian in the near future. "I hope to be a better player and a better striker, but not to be compared with Agüero," explained Tevez. "He plays every game, he's very important for the club; without him they're not in the position they are now. For me it's about doing my job and contributing to the team. The most difficult thing is to say that I want to come back to Manchester City in two or three years, if I'm still a professional. We'll see in a few years at this age. Maybe not until, but I have a contract with Manchester City until June 2017. I've said time and again that I want to have a long-term contract." This may come as little surprise to those who follow Tevez closely, and it's certainly a contrast to what he said shortly before moving to Manchester City. When he first left River Plate in 2011, he was an up-and-coming forward who had been in the stands for the club's youth teams along with Tevez. Just weeks after his loan move from River began, he told reporters at the end of that season that he wanted to stay at the club, but that he hoped to get first team opportunities. Just nine days after his comments, Tevez left City for Old Trafford, and since that day the club have been talking about how they're a big part of his decision. "It doesn't surprise me because when someone says they want to stay and that they want to stay longer, I'm not surprised," Tevez said at the time. "I have a contract with a club, and sometimes the club thinks twice about letting a player go. If you don't do your job, that can happen in any sport, but football is different, as the money is big. In England I played in the Champions League at City, was named in the team of the year in 2012, and then I went home."

Lets get started! We need to find a name for a new game. Here are some possible names: Cup O' Joe: A game about creating your own unique cup of joe. Cup O' Joe. Cup O' Joe. Cup O' Joe. Cup O' Joe Coffee Break. Cup O' Joe Hot Coffee Break. Cup O' Joe Tea Break. Cup O' Joe Coffee Break with Caffeine. Cup O' Joe Hot Coffee Break with Caffeine. Cup O' Joe Tea Break with Caffeine. Cup O' Joe Hot Milk Break. Cup O' Joe Cool Caffeine. Fancy Cup O' Joe Game! Cup O' Joe: The Game, or simply cup O' Joes. Cup O' Joe: The Game. Cup O' Joe. Cup O' Joe: The Game. Cup O' Joe. Cup O' Joe: The Game. Cup O' Joe. Cup O' Joe: The Game. Cup O' Joe. Cup O' Joe: The Game. Cup O' Joe. Cup O' Joe, or cup O' Joe: Game or simply cup o' Joe? Cup O' Joe: The Game. Cup O' Joe. Cup O' Joe. It'll be a brand new game, but with familiar elements. I imagine the main game will be about creating a cup of joe for one of the players. They will get that one cup with their ingredients chosen at random. Once this cup is filled up, they are awarded a point or two and move on. They won't have too many ideas when filling their cup of joe. For the actual game there will be one board. All players will start off with a pile of cups. The table is a little large, I'll go with 60 players at 60 tables. The board will be 6×6, 5×5, 3×3, and 2×2. Each table will have a board with 2 tables on the same side, this will create 2 different cup of joe games. Players will start with 15 cups, and they'll move as far as they can. Each time they hit a wall, the cup is discarded, and that player adds a cup to their collection. Once they hit the end of the "Cup Road", this is "Cup Road". The player's score is based on total cup collection. The first player to get 100 points wins. First, lets make the ingredients. Each ingredient will have a name and a number. Flavors 1-5. All players create a cup of their flavor. These don't have to match the flavor number, you may make a unique cup of joe. The cup of joe will look in a random direction, it can be to the left or right, or in any direction. Cinnamon: 0-2 Cinnamon Kahlua: 1-3 Kahlua Vanilla: 4-5 Vanilla Mocha: 6-1 Mocha Peppermint: 2-4 Peppermint Vanilla bean: 3-5 Vanilla beans Mint: 6-6 Mint Lemon: 7-8 Lemon Sugar: 9-10 Sugar Cinnamon: Cinnamon is easy: Just find the number from 1 to 5, add them together and get the number in front of your name. For example, "1-2-4-5-6". For the "Kahlua" ingredients, find 5 in front of your name and add them all together. For example "4-5-6-8". For the "Vanilla" ingredients, it's much more involved. To find the number, the player must match the number before their name up with numbers from the next row up. This will count for 5. Once you put them in, match the number before it to "9-10". This will count for 10. Once that is done, match the numbers from the next rows up with the number below it. If matched, you get your number in the row below. For these examples, I used the numbers from the following row: "1-2-4-5-6" "4-5-6-8-9" This should match up exactly with the numbers that are on your ingredient ingredients. I also put "6-8-9-10-11" in there as well. The next thing we want to do is add them all up for the total score. This will give you the total score. Now you can score each player at anytime.
