The next level of the most advanced PC in the world, the GTX 1080 Ti is a quantum leap in performance over standard GTX 1080 graphics cards. Based on NVIDIA Pascal™ architecture, the GPU delivers a new level of gaming immersion, allowing you to game on an incredibly smooth 60 frames per second. It also supports DirectX 12 features and enables the next generation VR technology through 3D Vision. The GTX 1080 Ti is rated at 2.5 times the performance of reference design GTX 1080 graphics cards. What's in the Box The EVGA GTX 1080 Ti FTW3 Gaming Tower takes a page from the Tesla: In case your card runs out of steam, don't let the hardware failure scare you away from building and gaming on. With the EVGA ACX 2.0 cooler, you can now game with full confidence in your performance. EVGA ACX 2.0 coolers offer unmatched cooling capabilities to lower GPU temperatures by up to 5 degrees Celsius.

The FBI says an 18-year-old high school student allegedly kidnapped at gunpoint and killed at least 11 people at a rural Wisconsin farmhouse, calling the crime "senseless." Interested in ? Add as an interest to stay up to date on the latest news, video, and analysis from ABC News. Add Interest Authorities have identified six of the 12 victims of the Oct. 1 shooting at the rural residence in Oconto County, north of Green Bay, on the other side of Lake Michigan. Police have arrested Cody Cousins, of Oconto, on charges of first degree murder and 11 counts of first degree intentional homicide at the family farm, according to the Green Bay Press Gazette. Police are still searching for the other victim who died in the attack. The 18-year-old, identified Sunday as Dylan Klebold, is from Newtown, Connecticut. The two are students at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colorado, where they killed 17 people last April. Authorities have said they believe the gunman had planned the attack for at least three weeks. It is expected to take weeks for the criminal investigation to determine a motive behind the killings that were likely deliberate, according to the FBI. The FBI said Sunday that Cousins, who turned 18 on Oct. 30, is now in custody. It did not release a possible motive for the killings, though authorities said he was upset over family matters. "Although we mourn the tragic loss of all our victims and have continued to investigate throughout this investigation, we know that the FBI's investigation into this tragic event continues," the bureau said in a statement. The FBI statement said it will make this statement in more detail at a news conference scheduled for 1 p.m. ET Monday in Washington, D.C. at which the agency will explain why it believes Cousins acted alone, and specifically whether he was motivated by a criminal or personal problem. A search party is searching for the gunman's remains on farm land across the street from the farmhouse. Cousins may have also been injured during the attack, the FBI said, but his wounds have not been "life threatening." The FBI said authorities were "working to determine whether this was an act of domestic terrorism" or a "gang-related event." Investigators are still trying to determine if there was any advance warning of the attack, or if it was a random act of violence, the FBI said. "This was a well planned act of violence, so we have to determine if this was planned to be a random act of violence -- did anyone anticipate this? The motive is still unclear," FBI Special Agent Bill Sweeney said Sunday. Investigators are seeking a motive and will be pursuing all available tips. Police said that, if the investigation finds Cousins was not in "direct control of the crime," it "will not necessarily indicate a role" of him in the crime. Authorities are unsure whether the suspect was inside the farmhouse and firing at the victims as they entered or whether he escaped from the scene. The FBI said it will not be releasing where the shooting occurred because of the situation's sensitive nature. Police have been searching the farmhouse with dogs and a helicopter but have not found the suspect. One of the victims had a concealed carry license. Another apparently was killed at the scene but his body was left there. The other victims, including an 11-year-old boy, were inside the home but escaped unharmed, authorities said. Police and SWAT teams rushed to the scene after being called to a domestic disturbance call at the farmhouse. They had responded to reports of an armed suspect on the property. Authorities have said they are not yet sure what led to the shooting. Police have said that the suspect had recently been receiving threatening text messages from a female friend. "I had friends at Columbine. They were killed in Newtown Connecticut," the friend reportedly texted Cousins.

I've got an important message for you. You can keep your iPhone and iPad. But your iPod will, without a doubt, be the most difficult to replace. The iPod Classic is more than 25 years old. That's old enough to have seen a lot of changes. It's old enough that it's long overdue for a major makeover. That's the reason why I don't see Apple being willing to sell its once-glorious iPod line to a third-party and will not discuss the particulars of the company's decision. But from a technological standpoint, what's changed is that even though there are no apps to go along with the new devices, there are hundreds of different ways people have already changed their iPhones into iPods. So we're going to start with some things people know people do when buying iPods, then we'll explore some of the things that don't happen very often, then we'll move on to some of the things we still don't know or appreciate about how people make them. PICK THE RIGHT APP FOR THE MOMENT. A lot of people like to know that their new iPod is the right fit before they buy it, and that's understandable. When you're considering a new phone, there are certain things you have to know about it in terms of physical specifications and performance before you get to the fun stuff. And when you go to a department store and buy something new, you're faced with dozens of options that cover dozens of different price levels and features. But if you are the kind of person who wants to know and have all the details before making a purchase, just go to Apple.com and enter your information and order. Then tell them you know what you're doing so that they can offer some guidance. They'll help you figure out which models are suited for specific conditions. But just know that the majority of the iPhone 8 and iPhone 8 Plus models are fine for most people on most days. This is important. If you go to the Apple store and get someone else's advice, you might pay more than you should and get a worse experience in the store. Also, the iPhone 8 and iPhone 8 Plus come with wireless charging, but some other phones in the premium iPhone line — most notably the iPhone X and iPhone X Plus — do not. But to be fair, we don't even consider these premium features when we're reviewing phones for you or when evaluating what we think looks and feels great. And it's also worth mentioning that you should not buy a phone using Apple Care+ just because it's an iPhone. The premium products do cost more, so the iPhone 8 and iPhone 8 Plus can pay for themselves much faster in the long run if you don't purchase Apple Care+. I want to reiterate the importance of taking your time. If you pick up a high-end smartphone that runs out of battery before you're finished, you're going to end up paying a steep bill and you'll probably wonder why Apple doesn't charge a little more for an insurance plan based on how long the phone can run out of battery. I have personally purchased more than one model of the iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus — one for me and one for my sister. In two days, I replaced the older model back from a service center where it had been for two years. That was $30. Not too long ago, we bought a iPhone 7 Plus off an Apple website in China at a very good price on an international payment. That was an extra $40. But you need to pick the phones that work best for you. And if you're going to make a serious investment in a new phone, you don't want to buy an iPhone based on Apple marketing or rumors. You want to get a phone that fits your lifestyle, that meets the needs you've decided for yourself, and you want to be making a long-term decision. BE A META-MANIPULATOR. This is a problem that's not limited to iPhones. We love to make predictions, and we think we know what people will do when they put a new phone into their pocket. But it never works out like we think. For example, I love to say that people will start carrying around a second iPad more often. And I'm very confident that there is going to be something that will come along — something you use to multitask better than the computer that we just bought. But it never does. We also think people will buy two phone numbers with the iPhone 8/Plus. But in a recent research study we ran on cell phones among 1,000 Americans, we found out that about 80 percent of that group would still buy only one number. We think that every time you get a phone number, you'll start using it a little differently — taking a minute to think about what you are going to do when you pick up your phone and what you're going to use it for. And that will

The most important thing you probably don't know about your body is that it is made up of more than 60,000 cells and tissues that each perform crucial body functions. They all play a role in keeping our health by absorbing nutrients and maintaining a normal pH balance to prevent illness. Many of them play a role in regulating how the body develops: how hair forms in the scalp, how bones and tissues develop and where new organs and blood vessels will form. Most of these cells and tissues develop in the embryo. But some may be formed when cells in a developing part of the body — known as an embryo — undergo changes in their DNA. When these cells and tissues go on to become other organisms — like a fertilized egg — they have the genetic potential to become other parts of that organism. It is often said that the human body contains billions of cells. And if you are lucky, you might even get to meet a cell in the body for a week. But that will never happen in the human body where more than a trillion cells are in every cell, and those are the cells of every living thing. If all the cells in your body existed in a solid ball, called the cells of a single body part, then the mass would reach 30.5 billion tons. But the cells that make up the body do not all have this same location: skin, muscles, blood vessels, and other organs and tissues have different locations. The human body contains 50 trillion cells, each making up about 50,000 body cells. The cells in the eye have only half the surface area of the eyelids. The cells of a single organ, like the brain, can overlap. If one organ were to replace another, the resulting organ would contain cells from half the cells of whichever organ it replaced. A new survey found half of Americans say they don't consider the military to "serve the American people." (Bryan R. Smith/AFP/Getty Images) About half of Americans believe the military is out of touch with American values, with another 40 percent saying they "don't think the military cares too much about Americans' freedoms." Just over one-third — 35 percent — think the military's values are in tune with American ideals. The Pew Research Center conducted a survey last week to examine how Americans view the role of the military, and their opinion of the military itself, and also how they view other institutions in society. One striking finding is how far public opinion has shifted from where it was in the 1950s and 1960s. "You can point to a particular generation — the Baby Boomers, for example — as taking a more critical or negative view of the military," said William E. Hartung, an expert on the Middle East at the Center for International Policy. "There is not a consensus about how important the military is to American society, except among elites," said Eric A. Posner, a professor at the University of Chicago Law School and author of "Why Americans Hate the Military." But the military is "the only institution in society that has been able to expand in terms of scope and budget during the past 50 years" while "other institutions have decreased in significance," he said. [The military's role in domestic politics is more influential than Americans realize] The findings suggest that Americans have come to view the military differently, and differently from where they started, said Hartung. "It's not just a small group that have this idea of the military as distant, a relic of the past," but also the general public. The military has seen its popularity soar, especially with young Americans. According to a study by The Center for Public Integrity, two-thirds of Americans in the 18 to 29 age group are "very interested" in joining the armed forces. Only 27 percent of Americans 55 and older said they have a "very personal" interest in military service. But there is still a long way to go: Fully 54 percent of those who want to service in the military don't consider their potential service in the military to serve "the American people." And only 38 percent of Americans think the military has the people skills needed to serve America's needs if it goes to war. [How a woman turned a military recruitment ad into a powerful protest] The Pew survey showed that Americans view the military in two ways, according to Philip Klinkner, a professor of political science at Virginia Commonwealth University and author of "American Politics in the Military and War in the Military." It is portrayed as a "militaristic institution" — an idea that might be rooted in some kind of moral judgment about the institution, but that "does not really go beyond that," Klinkner said. Or, Americans see the military as an institution that is at odds with liberal values and democratic values. For example: "Almost half of Democrats, 53 percent, say the military doesn't serve democracy well, compared with 41 percent of Republicans," the survey said. Americans were somewhat more likely to consider the military a military institution for "socialist, authoritarian or dictatorial governments" than it was for democratic republics, according to the survey. But majorities also considered the military to serve democratic republican and socialist principles. The majority of those polled felt the military was more interested in the needs of America's "elite" than about the needs of the average American: 54 percent of respondents said, for example, that they believed the military was focused on protecting elite privileges compared with only 32 percent who felt the military was "more focused on the needs of the average American," the report said. The survey also showed a significant number of respondents view military service not simply as part of their civic duty but as a "passionate pursuit." "The vast majority of Americans who serve in the military think about it in terms of their personal values and what they want to do with their lives," Posner said. [The secret life of Navy SEALs] It wasn't all negative responses in the military poll. An independent group with the same name, the Citizens in Charge Foundation, conducted a similar poll about two weeks ago, in a similar format, and came to similar results — that about one-in-four Americans had a "very favorable" view of the military, and that almost half thought its role was to serve the public. The survey, conducted by ORC International, asked how Americans view the military based on seven questions. The first was "Do you think the U.S. military is out of touch with the values of the American people?" The second was "Do you think military policy reflects a commitment to protecting American democracy or protecting American privilege?" The third was "Do you think the U

A group that wanted to know more about the new iPhone's security features — and whether they would allow users to remotely wipe the iPhone — has succeeded. Sixty-two members signed onto a Facebook group on Monday, with the simple goal of trying out a new hack that allowed them to completely erase the iPhone 5. "The iPhone 5 can be turned off by a simple wipe and reboot," one member wrote in the group. "So after a month we went on a mission that we have not been able to stop." Another added: "After three days of hard work we did it! We have broken the security on the new iPhone 5!" But just a few minutes after the post was published, people pointed out that the iPhone 5 could be made to stay turned off by a malicious attacker with a similar hack. So Apple issued a statement — first published on Tuesday on the company's website — and later on Tuesday it also put out a software update. The new software update turns iPhone 5 users' screens into iridescent white, just in case there is somebody in your home who wants to take a look at your iPhone and wipe off all the data it has. Apple also added a new message for users who want to wipe their iPhone and reboot it with the screen up. "This new feature protects your iPhone," the company's statement began. "This technology requires the iPhone 5 to be connected to power in order to function. If you have recently upgraded to iPhone 6 or later and are concerned about the security of your device, you can update to iOS 8.3 via iTunes on your device." The company says the new feature is limited to just iPhones 5 and 6 models — but if you have an iPhone 3GS or 2G, then it may have worked for you already. And that's an important point: It's not as if these two hackers are the first to make this sort of iPhone 5 destruction trick. Earlier this year, security researcher David Wagner posted a video demonstrating an attempt that turned iPhones into spy cams after attaching them to various gadgets including smart TVs and Google Glasses. And Apple has been trying to make its smartphones a bit more secure, making it easier for app developers to put in extra layers of security. That includes the new iPhone-to-iPhone pairing feature, which allows Apple devices to automatically pair with one another using a unique code the user has to enter.

The following correction was printed in the Guardian's Corrections and clarifications column, Tuesday May 4 2007 In a series of articles which began in the first edition of this week's print edition, we described the Israeli government's intention to hold public hearings on how its government should respond to Israel's treatment of Gaza. But since the beginning of the operation in Gaza, a decision to hold such hearings had not been made. On Tuesday June 17, the Israeli cabinet approved a request for an investigation of how its government had acted as a "neutral party" in the Gaza conflict. This included a public hearing. The cabinet said it accepted the UN's demand to hold a hearing that would be held on the Israeli air strikes on the Palestinian city of Rafah. The Israeli prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, said he wanted to hold the hearing as soon as possible to determine whether the civilian deaths during the air strikes were justified. But, on Monday, the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, said the Israeli government was not interested in the details of how its air force behaved as part of the ground operation. He said: "No Israeli prime minister, and certainly no Israeli cabinet, has had any interest in the rules of engagement for the military operations, because they know how to behave themselves." The next day, the Israeli government said it had ordered a public investigation, but no details have been unveiled. Benny Hill E-mail the writer at ehillbenny@guardian.co.uk

As we noted before, this week's issue of Famitsu has an interview with Namco Bandai's Hajime Tabata. The interview covers pretty much all things related to Final Fantasy XV. It looks like there is some great news about Final Fantasy XV that will be coming out soon. Here's some of what Tabata-san had to share: The original idea had been for a "new Final Fantasy on new hardware" for this year. I'm happy to know that this isn't the case. There will be a new battle system as well as a new story. Tabata-san-san also talked about the original character designs that have been leaked. He said the following in regard to the designs, Of course I was very surprised when I saw designs for Noctis and the party. Tabata-san-san had a special kind of satisfaction with the party's costumes, which you may remember as "a bit too much for me", (that has) come to feel like they're becoming part of the players' hearts. There is something more. "The development staff" from the project are all going to do a "live action show featuring our development team as a whole." I really can't wait for this. I really can't wait for this. I also want to bring out a concept for Noctis/Tidus that is even deeper, darker, more mature than his character design. I'd also like to try doing a music video for "Lulu's Theme". The interview also mentions that the project is being completed over a shorter time, as a whole. The overall time that the project has been in development is about 4-5 years. The reason for the shortened development time is because "the team is on a different rhythm for a very long time." Tabata-san-san-san also talked about how there is another team that is working on games for the Nintendo Switch. You can grab a copy of the magazine here: http://www.famitsu.com/en/gdc/ As for what we can expect from the game for the Nintendo Switch, it seems as if it will be a continuation of the console's launch. We will have lots of details about that soon.

In a small ceremony in a small town near the northern border of the state of Maharashtra, an ancient sword has been blessed and consecrated by a man known as 'Karnarangi' and a small ceremony is being held to mark it as 'muhurta' by one of the biggest temples in the region, the Jain Bhadrapal Temple. "This sword is very special. The sword was bestowed to the great temple by the king's brother and the sword was in his name which is unique in the region," said Valsi, a resident from Maharashtra's Chinchwad district who is in charge of maintaining the weapons. Over 150 swords from other regions were scattered in Maharashtra's Chinchwad district, and these were arranged in a procession which passed through Chinchwad and Rann of Kutch. The procession was started by Rakesh, a Jain who had a large temple in Chinchwad who is one of the biggest Jains in the country. The Jains in Maharashtra, a state which has a vast population, are mostly concentrated within the Pune region. Some of them also live in Bhavnagar where they worship at the Jain temple. "This is the first time since the Pune region began having Jain temples that we will have a 'Muhurta' sword," said Valsi. "After studying it with experts from the United Nations in Geneva we decided to make the sword in the village of Bhagatpura because we need the temple's blessings. So it was blessed here last night," Valsi stated. Valsi said that there is no other sword like this in history and it is the first of its kind in South India. In fact, the temple had gifted a replica sword to the king of Nepal in 1987, after his coronation, which was presented with a small ceremony to Jain leaders visiting Nepal. "These swords are the pride of the people of Chinchwad who have maintained these weapons for many generations. These swords are considered as a symbol of peace between the peoples and their respective villages," Valsi noted. Some experts said that 'muhurta' was considered as a sign and seal of good luck for the swords and that Jain scriptures describe it as an act of worship and blessing. "It symbolizes both blessings and peace. Some say that it symbolizes peace in the soul and is proof of the purity of the soul after death. Some believe that it represents the victory of good over evil, and that it denotes the victory of good over evil in a war," said P.K. Mishra, a prominent historian from Pune. Experts said that this sword is believed to be from the 9th century, but they said some historical records claim that it dates back to the 8th century. "It may be the only 'muhurta' sword in its entire history. There may be many other weapons of this type but it is unique. It is unique in South India because of where it comes from and because it is a symbol of harmony," Mishra said.

If you thought that it was hard to convince voters that the Republican health care bill was anything other than a massive tax cut for the wealthy and massive tax cuts for the health insurance and pharmaceutical industries, then get your head out of the sand. On Tuesday, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office reported that the Senate's Better Care Reconciliation Act would result in the loss of health insurance coverage for 24 million people, even after fully repealing the Affordable Care Act. For those of you who have forgotten what the Affordable Care Act is, here's a reminder: Obamacare allowed the insurance industry to charge more for people who had health problems and to provide coverage that was no better than what you'd get with a pre-existing condition. The Affordable Care Act has been a huge success. It is a great idea and a good idea for the United States and a good idea for the rest of the world. Republicans seem, for their own reasons, to have decided to stop working on these ideas. Senate Republicans and President Trump have not done a very good job of explaining how their plan is a good idea or explaining how it will achieve its supposed goal of making the Affordable Care Act better and cheaper. The Senate bill does not fix the problems with the Affordable Care Act, such as giving insurance to everyone and holding insurance companies accountable. It keeps some of the most damaging aspects of Obamacare, like restricting insurance for the disabled, giving tax breaks to health companies that leave the sickest patients to die in the streets, allowing the insurance industry to charge more to older Americans for the same plans available to young Americans and allowing insurers to change the coverage they offer to people so they can increase profits by keeping premiums and deductibles high. And the Senate bill does not deliver on promises to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, with promises of better health care and cheaper premiums. To be fair, the CBO did not expect the Senate bill to get passed. It expected most states to decide not to comply with those insurance market reforms created by the Affordable Care Act. But to say that 24 million people will lose health coverage when you have an actual plan to replace it is ridiculous on many levels. For starters, if the Republican plan were to actually replace Obamacare, not just try to get rid of some parts of it, that would still leave about 24 million people with no insurance at all. But it is also false when it says that Obamacare will be repealed and replaced under the Senate bill so that "people with preexisting conditions can finally be covered." The Senate bill allows states to impose a condition on the coverage that someone needs. People who live in a state where there is no such condition, such as Florida, Kentucky and West Virginia, can get insurance if you give them your word that you won't end up in the emergency room because you fell ill and in turn need a lot of medical care. But states such as California, New York, California and Oregon cannot require such a commitment to the insurance companies. That means that people cannot get coverage under the Senate bill if they will end up getting serious illnesses or serious injuries. This plan is like insurance that you sign up through the back door, where you are not guaranteed that it will cover you because if you get sick you don't receive the benefits you believe they are going to provide. People may not have health insurance now but they will when they cannot get insurance through the back door, something that happens with people with chronic disease and those who live near the poverty line. People living under Medicaid or Medicare have insurance no matter what. People with private medical bills can get coverage through insurance companies or pay their medical bills and in most cases will pay for their medical bills instead of the government. And the Senate bill ends tax credits that give the very poor higher subsidies based on their health situation. The Congressional Budget Office has found that if people with low incomes lost tax credits because of repeal of the health care law, more than 14 million people would no longer be able to afford insurance. If any of this sounds like it's bad enough, there is also the fact that Obamacare does not provide health insurance to all. A recent study found that 19 million Americans still don't have access to health insurance. The Senate bill could provide coverage to some of these people. So that's another advantage. But the Senate bill could give insurance to only 7 million people. The Congressional Budget Office predicts that 3 million fewer people could be covered over the next decade if the Senate bill goes ahead. And some of those people who will lose health insurance might not have any insurance at all. This bill could make it possible for states to stop Medicaid expansion and cut people's health coverage. Many states have seen an influx of people coming off Medicaid who were formerly eligible for it but who were not covered by the expansion. So, yes, there could be some coverage for some people. But that will probably only be for those who

How much will you spend? How much will you spend? $5 + $2 = $8.50 $5 + $500 = $8,500 $25 + $2 = $37.50 $25 + $500 = $75,000 This will pay for: 1 year of college 4 years of grad school 4 years of law school 7 years of business school (assuming you plan to practice only until age 50) 7 years of medical school The average monthly pay for a lawyer in 2017 was $4,067, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The monthly wage was $6,868 in 2015 (not adjusted for inflation), according to salary.com. The current median American salary is $62,300. However, the pay for a single junior lawyer (i.e., a junior associate at a firm) has more than doubled since 1993 ($8,500 in 1993) to $22,500 today. How much do you need? How much will you need? First year tuition & fees: $60,000 + books = $160,000 + $2,500 = $240,500 (assuming you can get into a top law school but won't have to take out loans on top of your law school loan for at least 5 years, and assuming you are doing this after you graduate) Second year tuition & fees: $72,000 + books = $144,000 + $3,000 = $214,100 (assuming you can get into a top law school but won't have to take out loans on top of your law school loan for at least 5 years, and assuming you are doing this after you graduate) Third year tuition & fees: $98,000 + books = $178,000 + $5,000 = $234,500 (+ 2.7x your average annual salary above) (assuming you can get into a top law school but won't have to take out loans on top of your law school loan for at least 5 years, and assuming you are doing this after you graduate) Fourth year tuition & fees: $132,000 + books = $240,000 + $8,000 = $334,500 (+ 6.3x your average annual salary above) (assuming you can get into a top law school but won't have to take out loans on top of your law school loan for at least 5 years, and assuming you are doing this after you graduate) Financing the gap Even after paying for tuition and fees above, your student loan burden still may be a problem. If you are applying into the law as an out-of-state lawyer who wants to practice in North Carolina, your student loan debt will probably dwarf your starting salary. For students who borrow from public lenders (like FHA/annie), the debt may also make it difficult to purchase rental properties—because, in many states, they might not be able to access mortgage finance for a certain period of time. Fortunately, many programs help mitigate the burden—through income-based repayment plans, deferment programs, and other financial tools. These programs can help you stay on track if you aren't able to work for several years. Some other ways you can help You can consider a scholarship There are many scholarship programs out there that can help you cover the cost of law school. One program we recommend to students is the American Bar Foundation's (ABF) Scholars Service. You can use your award money to pay for school instead of taking out loans, and if you take advantage of other types of scholarships and grants, the difference can be considerable. For a list of ABF Scholarship opportunities for 2019, click here. There are also a variety of non-borrowable scholarships, grants, and internships you can check out, along with the Legal Aid Society and the Legal Services Corporation of the United States. For information about what you can do to repay your student loan debt, click here. You can borrow from your parents It might not be the most efficient way to pay for school, but according to National Conference of State Legislatures, at least 30 states offer some form of tuition assistance to students who aren't working. For example, many states provide free tuition at public postsecondary institutions (for a few students), and some states have loan repayment programs specifically for undergraduates. To learn more, click here. More ways to pay for law school You can start paying law school with an offer of employment Once you've been accepted to any law school, the second step is often the most critical to finishing. Because you are paying almost the entire cost of your education in fees, salaries, and the books you need, you need to find another way to make extra money during law school.

The federal government says it's giving another $15 million over two years to Alberta's oilsands. "With new investment into our provinces' industries, we have the flexibility to invest in skills, technology and capacity that create good jobs, and help secure our energy future," Finance Minister Bill Morneau said in a statement Thursday. The money comes at a time that Alberta is seeking another $1.6 billion from Ottawa to offset losses in the oilsands sector under its recent carbon tax. Story continues below advertisement "These additional investments will allow us to better understand our oilsands and provide critical support to its workers," he added. "We are also focusing in developing new technologies to improve Alberta's productivity while expanding and improving our production capacity." The budget for the oilsands includes $2.5-billion in capital investment over two years. It also funds an initial $12-billion grant to the province for the industry over a nine-year period. Alberta's NDP government is seeking $10.5-billion over nine years to deal with the downturn. A report released Friday by the Canadian Centre for Policy Alternatives says the tax revenue has not made a material difference to the overall economy.

TUSCALOOSA, Alabama -- Two University of Alabama students accused of robbing a West End bar Friday have been charged with armed robbery and aggravated assault during the incident, according to a police press release. The university is now investigating whether the incidents of the two men taking a female bystander and stealing $80 in an ATM machine were connected, according to the release. Tuscaloosa police said that after they went to the West End bar, 2032 University Ave. E early Saturday morning to conduct surveillance on the location, they saw a female and a male enter and exit through the door. Police said the male suspect then grabbed the female victim from behind, pushed her to the ground and started the ATM machine. The victim, who was not a University of Alabama student, called police via a cell phone and said that she and another bystander had been mugged inside the bar. Police said the video showed the female victim trying to fight off the male suspect who then ran to a waiting car. The male suspect then got into a car and took off, police said. While chasing the men, another female victim took out a weapon and shot at the car, police said. At this time there do not appear to be any additional victims, police added. Two students were taken into custody and are being questioned for their involvement with an armed robbery at the restaurant Friday. The first suspect was identified as 20-year-old Brandon Mitchell. He was charged with armed robbery with a dangerous weapon, aggravated assault without inflicting serious bodily injury and robbery during a robbery. He is being held at the Tuscaloosa County Jail on $15,000 bond. The second suspect, 20-year-old Tyler White, is charged with aggravated assault with a dangerous weapon and possession of marijuana. He is being held at the Tuscaloosa County Jail on no bond. The West End bar is on University Boulevard in Tuscaloosa. Check back with AL.com for more details.

The U.S. will continue to have its embassies in Cuba but the U.S. will no longer supply them with food and other supplies because of security concerns. The State Department said Friday it has "no plans at this time" for a full lifting of the trade embargo, which was imposed by President Jimmy Carter in February 1980. White House Press Secretary Jay Carney emphasized the importance of getting Cuba back to the negotiating table on human rights, and said Cuba must begin releasing the U.S. political prisoners. ADVERTISEMENT "This administration is clear about our priorities," Carney said, pointing to "our support for restoring the relationship with Cuba and the restoration of normal diplomatic relations with the government of Cuba." Secretary of State John Kerry John Forbes KerryRubio wants DOJ to find out if Kerry broke law by meeting with Iranians Time for sunshine on Trump-Russia investigation Pompeo doubles down on criticism of Kerry: The Iran deal failed, 'let it go' MORE also made a statement on the embargo, saying his country looks forward to working with Cuba's government toward a full, full and secure thaw in relationship. "We recognize that the United States must always remain true to its commitments under the 1961 Cuban-American Mutual Recognition Act and our commitments under other agreements with Cuba; to refrain from economic or commercial transactions with Cuba contrary to our interests and to promote respect for the rule of law and fundamental freedoms, including the right to free religious expression," he said. "We also recognize that Cuba is a country with a rich and vibrant democracy with which we have had a comprehensive and strong relationship in recent years. There is no reason why the United States will be in a position to provide assistance or trade in the future to Cuba if that would be contrary to our interests or a breach of our obligations under other agreements with the government of Cuba and other countries." In April, President Obama sent to Congress an executive order that said he could take steps to ease Cuba's economic embargo, including opening embassies and allowing U.S. companies and private individuals to do business in Cuba. Cuba announced last week that it was preparing to send to the National Security Council a draft agreement with the United States to help begin opening embassies to U.S. firms in Cuba. But the embargo remained, as did an oil embargo and an arms embargo. But Carney indicated Friday, for the first time, that the U.S. could begin to lift the travel ban for American citizens in the Cuban Embassy in Havana. A Congressional aide told NBC News that the staff who worked on the Iran nuclear deal are now working to prepare the document that would require the U.S. to end its arms embargo against Cuba, which would require a vote in Congress. The aide acknowledged that there is no guarantee that the embargo will be lifted by November. "We always look forward to further engagement on the issues that matter to the majority of Americans, our interests in our relationship with the Cuban government and our priorities around human rights, especially the right to live freely, without fear," Carney said. The official noted that the State Department continues to support "reforms that help promote the peaceful transition of the government of Cuba." Carney said the U.S. would work with Congress and Cuba's Government of Cuba to determine the best path forward. The aide noted that this morning's announcement by the State Department of the ban against the U.S. government's "trade, investment, or other normal commercial activities" in Cuba will require congressional action to lift it. The aide also said the State Department would be ready to begin lifting the trade embargo on Cuban cigars once new legislation is passed by Congress. The aide emphasized that the State Department has made very limited exceptions to the oil embargo, which is aimed at halting the nation's ability to export energy products — particularly to its people. As a result of the oil embargo, the U.S. can no longer send products to Cuba to buy energy, or use the U.S. dollar to buy them. The embargo now affects the purchase of Cuban-made commodities from any other country. "That applies to both the importation of raw materials or finished goods to or from a commercial enterprise by persons of the United States or by a United States-registered entity," the State Department said. Also Friday, the State Department announced a new visa waiver program — including a special one-year visa, the only kind of tourist visa available to U.S. citizens or lawful permanent residents — which it said would open up opportunities for Cuban citizens to visit the United States.

If you're like millions of Americans, you're paying close attention to the 2014 midterms: your senators and representatives will decide whether the Constitution should be amended so that the Supreme Court might overturn the Supreme Court of the United States. You may take comfort in that fact that the last time the country did this, it took an event to achieve it. In the 1960s, America's Senate voted down a proposed amendment to the Constitution that would have allowed the president to fill Supreme Court vacancies with justices appointed by and with the advice and consent of the majority of the Senate — because the Senate had not appointed enough. For one moment, America was ruled by Supreme Court justices with little public respect and whose decisions were almost invariably affirmed by the Court as a whole. That was not the end of the story. After the Senate failed to re-nominate John Paul Stevens to the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in 1980, the Senate took a break: the chamber nominated him, and the president named him. By the time the Senate voted in 1982, the Senate had taken a second break: it nominated Thomas Swayne to his old seat, just to be clear, and he was confirmed. And that is how it went for five years. And this time America is taking care not to make the same mistake. The Senate Judiciary Committee has already started holding hearings on the next president's nominees — two or three for each vacancy. "I think that would be good if the Senate had the opportunity to hold hearings because of the way the system is set up that we would not have any of these vacancies for the rest of the Obama administration," says Daniel Mach, former solicitor general and deputy solicitor general under President Clinton and a leading scholar of the Supreme Court. The problem is that under the Constitution, a president nominates a Supreme Court justice, and the Senate chooses the full 12 justices to fill that seat during its "advise and consent" role. Once the nomination has been forwarded to the full Senate, it is up to the Senate: a) "advise and consent" on the nominee; b) vote to confirm or reject that nominee without delay; or c) "advise" and "consent" but then fail to act on the nomination for a full year, allowing time for consideration by the Senate Judiciary Committee. The last three options are very rare: only nine out of 644 Supreme Court nominees since 1835 were confirmed in that manner. The Senate cannot, however, choose between "advise and consent" and "advise and notify" — its only option is "advise" and "notify" — and thus the current Senate majority has chosen the latter. The president would like to appoint Scalia's successor on "fast-track" authority so that the vacancy will not remain open for longer than 18 months, which is the current federal deadline to fill Supreme Court vacancies. President Obama wants the Senate to hold hearings for the next nominee to fill a vacancy on either the Supreme Court today - Elena Kagan or Sonia Sotomayor, who are likely the two most likely candidates — or his chosen nominee from the lower courts — Justice Samuel Alito. At this point, of course, there are not that many other nominees who would fit in the range of possibilities for who could be the next Scalia, or any other potential nominee. So the Senate's task is more or less to make the next Supreme Court appointment by August 2, the date of the next inauguration — a date whose timing was negotiated in advance of President Obama's first inauguration. So the best they can do now is to make sure that the next president gets the Supreme Court nomination he or she wants while not wasting anyone's time. There could be a more radical option if Senate Democrats decide to obstruct the nomination of a right-wing conservative as their "number one" choice to take the seat. That's a move we haven't seen yet, although several senators have told the Washington Post that that kind of "showdown" would be unlikely to succeed in a court-majority Senate. But that is an option on the table. If Obama nominates a Justice who turns down the appointment and is confirmed by a vote of less than 60, they could vote to change the constitutional rules of the Senate, which would be an unprecedented move but one not outside the realm of possibility. But that would be difficult to pull off, if for no other reason than there are a lot of justices who have been appointed to fill the last three vacancies on the Supreme Court, as of now. So there has been a lot of chatter lately over whether a President Mitt Romney is going to nominate just a right-wing Republican to the seat. If he does, I think there's a decent chance that a Supreme Court justice will change his mind on his own accord — but who will the president nominate? And while the answer may not be a Scalia-style conservative, it would be a lot more palatable to liberals and progressives, to

You want to make it clear that you're a proud member of the "real" American middle class? Then you're one of two possible responses to this question: you're either a clueless snob or you're a snobby middle-class stooge. I'll settle for the third option: You have a pretty big mouth, which makes you a smug hypocrite. In the wake of last week's presidential election, people have been debating about what exactly defines the middle class. The American Economic Association's Working America project recently published a survey showing that many Americans still think the middle class has shrinking importance. The survey found that 48 percent of us think the middle class has been shrinking since 1975, and 32 percent think the middle class has been shrinking since 1980. But there's a bit of a chicken-and-egg problem. Is there really a "middle class" in America – or is it a myth? (See the chart on page 15 of Thomas Frank's What's The Matter With Kansas? for what that question really is.) Let's start with this: a lot of Americans think they live in the middle class. According to a January 2012 Gallup poll, 41 percent of Americans think they are middle class; another 18 percent think they are lower class. The middle class is a myth, people. What we have are the low-income, the low-skilled, the poor and the homeless. Now, one might quibble about the question on that survey, which asked, "Do you think the US middle class has changed or gotten smaller between 1975 and 2010?" If you put "change" in quotes, you're really just talking about "has the US middle class grown since 1975?" But if you put "less" in quotes, you're really just talking about "decreased." To put it another way, the middle class doesn't have grown. They have changed. Some of the reasons why the middle class has changed include globalization, the rise of the "gig economy" (for the jobless who don't have a steady wage), "free trade" (which has meant millions of job losses in manufacturing but millions of new jobs in developing countries like China and India), and the increase in inequality we've seen over the last four decades. The middle class has changed, and it has grown. That is important in our current debate about American social policy. The other question that I was going to answer at least partially by telling the "real America" snobs to watch some Fox News Channel would have been about this: How has that middle class grown? It's impossible to determine the extent to which the US middle class has grown because the US government has no official data on it. In the past, we could look at what people earned by looking up their median household income. For most of this millennium, median income has steadily declined, and no one thinks the US middle class is growing. But if you're going to do any kind of official analysis on this, you should also look at the number of people living in each household. If the overall size of the US middle class remains constant, then the numbers of non-working households would also probably follow, leaving us with a middle class of working households. And then of course, we'll all have to account for the rising portion of elderly Americans who do not have dependents, so let's add those to the equation to come up with the number of US households "in the middle" – and then we can have a better discussion. But this is where you end up with "middle class" as someone's best argument for why the working class should not oppose policies designed to help the middle class. This isn't to say that there aren't plenty of policies that work to strengthen the economy and lift the working class higher. They do. For example, the US tax code is basically a simple progressive income tax. This has helped to make the US an "offshore haven" for capital, which has resulted in a massive capital gains tax in the form income taxation that is higher for those who make more. There's no denying that the working class is getting hurt by this. In theory, the high tax rate paid by those rich Americans in the top brackets is hurting most of those at the bottom of the income distribution, since their average tax rate is above the corporate tax rate. In practice, though, the top 1 percent does much better than the average working person since there are lots of ways that rich Americans can shelter so many profits at lower tax rates. According to the Council on Foreign Relations, some 75 percent of the top 1 percent pay no taxes on more than 30 percent of their income. Another reason that I don't buy the middle class myth is that there is virtually no evidence that the middle-class has shrunk in the US. A recent analysis from the Economic Policy Institute on the income distribution in the US shows that if anything, the

A new set of images from Star Wars Episode VIII – The Last Jedi was released today and they continue on from what is a rather solid teaser. While some have felt the previous teaser looked slightly too busy with the Star Wars theme and a lot of the shots are of vehicles, this new set of images take that off the table and focus on locations. And not a lot of them. We've got some exterior shots of the planet Ahch-To, some of its residents, which include some new TIE Fighters and some new Imperial Troops. We've even got some interior shots of the city and it looks very nice. However, it wouldn't be a bad idea to take out that "C" on the main city sign too? We've seen a lot of new images coming out. We have a great looking shot of Maz Kanata, a new stormtrooper and an Imperial Trooper that is completely different from the ones we've seen before – the ones shown during the prequels. And then, we got another new Star Destroyer! It looks a lot like a black one, but we've got to take more looks at this one before we call it a black one. Speaking of ships, we've got a new look at the Star Destroyers, and this one takes the cake for me – I love this one because it's so different from the others. We've even got one of the first shots of Snoke and Kylo Ren together. And, Kylo Ren is the Sith Lord who has been missing in action in the past few movies. Here's a look at some of the new Sith characters. Another set of images from the new Star Wars sets has come out, this time with the new villain Maz Kanata (Emilia Clarke)! With all the news on the new Star Wars films coming out, and with some still-to-be-screenshots we're getting, it's been quite a busy time! While there are still quite a few more hours of Star Wars: The Last Jedi to go, today we are finally at the point where we can see where Episode VIII is taking place… and it's actually more reminiscent of Return of the Jedi than the prequels were… I'm a fan of that, so… not much to say about a day when we didn't want to go to bed. As a parting gift, here is the final teaser for Star Wars Episode VIII – The Last Jedi:

I'm not sure a single person of any background was surprised when Donald Trump was elected President of the United States and that he has, even more recently, begun to push his agenda with the help of a Republican Congress. I'm not sure people were surprised that, in the process, he continued the culture war on women through efforts to repeal or defund Planned Parenthood as well as defunding other important groups that help support women's health such as Title X and ACA, all of which have led to more unplanned pregnancies and unintended pregnancies. As a result, more women of varying degrees of ability are being turned away from health care services altogether. Some people are concerned that Trump's election has caused some women not to pursue reproductive healthcare and perhaps even to change their reproductive healthcare providers because they feel that the abortion debate has already been settled. However, this is not true. Despite his previous rhetoric, even Trump's pick of Judge Gorsuch to fill the late Antonin Scalia's Supreme Court seat has nothing to do with whether women can exercise their reproductive rights any more than Trump's nomination of Judge Neil Gorsuch to replace Scalia helped end the abortion debate. This is especially true for women who already have legal abortion and do not need to take the extra step of getting a prescription for the medication that goes with it. To the extent that President Trump has been able to achieve any significant legislative victories, his victories have done little in the way of restricting access to abortion. Although the Trump administration has taken some steps to curb the availability of telemedicine abortion, the availability of medication abortion drugs varies, and telemedicine often relies on third parties. Furthermore, while there are many new legal restrictions on abortion providers, there are also significant restrictions on abortion care as well, which include state restrictions on Medicaid reimbursements for abortions and prohibitions as well as federal funding restrictions. In other words, even if the Trump administration has been successful in getting at least some of its priorities through to at least some of its goals in 2017, that will not affect access to affordable and legal abortion. What about changes that people might be concerned about, particularly for women who have abortions? Some of these women may choose to undergo the abortion procedure in the United States with the assistance of their state insurance coverage, so women who are not able to travel will still have the opportunity to obtain this. There is also a potential for some anti-choice forces to take over states as well as the federal government, possibly by seeking to undermine the Affordable Care Act and Medicaid expansion. It is unclear whether anti-choice forces would continue trying to defund or otherwise end health services for women that rely on Planned Parenthood, but it is certainly possible. This, however, would not end the abortion debate once the Affordable Care Act goes into effect and the Medicaid expansion is fully implemented across the United States. This would, however, affect access to abortion care in general in the future. For example, in some states that are still running Medicaid expansion, the state will have a hard time paying for abortions for women under the new expansion because the expanded Medicaid population is so large and there is so much money available for it. Furthermore, some states, including Massachusetts, might want to limit funds available for Medicaid-expanded women to prevent some of those women from seeking publicly funded abortions. A conservative Congress might try to reverse this situation with some form of federal block grant. There are many other areas that the Trump Administration will have to focus on, so it will be years before we know what the end of the abortion debate will mean. Nevertheless, it doesn't matter to women who already have abortions or who have considered having an abortion how hard it might be to get access to abortion. They still have the right to have one and the right to access and use the care they need in their particular medical conditions. Abortion opponents have already proven themselves incapable of making even small changes to what happens to women when they seek out and pay for an abortion. Women's access to reproductive health care is not an issue to be settled now or within the next four years. Abortion may be an issue in the long run, but it is not an issue to be taken up by people who claim to be supporting the rights of women to control their own bodies.

I'm on a new job, and I'm hoping not to make a lot of mistakes in my first week working. I'm in the process of installing a new router. My home network is just about at end-to-end, and I'm installing a switch from scratch. That, of course, means I'm going to have to learn all I can about routing and IP addresses. I'm going to need some tools, like a Wireshark script and a router simulator. I thought to use the Wireshark Script. But I have tried that tool for quite a while and have never been satisfied with it. The Wireshark script is good for browsing the network to see how the network is set up so you can use the GUI to configure some of the routing. But I've always found the Wireshark scripts, even the GUI version, lacking the ability to do a lot of configuration. After having worked for years as a system administrator, I've been conditioned by my experiences to be able to edit the configuration of my network in the GUI. I finally decided to write my own script. It's a very simple script, and the instructions that follow will cover it. It doesn't have a huge amount of features, but at least I'm getting more familiar with that particular tool. It should be relatively easy to adapt to use with any similar protocol, and the instructions can be used for other network simulations as well. The commands you'll need to know to make the script work are: netsh interface show all netsh interface version netsh status The script will start by showing you the name of the router, and it will list all of the devices it's communicating with (which could be a single computer as well). If you look at the name of the host on the router, you'll see something like "MyIP". You can determine the IP address of a connected computer by calling netsh interface ip show hostname. Next, go back to the start of the script: #!/bin/sh  ### START OF SCRIPT while true; do if [ -f "/etc/hosts" ] then echo [ -n $1 ] echo ${1##*/} else echo $1 > /var/tmp/hosts echo ${1##*/} fi sleep 1 done echo "Done!" ### END OF SCRIPT rm -f "/etc/hosts" The script then starts by checking to see if you've setup a default gateway or gateway hostname (you wouldn't want to have them both defined, at least not that early). If you haven't setup any, it'll display the gateway name you would have entered into the command line. What the script will do, then, is look the name of the default gateway. It will determine if it is IPv6, and compare it to the name it came up with. If they are the same, the script will display a new line for the gateway. If the two are different, the script will set the gateway to a different hostname (the name of the default gateway). So, what's going to happen is, if two machines are both IPv6, but use different default gateway names, the IP will be routed to one network address, which is the old gateway, and the other into the new one. To keep it consistent, we'll also want the gateway name to be the same. #!/bin/sh ### BEGIN OF SCRIPT netmask=21 gateway=192.168.0.10 # END OF SCRIPT The next thing the script does is check to see if any device is connected (which means an ethernet connection or port is available). If a device is connected, this line of the script will set it to active in the device, so it can be used if needed. If two computers are connected, the script will try to determine the name of the device they are connected to. If that matches the localhost name, the script will set it to active. If you just need to be able to change a device into active (like with the wireless card), you could set it to active with the # command. It's worth noting that this script is not meant to be run on any host. You will have to get the IP address of the device you are trying to set to active, or the gateway name, either in a command prompt, or by using the /proc filesystem. #!/bin/sh ### BEGIN OF SCRIPT int ip; ip=${#ip}; echo ${ip##*/} ether [ -1 +0 ] ; if test -d /etc/ethers &

The new Apple TV streaming media box might be limited in one way — it's not supported by the iTunes Store, and it can't access any of the paid version of music or video rentals. Both problems with the new Apple TV have popped up over and over, with multiple manufacturers, iOS developers, and even Apple itself pointing to a variety of reasons for why streaming Apple TV services doesn't work. The best that can be said is that you might see some slow down or random disconnection, which may be the result of having iTunes Match enabled or because it has no direct Internet connection. A new report says that the reason Apple TV and iTunes are missing out on music and video rentals might be that iTunes has been hacked. As reported by MacRumors, Apple has found several hackers using a tool called "Maver" to access the iTunes Store remotely. According to the report, Apple could take further action, but at this point, it seems its best course of action is to just let the hackers have the iTunes Store access.

What's the first thing you do when you land on the beach? You take a look at your sandals. Now compare that to what one woman told me when I asked her which was her favorite sandal. And her answer wasn't a surprise. "They're all the same," she said with a laugh. I don't know about you, but I have a tough time disagreeing with someone who knows me as well as her. In the end, after trying to talk her out of her opinion, I did some research and found that a lot of women are wrong. As I found out, there are different types of sandals, and some can definitely be considered the "wrong" ones. 1. Shoe sandals These sandals are what some call a "one-size fits all" sandal. As a result, they work just like traditional sandals. 2. Slipper sandals These look and function better with flats, or a thick sock. They're comfortable and they don't require excessive laces. Not all slippers are the same. A narrow toe is a sign of a good slipper. I think this one is mine. 3. Ballet stilettos I wear these because I like the shape they give me. It's not exactly the right shoe, but it certainly is functional. 4. Shoe boots These may be a good choice if you're wearing a suit; but I think they work so well with shorts and skirts because they look so stylish, they look smart as well. 5. Ankle sandals In my case these look too big and heavy and I've tried to size down a size or two. However, for me their shape can sometimes make it look like I have a bigger foot, so I have to take the extra time to check out the fit and the quality of the shoe. I also don't like the way they keep slipping. 5. Sneaker sandals In general, I feel like these are not the smartest choice; they do look nice and fun, but that's about it. 6. Barefoot sandals No surprise here, these would look terrible and impractical to most people. I think my preference lies with slipper sandals. 7. Crocs These may be comfortable, but they can't match the feeling of a perfect sandal. They just feel too tight and restrictive. My only recommendation is to avoid these unless you are very sure to be in "the flow." 8. Bandanas For me, Bandanas can be a nice touch to one or several sandals, but they're not a necessity. So, while many women (myself included) wear sandals for the fun of it, in the end, the right choice is something that only really matters to you.

R.E.M. made a major announcement last weekend. The band's new album, "Autobahn," was going to be out September 9. But the band wanted to delay its release while the record label worked out the best way to release it. We heard it for free on Spotify a month ago. Here's how the album sounds: We'd rather play "Autobahn" for you straight, so here it is in its entirety on YouTube. "Autobahn" features a lot of heavy metal, but it has a soft, fuzzy sound and a mellow melody. And it includes a song inspired by a poem by Jean Genet: "L'oeil et la gaule." The whole album is available on Spotify.

The UESPWiki – Your source for The Elder Scrolls since 1995 Quick Walkthrough [ edit ] Detailed Walkthrough [ edit ] The Waypoint [ edit ] As soon as you enter the Dark Brotherhood Sanctuary, you will see five Brotherhood members standing near a fire: Vex, Brina Merilis, Serana, Alain Dufont and Serana. If you go up the path to the right (eastward), you'll see Rolff Stone-Fist, the master of the training area, talking to him. Note that he only allows you to train yourself if you're at least level 10. You will then be approached by Brina with a choice: You can attack her ("The Battle of Balmora" quest line). Or you can attack Serana ("The Battle of Balmora (Part I)" quest line). You can choose either choice and proceed to continue. The Training [ edit ] Once you're done with your dialogue with Brina, head inside the training rooms. The first task is to walk through the two rooms and get through the obstacle course to the second room. You can use the wall tables and the wall doors as obstacles to avoid. Make sure you have at least 40 Speech in order to make your way quickly in this arena, as there are many distractions. You will get a set of training robes at the end. For the most part the opponents in these rooms are easier than those in the courtyard, and should not be a significant issue. The challenge is still being a Master Thief and not dying a lot, though. The second, and easier, task is an escape from the arena with Serana. She will talk to you and offer to be your "guardian" (that is, she will follow along with you). As she says so, make sure you have her in your party ("The Battle of Balmora (Part I)" quest line). You will automatically move her from the courtyard to a room on the western side of the Sanctuary, near the entrance to the training area. The best location is between the two pillars outside, which are in front of you when you cross the courtyard gate. The other two can be on the upper level with the statues. Simply find the one nearest the entrance and go to her. She will sit with Serana and the two of you will exit the arena. She will walk off and the rest should follow. As she talks about what happened, make sure Serana has joined the Brotherhood. With the training complete, leave the Sanctuary. It'll be night so head back to the Daedric Shrine. The Shrine [ edit ] To return to Moraelyn, head back to the entrance to the shrine and the entrance into the Dark Brotherhood Sanctuary, which is also located here. There's a gate down and three other guards in front. Defeat them and you'll fight the boss, Moraelyn. He is level 30 (hard to kill due to his high armor class). He has the ability to summon an ebony golem. As a tactic, a group of warriors is an efficient way to take him down, but they can't heal their allies nor do much else while on the ground (except for the one you can heal the most with the Ring of Hircine). Mages can usually kill him just using spells and the ring. An alchemist is another possibility, since their bombs and Fire Salts will take out some of the golems on their own and might also work against Moraelyn himself. The key factor is that each golem has a threshold of health that depends on its level and is easily bypassed even with a low level mage. If you try to fight Moraelyn, make sure you put as much distance between you as possible. If you can manage that, the two mages with the most fire damage can do a good bit of damage to the golems while keeping enough distance to remain safe. As a tactic of staying still and healing if needed, you can also try using the Stendarr's Aura spell once each. You don't need to use the spell for the full duration because he still heals himself when you hit the threshold, so just the full circle. Also when using the spell, you should make sure not to use any spells on the golems themselves, as you can cause their health to go out of bounds. However, this doesn't apply to when you are healing Moraelyn as they are completely immune to magic attacks, so you can heal yourself in between using the spell. Moraelyn will drop a Daedra Heart at this point or if you had killed Vicious Dog (who you can't loot). Either way is fine. Sister's Rest [ edit ] After the fight you will see the three dead Brotherhood Initiates on the floor. One of them is actually Serana. You see two Elder Signs coming out of the dead warriors. The councilman said he intended to work with both development companies and homeowners to bring about a "sophisticated community," one that would preserve affordable housing in a neighborhood with high rents. On Monday, a representative for the developer said that there would be no building permits or permits issued for any residential construction at the site by the end of this year, and that the company was hopeful that the project would start in spring or summer of 2009. The site has the potential to be a vibrant community, the representative said, adding that it "sounds awesome." The councilman also pointed out that the project would not include the shopping and dining center currently planned, though he hoped to bring those businesses to the site. According to a map on the developer's website, the project would include about 500,000 square feet of retail space, a park at the west end of the project, a "gondola" connecting it to a "new river" that may someday be developed, two hotels, a parking structure — and a new development adjacent to a park. The plan calls for the river to be developed as a mixed-use development that would include restaurants, stores, parking facilities and a riverwalk. The developers are asking for $45 for every square foot that they wish to develop for a total of about 30 acres, though Mr. Kressman's representatives declined to confirm that figure to The New York Times. The development has been approved for a federal tax break, which would grant nearly two-thirds of the tax breaks that are available to projects of that size for 15 years. The other third of the tax breaks would have to be acquired through property tax payments. Photo The tax break will likely create a backlash from city taxpayers, and some city officials say they are not willing to give the tax subsidy unless it includes strict limits on parking. While developers will be allowed to build about 2,500 parking spaces in the new development, a city planner has warned that there will be "significant challenges" attracting the necessary number of off-street parking spaces to the project to make it economically viable. Last Wednesday, the Times reported on some of the neighborhood's critics, including some residents of homes in the area who questioned the viability of the project. At the news conference, Mayor Linder said he believed that most of the opposition to the project would die down in time, and then most of the new neighbors would appreciate the benefits. "People get over it," he said, and the project would become a "major economic development" in the community, bringing businesses, housing and other amenities. "We will give the neighborhood a chance. I don't think we need the negative publicity out there. We don't need to try to scare people away," he said. In an e-mail, a spokeswoman for the city housing department, Jill Krieger, said that the city "is aware of the project's plans and is actively working on the city's part." Ms. Krieger added, "We welcome the neighborhood to have the opportunity to participate." Advertisement Continue reading the main story Asked about the tax breaks, Mr. Kressman's representative, Kevin Walsh, said they were a "great" use of tax money and a "first of its kind" for a project of this size and type. He said it would be a "difficult development" to move forward without the tax breaks though, and the company had agreed to work with the city to make sure that was the case. "We are trying to get a developer to take a more progressive approach," Mr. Walsh said, adding, "We're not trying to give them any slack at this stage." As with other major projects in the city, the neighborhood will be forced to weigh in on the site when its zoning, the size of the development and the amount of parking required comes before the Planning Commission's committee on neighborhood concerns on May 18. Filed in: The Verge The company that makes the Raspberry Pi has just announced it will sell to consumers with the Pi 3.  As the Guardian wrote, "It marks the first time the Raspberry Pi has been released to consumers. At the time of its launch in 2012, the product, which plugs into a television, computer or mobile phone, was a prototype."  Since then, the Raspberry Pi's fanbase has grown considerably, and the first versions of the machine, released in 2012, were a hit in classrooms and universities around the world.  By this year, there were more than 20,000 Raspberry Pi units sold, so it looks like the company made a wise decision to release them to consumers.  It will be interesting to see if this leads to similar success for the Pi 3.  (Via The Guardian, image is from the Raspberry Pi web site) Powered by Cincopa Video Hosting for Business solution.

Tamerlane, 33, shows the terror group as "idiots" who "just want to cause chaos". In a new clip of himself, he says: "We've got the best military strength as the world has ever seen in the world, and we don't even have enough to clean out London." Tamerlane goes on to say the terrorists' actions were proof that extremists are "losing the battle" with their enemies. "I believe ISIS want to prove they are losing, they just want to cause chaos. (Image: Sky News) (Image: Sky News) "They want to make a statement," he says. "But we are the only ones who can bring down this wall of fear in the land which God has given us. "That wall is a very narrow place, only about the size of the city of London. And the only way we can destroy it is with a force, with a movement, with our families, with our kids, with our men, with our women on our land, the land of our ancestors. "It's not like the way it is in many other parts of the world." Tamerlane goes on to tell how he and former London Bridge bomber Khuram Shazad Butt drove to the scene of the attack on Saturday night despite having been tipped off that there was another attack in the works. He describes Butt as "a very nice guy", while saying Butt had acted like a professional on the night and that he was a "very nice guy". He praises the way Butt, 30, was able to "go to the event" after he was "scared" of the incident and even went to check on his brother Nasser and their mother. (Image: Sky News) He says: "I want to remind him that his own security is a lot safer than his brother's. "This is our brothers' people, not our dogs, we are a lot better people than the ones who attacked the crowd, and you know that we are going to bring this organization to its knees in the only way possible. "We are the only ones that can put a stop to this. "It's not just Toulouse - all of France is under my control. It's not for want of work. "We have every weapon. We are Muslims and we are ready to go to war, so long as it is an Islamic holy war." (Image: Sky News) Speaking to Sky News, Tamerlane says the attacks in Paris have "put the security services on the spot with terrorism" and said he's "worried" about France but is very proud of how his men in Paris defeated ISIS . He insisted they will continue their attacks on the terrorists, calling them "idiots" who "don't have a plan, don't have a strategy". "What I want for the future of France is stability again," he said. "I want our society to be secure. And by that I mean, like you did after 7/7 of course, we have to be extra vigilant and more alert. "But also we've got to be alert to the radicalisation that is out there. Because you can see there are a lot of people. There are a lot of people from all walks of life, you know, who are becoming radicalised." Tamerlane added that he didn't believe any intelligence reports that an attack on London was imminent, insisting he's been able to predict them and stop them, saying a "lot" of warnings did not turn out to be true. He said: "A lot of times these warnings come out as a lot of smoke but there is a lot of fire because they don't want to warn us. "We have these idiots doing these things, they have no strategy and they don't have a strategy - you know, they think ISIS is going to take over the world in six months. "Why can't they see this for what it is? "They are stupid, these idiots and I don't like dealing with these idiots, because you can't even take a good joke like this, it's really something." When asked how he could remain so calm, Tamerlane replied: "I am very strong. I am not in panic mode. I still see things coming. (Image: Sky News) "Some people can run - I am very strong."
