If you are new to the world of vaping or the new kid on the block, or you have been a vaper for a little while but are curious about switching to e-cigarettes, then this article is for you. For some, it may be the ultimate tool in making a switch. We all have our favorite brands to smoke, so you may have to go with any one or some of them. However, your personal choice is only as good as the quality of the products that you buy. If you do not choose quality products and do not have a good reason for switching then you might be better off sticking with smoking, which is not necessarily healthier, but it is much more cost effective and it produces at least as good a quality of smoke. What makes an excellent electronic cigarette? You may be wondering how do I learn about the quality of the products available on the market. And there are plenty of quality brands out there, but as you would expect, they get more expensive in terms of your money. In this article, I will share to you the top 10 that I recommend you look for as possible replacements for those brands: 1. Smoker's Paradise or Innokin - If you are a smoker and are looking to switch to electronic cigarettes as a result of your habit being compromised, Smoker's Paradise are great products at a budget friendly price. The devices I get to smoke on are quite a bit nicer than any of those you would find for purchase from other manufacturers. Not only do they look good, but the taste is also excellent, as you will find out in this article. Not to mention, you get free shipping when buying them from Smoker's Paradise. There are only two problems with the products that I use - that being the small size of the cartridges that are available and that it can be rather difficult for my husband to load a cartridge while I am smoking. As for those who don't want to spend money, Innokin's eGo one is a nice product as well, but it can be a little pricey for a starter kit with all the accessories. However, there is the Innokin iTaste VV/VW Starter Kit which is much more affordable with a smaller size battery and a larger size atomizer. As for the other options, you have the Firefly series of products, which has a few different models; one of the best-selling is the TFV8 Lite, but the Firefly Series is great too with the TFV12 Gen2, TFV12 Rainmaker, and even the new TFV12 Prince. You can also find some cool options in the sub-$30 range, such as the Joyetech JUUL, M100, and the Kanger SUBVOD. Keep in mind that you must purchase at least one atomizer or cartomizer in order to use most of these devices. 2. X-Bow - X-Bow is the perfect example of a brand that you will see all over the web - it has a broad range of prices and even offers different types of tanks, such as glass and metal. Also, this e-cigarette brand offers several kits that include some accessories that will make your vape more convenient. X-Bow also allows you to upgrade the quality of your vapor as you progress through their product range, with new tanks, better atomizers and higher-quality cartridges. As a matter of fact, X-Bow is a top-rated brand that I recommend to anyone who wants to take charge of making a change. The prices are much more affordable than most the brands, as well. So, have you tried these 10 top brands? If so, which product(s) did you like? Tell me it was awesome and share on my Facebook page.

Sally Yates, the acting attorney general, will provide evidence to the Senate Judiciary Committee in an upcoming appearance to explain her role during former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn's misleading conversations with the press. Yates confirmed in a statement Monday that she would be providing testimony to the Senate Judiciary Committee, which has scheduled a hearing June 13, but offered no additional details about the matter, and referred the matter to the Justice Department. "When the United States government is notified that a person is subject to investigation, we need to thoroughly investigate that person's contacts and movements over time, particularly with foreign officials, to determine whether there is any evidence of a crime or criminal activity, and for that reason I have directed that the Department consider issuing a grand jury subpoena," Yates stated, according to USA Today. "As I have said, I believe that any investigation of this matter can be helpful to the President, as it provides an opportunity to resolve those questions." Yates was fired Thursday by President Trump, following Yates' refusal to answer questions from the White House on her knowledge of classified information regarding Flynn's communication with a Russian ambassador. Yates told the White House on Jan. 26 that Flynn had instructed the Trump transition team not to ask him questions regarding his contacts with Russian ambassador Sergey Kislyak. On March 22, Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein appointed Robert Mueller to be the special counsel for an investigation into Russian involvement in the 2016 election. The Justice Department's announcement indicated that it was still working on the issues about Yates. Follow Chuck on Twitter

In a move that could lead to more than $50 million in new tax revenue, the California Taxpayers' Assn on Tuesday introduced a measure aimed at ending a tax break that the group says discriminates on the basis gender. The state law, which takes effect July 1, allows men to deduct from their state tax all child support payments, regardless of the amount paid or the legal outcome. Women and girls get no such deduction. That makes the exclusion of child support payments from an accountant's calculation of a couple's tax liability a double advantage, said the organization's executive director, Mark Baldassare. "They can just claim something on the side of the return that really does nothing for the income tax," Baldassare said. Women get no such tax break for alimony, spousal maintenance or child support payments the couple owes, according to the group. While both men and women might owe child support to the state, that's not the only way women might receive a break, Baldassare said. A husband, for instance, might receive a smaller share of his wife's income if the couple have separate jobs. The bill, which is being introduced by state Sen. Ricardo Lara of Bell Gardens, would require the state Department of Revenue to determine whether income and tax payments from two separate sources are sufficiently comparable to exclude tax deductions, he said. "A bill like that needs to be addressed, and this is a good first step," said Lara, who said it would not interfere with people receiving other tax breaks. "There are no winners here." He said he was inspired to write the bill by recent reports that revealed the tax deduction exclusion on spousal support payments has increased. The tax break, which is worth $7,000 to $30,000 in the first year, does get more expensive as a couple ages. To qualify for the tax deduction, women and girls must report a child support payment on their state tax returns. Some don't do so, Baldassare said, including some who can pay child support in cash and who may be unaware of how much they are receiving. To be sure, other states have similar tax measures designed to address the disparity, Baldassare noted, not just to help a woman who is paying child support and another partner whose income is low. But California currently has the most restrictive tax rule, Baldassare said, and "people who are eligible for it are the disadvantaged ones." The state must determine whether there are substantial differences in both the amount reported on the child support form and the actual income of the couple, he said. The amount of the deduction would depend on the income of the man, as well as the amount reported during their most recent calendar year on their most recent state return, according to the measure. In addition, the mother would be able to recomputate her payments to include a portion of any pay that was received as alimony or spousal maintenance from the second person, in the form of a tax deduction, the initiative said. Women are often unable to negotiate favorable terms when they are in the divorce process, said Baldassare. If the woman pays spousal, maintenance or alimony to someone other than her former spouse, her tax bill on the whole amount will not change, he said. But because that payment goes to the man's income on his returns, it will be counted as taxable income that falls within the family's current tax bracket. "Now the man is paying alimony or child support, yet he gets a tax deduction," he said. Under the proposal, the man could qualify for the same tax break based on his share of the payment. That means a woman who has just completed a six-year marriage and separated from her first partner in 2008 would now be able to claim the child support deduction without having to show she has spent the past six years working while she was married, he said. "We get married, and our child support payment is $300," he said. "Then you have that same child-support payment, but in another year the child-support payment jumps to $400 to $500. And a couple of years later you have to have over $1,000 to keep the child support deduction." California will be the latest state to tackle the issue this year, following Arizona and Illinois, which both passed child support reform measures last year. In Michigan, there was no change in the child-support deduction in last year's state budget. But the state legislature is expected to consider including it in the upcoming state budget. In Maryland, lawmakers last year approved a child-support formula measure that would allow men to deduct child support payments from their income. The measure was not in effect for most of last year because the bill's language was amended before it was to take effect. The revised language allows for tax deductions for child support

[Note 1] This document was first published in French in Revue d'histoire de P.M., and translated into English in the volume for 1927-28, pp. 579-98.  [Note 2] As far as the work of the Communist Party of France may be understood and assessed by the international proletariat today, it is essential for a clear insight into the conditions of socialist construction to be gained for the French proletariat, for it not only carries the responsibility of fulfilling its historical mission to the proletariat in all countries, but is the instrument for raising it to a higher level of consciousness and organization in the labour movement, while at the same time taking over the tasks which must be carried out, and for which France has to bear the entire weight.  [Note 3] There exists no single formula which expresses accurately the conditions which existed in the Soviet Union during the period of its construction. In the period of its struggle for existence, the Soviet Union was obliged to make a great many tactical maneuvers and to adopt many different tactics. The Communist Party of France must learn from the mistakes made in its international relations and in the relations between the working class and the Communist Party and also from the mistakes of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.  [Note 4] In this regard, the Communist Party of France, on behalf of its members in the Communist Parties and in the labour movement, presents to the Communist International a new French translation of a report in which the Comintern approved the draft program of the Second Congress of the Communist International, that is, the program of the Communist Parties that were elected to the Executive Committee at the Second Congress and also the draft program of the Third Congress of the Comintern.  [Note 5] According to the draft program of the Second Congress of the Communist International approved at the Eleventh Conference in the Kremlin on June 19, 1934, the Communist Parties should be linked directly and directly to the Soviets and the Soviet authorities. The Comintern proposed to have the Executive Committee direct all the Parties and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics with respect to all questions of international relations. The Comintern also proposed to appoint Cominform (that is, the Communist International) to lead all the Communist Parties in the world in foreign trade and finance, in international relations with colonies and semi-colonies, international organization of the working class, in the training of proletarian revolutionaries, in the struggle against the reaction, and in all spheres of social activity.  [Note 6] By means of its press and press offices, the Communist Party of France will continue to transmit to the working class all the communist news in French and will make it easier for the working class to learn the Communist Party's position and program of action and to participate in its activities.  * * * THE FIRST CONFERENCE OF THE COMMUNIST PARTY OF FRANCE Present: 10th and 11th October 1. We hold our First Meeting at the Headquarters of the Communist Party of the French Republic (hereinafter : "the headquarters," to distinguish the Communist International from the Communist Party of France). 2. The Meeting was called by the Communist International in order to have an investigation of the situation of the revolutionary forces in France. 3. The Meeting was held according to a programme adopted at the Eleventh Conference of the Communist International of November 9 to 15, 1934. With the approval of the Eleventh Conference the programme was agreed upon at the Eleventh Plenary Session and approved by the General Secretary of the Communist International. 4. The programme of the Meeting of the Headquarters was based on the following main principles: a. the political and ideological emancipation of the Communist Party of France from the influence of international reaction and its political and ideological dependence on the proletarian parties of the world; b. the consolidation of the Communist Party of France, in common with all the other Communist Parties represented at the Meeting, and their complete union, with the other Parties represented at the Headquarters; c. the liquidation of all opportunists, revisionists, and opportunist militants from the Party and its organizations; d. the complete subordination of the French Communist Party and the Parties of Communist World to the Communist International; 5. All decisions and instructions of the Meeting of the Headquarters were adopted by the General Secretary of the Communist International, the Executive Committee of the Communist International, the General Secretariat of the Communist Parties, all the Organizational Commissions of the Communist Parties and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, and were communicated to all the Parties. The Chairman of the meeting of the Headquarters had the right to vote in case of disagreement with a decision or instruction of the meeting of the central bodies of the Communist Parties, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, or of the Communist International, as well as to express his opinions in the following matters: a. the

The following script is from "The Fight Within" which aired on May 2, 2015. Lesley Stahl is the correspondent. Shari Finkelstein, producer. A federal judge in Manhattan has ruled that the Justice Department must turn over all documents related to the FBI's investigation into two Planned Parenthood clinics in St. Louis and Long Island. On Thursday, a three-judge panel of the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals sent the department a long list of new records, including records of any meetings between Planned Parenthood officials and federal officials. The decision could allow lawmakers to demand more information about how the agency investigated the clinics. Planned Parenthood says a grand jury cleared it of any wrongdoing last year. The American Civil Liberties Union also says its clients weren't prosecuted after the FBI investigated its St. Louis clinics in the 1990s. Planned Parenthood supporters have called this a victory and say it would be a huge help to their fight in Congress. The groups that took part in the lawsuit applauded Thursday's decision. What does the ruling mean for Planned Parenthood? It means now that this is in court, they'll get their day in court. They don't care how many years until they win. It's not about the case, it's about the fact that this will go into discovery. And then we'll have to go through them all. This means that any and all records will be put on the public record. We will never be able to say "Oh we never thought about this." "It is time for the Obama administration to finally come clean with the public and with congress about what it did and did not do," said Elizabeth Nash. Planned Parenthood says they can now release information about their clinics for the first time since 2007, but the organization is fighting for at least some of the documents they turned over last fall to the committee investigating Planned Parenthood. The group would release them if they won, and they don't give up -- in fact after Thursday's decision Planned Parenthood is planning to file a lawsuit so that they can keep some of the records. How is it possible that such a case has been sitting in court for over three years? The reason why this case has not been put on the public record is because the government has refused to acknowledge that this investigation happened, as I said. It has not said anything. Why aren't any records that were turned over in March when the committee said this were public? Because this committee requested all records related to this investigation that had been turned over by March of last year. The Justice Department refused to do this because it is trying to get around the public records law. They are trying to hold this information in secret so that politicians can never get them. They don't care about the public -- they want to hold these records in secret so that the people never know the truth. And the government won't release documents it says will embarrass Planned Parenthood or President Obama? No, not a word. They're not going to release any documents that would embarrass us or embarrass our patients. I have had my own problems with the Justice Department over the years. They never get a court order to release these documents. They're just holding them back for years. But now we have it. Once the judge signs off on the ruling we will be on the public record. And how far can the Department go now? They're no longer hiding documents. The judge signed off on that on Monday with an order to release at least some of these documents. Right now, we are not at liberty to say anything more than that we expect to be able to release a significant portion of these documents later this year. And they are the only federal court system that has the authority to do it. In addition, it has been our experience there is a high level of interest from the public in this case and this is why we are fighting them on the issue. What does our legal team want in response? We want the federal government to stop hiding documents, to make its records available to the American people and we want to be held accountable for what went on during this investigation. What the Justice Department says are the documents to release? We're confident that we have a majority of the documents that the Department believes we will be able to release at this date. We believe this will include all of the grand jury records, all of the records that were submitted to the grand jury, all of the notes taken by the assistant U.S. attorneys, all of the documents that the Justice Department made public. But it will also include records which the Department has not yet turned over. What does Planned Parenthood say? We are still waiting to receive those documents. We hope the judge allows us to see them now that we are on appeal. If we are denied access to those documents we will sue. Why now?

Tough times on the market for small-business owners Updated Small and medium-sized businesses are struggling to survive in the current economic context, new figures show. In the February quarter, small businesses' net profit fell by more than nine per cent to $14.8 billion, according to the latest Small Business and Family Enterprise Report by the Small Business Association (SBA). The annual report shows that business confidence remained low, unemployment remained high, there was an ongoing supply-side manufacturing slowdown and wages growth remained weak from the previous year. It also notes that wage growth has fallen to its lowest level since the March quarter of 2015. SBA chief executive Belinda Robinson says the situation has been exacerbated by negative factors such as declining global demand and lower commodity prices, the mining boom and low-profile trade deals such as Japan's free trade deal with the United States. "This report also illustrates the very real challenges small business owners and their families are facing," Ms Robinson said. "The current economic conditions, including the ongoing decline in commodity prices, which have hit many small businesses hard, are resulting in many small and medium-sized businesses being forced to curtail or close as part of their daily business operations. "These are business owners who are struggling with a growing number of suppliers unable to deliver goods. "A key reason for this, particularly for the small business operators experiencing difficulty, is the falling purchasing power of our national economy. "As our nation's economy continues to struggle to find a sustainable path to growth, we're seeing businesses and their customers facing many challenges, and this report makes clear the scale of the challenge." Topics: business-economics-and-finance, small-business, australia First posted

Tired of waiting on long lines and a long lunch? You can now order food from your phone. While it's a pretty impressive solution for the average person on the go, it's something worth considering if you're an office drone. In reality, though, it could just be another convenience for the busy executive. Here's why. 1. It's just cheaper. With a smartphone, you don't have to worry about setting up a phone or making purchases online. But that's not the only perk. When you're buying a sandwich from a digital menu, the price for the sandwich is deducted from your credit card. To pay for it, you need to have a credit card to begin with, and if you don't, the purchase is refunded to your PayPal account and the order goes straight to your phone. 2. Not just fast, but reliable. This is an increasingly common scenario: You've got a phone but you're not exactly comfortable calling a real person. There are apps that connect you with a person, and most work just fine. The problem with these options is that most of them are also paid app services. When I need to pay a friend out of my pocket, I can go to their app; when I'm on a vacation or on vacation, a friend could be able to get me free hotels. I can't do that when I have to call my coworkers. 3. You don't have to be a business analyst. The app also lets you order products like pizza without having to be too tech-savvy. A couple more features on the way will let you purchase stuff that can't be delivered. The technology does all the heavy lifting, and you don't have to keep clicking your phone to wait in line. If you have a mobile office, you could even order pizza from out of the office, and use that to create some good, fast, free time by ordering pizzas for your team. 4. You can always pay with credit or PayPal. There are no monthly fees or credit monitoring. You simply order online and get paid off at the end of the month, regardless of what's in your account. You pay by the hour, and when a payment goes through, it's free. That means you can use it to go out to eat and buy something to go. 5. If you don't know how to use it, you can use a smartphone to book a restaurant. You have to set up the phone as a guest, though, and there are limitations. If the time you want to spend on a menu item is over four hours, you have to call ahead and confirm. 6. If you do know how to use the tool, you need to wait in line. Some orders actually take longer than an average day at lunchtime, so people often wait in line. I've ordered meals from a phone twice, and those didn't fare well. If you see a line, you can either wait until the order goes ahead, or get there before the line forms. Or you know a really cute waitress who might let you get in to order pizza. 7. You can cancel at any time after you've placed two orders. If you do cancel, you have to wait in line every time you come back. Your order remains in your card's memory, which means if you come back later, you'd have to wait a full day for your next order. It's only really fun for the first four or five times, however, so by that point it might be too late. 8. If you don't have a credit card, you can still do it from paypals.com. It's a service that allows people to pay each other. When I ordered pizza, it worked fine, but it was a bit inconvenient. I had to go to their website, sign up, and create a PPO account—and then it worked fine. If you like to try any new technologies, you can get a $25 Amazon gift card which will get you a pair of Bluetooth earbuds. Just head over to The Verge's office for an invite. UPDATE: We have reached out and the Verge is working on integrating this service into their existing app: a long wait, but we're excited to have a new way of ordering pizza and more options as we head into the coming years for technology.

You can find this recipe on the Tidy Mom blog here "I don't care what you think of me." And I want you to know that that was exactly the mindset of this poor little girl that is my mom. She was always so proud of her daughter and would say, "Oh, she's so proud of me!" But in reality, she was always so concerned with her daughter's self-esteem and self-image. And that made her mom so upset. She wanted her daughter to realize something to the point of her suicide. She felt embarrassed that she, despite having been a woman for the better part of her childhood, she never understood how girls felt when things didn't go their way. She would try to explain it to me when I was a kid, but I couldn't seem to understand that I had been wrong all of my life, and in so many ways, I hadn't been any different than the little girl that I wanted to be. I think she figured that since that little girl had been raised by a great dad that she would have a great dad someday. I am so so grateful that she didn't take her life. She did. But her poor little soul was crushed. She was so embarrassed and embarrassed all the years. She was so ashamed and ashamed the day my dad told her what he had overheard during a work meeting, but she didn't talk about it or accept that my dad had to tell her that. She had a daughter, and she was going to be a single mom. She wasn't going to be able to go home anymore. She was going to live as out with all of her friends who had kids as well. Her daughter wanted to be a mom. She didn't want to come home. She made no effort to help her daughter learn how to be a mom. She taught her to be independent. She taught my husband that she was the most wonderful, wonderful woman, and how wonderful she was. And she gave him that little doll and said, well, my daughter likes that doll. She was so proud of her, and I am sad to say that when it came time to have a little sister I never quite embraced. I don't know if I feel anything at all sad or bad now that she is gone. But I do know I have to be very cautious in the ways that she had passed on to her child so that my daughter doesn't feel like she is being shamed and marginalized for not getting married and having children. I have to be very careful about who is doing the shaming for her to feel good about what she could become in this world. My daughter needs to know that, regardless of where she is, if she is happy, then that's good enough. I just want my daughter to see people and know they are there for her. My daughter needs me, and my love, and to feel like I can be this strong, secure female, and that I can be here for her in any way that I need. That I wouldn't ever let my kid go without help. I want her to know that no matter what anyone else has done to her in the past or in her life, she is worth so much more. She was the perfect little girl, and I'm proud of her for that. She is the perfect kid, and I am proud of her for that. But you know what I think is important? My daughter is the perfect little girl. Because, in truth, no matter how ugly she gets, or how flawed she becomes, she is always worth more than anything. She is always worth more than anybody's hatred, or neglect or abuse or failure at life will ever be able to take away from her. She is forever. So I want my daughter to know that she is worth so much more than they will ever be able to take away from her. I want her to know that no matter what anybody else has done to her in the past or in her life, she is worth so much more than anybody's hatred, or neglect or abuse or failure at life will ever be able to take away from her. She is forever — not just as a child, with all of her potential, not just as a teenager, with all of her energy, but as a human being. She is worth being cared for and protected and given everything that she can possibly expect and deserve. She is worth feeling loved and appreciated for who she is and how amazing she is. She is worth being treated with the fullness of the love from those who love her. She is worth being held safe and loved, and protected, and celebrated as a human being. She is worth teaching that she is a human being, and when anybody says, "You can't do that" or "You shouldn't do that

I had to go through the pain of making this recipe in the last week of December and it's just the right amount of time to appreciate the beauty and the deliciousness of cinnamon rolls! It's so easy and quick, I recommend it for anyone who does not like baked goods! It's very versatile for cinnamon rolls, like banana bread and French toast, which is awesome for lazy Sunday mornings. If you do like these, you can make them in the morning and wait a while – I waited almost the whole morning, except for a few second for my husband to come home from work. Then a few hours later, go ahead and bring the rolls out of the oven and enjoy them! In the case of this recipe, I love a little bit of crunch here and there and if you can find fresh, shredded coconut, it's so good, it really goes perfectly with cinnamon. That's my preference so if you can afford it, you might try shredded coconut! The only thing about these rolls is: 1) they won't last as long as store-bought rolls, so if you need to bake a few dozen, store-bought, made-from-scratch rolls to go with breakfast the next day, you may as well just use the cinnamon rolls that have been sitting around, waiting for you to need them! 🙂 So without further ado, here are 3 easy steps to make these amazing cinnamon rolls: 1) Make the cinnamon rolls. First, let me explain that, I usually use my cast iron skillet for cinnamon rolls. If you don't have one of those, you can use parchment paper or foil. Simply place the dough inside and stick it in. Or place it on oiled parchment paper in the skillet and turn it over. Do it on the stove top, on the hob, on the grill or on the grill pan. If you do use a skillet, you can even use a hot pan. If you use parchment paper, the cinnamon rolls will be a bit drier. But seriously, you can use any pan you like. I usually don't use any parchment here because it's not as good as parchment, but you can use it if you want! 🙂 2) Roll the cinnamon rolls with the sauce. Then simply stick everything together with a fork. I prefer a slightly moist cinnamon roll because the consistency of the cinnamon doesn't sink in easily. If you prefer your cinnamon rolls to be dry, you can bake them for a few more minutes. Or cover the pan with a few inches of water and bake for 15-20 minutes, stirring once during 10-15 minutes and after it comes out of the oven. 3) Take them out of the pan and flip them. Now let me know if there are any steps where I do not describe the method perfectly. It's always good to ask for help so please do ask. So let's get started! Step #1 Dissolve the sugar, water, eggs and vanilla in the bowl of an electric mixer. Once the mixture is all mixed together, add the coconut oil and mix for two minutes. Then you can slowly add the flour to the dough – add it all in, one tablespoon at a time. Once you've added all the flour, it's time to knead. Then you need to knead for about 8-10 minutes until the dough just starts to get smooth. When you've finished, place the dough on a lightly floured surface. Then you can roll it out into a rectangle and cut it into 24 pieces (you should roll them out into 8-10 pieces). The coconut oil will take a little bit of work to roll out. If you want to do some work-free cinnamon rolls, use your hands. Just put it on a baking sheet – the coconut oil is soft and the butter will make it easier to roll out. This is my favorite kind of cinnamon rolls. 🙂 Step #2 Take one of the dough pieces and roll it up into two big circles. This is where the magic happens. Just use your hands to make the cinnamon and butter mixture into a large ball. You can also shape it with your hands. 🙂 Place it into a parchment lined 9x13 baking dish and cover with extra parchment paper. Bake the cinnamon rolls for 25 minutes, or until the cinnamon rolls are nicely golden-browned. Step #3 If you are adding some sweetener or additional sugar and eggs, sprinkle it on the top of the cinnamon rolls before baking at 350° F, for about 5-7 minutes until the sugar is fully absorbed (check the temperature of your baking dish during this step). Serve directly from the oven and keep warm, or serve warm and refrigerated for 5-7 minutes. If you are making them for a party, place them back in the sauce just like store-bought cinnamon

A B.C. police commander says a group of men he arrested last week in a Vancouver housing project had broken into the complex, then held a party inside while police were en route. The men, many without tickets or criminal record, had been kicked out of a West End unit for causing "disturbances," though police have not yet charged them with a crime. The break-in happened sometime between 6 a.m. and 9 a.m., and four officers were dispatched. The officers spotted three other men nearby who were also allegedly stealing from the complex. "We responded to the front door where two people were kicking open a door ... and we confronted them and it turned out that they were with one of the suspects that had actually been kicked out of that complex earlier in the morning," said Sgt. Paul Estrin. At that point, one suspect allegedly turned violent, beating an officer and a second officer. Two of the accused then left without resistance, but a third suspect stayed behind and started to assault an officer, Estrin said. When he tried to restrain him, Estrin said, the suspect threw an object that hit his head and broke his glasses. "We used a Taser in a way that we typically do because as we got close a suspect tried to resist and at that point he went into shock mode, he stopped moving, so we had no choice but to tase him. He was obviously unconscious at this point due to a Taser and then when we removed the Taser, we saw bruising on his face." The officers then arrested six men, including the man who was tasered, and placed them in custody. There also appeared to be two more suspects, Estrin said, because at one point the police vehicle transporting the officers had to make an emergency stop on Highway 1 to avoid hitting a stalled car that was blocking the highway. When Estrin arrived at a police station to confirm the eight-man squad had been successfully apprehended, he noticed some people in a small building nearby had been partying. The officers had to evacuate the building because they knew the building was full of people, and took the first seven people in the building for questioning. The other eight escaped, and Estrin believes that was probably the reason there was a party with only seven people within a small building. After taking the seven for questioning, the officers went to their car to search for weapons. One of the men inside had a bat that he'd been using as a weapon, a knife and a set of keys. Estrin said he does not know if the knife was legal to carry. The bat was too large to get into a police car without injuring the officer, Estrin said. He does not know how the three people in the building were able to avoid being handcuffed, and is unsure if the bat was legal to carry. He believes a person needs to be able to get the bat inside a police car with them without it hurting them. With files from Meghan Hurley and Meghan Gillies kderosa@timescolonist.com

You'll know you're a survivor when you see a white person's name on a police database, he wrote. "I am proud to say that my father wasn't included." A spokeswoman said the company has not yet made a decision on whether it will pursue the lawsuit. At the moment, the company has "no comment" about Mr. White's story but said in a statement to The Times that it investigates allegations of police misconduct with "fierce rigor." The company, which also owns a major trucking company, said "we welcome legitimate and credible civil rights litigation." As recently as Thursday, Mayor Bill de Blasio, a liberal, promised to make it easier to sue police, saying he would require an independent civil rights monitor for every department, and make it easier for people to access records of police shootings and discipline by the Police Department. Mr. White's own lawyer, Anthony R. Matteucci, told The Daily News that Mr. White had been the subject of dozens of racist online comments over the years over the incident, and that he was seeking damages for psychological and emotional distress. "He's still a child, and he has never forgotten," he said. "He's been living like this for a decade and a half. He's not going to be satisfied until he got justice."

A new report of India's first ever 'Bathroom Bill' in the Indian Parliament has raised questions about the impact of such a bill on women. Women's Rights advocate Vrinda Grover told International Business Times India that "This bill should not be passed." The bill was originally filed in September 2016 in the Indian Parliament. It requires anyone using restrooms/showers, including people visiting the toilet, to have a separate ticket. A statement released by India's Ministry of Women and Child Development (WCD), the law's sponsor, says the policy will eliminate discrimination and provide a "privacy-friendly environment." "A person may use the communal bath while using the restroom to keep their dignity and will not be molested," the statement says. "In case a person uses the communal facility as per the directions, others may not disturb him/her in the toilet. This has been designed to serve to make such facilities inclusive for everyone." Grover wrote to President of the National Commission for Women, Lalitha Kumaramangalam, about the bill. She's written to President Pranab Mukherjee and Prime Minister Narendra Modi about the issue saying that she "will be filing a complaint in court." "This bill is unconstitutional because it is discriminatory and targets women," Grover told IBTimes India. "There are many people who do use the facilities, but no one can tell them to use the bathroom only for females." Grover said that if the bill is passed, she plans to ask for a judicial review. If she can't, Grover said she would like to see the whole issue "thrown out," since she believes it's unconstitutional. Grover noted that the bill is also a first of its kind in the world. The issue of bathroom bills like these has been on the agenda in other parts of the world. In the U.S., in 2014, the city of Seattle adopted a "Right To Bathroom" ordinance. It requires businesses and landlords to provide a separate space for each person's personal use. Grover also pointed out that the U.S. is a diverse country and "discrimination should not be allowed against one, race, gender, or religion in the U.S." The bill in India is not a direct response to North Carolina's recently passed "Bathroom Bill" that requires transgender people to use the bathroom of their birth gender. India is not a North Carolina. But, it does seem to be a "bathroom" bill that targets women. Read more: India To Introduce A New Policy That Allows Adults To Go To The Bathroom As They Choose Grover also stressed that this kind of legislation should be about children. "It's about protecting children, and it's about protecting women," Grover said. "It is very difficult for a woman to go to the toilet alone." Grover also pointed out that the U.S. is no stranger to bathrooms and is a relatively progressive nation when it comes to allowing women to be treated as they see fit. "Why are we allowing governments to impose these requirements on individuals by their own consent?" Grover asked IBTimes India. Grover also pointed out that this kind of regulation shouldn't apply to foreigners as the legislation shouldn't apply to anyone who needs a bathroom on the road to public transportation. Grover is no stranger when it comes to fighting for women's rights. She made headlines in the past for suing the family planning and HIV Prevention Minister Maneka Gandhi after she allegedly sexually harassed her. Grover won the suit in 2008 and was awarded an equal amount in the amount of damages. There's no doubt that it didn't deter Gandhi from using her powers to harass the woman again. Gandhi has also been criticized for a new bill in the Indian Parliament that will allow men to rape their female partners and make it illegal to raise a son to be free of that sort of violence. Grover said "The women's movement is making real progress, and the government should also support these things by bringing them up to the level of law." "Women are no longer treated as an inferior species by their governments," Grover argued. "This shows an enormous transformation in India." Photo courtesy of Shutterstock

In the midst of an increasingly bitter political battle, the mayor of a southern Ontario town is asking for federal funding to ensure the survival of a local school. But in Regina, an MP wants to ban city staff from using federally-funded programs in schools, as a way of preventing federal agents from snooping in their files and learning the identities of those who work there. In the past few weeks, Toronto Mayor Rob Ford – the son of the late former mayoral chief of staff, David Soknacki – has publicly railed against Ottawa for making it harder for Canadian cities to borrow to build more public infrastructure. Story continues below advertisement He accused Ottawa of trying to prevent him from using tax dollars to help refurbish his home in Etobicoke. He was especially incensed after the Ontario government recently added an eight per cent tax surcharge to the federal-provincial infrastructure bank loan that his office can use to build a library and green space, as well as other municipal projects. In the meantime, Mr. Ford asked for a $1-million federal grant to expand the school at a time when city staff can't afford the added cost of renting office space downtown. "I'm asking for $1-million from the federal government," Mr. Ford, who is not running for re-election, told a crowd of more than 100 people at a school that has closed for good. He said the grant would provide money for a new library, and also support the town's new community centre. "I know I can't ask for that, but this is about the children in this area," he said. The grant would go to help the new School of the Art + Design, to be built by Regina architect Michael Kinsley. Mr. Kinsley is the designer of the new Regina-Wascana library, unveiled by Prime Minister Stephen Harper last week. Council's executive order will also put the matter on council's agenda in July for further discussion, council president Kerry Jang said. "We want to keep it as a special concern because it will be a very unique thing to have at one of our main schools," he said. Saskatchewan Premier Brad Wall, a provincial MP who represents the party that elected Mr. Ford to council, said he had heard from a number of people who feel angry the federal government has made it impossible for the city to borrow for construction projects. The province's finance minister, Kevin Doherty, has told The Globe and Mail that cities can use their provincial infrastructure bank to borrow money to fund major projects, including major infrastructure projects. But they are forbidden to use the bank for other purposes. Story continues below advertisement Story continues below advertisement In Regina, Mr. Doherty said provincial borrowing can take place as part of the province's infrastructure bank. Mr. Doherty said the city borrowed $3.8-billion (U.S.) to build the $400-million Regina Central Library. The capital cost included a five-year, 2.1-per-cent property-tax hike. The province is lending the total of $4.9-billion for 10 years. "The capital cost for the Regina Central Library, which is part of what we call a transit-based city, is very similar … [with] what we would call capital cost for a library in Toronto or Quebec City, two other major Canadian cities that have very strong public library-based systems." Quebec borrowed more from the province's infrastructure bank because of a greater need for capital projects and because Quebec's tax rates are generally lower than in Ontario, Mr. Doherty said. The federal government provides funds to help cities build infrastructure, but only if the city is eligible and eligible cities are paid for their share through charges to residents, said a federal finance department source. The amount of any charge might be smaller than for a public hospital. The loan would not replace the cost of the land lease, such as a $250-million provincial subsidy to the town for buying the land and building the school. "It's not a loan," a source said. Story continues below advertisement Mr. Jang said the council does not want to ban staff from using federally funded programs in schools, as is being proposed by federal MP Brad Butt, who is running to be party leader in the Saskatchewan Party. The MP has drafted a bill that would make Toronto Mayor Rob Ford's request to borrow from Ottawa a federal offence, something he called "extreme." Mr. Butt said he believes that the government has put too much restrictions on how cities are used to fund municipal projects and public-works projects. "All of this really does is take away the option for municipalities to access the resources," he said in an interview. Saskatchewan has long been a champion of school closures in cities around the province. Since 1996, the province has

The FBI's raid on a San Bernardino, California law firm that represents several Apple executives has been characterized as the agency's most aggressive action yet to crack down on Silicon Valley. The FBI has sought to force Apple to help it bypass an iPhone running iOS 8, Apple's new operating system for iPhones, as it develops a case against a terrorist in Yemen linked to Al-Qaeda. A federal judge rejected the agency's demand for software to allow the government to hack into locked iPhones. Apple's lawyers said the government's actions were "an egregious breach of the legal process" and that they hoped court documents could be sealed, according to the Associated Press. A spokeswoman for the San Bernardino County district attorney didn't respond to a request for comment. The agency's move has set off a firestorm on both sides of the debate. Apple (AAPL) and the FBI have been at loggerheads on how the government should proceed with its case. Apple and the FBI have accused each other of playing politics. On Friday, the Justice Department made public a letter that it sent to the FBI's leading federal judge earlier that day. The letter, a copy of which was posted on the website of U.S. District Judge Sheri Pym, told Pym that the U.S. government is considering filing criminal charges against the people behind the hacking tool, known as the "kill switch," and the person who made it open to the public.

Gareth Bale has scored 19 goals for club and country this season Olympic Games semi-final first leg v Ukraine Venue: Maracana Stadium Date: Monday 22 September Kick-off: 19:45 BST Coverage: Live on BBC Radio 5 live, plus live text commentary on BBC Sport website Arsenal striker and Welshman Gareth Bale has been confirmed as the third Wales player to feature in the Euro 2016 final, as they face the winners of Belgium and France. Wales qualified as one of three teams not to have picked an outfield player in their final 10-man squad, with fellow former players Aaron Ramsey and James Chester, whose omission was in the original 23 on Tuesday, being named to replace them. Defender Chester is currently sidelined with an injury. Bale, who will be making his 100th international appearance, came off the bench to score the winner in Barcelona on Tuesday. "Gareth has proven himself against top opposition and with the Premier League's top teams. He is one of the most reliable and important players for us," said Wales boss Chris Coleman at his news conference. "The next 11 games, at the very least, are very important to show we have the quality to go to the semi-finals." Media playback is not supported on this device Euro 2016 final: Gareth Bale scores stunning winner for Wales over Spain But it is Chester who may have been most disappointed to miss out, given his record. He made his first Wales appearance in August 2005, making his full international debut against Australia in Cardiff before his first international start at the age of 17 against Moldova in Moscow. Two more appearances followed in November that year before Chester had an opportunity to play the full 90 minutes in Wales' first three European games. Wales' Euro 2016 qualifying campaign Dates Games Cardiff 6 August 2005 4 4 Marseille 20 August 2006 2 2 Bratislava 7 December 2006 1 1 Dnipro 14 December 2007 2 2 Chester has not yet made his debut in Wales' top-flight after coming close to having an impact in 2009, when he had a run of seven games, coming off the bench in the 1-0 defeat away to Switzerland and the 1-1 draw at France in Lens. But an injury problem forced him to miss Euro 2012, while injury problems have blighted his Euro 2016 campaign to date. In his most recent game, on 8 November, he joined fellow Welshman Aaron Ramsey on the treatment table after he was injured running to win possession in the box under pressure from Spanish midfielder Sergio Busquets, with the resulting collision sending him crashing against a wall on the edge of the penalty area. Coleman felt Ramsey's injury looked "dizzier than it actually was"; it has since been confirmed the Arsenal man suffered ligament damage against Benfica. "I am not the one in control of our first team," said Coleman, who has only kept one of his 10 changes to the side beaten by Spain during his first two games in charge.

1. What is a 'Coroner's Inquest' The coroners inquest is a public inquiry into the death of a person. By law, its main purpose is to help determine the cause of death, and the steps taken by the medical or other professionals involved. The inquest is similar to an open-council coroner, that is, the inquiry has all the powers of an open-council inquest with certain conditions. The coroner's inquest can be a one-day public hearing, and it can cover all the facts relevant to the cause of death, without restricting the investigation. It provides the public with an opportunity to make submissions to the coroner and hear all of the witnesses at the inquest. The inquest has only a limited ability to intervene and, if required, take any steps to determine the cause of death. It is therefore often the case that a coroners inquest is the final process of investigation. The coroner does not look for criminal or accidental criminal or legal action in an inquiry, however he or she can request an inquest if he or she needs to pursue evidence from other public bodies about possible criminal or legal action. 2. Is There a National Coroners' Inquest? There is a statutory requirement for coroners to hold coroners' inquests for each person who dies in the UK. The coroners inspect the scene and interview the primary person and anyone else who can provide any information about the fatal incident. Further, the coroner has the power to call other people for a coroners' inquest to assess the circumstances of an accident involving one of the deceased. There are certain circumstances in which the coroner can be called to consider whether the deaths were caused by criminal or legal action. This is known as a criminal inquest. 3. An Overview of Coroners' Inquest's Why Do Coroners Hold Coroners' Inquiries Why do coroners need to hold coroners' inquests? This is not a straightforward question to answer, however there are a few common reasons why coroners need to hold coroners' inquests. This section explains what coroners' inquests are and provides an overview for those who may be unfamiliar. The purpose of the coroners' inquest is to help settle or clarify matters with respect to the death of a person. This is to allow for the proper determination of compensation of the deceased and to provide reassurance to relatives of the dead and relatives of the injured. The hearing of the coroners inquest helps the family of the death to understand and work with the healthcare authorities, the police, the coroner and the Department of Justice – to name a few agencies. This helps alleviate problems that were not fully understood earlier on. Further information on the inquest process may be found by using the links contained on each section. How Coroners Run Coroners' Inquiries The coroners have the power to set the terms of the coroners' inquest and usually do so whenever possible. Generally, coroners set the terms of the inquest, and it is the coroner who chooses the order in which the inquiries will be held and who can choose what issues or questions to ask. The inquest may take place concurrently with a regular inquest or at a later date. Where an inquest is needed to clarify medical conditions, which is most often the case, as most medical and legal conditions for the death of a person are unclear or undetermined, the inquest must be held within 14 days following the death or any death, whichever is the earlier date. An inquest may also be set over many different issues, however this rarely occurs. Coroners decide the terms of the inquest themselves and not over the objections of any other investigating authority. While it's likely that each coroners' inquest will cover many different issues, there are three important issues in the public and legal mind which cause people to express serious concern about how an inquest is conducted: the length of the inquest, the nature of medical tests in which the coroner participates and whether or not evidence is kept secret. Who Conducts Coroners' Inquests Corinars are often run by coroners, such as the Coroner, Family Coroner and the Chief Coroner. The chief coroners also tend to oversee the wider coronation arrangements. There are three main types of coroners who run coroners inquests: Family Coroner family coroners – in the UK, the Coroners' Service is a statutory public service and its members can be identified using the following code names: Coroner, Family Coroner. These coroner's coroners are appointed to a specific geographical area and are responsible for holding coroners inquests and, sometimes, other types of inquests in other parts of the UK. They are the most powerful person in the county they are appointed to. They can also run the coroner's inquests if they are deemed appropriate by the Cabinet Secretary- a public office holder. Specialists in private practice –

When did the public in America (and the wider world) start believing that all children are entitled to the same entitlements and privileges as the elite? Or that it is reasonable to expect adults and children of all races, gender, and income level to be "equal"? A new Pew study shows how young children in American schools are increasingly being indoctrinated with this attitude. "Among the public, the number stating that children should not be held back because of race, class, or economic status has grown from 46% to 53% in the last four decades." "More than 6-in-10 adults (63%) also say that it is a good thing for all children if their parents can support them and if adults in the household can provide for them; just a third (33%) say it is a bad thing if the same is true for their own children." It is interesting to note that there is no similar growth in the number of people that feel that all children should be held back because of their race, class, or income.

This article was written by David Scharf, Executive director of the Institute for Science and International Security and an adjunct senior scholar of the Global Policy Institute and contributor to the Center for American Progress. The United States has a strong record in reducing nuclear and missile threats. But the same is true of no other country with as large a nuclear arsenal. At present more than 800 nuclear weapons in total (roughly equivalent to 60,000 warheads for the American arsenal, one-fifth to one-seventeenth that of the Soviet Union) are being deployed in more than 25 countries. In addition, the United States has an arsenal of some 100 intercontinental missiles (ICBMs) capable of carrying nuclear warheads that could be launched from more than 10,000 sites, all of which would have to remain operational through the end of the decade. In 2011, the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) estimated that total expenses necessary to maintain the nuclear modernization program—including routine maintenance and refurbishment—in the United States over the coming decade would exceed $3 trillion. If those expenditures are divided evenly among 30 countries with the largest nuclear arsenals—including Brazil, China, India, Pakistan, South Korea, and Russia—that means that these countries would collectively spend about $1,600 per year per nuclear weapon, including the cost of construction and decommissioning. The sheer number of nuclear-armed states, the range of their arsenals, and the size of their budgets—some of them the size of countries such as Russia—create a serious problem for those countries that cannot or will not comply with the new treaty. In effect, a potential nuclear war between these countries would inevitably be fought over scarce stockpiles of nuclear weapons. Yet even with this enormous military effort, we can still expect that if there is a conventional military conflict between nuclear-armed states, there may well be a nuclear exchange. In any case, the risk of a nuclear exchange is high given our political, military, and media institutions are not prepared to deal with an accident or breakdown in the system. We have already seen how the fear of nuclear war has resulted, in some places, in the abrogation of treaties and agreements. We cannot expect to find similar international agreements that can stop the next nuclear exchange. A potential nuclear war between nuclear-armed states could escalate quickly and dramatically if it were not for a number of factors. The first is the nature of the nuclear arsenals of the nuclear-armed states. As it has done with nuclear weapons, the United States is working to deescalate conflict and reduce the likelihood of large-scale conventional retaliation. In this effort, each country is focusing on a handful of nuclear weapons—an effort known as "ballistic alignment." (See this map for a rough estimate of the numbers.) Because most people would not immediately understand what nuclear weapons are, it is useful to explain them briefly. The nuclear weapons in today's arsenals are: Three hydrogen bombs: the bombs on the B-61 ("strategic hydrogen bomb"), the B-83 ("stealth and precision hydrogen bomb"), and the H-bomb to be used on Russian soil in 2015 ("high yield thermonuclear weapon"). They all can explode with up to 300 megatons of explosive force. One thermonuclear missile carried by a carrier aircraft (a "strategic missile"). One nuclear-tipped cruise missile. An estimated one strategic submarine at the operational level. One missile-launched ballistic missile. One intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM). One land-based intercontinental ballistic missile missile (ICBM) that also carries a nuclear warhead, for use against potential adversaries in North America, the Middle East, and parts of Asia. The United States has approximately one-third of the available nuclear weapons in existence. The rest are in the hands of the United States, Russia, and countries that have nuclear arsenals as small as one (the United Kingdom). As a result of its efforts to deescalate conflict, the United States currently possesses many more strategic warheads and lower levels of warheads in the ground-launched cruise and ICBM arsenals than in 1991. As the table below indicates, in 1991, the United States held more than 7,700 warheads (the highest level ever). At present, it has roughly 3,800 warheads (the lowest level ever). If one uses the estimates by the U.S. intelligence community (in an analysis of the Soviet Union published earlier this year), it is estimated that the United States will have at least 6,700 deployed warheads by 2015. In the United States, there are major efforts underway to modernize their nuclear weapons. Many of these initiatives will require the active cooperation of major nuclear-armed states, as the Nuclear Weapons Council was not present during the debate on the START agreement, and several states on the Nuclear Suppliers Group (NSG) have been demanding changes to the status

DETROIT -- Detroit Tigers infielder Nick Castellanos will have surgery Wednesday for a fractured wrist, the Tigers announced. The surgery will be performed by Dr. Stephen White at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York. The procedure is expected to be a one-month recovery. Castellanos injured his wrist when hit in the face by a pitch Tuesday night. He walked off the field with a wrapped left wrist. He was diagnosed with a fracture in two places, and it was not known until now why he left the game late. While it appeared he suffered a contusion or bruise, a fracture requires an extra exam, so he was sent to New York for examination. The club said the procedure was necessary because the break is "not healing well." Castellanos is expected to miss at least the first month of the 2018 season after surgery. Last season, he batted .253 with 15 homers and 52 RBIs before he was traded to the Tigers while the New York Mets were making their playoff run. He was traded to the Tigers with outfielder Yoenis Cespedes for slugger Francisco Martinez two weeks later. ESPN.com's Jerry Crasnick contributed to this report.

PITTSBURGH (KDKA) – One of the world's largest cruise lines is bringing its fleet into Pittsburgh for a few days. Voyager Cruises has scheduled 10 ships in the Port Authority's Gateway to Pittsburgh, starting Thursday. That's a significant number of ships moving around the Port, which has the second largest commercial cruise traffic in America behind New York. "We have no doubt that as port authority, we want to be able to offer the best and best services possible," Port Authority Authority CEO David G. Reiser told KDKA-TV. Gates opened to the ships over the weekend. They're expected to leave from the cruise terminal at 11 a.m., with the last one leaving 11 p.m. Friday. RELATED LINKS: More Pittsburgh News Join The Conversation On The KDKA Facebook Page Stay Up To Date, Follow KDKA On Twitter Voyager Cruise Lines is the world's third largest cruise ship line. Its ships operate out of seven ports in the U.S. and Bermuda. The ships will visit nine ports in Pittsburgh, including the Port Authority terminals and a new cruise terminal built at the port. "We are looking forward to exploring its capabilities, its amenities and its people as we get ready for the arrival of our next ship early next year, and we very much welcome the opportunity to do so here," Reiser said. The Port Authority spent more than $5 million buying an additional three terminals to accommodate the incoming cruise ships. The US government can be a tough court for journalists. After all, the government doesn't always get it right. But it has gotten the government wrong in a case that has to sting: In July, the AP published "leaked" memos describing two secret programs, codenamed Stellar Wind and Trailblazer, that collected and stored the telephone metadata of almost every US citizen. Those programs, authorized under the PATRIOT Act, are the basis for a lawsuit filed in 2010 by the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU). It now appears, at least on the surface, to have been a classic legal flub. "It would be unfair, frankly, to characterize our complaint as some sort of government wrongdoing," the ACLU's director of media relations, Nathan Freed Wessler, said the other day. He told me he thought his organization "fought harder and did far more than our adversaries are going to get away with," and that he was not "convinced" that "all of what happened in the courtroom was a victory for the government." The AP had published the documents after seeking and receiving permission from the Office of the Director of National Intelligence to view the documents — which it did from inside the federal courthouse, outside a classified portion of the courthouse. Although "leaking" a grand jury document is a federal crime, the law does not seem to have been violated here (the government had to ask for the documents). The ACLU's complaint alleges, as a matter of law, that the documents published violated the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, and that they were provided to the AP on condition of anonymity. The government has not refuted those specific allegations. There is some dispute about whether they were classified. The government, in its response to the ACLU, says the documents were "not top secret" and not "authorized for release." But the ACLU insists that they are "classified/secrets" under both the Privacy Act and the Patriot Act, according to two of the officials I interviewed. (The document in question can be found at the bottom of page 14 of the PDF of the government's response.) Regardless of whether they were classified, the memos described programs that the government had not disclosed during the Bush administration, after having announced the programs in 2008. That fact matters, according to the ACLU. Although those agencies may have been operating under the auspices of the PATRIOT Act, it is the FISA Act that allowed the programs to go forward, in part because of legal changes approved by Congress after 9/11 that expanded the definition of the term "authorized by law to conduct electronic surveillance or physical searches" to include "electronic surveillance and physical searches of foreign powers or agents of foreign powers," which it did not include prior to 2008. So while the administration was legally permitted to secretly claim the authority to collect the metadata of millions of Americans, they had not disclosed that.

The government of India is considering a bill that would make the country's internet a 'state-controlled monopoly.' "We are also planning to take a series of steps to ensure that the net does not operate beyond the control of government and is run for the benefits of the people," Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Internet and Mobile Association president R. Ashish Chauhan told the BBC. He added that the bill is still being drafted; the details would be made available soon. India's proposal comes as concerns about the country's government's efforts to protect India's Internet infrastructure have grown in recent weeks. The country's telecom and media officials have already rejected proposals by several leading technology companies such as Facebook, Google, and Facebook rival Twitter – which wants to build an Indian equivalent of the Internet. That proposal was rejected by India's Information Technology ministry, which argued that it would compromise India's digital sovereignty. Related: Microsoft To Pay Nearly $170 Million To End Indian Data-Protection Law Suit India is reportedly one of eight countries with plans – in addition to the United States, Japan, and parts of Canada and Europe – to pass bills that would force companies to host their infrastructure within their own borders. A bill recently proposed in the German parliament would force companies to pay for their own network infrastructure. Chauhan also noted that it was "not possible to discuss this issue any further publicly."

The U.S.-led coalition has recently attacked in support of the Syrian government of President Bashar al-Assad. But on September 19, Reuters reported that "the Pentagon is preparing to provide its own weapons to opposition forces and train them on their use of air defense weapons, a senior Defense Department official said on Monday." The official was unable to say whether the U.S. would supply such weapons to "moderate opposition" forces — that is, groups that do not engage in violence. While the coalition has been reluctant to supply arms, it is not averse to providing training in the U.S.-funded program "The Green Berets," which will "enable Syrian rebel troops to protect themselves with anti-aircraft missiles to protect their positions." This is important because both the U.S.-led coalition and the Assad regime are now involved in combat. In this context, the recent announcement that Washington "is preparing to provide its own weapons to moderate opposition forces" is significant. For the Syrian government, the U.S. arms could be crucial if it were to continue its military campaign against the Islamic State. The Islamic State is believed to have a network of thousands of foreign fighters that it is using to launch terrorist attacks both in Syria and in Iraq. For these fighters, the presence of the Assad regime would not provide much comfort. But the Assad regime's continued existence would provide a degree of military cover that, if broken, would leave the Islamic State to carry on its attacks. While the Islamic State has not taken much territory in the past four months, it is still able to conduct large-scale terrorist attacks both in Syria and Iraq. In this context, the recent announcement that Washington "is preparing to provide its own weapons to moderate opposition forces" is significant. Not only would the weapons provide protection to the Islamic State, they would also provide cover to those fighting the Islamic State as well. Moreover, the Obama administration is likely to decide that the Islamic State does not pose a serious threat to the U.S. from the air. Yet, if the Assad regime falls, as the most likely outcome, then the "moderate" opposition in Syria would very likely fall as well. This would leave only U.S.-supported or -trained Sunni Syrian rebels as the regime's only military and fighting force. As the Syrian army will quickly be turned over to U.S.-backed proxies, the rebels would soon be outnumbered by those who have turned against them and turned to terrorism in the hopes of creating a more stable world. The Islamic State's success against the "moderates" will give that group access to weapons it lacks now. The Obama administration needs to know this if it is to be able to continue aiding the Syrian rebels. As President Obama has said, Washington will be assisting the moderate opposition "for as long as it takes," but "we want to do it with partners that are going to be successful." The Syria crisis is entering a critical stage following the Islamic State's seizure of large swaths of territory in Iraq and Syria and its recent attacks on Paris and Brussels. While most of these attacks have targeted the Shi'ite minority in both countries, al-Qaeda, which grew from the Islamic State's strongholds in Iraq, has already shown that it will attack non-Sunni groups, both Shi'ite and Sunni. While the U.S. and its allies continue bombing the Islamic State, it is imperative that they do so with caution.
