In the latest installment of the "I'm not mad anymore, and everything is alright" series, the Minnesota Vikings are one of the teams that had the franchise's worst run of seasons in 2012. It's now 2012 again. The Vikings may be 0-8, but you just have to smile to yourself right now. The Vikings' 2013 season is still almost a month away, and this time, the Vikings are all smiles. "I think we are all in a good place," Vikings coach Leslie Frazier wrote on The Players' Tribune. "We all see a lot of things that we can do better, but I also see a lot of things that we still have room to grow on." The NFL has gone wild, but there remain a few silver linings in this Vikings mess:

On a morning drive on Interstate 89 in northern Wisconsin, Michael Noll, 41, saw a tractor-trailer stop and a man in the backseat run from it. Noll, who was driving home from a conference in New Jersey with his wife and son, pulled over and called 911. He didn't know whether the driver made it out of the wreckage with her son. Noll never made it out of the wreckage. Instead, he died in a fatal crash in 2011 while driving with a suspended license. Authorities said the driver, 43-year-old John Gebhardt, was "completely sober" at the time of the crash and cited his failure to put on a seat belt as a major factor in the tragedy. On Tuesday, Gebhardt pleaded guilty to misdemeanor vehicular homicide, a misdemeanor, in Walker County Circuit Court. He will serve 45 days in the county jail. Gebhardt told the judge he was remorseful for his actions. "I don't regret driving fast," he said, according to the Journal Sentinel. "I don't regret what happened and I don't regret what I've been through." Assistant District Attorney David Smith, a prosecutor in Wisconsin, said Gebhardt's actions "were totally reckless because he knew he was driving drunk." Noll was driving 75 mph on a stretch of interstate known as U.S. 31-91 in Green Bay when he saw Gebhardt, who was pulling out of the road. Noll told investigators that he followed the tractor trailer, which hit a guardrail on the interstate just north of Green Bay. Smith said that Gebhardt failed to turn on his emergency lights, didn't put on the seat belt and drove off before Noll called 911. The crash occurred three to five minutes after Gebhardt saw the crash, according to the Journal Sentinel. Noll managed to pull the family of four out of the vehicle after his body ended up pinned underneath the mangled tractor trailer, the prosecutor said. The newspaper stated that Noll's wife was hospitalized for a week with back injuries. The son was treated in a local hospital for facial and head injuries. Gebhardt was sentenced in a plea deal to two years of partial suspension. He will be under the supervision of probation for three years. He will also have to do 120 hours of community service. Copyright 2016: Associated Press ---------------------------------------------------------------------- UPDATED Monday, June 15, 2015---1:50 p.m. MADISON, Wis. (AP) -- A Wisconsin man convicted of drunk driving after a fatal crash is facing more than three dozen charges, including multiple felonies. John Gebhardt, 43, of Green Bay, pleaded guilty Tuesday in a deal with prosecutors. He faces up to 21 years in prison when he's sentenced July 13 in a Walker County courtroom. The Associated Press learned of Gebhardt's plea while reviewing court records. Walker County Circuit Court records show that Gebhardt was scheduled to enter a plea Wednesday. Gebhardt was driving 75 mph in a 85-mph zone on northbound I-89 just north of Green Bay in February 2011. He failed to turn on his headlights and didn't use the seat belt. A Wisconsin State Patrol investigation later found that he also failed to stop using his turn signal. Authorities said Gebhardt, who didn't have a Wisconsin license, was "completely sober" when he fatally crashed his pickup, which was carrying his wife and two young sons. Copyright 2015: Associated Press -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- UPDATED Thursday, April 19, 2015---2:30 p.m. MADISON, Wis. (AP) -- A Wisconsin man known for playing a "mad scientist" on TV has been sentenced to more than 20 years behind bars for causing the fiery deaths of his family with the drunken driving of a truck. A judge Thursday sentenced John Gebhardt to 21 years in prison, more than nine years longer than prosecutors sought. Gebhardt's victims sat stone faced in a courtroom as Judge Patrick Wigenton sentenced Gebhardt with the words of a victim impact statement: "We have lost three family members that were like a large family to us." Assistant District Attorney David Smith told the judge Gebhardt "was driving without a license and a seat belt -- two factors you know he didn't know he would be facing" in the June 2010 crash. Prosecutors said Gebhardt had a blood-alcohol level more than twice the legal limit when the wreck occurred when he was driving a pickup truck carrying his wife and two sons around 11 p.m. in Green Bay. Gebhardt's children were ejected from their car and died. Their father's seat belt kept him from being thrown from the truck when it began to burn. Copyright 2015: Associated Press

A few nights ago, the first episode of the fourth season of The Office aired. It was a huge success. While a majority of the episode was dedicated to the characters' relationship with each other, one segment was dedicated to the company as a whole. It's not hard to see why. It all started with Pam. In Pam's first scene of the night, she sits in her office drinking coffee. There are only five or so people in the building. But wait. Before she gets up, she calls Jim, who has already left for work. Pam: "Hey Jim, is that [Jim's] car? I think he's driving down." Jim: "Yeah. She left earlier. Should I ask her if she's okay?" No! Why do that? Don't you know how to treat her friend like a real person? As the episode ended, Jim walked into Pam's office just as she was about to call him. We later find out that he was in there all along. The Office has always tried to portray the world of the office as a place where everyone is in on the joke and in on the joke together. At the end of each episode, the staff of Dunder Mifflin makes an appearance. But it's the character of Pam who embodies all of the aforementioned characteristics. That's because Pam is one of the few people in the office who understands Jim's humor. She's actually on a firstname basis with most of the other employees. Pam is a perfect example of what I believe to be what "characterization" is all about. We see everyone else in the office, but we only see a few people in Pam's world. We never actually get to see the full spectrum of Pam's personality. She's almost always seen as "smart", "gifted", and "entitled" in Jim and the office. But what we do experience is a few things: Pam's intelligence is what helps her make the jokes she makes, though even then sometimes we're seeing things that we would not necessarily think of when they are told on television. In real life, Pam would not always do things out of her character. In the episode when Jim asked for the company car, he asks for Pam's opinion because he knows that she doesn't know the difference between American and European cars. But Pam has done this kind of thing a million times before in the office. The other "character" traits she exhibits are her gift of gab and how she is always ready to offer someone else's opinion on anything. This is why she's the main character of the show. Pam's character makes no sense as presented in the show. That's why I call it "characterization". Now let's look at Jim. When the characters come together in "The New Monuments", the story goes on to detail Jim's first encounter with Jim Halpert. Jim: "Okay, Jim, how's the new monke… monu… thing going?" Jim's co-worker: "Um, not great. [Laughs] You need to get out more." If Jim had just asked Pam how things were, the show's portrayal of that interaction would have taken an unexpected and somewhat silly turn. Instead, we experience Jim's reaction, with its full consequences. Not only does Jim lose Pam's friendship, but now he's seen as selfish by her. At the end of the episode, you can see Pam's face in Jim's back pocket. What that says to us is that while Pam probably would have been happy talking to Jim about his life, Jim's reaction could have really damaged Pam's reputation for a while. Jim is our role model. We see Jim's reaction to Pam in his face, but we can also say as Pam's character develops in The Office, she has to show us what it's like before she can say anything in Jim's defense. It's the same for everyone else in the office. Our view of them is conditioned by what we've been told. And as a result, we are often blind to what other people think about us. People are not real. They're made up. There are other people's thoughts, and other people's opinions, all of which are just as valid as any we might think of ourselves. So when we think of the character of Pam, we need to remember that she would have said the same thing back then. She probably would have said the exact same thing again. And if she did say it again, wouldn't she have changed how she was thinking of his actions? I know I would have. Because she is my role model. I'd say that the character of Jim Halpert is also my role model. Jim is my role model because

The following information is provided by the National Security Agency in support of the Freedom of Information Act process. No claim is made that any information provided here or elsewhere is accurate, complete, or current. The Agency will make every effort to ensure that all of the information provided by the requester is provided promptly and within the time specified by this request. Information about the requester is only available for review and comment and will not be used other than as required in the performance of its duties. Information about whether or not certain requests have been granted, or a decision on the request has been made, may not be provided in an electronic format. FOIA The federal government is subject to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA). The FOIA permits the release of information to which the information subjects do not have a legitimate interest in the information. The Freedom of Information Act was passed in 1966 by Congress. It is administered by the Office of the Information Commissioner, a division of the U.S. Department of the Treasury. FOIA is a civil rights statute and is meant to protect personal privacy and to foster open government. It is not intended to protect information that is subject to executive privilege or other privileged information. Any person requesting information or documents on records or other materials under the FOIA must submit a written request addressed to the "FOIA Officer" at the National Security Agency (NSA) or the Security and Counterintelligence Division in the office of the General Counsel of the National Security Agency (NSA), the FOIA Office at the National Archives and Records Administration, in Maryland, or to any other agency or person designated by the Office of the Information Commissioner. The request must contain the following information: 1. What records are sought? A request or request letter for the information must describe: • The records sought • The circumstances surrounding the request • The purpose for seeking the records • Whether any exemptions apply under FISA, Title 5, or Executive Order 12333. A FOIA request may also include written questions regarding the record or documents sought or whether any exemption applies. 2. How to file a FOIA request for records about the National Security Agency An individual must make a FOIA request based on an agency determination or an exemption in the Freedom of Information Act. A FOIA determination refers to any determination made by an agency that the information or records sought have a clearly defined exemption(s) or information is not subject to disclosure. Each request for information, or request on a record or other materials, must specify the requestor's legal title, rank, and occupation in some way; the requester's position or duties as specified by the agency (e.g., "CIA"); or the individual's assigned agency or position (e.g., "CIA, CIA Deputy Director for Operations"). The FOIA also provides a mechanism for the submission of legal and FOIA-compliant factual allegations to the NSA (including to the Office of General Counsel of NSA), and a mechanism for filing a legal brief (Form 12b-5). Information regarding the procedure for filing a legal brief with NSA is included in the FOIA Regulations section of this Web site. 3. What happens next? Once a FOIA request has been submitted, the information subject or FOIA recipient will be provided with notice. The FOIA officer may then either complete the request or will notify the requester of the status of the request and will also request written comments from individuals and groups of individuals who have views or objections to the document, agency or agency position, or to the request under consideration. Information may be withheld if it would harm classified or sensitive national security information, would reveal the identities of confidential human sources, or would reveal any other exception that limits the use of the information or records sought. Examples of information withheld under these criteria include, but are not limited to, information related to specific individuals or programs, specific locations of the Agency, or information deemed to contain trade secrets or commercial secrets 4. How information can be provided Although the requester should be as specific as possible when describing the requested information or records, and must indicate the information or records sought and any exceptions that apply, the Agency cannot always respond to your request without knowing the subject of the request. If this is the case, an Agency liaison must contact you in accordance with Agency procedures. A requester who does not wish to participate in that interaction should submit a statement to the Agency requesting confidentiality, and you should provide the Agency the necessary information to support your request. All Agency records are open to public inspection and copying in accordance with the Freedom of Information Act. 5. How can you appeal a denial of a FOIA request? An unsuccessful FOIA request can be appealed in accordance with the guidelines described in the Agency's Subpart F appeal and review procedure. An appeal should be submitted in writing within 30 days of the date that the FOIA officer denied the request. 6. What types of information does the Agency hold? The

PESHAWAR: The militants of the banned Lashkar-e-Islam have launched a major attack on a police office in Peshawar.A suicide bomber detonated his explosives near the office of the police's counterterrorism wing in Shah Shahid area of Peshawar on Tuesday morning."Around 35 people [were killed], including three police officials. Police was on alert due to recent attacks in the city," Major Muhammad Khakhar, spokesman for the police, told Dawn on Wednesday. The officials were killed in the blast, Khakhar said.The militants of the Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) had also launched several attacks on police officials in other areas as well.Last Friday, a major explosion hit the office of an interior ministry of Punjab province's counter-terrorism department in the Khyber tribal region of Pakistan, killing at least three people and leaving at least four others injured.The attack was claimed by the Jamaat-ul-Ahrar faction of al-Qaida, which is fighting the Pakistani government in a campaign of violence against the military-backed government, judicial system and minority Shias in Pakistan.

HONORABLE MENTION Best New Series: "American Crime" What a season it's been for FX and "American Crime." The crime drama has been one of the most talked about new shows this fall, thanks in large part to its star power. "American Crime" is one of those shows that has captivated fans in a way that few other shows do. "American Crime" is based on the true story of the murder of 18-year-old Elizabeth Smart, who was kidnapped and held captive by a man she had met on a dating app. While many critics have deemed the show's depiction of the Smart family "unreal," the best part about the show isn't the characters or the storyline, it's the stellar cast. In just one of her many appearances on the series, Jennifer Lopez sang the title song from the show. Her amazing rendition of the track (and in her own words, she does some very impressive singing) was so popular that the singer received a standing ovation from the people in the audience. Not only did actress/singing sensation Lopez help raise money for the show, she also helped the show raise awareness from the community and the media. And Lopez wasn't the only star who contributed to the show's incredible success. RELATED: "American Crime" Showrunner Explains Season 1 Finale 'America's Got Talent' Star Casts 'American Crime' Voiceover Watch: Jennifer Lopez Performing 'American Crime' Song The show brought in plenty of fan support as well: "American Crime" has been nominated for multiple awards, including a Creative Arts Emmy, a SAG Award, a Drama Desk Award, and several SAG Award noms. In its first season, the show has been nominated for the Writers Guild of America Award and won two Emmy Awards and a Golden Globe Award. "American Crime" may take a hit in the ratings, but it is one of the best shows on TV. It's an emotional thriller that will keep you on the edge of your seat, and its cast (including Lopez. who has also earned two Emmy nominations, one of them for the series' performance) has done a bang up job of keeping everyone engaged.

A large number of people have been detained in the northern Sinai Peninsula following the arrest of 12 suspected Al-Qaeda members in a joint operation by the Egyptian Security Forces (EGF) and Egyptian Border Police. "The Egyptians have arrested 12 suspects accused of belonging to the so-called Islamic State (IS) movement in the Sinai peninsula, including one Brit and two Americans. They were arrested and transferred to the headquarters of EGF in Al-Arish," a statement by EGF revealed on Tuesday. The statement also stated that the 13 suspects accused of belonging to Al-Qaeda "were detained in collaboration with the General Intelligence's Counter-terrorism unit," and added that they were taken into custody on Sunday afternoon after an information-sharing agreement between the EGF and Egyptian intelligence agencies. On Monday, the EGF issued a statement announcing that the two American men, including an employee of the Defense Intelligence Agency (DIA), were detained along with the four other Americans from the UK and two Australians on Sunday. The group of Americans was also identified as: Ahmed Mohamed Abdullah, 29, of Colorado, Patrick Harrold, 35, of California, Khaled Abu Thurayeh, 29, a Jordanian national from Jeddah and Mohamed Ahmed Awwad, 23, an Egyptian citizen residing in Houston, Texas. EgyNews.sy also reported that the British man, Ahmed Mohamed, was one of the "British nationals" detained in addition to the four men. Meanwhile, El Watan newspaper reported in its Monday edition that the U.S. government is aware of the Egyptian government's efforts to capture members of the Islamic State (IS) militants that have been apprehended. The Egyptian counter-terrorism forces arrested 13 people suspected of belonging to the group Islamic State in Sinai (IS) when they raided their dens on Saturday night, on the outskirts of Sheikh Zuweid in Rafah town on the North of the North Sinai Peninsula. According to the newspaper, the arrests were made at the site of the operation carried out by Egyptian security forces from army engineers to apprehend the terrorists and rescue the people held hostage. The terrorist suspects were arrested while digging around the perimeter of the dens after a special military task force was sent down from the Karmel governorate to carry out the operation. Meanwhile, the British men, Ahmed Mohamed, Patrick Harrold, Khaled Abu Thurayeh and Mohamed Awwad, are alleged to have confessed to have been active in the extremist terrorist group in Sinai over several months by using internet conversations and videos. The newspaper further claimed that the captured terrorist suspects are linked to several Al-Qaeda affiliates and are planning to launch an attack in Sinai, targeting tourist resorts, including the one in Sharm el-Sheikh, the EgyNews.sy reported.

KIEV (Reuters) - A Ukrainian court on Monday threw out the appeal by Ukrainian opposition leader Yulia Tymoshenko against her six-year jail term for abuse of power in a case brought by former President Viktor Yanukovich. Tymoshenko, 61, who now lives in Switzerland, asked the court to find that prosecutors had not presented enough evidence to convict her of the original charge, in which she was convicted on more than 40 counts, including abuse of power and fraud. But she also appealed for the acquittal of an additional 15 counts of abuse of power - mainly related to her 2007 decision against a gas discount scheme when she was energy minister. Those counts would still be in force. Tymoshenko's lawyer said prosecutors still had not provided any evidence proving the charges. The case, brought before a Ukraine appeals court in February this year, has attracted international attention, with diplomats and lawyers from Western powers arguing against her long term in jail. Tymoshenko has become a symbol of anti-government protests led by jailed Yanukovich loyalists in the fall of the country's pro-Russian president in February 2014. She has denied any wrongdoing. Oleksandr Turchynov, the new acting prime minister, said on Monday the court in Kiev did not find "any grounds" for Tymoshenko's appeal. "I consider her the queen of corruption and a criminal in the making," he told reporters in Kiev. A verdict will be announced later this year, he added. Slideshow (5 Images)

The government has taken some major steps to bring India's poor out of abject poverty. The country has succeeded in eliminating absolute poverty as a percentage of the population from 40.3 per cent as per the last count in 1996 to 13.1 per cent in 2015, according to the poverty line released by the National Sample Survey Office (NSSO) in January. India has become one of the fastest moving countries in the world when it comes to reducing absolute poverty. During the period between 1990 and 2014-15, its decline stood at 19.4 per cent and its share of the total world poverty reduction reached 2.8 percentage points. India's impressive success is partly because of a combination of economic reforms implemented over the last three decades, high tax collection in the state-run sectors and reforms in the policies of the central government. But if we look at the details, we can also find a reason for the India's economic growth. At the macro level, as I have already analysed in a detailed paper, economic growth is most likely to have resulted from the adoption of the policies of growth and liberalisation advocated by the government, rather than on the basis of the free fall in prices on account of excessive monetisation undertaken for the past two decades. The policy reforms implemented by the Indian government, including the financial liberalisation, the introduction of the Goods and Services Tax and the opening of the coal, petroleum and natural gas sectors to private players, reduced poverty in India from 49.1 per cent in 1991-92 to a much more reasonable 25.4 per cent in 2010. The liberalisation of the economy led to an enormous growth in manufacturing and an equally rapid growth in services. It is estimated that between 1990 and 2008, India's total factor productivity went up by a factor of 15. The number of jobs in manufacturing did not change from 576 million to 592 million, while 1.86 million jobs were added to those in manufacturing. The number of jobs in services, by contrast, increased from 706.1 million in 1990 to over 800 million in 2008. The Indian economy has achieved a high rate of productivity growth due to its high share of skilled workers in the workforce, as measured by the share of the skilled workforce in the overall labour force. This, in turn, has led to greater labour force participation, a larger proportion of workers in the non-agricultural sector and a higher share of low-skilled workers in the workforce. To a certain extent, labour market deregulation was the product of efforts by Rajiv Gandhi to attract foreign direct investment. But the policy of the government was ultimately a response to the labour demand that had grown as a result of the reforms. As a result, this growth in the labour force led to an increase in labour productivity, which in turn leads to an increase in labour force participation as well as higher growth. The labour demand that fuelled growth also fuelled the creation of new jobs in different sectors, particularly in manufacturing, services and construction. The impact of India's reforms on growth is also apparent in the labour productivity growth. As has been shown by a number of studies, these reforms were accompanied by a productivity growth of between 15 and 20 per cent, and the growth rates of both the total factor productivity and labour productivity increased significantly. As the labour growth became more inclusive, the growth in labour productivity and hence total factor productivity also became more inclusive. Overall, the policy reforms implemented by the Indian government during the last three decades and especially the financial sector reforms have played a huge role in transforming India into an economically advanced economy. And the economic growth has been largely due to the policy reforms initiated by Rajiv Gandhi. The question then is not of who benefited the most from growth; the question is how much the Indian economy has benefited from both the policies of growth and reforms, and to what extent did these reforms promote growth. There have been several studies on the impacts of the reforms in the agricultural sector, specifically on agricultural income share. It is evident that the reforms facilitated the conversion of agriculture into an agro-economy. Over the last four decades, the share of agriculture in the total value of India's GDP grew from 6.1 per cent in 1970-71 to about 29.5 per cent in 2005-06. In 2013-14, about 51 per cent of the total value of rural labour force was engaged in agriculture and this constituted almost 35 per cent of rural people's gross income. The impact of agricultural reforms In 2012-14, the average rural wage in India was about Rs 3,000 per month with a weekly earnings of about Rs 20,000 per day. The government estimated that in 2014-15, agricultural incomes amounted to almost a third of the total agriculture and forest income. In fact, most of the income from farmers comes from the sale of cereals. If the farmers had to sell this income to the market, they would be able to earn much less. On his part, Prime

The Department of Justice is investigating the Trump campaign's ties to Russia, and one of the topics being probed is payments that Russia made to a lawyer for a former Trump campaign foreign policy adviser named Carter Page. Fox News is reporting that the Justice Department is exploring the legality of the money. Page was also one of a few Trump advisers who spoke with Ambassador Sergey Kislyak during the 2016 presidential campaign. Read more

There are many factors to consider and many factors which need to be taken into account when choosing a car to lease or own, including: Mileage cost Monthly fees Fuel Economy: MPG versus Fuel Efficiency Payment method options and APR (Annual Percentage Rate) Interest rates and monthly payments What is a Lease? Leases come in two main forms: one-year and six-month renewals or leases. One-Year Leases A one-year lease has two phases - the early commitment phase which occurs when there isn't enough funds in the account to pay the entire balance when you take the car out for the first time and the final payment phase which takes place when you have all required funds in your account. Lease Duration : 5 years, 24 months @ $18.95 per month : 5 years, 24 months @ $18.95 per month Monthly Fees: $7 per month Lease payments are due upon signing the lease agreement. Lease Rate : 16.5% APR : 16.5% APR Payment Type: 14.75% variable or 25% pre-set monthly payment One Year Auto Leases One-year auto leases are also offered through multiple automotive finance companies. Typically, leases for vehicles between 18-34-months in length have a four-year term. Leasing cars for a few years is a good way to reduce the potential impact of depreciation and pay off your car sooner. Lease Duration : 4 years, 24 months @ $18.95 per month : 4 years, 24 months @ $18.95 per month Monthly Fees: $7 per month Lease payments are due upon signing the lease agreement. Lease Rate : 16.5% APR : 16.5% APR Payment Type: 14.75% variable or 25% pre-set monthly payment There are some exceptions to the one-year term lease rule - for example, in a situation where there's a large down payment or a substantial purchase price drop, you may have a lease that extends your time to own your car by up to 60 months. Lease Duration : 6 years, 24 months @ $18.95 per month : 6 years, 24 months @ $18.95 per month Monthly Fees: $10 per month Lease payments are due upon signing the lease agreement. Lease Rate : 30% APR : 30% APR Payment Type: 30% variable pre-set monthly payment Leasing is a great way for you to drive on long trips, or to do other errands and make car payments to the point where your car is truly in use while you're away. Six-Month Leases Leases for vehicles between 32-44-months in length have a five-year term. Leasing is a great place to rent when your car is older or for a long time, or to move, or to sell your car. Lease Duration : 5 years, 30 months @ $11.95 per month : 5 years, 30 months @ $11.95 per month Monthly Fees: $5.95 per month Lease payments are due upon signing the lease agreement. Lease Rate : 19% APR : 19% APR Payment Type: Fixed 10 months @ $27 per month Leasing can be more than one way to pay off your car. For example, you may choose to get out and sell your car to a customer with an agreement that includes a leasing amount, and the remaining balance of financing would be paid once you're moved or sold. Lease Duration : 5 years, 30 months @ $18.95 per month : 5 years, 30 months @ $18.95 per month Monthly Fees: $7 per month Lease payments are due upon signing the lease agreement. Lease Rate : 19% APR : 19% APR Payment Type: Fixed 10 months @ $27 per month There are also situations where you may be able to pay less up front for your car - such as when you know the exact price you'll be paying at sale. Lease Duration : 5 years, 30 months @ $18.95 per month : 5 years, 30 months @ $18.95 per month Monthly Fees: $7 per month Lease or Lease & Lease & Purchase If you're a student that does well in school, you might be able to work a lease arrangement with your school, and work out the final payment to ensure you pay off the full amount without having to purchase your car. Your school would usually be your lender, and you wouldn't have to put a lien against your car. Lease Duration : 6 years, 30 months @

A new campaign from the British Humanist Association is attempting to get a public debate around the issue, with a website offering advice on how people can get involved. The campaign will involve several online campaigns over the next month - such as 'Make Britain A Better Place For Atheists and The Non-Religious', which will target government and media with a call for action. The campaign's lead organiser, Andrew Copson, said: "We are now facing the first election in a generation where politics is being dominated by the Christian right and it is clear that public debate is very much a matter of when, not if. "This is why we need to fight for a secular country that is open for ideas from all sides and an inclusive one that works for everyone." The website includes links to online forums, such as atheist Facebook group Atheists of Britain (which has nearly 4,000 members), which can be used to join, promote, and help organise campaigns around the campaign. For more information visit www.bhaofficial.org

If you're not satisfied with your work from day one, it's pretty hard to get motivated to do more – even if you already know how awesome you are. I've written before about why motivation is hard to replicate and how to build habits that stick (that you actually want to follow). But, I'll go further. Why Motivation is Hard to Build I learned this the hard way when I tried too hard to get motivated, rather than just being inspired. If you're feeling motivated, but you're really only inspired, you're going to fall short. This isn't necessarily wrong, or even especially rare in the first place, as I've worked with plenty of people who haven't always had the "motivation" part (although many have felt great about their work). This is how I learned to build habits – building in small daily wins that make you feel great right now rather than thinking about getting there later or getting someone else there. I've written before about how my habits (that can be pretty challenging, although I learned them by experience) have gotten much easier in part to that principle. The reason this "getting started" principle is important is because as you start to do more you need to know why you're motivated. You need to know what you love about working on the project. You need to know why you do it. And the best way to find that out is to get started. If you can build momentum, you don't even need to worry about motivation. You can be motivated with your work on the initial day. Just make sure you're motivated to do that initial day's work. Otherwise, it might come the next day and you'll regret your decision to get started then. If you'd like to see an example of how to start a habit and get started with minimal to no motivation – check out this article on setting up your first project. Why Motivation is Hard to Get Back If you're feeling motivated to do more, then it might come back or you'll try to do it more regularly. Even if you do it again, motivation won't necessarily be there at that point, so you'll do that again. This is why it's so crucial to have a consistent approach. Don't let yourself get into a rhythm where you start getting excited every time you do something. That doesn't work for long-term habits. If you need to be motivated to work on a project, schedule one thing every day (or even every hour) in a way that you're not motivated in that task, then you're likely just setting yourself up to fall into the trap of just doing the task every day. When setting up each task, I recommend making it about getting that one thing done so it's not about doing a task every day and not feeling motivated about it and not feeling motivated doing it. Focus on getting only the right thing done – the goal. How to Work on Habits When You're Not Motivated I often tell people that once you figure out what your main interests are, you can make a habit of following those. You should have a specific routine for your projects that you can do whenever you want to (without any pressure to actually follow through). Most people can't do a routine like this because many things we care about are too complex and can't fit into a routine that doesn't involve some kind of action. These are the kinds of things we can do to build habits that stick so you can make progress that doesn't feel impossible. These are the kinds of things I'd recommend you do. Focus on Getting Your First Thing Done Every Day The first step you need to develop habits and build confidence is to focus on getting your first work done every day (and on doing so consistently). This is a process I describe in my book, The Productivity Project. To do that, you need to follow a process that makes sense for you. This starts by defining your "big picture" goals (the things you want out of life), and then going about taking one action every day to get that first work done on those goals. For example, here are some examples to get you started: Identify your big picture goals (such as "build a better relationship with a friend I like" or "start doing more travel again"); Set a schedule on how often you'll do that action every day (instructions on how to follow these will come later); Set a small reward for yourself so you do it every day, such as a small accomplishment (such as checking your email for the first time in a while) to help you continue following through  There's a lot of potential here and lots of variations. What works for you is a matter of what makes sense for your own routine and what motivates you. Once

[Editorial Note: A recent poll showed that many Americans favor keeping current immigration policy. In order to better define the debate, I have created a special "Immigration Proclamations" page. These, and the immigration discussion more generally, have become an indispensible tool for students of history, immigration, and US policy. To add, comment, or ask questions, just scroll down and click that link!] The United States' current immigration system is complex. It is also confusing. And it is often forgotten that the issue of immigration is complicated. For example: It is hard for Americans to understand why it takes so long to get a green card. But when you consider that there is actually one "green card" per person, this can be understood in a simple way. Each person gets two green cards. Since the number of green cards per person is a matter of luck and not choice or need, if, say, only one person is ready to immigrate to the United States at a given time, we can state that this person can receive two green cards. But that means that someone can get an extra green card on top of his current one (or another person's) by "waiting", or by "working". What does that mean? And what did it mean when the "waiting period" ended in 1996? What is a "Waiting Period"? You can imagine it like this. Each person gets a waiting period. For example, let's suppose that no one ever gets an extra green card. The waiting period ends in 1996. Then someone can get an "extra" green card. (That would be a "green card" per person.) But there are three caveats to this simple explanation. First, the "waiting period" is just a theoretical period of four years. It is sometimes described as eight years after an immigrant gets his initial green card. Second, the waiting period can end earlier. The waiting period ended on September 12, 1999, when the US enacted a law to allow some illegal immigrants to obtain green cards by waiting. The third caveat is that in some cases, the waiting period did end earlier. In 1999, the legal immigration status of two categories — H-1B and L-1B — were changed to allow additional immigrants to stay in the United States while waiting. Some of those immigrants, called special immigrants, are now on waiting lists. And since the time of this writing, that list is about 100,000 people long. In addition, the process of the "green card lottery" is still under way — people apply for green cards at a rate of more than 200,000 per year. If you assume that each of those special immigrants was waiting for his green card to be issued in 1996, and that, of course, he did eventually receive one (assuming everyone else was waiting), his waiting period is now about a year — or a bit less if he is a first-time citizen. Why would a person "stay" a year or more in an illegal immigrant waiting list, if there is simply one waiting period? The answer can be found in a bit of history. Before the "green card lottery" When the country was first conceived, the idea of a nation-state was not the same as it is now. To begin with, there were multiple ethnic groups in the US. So there probably was an ethnic diversity that people could feel comfortable in. Thus there were ethnic groups within each ethnic group. This was an important reason for the decision that people "had the opportunity" to immigrate. They couldn't be kicked out for having an ethnic difference. Furthermore, the immigration policy of the country at that time was based on an idea that there were only a few groups who had a right to immigrate. For example, as early as 1596, King Charles I was worried about a new "native-born aristocracy" emerging in the country. In his opinion, the country wanted a diverse population, so it set laws to allow anyone to settle and live anywhere in England. But over time, these laws became outmoded or simply ignored. Most immigrants ended up settling in places where they could easily assimilate, such as Scotland, Wales, and the US colonies (such as Virginia). Thus when the country started to develop a national identity, the rules changed. In 1789, when America became a nation, it became possible for all immigrants, except those from the British West India islands, to come to the US. However, as it became clear that some foreigners could not become US citizens, they became illegal visitors. So, as we can see, before 1896 (some estimates have the change at 1691), there were people who "had the opportunity" to get a green card. But before 1896 (again, estimated at 1591), there were people who did not have the opportunity to get a

In a very large study published back in 2006 (in the Journal of Psychopharmacology), scientists found that the more recreational drugs users used, the more likely it was that they would get into serious trouble with the law. The researchers were actually surprised, as this was not something they had expected to find. However, what they found was quite startling: the more people used an illegal drug, the higher their chances of getting into jail. This could explain why in a world where cannabis is legal, the government has a higher percentage of cannabis consumers jailed or given jail sentences than in a world where marijuana and cannabis are still illegal, or in a world where marijuana is only available to anyone over 18 years of age. How did they determine the legal status of the drugs? They used an "experimental design", a method for validating the results of a study by a third party; they got people to answer questions about the legality of a drug and then tested their answers; if they got the question right (i.e., had answers that were correct when their actual answer was true), then they were given an experimenter's code that would then be shared publicly. Here are the top seven most legal and illegal drugs in the US: Heroin has been legal (and available) for use for many years, so the vast majority of people who use it do not get sent to jail. That said, it is certainly worth mentioning that the majority of heroin users are not using it recreationally, instead, they are simply using other more violent drugs like cocaine, PCP or crystal meth. DMT is legal, although you can be arrested for possession of the stuff. The main reason it is legal here is that the psychedelic experience is very intense. Some DMT users get hooked on this experience. While the majority of people find it more interesting than being in prison, it is still illegal to possess DMT or any other psychedelics in the US. I would imagine that most cocaine users will not find themselves going to prison either. Even in South America, which makes coca leaf cocaine a national drug, cocaine (as is usually sold) is legal, it is just not packaged in any particular way so to help get customers to buy it. A study published last month found that the use of LSD by college students is at an all time high, making it one of the most commonly used illicit drugs. The effects of marijuana are often used as a drug to create the illusion of being "high". That said, even if cannabis is considered "high", most people will be unaware that they are under the influence unless they start having extreme hallucinations. Methamphetamines, cocaine and methamphetamine are legal in the US, but are still highly addictive. A study from 2010 found in the U.S. that the number of young people who have abused prescription drugs like Vicodin, Xanax and Percocet has reached a four-year high. MDMA is a drug that is still classified as a Class A Controlled Substance, but it is an incredibly powerful stimulant. Because its actions are extremely similar to those of MDMA, users who abuse MDMA are sometimes considered to be "psychedelic". It is illegal in the U.S. DMT is still illegal, but it is still a drug that people use to trigger their "trance" trip. As a result, "trip" is frequently used as a synonym for "psychedelic," and DMT is sold in many places where illegal substances are sold -- places like head shops and headshops. If you think that MDMA is more common, you can check out a previous article (where I compared the effects of MDMA to those of LSD). Methamphetamine is an illegal drug sold as a dietary supplement and in various forms at the gas station. The most common form of meth is crystal methamphetamine which is more popular than "powder" meth. Although marijuana is not currently legal in the United States, you can buy weed in the US, it is just very hard to get. Cannabis is still illegal in nearly all states (it does not have much of a history of being legalized or decriminalized), but a number of states allow medicinal use of the plant: The most famous example are states like Arizona, California and Massachusetts which have decriminalized the possession of cannabis. Many of the things done with marijuana are done recreationally, and may become more serious in the future. Pot is certainly a drug; it could be classified under the umbrella of hard drugs like cocaine and heroin, but like most things, it is more complex than it first appears. Do you have a favourite drug? Are you a "user"? How many illegal drugs do you use? Would you use any of them in a "credible" setting with a "legitimate" therapist? Share this Article

Buddhist monks from India and Nepal hold their own funerals on the grounds of the Nalanda University in the Indian state of Bihar, India, in this May 31, 2017 file photo. REUTERS/Narendra Shrestha/Files By Rajesh Kumar Singh and Rishika Deva NEW DELHI (Reuters) - An unimpressed Indian court threw out a lawsuit on Wednesday filed by a man who claimed in 2014 he was kidnapped and held for three days in a dungeon-like building on a Buddhist monastery near the capital. The ruling is the latest in a series of legal defeats for a group of Indian monks that have been targeted by an ultra-nationalist Hindu group, which argues the monks have exploited their status to make money from people seeking spiritual enlightenment and chanting mantras. The lawsuit, filed in a western Indian city last year, said the Nalanda University in Bihar state, where the monks were based since the 1950s, was a "harsh prison in which religious liberty and moral dignity are violated." It alleges that two men with guns and chains kidnapped the man at gunpoint in September 2014 in protest at his refusal to repeat a mantra. They held him in a 10-meter long cell for several days in the Nalanda Teaching Hospital. Nalanda University, which is near the capital, was established by the Indian government on a mission to transform Buddhist beliefs to modern thinking, promoting scientific enquiry and fostering interfaith understanding. A judge dismissed the lawsuit, telling the court the men were not kidnappers and the monastery had no dungeon and was not a prison. "The plaintiff has not proved his allegations. It is also a clear case of extortions and extortion ... The plaintiff cannot prevail in his case," the court said. It ordered the case transferred to another district court for trial. The case will have to be heard again in about two months, when it will be heard on whether the Nalanda University is a museum or a research institution with a curriculum. (For a graphic on Indian monk prisons click tmsnrt.rs/2c4xVgT) Many Buddhist monasteries in India lack the modern facilities needed to treat patients or conduct research. The Nalanda University has no building, only a small part of a building used as a hospital in the capital Kolkata. In May 2016, an Indian court dismissed an anti-monk group's lawsuit which sought to stop a famous Nalanda monk from carrying out his work studying Buddhism in the northeast Indian state of Tripura.  (Reporting by Rajesh Kumar Singh; Editing by Jeremy Laurence)

Cats can be quite stubborn with their meals and are much more likely to resist food given to them than dogs. Here is a collection of some of the most interesting and unusual ways cats eat their food and how much it is likely to be in a typical daily meal. If you think the amount of protein might be too much your cat might just go for a small piece of dry dog, chicken or turkey with the bones and fat, you can have that for free to your cat, but just don't forget to feed them the whole food. In general, cats can eat much more than most people think and will happily take their portions just a little larger and with more vegetables. Cats will also take any food that looks like a bone as a bone if they don't eat it they simply toss it into a bin of food somewhere. A more unusual way cats eat is with a spoon. It is very common for them to eat their food with a spoon and you can try and encourage them to eat it like human children too by giving them a bowl of water. Try giving them a piece of water or a small piece of fruit. Cats will often eat by hand too and most people won't notice because of their large size and strong fingers. Foods that Cats Are Tasted After Eating Cats have a unique way of judging the quality of food they have enjoyed and will eat what they have not enjoyed as much. This is why you should try and be careful when cooking for your cat and only give a very small amount of food. Cats will not take a lot of food and you can feed them too much too fast and may just ruin something delicious for your cat. Catching the cat is a great way to catch them as a reward if they eat just a little. Cats are able to tell the difference between quality protein foods and cheap, poor quality food (a big difference between a chicken breast and a tuna fish at the supermarket for example), if they eat too much of the cheap, poor quality food they'll probably get sick and then you won't get food to feed them. Cats can also tell between quality meat and cheap meat, you can buy really cheap meat but you can also buy good quality meat in small cuts as they usually have a higher fat content. If you find the cat eating any of these food types, stop feeding them and try and get the cat to eat quality food. It can be a tough job to feed a cat good quality food because he doesn't have a lot of taste buds and if you can't get enough food for the cat's needs it can create a lot of frustration and can even result in them vomiting. Cats are much more likely to take the food they don't like and when this happens be patient and continue to feed them the quality food until it's gone. There is a risk cats can become so hungry that they eat their entire meal from the floor and if it's not a tasty meal to them there's a good chance they could die. If you want to do your best for the health and well-being of your cat and if this is to be achieved without killing the cat, you'll want to help them in the eating process by providing them with fresh, well balanced, high-energy meals and treats for them twice a day in order to provide a variety of nutrients which help them grow healthy and strong. Some cats will eat the food you give them without trying it but it is not normal, and they don't like to be told they're wrong and you can help them learn the difference by feeding them from time to time and showing them the variety that good quality food provides. It's also possible your cat can suffer from nutritional inadequacies and not eat the food they are supposed to. There are foods that are unsuitable for your cat if they are not kept under a correct diet, if your cat won't eat the food you have put in their bowl or if they have eaten it and suddenly become unwell. So remember, you can't feed the food you have made as they aren't able to digest the food, it would be extremely difficult and time-consuming making up these meals and then trying to feed them to your cat, just try not to mix too much and feed your cat a mixture of good quality meat and very thin cuts of healthy meat as this is a more healthy way to feed cats.
