The world of mobile gaming is full of surprises, and the latest comes in the form of Microsoft's latest hardware. The Windows 10 Mobile version of Xbox One, revealed today, has been in the works for a while, and it's a significant improvement over the existing Xbox One S. "We've taken the same basic principles [of its Windows 10 counterpart], but added in a couple of key innovations," Xbox head Phil Spencer told PCWorld in an interview. "One of them, the Kinect, really takes a lot of the power from the console to create content and really personalize what you're playing. We've also brought in a new processor, which is a much faster system. [ See Also: Xbox One X Review: The Most Important Windows 10 Update of Our Lives | GameSpot's Xbox One X Review | Xbox One vs. PlayStation 4: The Best Graphics Game on Windows] "We did all of that to enable us, again, to really focus on creating a great experience in mobile." With a processor that's three times faster than the Xbox One S's, Microsoft's mobile strategy looks strong. The new Xbox, which debuted at E3 this year, was built to run "beyond Xbox." This hardware includes both the Windows 10 operating system as well as DirectX 12, Microsoft's upcoming, game-development-ready graphics API. With more power comes more processing speed. Windows 10 Mobile, for the first time, will enable a 4K game for Xbox One, using the same Xbox One X rendering software. Spencer called this "the first time we've come close to 4K on an Xbox." Spencer also compared the Xbox to the Xbox One S, which has a 4K display, and said Microsoft's new console is "overkill" compared to the standard console for gaming. "This is the first time we've come close to 4K on an Xbox!" Spencer said. "Because when you're using the standard Xbox One, that's not a good experience. It's not fast enough; it doesn't have 4K support. And that's why when you look in the games catalog, there are only a few titles in 4K now. The majority of the games in the catalog are upscaled, 1080p [high-definition]." Spencer also emphasized that the Xbox One S is designed as a low-end device, aimed at enthusiasts. "The console is the lowest priced product we've ever released," he said. "So, we had to work hard to make sure that you can purchase a good 4K display, a very good gaming console at $249 or less, and still have a good experience." Microsoft has a new Xbox One X next month, which features a 6.2-inch, 2,000-dot LCD screen and a GPU that can hit 1.86 teraflops. The console will launch with a software version of Fallout 4 and will be announced during an E3 press event later this month. While Microsoft is focused on creating a solid mobile console, it doesn't appear that the Xbox division is slowing down. Spencer called it "the biggest gaming business" in the world, and said Microsoft will continue developing games for all types of devices and all price points. "There is no such thing as too much technology," he said. "When we design new hardware, what we try to do is take the best attributes of the things we've done in the past and take those forward." Microsoft is already working on its first Windows 10 games for mobile devices. Microsoft Game Studios senior vice president Yusuf Mehdi said the company is working on "some pretty cool exclusive" mobile-focused titles later this year. He wouldn't name many titles, but said they would "explore unique and new ways the company makes games." Microsoft is no stranger to mobile, either. The company was one of the original early adopters of smartphones and tablets. Its first mobile device, the Nokia N8, launched in June 2010 as an upgrade of its Windows Phone platform. But the Nokia N8 didn't sell well, and Microsoft's smartphone ambitions never really took off. Instead, Microsoft began focused on its new Windows 10 operating system. More recently, the company has become more focused on mobile. The company announced a number of Windows 10 mobile announcements at the beginning of this year. This story has been updated.

In the world of finance, everyone looks for the shortcut to the promised land. I'm not here to tell you you have to follow a certain playbook to become a millionaire. You have a vast array of possibilities, and the road to riches is paved with great discoveries and hard work. But I do think some strategies might serve some folks better. In today's article we're going to share five strategy I prefer to keep in mind while pursuing a goal. For example, I prefer to focus my energy on building my personal brand because it's been proven to have a positive impact on how successful I am in every field of my career. In other words, if I want to be a millionaire, I should be building a personal brand that makes me stand out from the rest. The 5 Strategies 1. Focus on the Right Thing at the Right Time The first step to becoming a millionaire is making some smart moves when you need someone else to help you. The other part of this equation is timing. Make sure that when you make your best bets to achieve your goals, you're not setting yourself up for failure. By investing in those little things that are crucial to your personal development, you have all the advantages you need. For example, when I think about the most important skill to learn for success in my career, I realize that I need to build social intelligence. Once you understand that the most lucrative job opportunities are going to come from people with the right personality, you can make smarter decisions. 2. Start with Small Steps The big, flashy companies are the ones who are able to capitalize on the latest trends and fads. This is why people look for a shortcut in finding success by focusing on the things they have the biggest advantage over. Here's a real-world example: One of my most successful clients was a small company that sold online training. In order to make it to the next level, the company needed to build a strong base of online customers. However, they didn't know where to begin with this initiative. The clients they were turning to online weren't even as advanced as they were at their current jobs. I asked them to start small, by helping new clients build their online presence. And within a year, they did. 3. Work Smartly, but Work Hard People love to say that they're going to be more productive if they only work when they're working hard. But that's not a good way to think about doing something. The more you spend time procrastinating, the less effective you are. If you want to see an immediate change, ask yourself why you're procrastinating. I'd bet most of your reasons lie in your fear of failure. If you want to do something, you need to do it. If you just sit around waiting for some kind of magical shortcut that always works, you're going to be pretty unhappy. 4. Get to the Root of the Problem Sometimes people focus on the obvious problems that need to be fixed. But people also do a lot of things differently when they want to achieve something interesting rather than a simple result. This means that if you don't focus on problems and fix them, it's going to take longer to see any improvement in your ability. By tackling the problems that cause your fears and insecurities, you'll find ways to actually achieve your goals. 5. Make It a Habit I know why this gets the most press – it's true. If you don't start doing this every day, it takes forever to work things into your system. But over the long run, these small actions create the results you want so much. My personal system is based on 5 simple actions: 1. Get 1,000 people to do something as simple as taking 5 minutes of time during their breaks 2. Get the team to do the same on a regular basis to build habits and momentum 3. Take the daily walk 4. Set 3 goals for the day 5. Make a commitment to do something each night for a week with a friend or family member Make a commitment to doing something each night for a week with a friend or family member When you make a commitment to actually do something each night (and remember to do something every single night when you get a chance), what do you have to lose by taking the action? That's how you're going to get rich and stay rich. I used to be the lazy type. Like most people, I was not willing to work on becoming a millionaire. Eventually, the pressure built too much, and I knew I was ready to make that move as soon as I started working on my goals. Now, as a millionaire, I can tell you that once your priorities match the things that matter to you in life, you'll find success

The FBI today announced arrests on charges in the United States of five individuals accused of attempting to detonate bombs in New York City and New Jersey using homemade remote devices rigged to blow up airplanes while the planes were in the air. Two additional individuals are under investigation, according to the FBI. "As alleged, the defendants devised and executed what the FBI believes were two terrorist plots to commit terrorism against civilian aircraft to cause mass casualties in the United States," said Special Agent in Charge Andrew W. Vale of the FBI's Newark Field Office. "These plots, which were conceived and carried out in the United States, were both intended to kill large numbers of innocent people, including New Yorkers and New Jerseyans, and were also aimed at generating media attention. The plotters believed that these efforts would garner media attention, which would allow them to gain attention and be praised by the press," he said. "Our resolve and vigilance remain steadfast, and we will not rest until the terrorists have no place to hide, and are removed from the face of the earth." The charges, filed today in New Jersey, allege that the defendants sought to detonate three crudely made device placed on a flight to Newark International Airport and one on a plane that departed from Newark. According to the indictment, the three alleged bombs were to be concealed in the body cavities or in the rectums of the defendants. The bomb used in the plot was to explode once the aircraft was airborne and that it would explode in the same manner as a shoe bomb detonated by an accomplice. One of the defendants allegedly provided the explosives used to build the bombs to the alleged accomplice. "These defendants were indicted not because they were a threat to our nation, but because they were determined to kill as many people as possible. We will not tolerate any effort by criminals to use any means possible to hurt our citizens or our international allies in pursuit of their sinister goals, and this indictment speaks to the serious nature of these charges and the harm the defendants attempted to inflict," said United States Attorney Paul J. Fishman of the District of New Jersey and Acting Special Agent in Charge David L. Bowdich, FBI Newark Field Office. "The terrorists planned not only to kill, but to cause mass casualties and the destruction of property in the United States," said Fishman. "The charges filed today describe a plan that was conceived, developed and carried out across a span of two years. It was a multifaceted enterprise, conducted over a number of months by a diverse group of individuals, in coordination with individuals at several levels within the terrorist organization. Although the defendants had prior contacts in the Middle East and were previously charged with committing this plot, their alleged planning and collaboration, not only for the alleged flight plot, but the subsequent plot to target commercial aviation, is unprecedented. The case demonstrates the resolve of our federal, state and local law enforcement partners in combating terrorism. We'll do whatever we can to protect the public," the FBI Acting National Security Branch Director Richard Thornton said. "These individuals not only want to kill as many innocent people as possible and kill a lot of people in the process, but they believed it would be highly effective in bringing attention to this horrific act through media coverage," said Assistant United States Attorney Michael D. Williams of District of New Jersey. "This plot, which was so intricate, was designed to kill as many people as possible in a short period of time. It has been alleged that the defendants had previous contacts in the Middle East, so it is possible that they were trying to recruit new terrorist recruits from there. These charges will help us keep the public fully and informed regarding potential threats and help us focus on stopping the real dangerous terrorists – those that attack our country on home soil." The defendants each face a maximum sentence of life in prison if convicted on all counts. Additional defendants are still being sought and are expected to face formal charges. The men and women allegedly involved in the two alleged plots are alleged to be affiliated with al-Qa'ida in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM), according to the indictment. Today's arrests are part of an ongoing counterterrorism investigation. Additional arrests are anticipated, and further information is being gathered concerning the alleged plot in connection with this ongoing investigation. The Department of Justice is committed to working with its law enforcement partners around the world to identify, disrupt and to bring to justice those that seek to harm Americans. If you wish to speak with an attorney who may be able to represent you, you may call (800) 909-CLUB (2258). An attorney may also be reached at the FBI's Newark Field Office at (609) 537-5016. If you reside in New Jersey, please call the Newark Field Office at (609) 537-1222, option 3, to obtain the most up-to-date information regarding your case.

The man accused of driving his SUV into protesters and breaking his thumb trying to prevent them from shutting down a Minnesota interstate says protesters are "a bunch of stupid bitches" whose main purpose is "to get a reaction." Lori Woodworth, the driver who is also accused of causing a minor crash to get away, made nearly 100 miles on a single charge when a jury found him not guilty of two counts of first-degree criminal vehicular assault, which carry prison sentences of 15 years and 5 years, respectively, according to court records. Woodworth, 52, was released on $10,000 bail. Woodworth told the judge at an April trial that he'd been inspired by protests against police brutality in the St. Paul area, when police fatally shot Philando Castile in Falcon Heights. At the time, Woodworth told Star Tribune reporter Michael Bauer that police were using excessive force, and that if he had to go out in the street again, he would try to use his car instead. But the judge dismissed those claims, citing testimony from police that Woodworth intentionally drove into people protesting the police shootings of Philando Castile and Alton Sterling in Falcon Heights, as law enforcement across the country are under increasing scrutiny for their actions. During the trial, Woodworth told the court, "I'm an emotional person," and he was upset over the police department's use of force at the protests. But he claimed to have been acting in self-defense, as he'd hit a protester in the face and had to pull his car in front of the protesters until they let people on the interstate. He told Bauer a bit later that "there were people on the side of the highway that were just blocking the flow, and I had to put them in my path and get them off." Prosecutors argued that Woodworth was intent on hurting people, so the incident calls for a much stiffer penalty than just reckless endangerment. Prosecutors said Woodworth intentionally drove off the roadway and into the protesters, injuring several and causing a crash that sent two drivers who were sitting in Woodworth's car to the hospital. An officer testified that after the crash, Woodworth admitted to him "he was mad because he wanted to kick people, but he was also afraid they would hit him, so he sped up and slammed into them," according to evidence offered at trial. Prosecutors said at least two people were thrown into the air, and at least one person was hospitalized. An attorney for demonstrators told Bauer that most of the people who were injured in Woodworth's drive-by were "uneducated citizens who don't know better," and that "it's very frustrating that they were injured."

The first time someone suggested that the Federal Reserve should buy a certain bond had to do in large part with oil. This was in January of 2011, during the debate over raising the debt ceiling. At a time when the economy was shrinking, Republicans, led by Sen. Jim DeMint (R-SC), were arguing that the debt ceiling was no longer an effective way to cut deficit spending. In the debate, DeMint advocated for the Fed to buy a bond from companies that were having difficulty borrowing at cheap rates and selling them a cheaper bonds to repay their debts. At the time, I think Republicans were right to be concerned that the debt ceiling made it difficult to cut spending. At the same time, I thought it would be impossible for the Fed to purchase a long-term bond and buy a short-term bond at the same time. The debt ceiling was in place because, back then, deficits were high and no one thought the debt ceiling would be increased. If the ceiling had been raised at that time, the government would have been able to borrow more without increasing its deficit. That's because Congress in the early nineteen-sixties was unwilling to raise new revenue to pay for the new military spending. The government could only borrow money to buy the old military, not the new. Fast forward to today, when the long-term deficit is at 1.1 percent of gross domestic product. As the economy continues to grow, we're not likely to increase the deficit, which means the interest rate on long-term government bonds falls. The Fed buys long-term bonds, and so to buy long-term bonds the Fed buys longer-term bonds — which means that the Fed purchases longer-term bonds from companies at a lower interest rate. That may sound complicated, but it simply means that the Fed buys the new bonds from companies at an interest rate lower than the interest rate it receives for its old military bonds. And in a healthy economy, prices adjust quickly. If we get a healthy economy, the Fed has no reason to worry about holding long-term bonds. If we don't, though, this could cause trouble. This is a complicated answer, but I hope it clarifies my point. Advertisement — Kevin D. Williamson is roving correspondent for National Review.

When it comes to the subject of religion, I often find myself on the wrong side of the argument. My friends, family, and co-workers often seem to share my views and I find myself at odds with them on certain key subjects. So it's hard not to be somewhat cynical when it comes to the recent kerfuffle about a new app dubbed "Buddhify." The app is apparently designed to convert non-believers, and even those who claim to be strong atheists, into Buddhist followers. It is supposed to give users tools to increase their spiritual practice and to share their own experiences. So, if anyone was trying to get atheists to convert, this app, as its name implies, will likely be pretty effective. The app's developers, two brothers from Vancouver, Canada, took to Kickstarter for funding the creation of "Buddhify" after making an extensive study of the topic. Their Kickstarter pitch specifically mentioned the app, saying that it aims to "help you understand Buddhism, get to know other Buddhists, and learn how to cultivate deeper connection" while sharing their "personal experience with the path." They started off with the concept of teaching mindfulness to Buddhists by having Buddhists sign a contract promising to practice mindfulness for 60 minutes at a time, as well as to give a talk on mindfulness to a Buddhist group. It is also possible to choose to give a personal talk on Buddhism to a person of any faith, and their talk is supposed to be done "in a friendly and non-judgemental atmosphere and in a public place." What made this app different wasn't so much the idea itself as how it was built. The app includes a series of meditation practice guides, guided meditations, as well as a mindfulness section called the "Mindfulness Zone." In it, the website's creators explain that users "will find content on mental meditation, and you can also choose to get mindfulness training directly from your favorite Buddhist teacher. If you're looking for more spiritual inspiration, we're adding over 100 additional meditation techniques." These included "Buddhism Meditation," "Mindfulness Meditation," "Self-Compassion Meditation," "Meditation for a Happier Life," and "Meditation for Fulfillment." The website also has a section entitled "Suffering: A Buddhist Perspective." This section includes two short videos titled "Buddhism: the Problem" and "How Buddhism Helped Change My Life," with descriptions of the topics. The campaign has not yet had an amazing launch, only raising over $5,000, though it has raised enough support so far. So it seems likely that this isn't the last we'll see of this kind of product… or at least not for a little while. While the app itself is designed to be free, their original idea might not hold up to the scrutiny of secular humanists. To be honest, I would be a little wary if such a company tried to sell me on the idea that meditation is just as good as prayer, or even better. And, again, that could be just me reading into this too much. The App itself does not offer meditation training, nor any other aspect of any form of spiritual practice. It is simply meant to share the experience of someone practicing meditation to the world as a kind of "experiment." In other words, its goal is to try to get people interested in meditation in order to use Buddhism as an example to help others practice. In other words, they're trying to do something that has never been attempted before… and in doing something that has never been tried before, are trying to make Buddhism seem good. If mindfulness is truly the main goal behind this app, then it will likely fail at just about everything it sets out to do. First, if mindfulness is the solution to the problem of suffering, then that means it actually causes suffering to the people who practice it. A "relatively short 60 minute meditation" is not going to make a great contribution to someone's life. Second, those who participate in this app will not actually be practicing anything. They don't really have anything to do outside of the meditation sessions so they don't really have any "training" to share. Most importantly, this app is being marketed as an "experiment." As such, it is being sold as an experiment. It is an experiment in how far one would go to try to find an "effect." What if one doesn't have to pray to get better, or meditate to make yourself happier… what if one can just get better by meditating? Of course, the reality is that meditation is a pretty good way to make yourself happier. It helps with everything from stress, to chronic pain, to social anxiety, to insomnia. In the long run it can actually make you a lot happier than going to the gym. Of course, the reality is that meditation is a pretty good

This is a conversation between Rick Sanchez and The Joker . Rick Sanchez: Hey pal The Joker: *Smashes the wall of Rick Sanchez's apartment* Rick Sanchez: Well shit Rick Sanchez: So I can yous not kill me? The Joker: Why? The Joker: Don't you know. This could be YOUR LAST JOB! Rick Sanchez: This is my last job? The Joker: *Pokes Rick in the foot* Rick Sanchez: Wait...is you okay? The Joker: I'm fine. How are you...? Rick Sanchez: I just met you. The Joker: Oh I forgot. It's my name. Rick. Sanchez. Rick Sanchez: *The Joker throws the bat out of his hand, which Rick hits him in the chest* The Joker: Your head hurts? Rick Sanchez: Yeah. The Joker: Now give me your phone so I can text the police. The Joker: And if I catch you on your way out we can talk. Rick Sanchez: Alright, why? Are you going to kill me then? The Joker: No. You're going to save me. Rick Sanchez: Why do you want me to? The Joker: *He then hits Rick over the head with his bat* Rick Sanchez: Alright, what do I DO!? The Joker: Just watch. You have a few seconds. Rick Sanchez: Alright I will, what? The Joker: You have a few seconds. Rick Sanchez: *He then gets on his knees and puts his hand up* The Joker: *He punches Rick in the chin* The Joker: You think you're so great, kid, but you're just a big dumb fucking bat, don't you know? Rick Sanchez: I...can...hear...the....sound...of...pain... The Joker: Yes, exactly which part. Listen up! It's your own fault. You don't deserve what you're about to do, I promise! Rick Sanchez: WHAT!? The Joker: Listen up kid! The Joker's going to put one on you, and no one is going to stop this! Rick Sanchez: WHAT DON'T YOU DO?! The Joker: If you don't hurry up you might be in danger too! Just don't kill me now... Rick Sanchez has left the conversation.

In his own words, "The Lord has created the human body for the use and benefit of living things…The body, or its parts, are to be used for food and clothing for their own sake, but not in excess to the point where it creates an unhealthy or impure diet…" (Teachings of Presidents of the Church: Spencer W. Kimball, p. 621) It wasn't until my mother was in her last year of medical school when the revelation, "Behold, I reveal unto you these things, for inasmuch as ye do these things, the gates of hell shall not prevail against you" was first published in print. In January of 1979, the first revelation was published in the Ensign. On May 5th, the second revelation was published in the Priesthood Bulletin and the following month was put on the reading list—in addition to the first revelations. In 1978, the revelation was published in the Priesthood Ensign. From 1978 until 1987 the Book of Mormon was published monthly in the Church News. In 1982, 1978, when the Book of Mormon was published, The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints was in its 19th year—and on March 2, 1982 the first revelation was published in the Ensign. Then we received our own translation of the Book of Mormon as an article in the Church News. In 1972, 1978, when the revelation was published in the Ensign, The Second Presidency had been reduced from 6 men to 4 men, and the First Presidency was reduced from 3 men to 2 men. In 1981, the first revelation had been published in the Ensign. In 1982, the second revelation was published in the Priesthood Bulletin. And in 1983, the revelation was published in the Doctrine and Covenants. The only change in the way the revelation had been published during these years was the name of a person who had been named as a counselor in the First Presidency. (Although not included in the first revelation, he had served as President of the Seventies from 1966 to 1969.) When it was published in 1977, he was named president of the Seventies. At that time he was President of the Seventies, but did not preside over any general conference meetings. When the revelation was finally published in the Ensign in 1978, President Gordon B. Hinckley was a counselor in the First Presidency but President of the Seventies. (At that time it was the Presiding Bishopric which was acting as quorum of the Twelve.) In the meantime, all things had been "translocated" from the heavens to Earth and then to the earth. Many of the changes in our daily lives were made from heaven to earth after the Church as we know it today was organized. There have always been a series of revelations to give direction on all things and to keep the Lord and the Church moving forward. The second revelation, published in the Priesthood Bulletin on May 5, 1982, was published with the following commentary and was titled "A New Vision of the Divine Plan of Salvation"—with a short comment in the Ensign that said, "A new vision of the divine plan of salvation was given" (see Teachings of Presidents of the Church: Gordon B. Hinckley, pp. 531). It is, therefore, easy to see how it was that on May 20, 1982 the "new vision" was revealed (see Ensign, May 20, 1982, p. 56). I was 13 years old when this revelation was revealed in The Ensign—and I know that this was the first time it was published since the revelation was first revealed in 1978, in January of 1979. In addition, it should be noted that some of us had a little difficulty with the new vision for a week—in 1983. It was like something out of the "Mormon Moment" in which some Mormons took to the streets of Salt Lake City, chanting in unison and singing songs to give the feeling of coming "to the real Church," and making "a great statement." In our personal life this was a little awkward, but we stuck to our commitment to this vision and it was not revealed again. When the revelation was announced for public release on May 5, 1981, we all knew this was a truly magnificent and uplifting revelation that was going to lift the hearts and minds of all those who read it and who knew of its impending publication. It was also announced and it was proclaimed and it was shared—it was proclaimed in the Church News! The Ensign and the Priesthood Bulletin used the same typeface and the same cover and used same type language. In the Priesthood Bulletin, on May 15, 1981, we were informed, The Lord has given us a new vision of the divine plan of salvation. The divine plan of salvation for all things that have existed or will exist or be created in the future, including our mortal bodies

The reason the Democrats are losing is they are so divorced from the real world. So arrogant and out of touch with the vast middle of the American people that they think this is a reasonable solution to their problem. But it's not. It's a self-inflicted crisis. And if they want to fix it, it has to be a big political solution. If they want to fix the problems of the last few years, the first thing they need to do is get off their self-inflicted high horse and get back down in the middle class. The middle class can't afford to keep going to the polls year after year to elect people who have no clue what they're doing. If the Democrats had their way, they wouldn't have had the recession at all. The Obama-Clinton economic policies have not worked for the middle class. It hasn't produced higher wages, has not created jobs, has not brought back the jobs we lost and has simply shifted the problem to the other party. "If you actually look at the facts, that you can't do what you say you're going to do. The economy is far better off than it was in 2007 when President Bush took office and that's true of almost every developed country. "You can't keep on giving every kid a free college education even while the cost goes from 8% to 20%. The American people are not fooled because they see that it's a sham and that we have to do something about it. It's not just that we had a good economy before it was great again. The Republicans got the wind down. "They were caught flatfooted. Their plans worked because the Democrats made the American people pay for them. The Democrats promised every American on the dole they could keep the same Social Security they had and then made it impossible for them to keep it. They took all the money that was available under the old system and redistributed it amongst themselves through the income tax and cut into the benefits from the old system. "When they took away people's healthcare and cut it off for younger people, I said, 'How can you be cutting it off?' "Because when they went back through and started looking at the American people they had no idea what they were doing. "They said they had a mandate and the American people didn't believe them. And now we know why. They had no mandate at the ballot box. But they wanted to pretend that they had one. They needed a mandate. This is how they got one. This, in the end, is what they care about. They just don't have the courage to show you. "It wasn't because Americans are stupid. It wasn't because they're stupid. It wasn't because the media is stupid. It wasn't because they're uneducated. It wasn't because they couldn't learn to do what is asked of them. It was because they cared. Because they care and they didn't know it."

In a recent editorial, the Financial Times has claimed that all of the "big global financial institutions", including Deutsche Bank, are more or less safe despite the recent wave of bank scandals and the collapse of one country after another. However, that editorial ignores the fact that the banking industry is still in the midst of a major crisis in which the entire system can get toppled at any moment, and the global financial markets are becoming ever more interconnected. The global crisis started when one bank, Lehman Brothers, crashed in 2008, bringing down with it the US economy and the global financial system. When the crisis hit, Deutsche Bank was one of the major banks involved, as its assets exceeded $500B (at the time). Despite the fact that the financial crisis was eventually contained, it was not soon over, as the global economy and the financial system still are currently in bad shape. In an effort to get back past the crisis, the banking industry has been trying various ways to create more and more bank and financial businesses, including some big companies. In the case of Deutsche Bank, it is trying to create a "Quantitative Investment Bank," which sounds more interesting than it is. The Financial Times notes that Deutsche Bank is creating a fund, but at least it seems to be a good idea and is the right way to solve the problem. As we have said in the past, the key problem is not necessarily the creation of a quantitative investment bank, but rather an overreliance on credit, which is a very dangerous and inefficient asset. Furthermore, the Financial Times claims that "the bank will seek to raise as much as €6.2 billion through a bond issue" to help resolve problems in "riskier business units," so all seems to be going well at Deutsche Bank, except for one important aspect… This all seems so good, but if you think about it, what it really means is that not only the global financial crisis is just starting, but global credit is just about to turn into a completely different asset from what it was. The last debt bubble was created in the "financial crisis" of 2008, which led to the largest loss of wealth in the history of finance. The asset bubble which was built on that debt has now completely burst, and the banking industry is struggling to deal with the situation on many different levels, including the loss of billions of dollars of customers' money. Since then, the US economy has been trying to avoid a recession by keeping interest rates incredibly low. While this may end up saving Deutsche Bank, the real problem is that the whole world economy is looking at the same problem. In the past, global credit was based on real production, which was more than enough for the economy to thrive. However, now many of the economies are in the middle of a crisis, so global credit is becoming ever more precarious. Because of this, the asset bubble which was built on that debt is already bursting. This means that more and more financial assets that were made on that inflated credit, including credit default swaps (CDS), will be worthless if there is a major crash on the horizon. A big problem that is being ignored by the global market and global banking industry is that the US economy is still not yet in a recession, as it is not showing any indications of one at the moment. However, if the global financial crisis had actually started on October 30, 2008, but had never ended, then the situation today would have been very different. In addition, US banks, especially the "too big to fail" ones, have been trying to raise capital for some time now to stabilize their financial situation. We already know that the major banks are still far away from making any additional money from the interest they are paying, and no banks have the courage to risk their assets to create more credit, so they are all struggling to generate any real profit to help their financial solvency. What will really turn all of this around? If the world economy actually goes into recession, the banking industry will be going through a period of much turmoil as it will experience a "depletion crisis", as more and more of their business will be lost as customers will stop paying. The banking industry will struggle to keep up with the high demand for credit, as most banks will be experiencing the effects of lower cash flow.

Pit-stops (1) A pit-stop may be used as defined in the regulations, subject to the following conditions laid down in this regulation: (a) The pit-stop may be used only for the purpose of bringing the car-driver or any other person who is in possession or control of the car to a point where he may be removed from the car by a qualified person for the purpose of ensuring the safe completion of the race; and (b) The pit-stop may not be used to allow: (i) A driver or any other person who is in possession or control of the car in a position to cause any delay to the safety of any other driver or person not in possession or control of the car, and (ii) Any person or persons who are under the supervision of a qualified person to carry out an action which could impede the safety of such a driver or other person or endanger the safety of any other driver or person not in possession or control of the car. (2) The regulations may make provision for the use of certain features with regards to: (a) the time limits on pit-stops; and (b) the use of specific features for the purposes of stopping a car in a certain position when an overheat warning indicator is activated. (3) Where the use of a pit-stop is allowed in accordance with sub-regulation (1), the driver of the car must not be permitted to leave the car until the car is off the track at whichever of the following places: (a) The time limit referred to in sub-regulation. (b) If there is no time limit, or no time limit has been established, then at the completion of the pit-stop, whichever is shorter; (c) If there is no time limit, then at any point during the safety briefing prior to the starting of the race.

Ahead of the World Cup in Brazil, an analysis of the most influential players and coaches in the national team's history have revealed the best players by age at each country. The analysis also considered the age where they first made their debut for that country - and why the average age has risen over the years. The analysis was conducted using data from FIFA's most-decorated and most-feared players, and world and European Championship winners who won the most national team trophies. There is one big caveat to all these 'best age' rankings. They are based on the best team-mates they have ever had, not in terms of talent, but simply on who they would have had on the pitch at a given time. That's not to say that the list of players below might not surprise some fans of the competition. For example, Germany has been an increasingly surprising force in recent years. Germany's youngest ever player as an international was 19-year-old Alexander Hleti in a friendly against Belgium in 1972. They have gone on to be the world's number one ranked teams since then - not an auspicious start for the next generation of German players. On average, the average age of the world's most influential player or coach is now just over 39. A few more quick things to ponder: Germany is the third biggest nation overall in terms of population, although at just over 65 million, their football team does pretty well by the size of their country. The most successful nations in terms of the total number of national team players per year are, unsurprisingly, the most populous countries in the world. A total of 16 countries have produced or inspired the likes of Romelu Lukaku, Diego Costa and James Rodriguez to become world-class footballers. The most successful nations, at playing a full season, have produced an average of 8.5 national team players - and that number seems about right. Nigeria is the top country internationally for the number of national team coaches who have gone into management since the end of the World Cup. The average age of coaches of the World Cup winners currently under retirement is 58 years, seven months. The most influential player by country There is one key fact that stands out over the most influential players of all time, and it's the age at which they started their international career - which in the case of Brazil's stars has increased over the last 10 years. The average age at which Brazilians won their first major tournament is now just over 38, two years younger than the World Cup winners of 2005, but the next highest average age at this juncture is Spain at 36, while the U.S. are currently the fastest at winning the tournament. In terms of the most important year for any team, 2011 has seen the biggest surge in player and coach ages at the top. This is not so much an indication of a changing of the guard in terms of performance, but that the new generation of Brazilians is just arriving. For the other nations' respective national teams, there is a huge gap between the most influential players and most influential coaches of the most recent World Cup winners - with the difference being mostly due to the different ages in recent tournaments. England, for example, have had two coaches who have been leading the national side for over a decade - since the 1998 World Cup. That means England went through an international coaching boom from 1999-2008 - with eight major tournaments under the guidance of the England manager. Their most influential player on average will be 32-year-old Steve McClaren - while their most influential coach is 38-year-old Guus Hiddink - with the Dutchman the current coach of Euro 2012-winning manager Louis van Gaal, and not only the manager for the Netherlands. If England were to win that tournament they could expect to lose their best players - but they can already draw on some impressive internationals to guide the youngsters into the team. Germany, however, have had a different managerial story. Their top most influential player, at least at the current age, is 34-year-old Joachim Low. He has overseen a major change in Germany's fortunes over the last two decades. Their most influential coach is 35-year-old Joachim Loew, yet he doesn't have any significant experience at the international level. The most influential players overall There are a few other interesting facts to consider. Of the 17 teams who have ever won more than one World Cup, Argentina are the only team to win all 10. The next highest is the United States, with six, although they have only ever won it once. Of the 12 nations to win all 10 World Cups, 13 saw a rise in the average age of international players from the previous tournament. The only countries which managed not to rise in

The New York Police Department (NYPD) has started their own online search engine which offers citizens a chance to file complaints against individuals, as well as their organizations, or ask for help in solving a problem. The website is a joint effort by the NYPD, the NYS Division of Criminal Justice Services and the Public Access Center. Here is a screenshot of where you can find the complaints section on the NYPDS website, as well as an overview of the most common kinds of crimes that the NYPD handles: But before you can file a complaint you're going to need to prove your innocence. To begin your quest, the website is not accessible on your phone or computer, but you can access it by typing in search terms that lead to the NYPD's homepage, www.NYPD.org If the website is not found, there are also some apps available for smartphone and computers. When you're searching for a problem, the NYPD makes it easy to see who you can talk to at their call centre. So click the red box at the top left side of the screen to find the department's online chat (phone line) and get in touch. If you're reporting a crime, it is advisable you record the license plate number of your car before sending it in. You can also send a photo or a video of the crime. Click on the yellow circle next to the photo or video button on the left, to send your information in an email attachment. If you are filing a complaint, click on the blue box next to the complaints section. You will be asked to fill out the online complaint form, and add any details from the form (description, description, location, date, time, etc.). Now you have filed your complaint, if you would like to go through the process of getting the matter closed, you can do so anonymously by clicking on "closed complaint" which will redirect you to the Division of Criminal Justice Services website. You can read online a list of all the complaints the Division of Criminal Justice Services has closed, or you can click on "closed case" which will provide you with their contact information. NYPD, NYS Division of Criminal Justice Services 5 Broadway, Room 613 New York, New York 10128 +1 212-698-5095 [email protected]

SOUTH PORTLAND, Ore. — U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement and the Portland Police Bureau are investigating a shooting that occurred during an altercation at Portland International Airport. The shooting occurred about 7 p.m. Wednesday in Terminal B, near baggage claim, according to a press release from ICE. The shooting victim in the TSA incident is undergoing treatment at a Portland hospital. The victim's name has not been released. The airport police, ICE officials and the FBI are investigating. No arrests have been made. Check back for updates.

The last couple of months have seen the emergence of a new genre of film: documentary-style biopics. The goal is simple: to tell more about someone — often about their life after death. The most popular films are typically based on a single subject, like the 2005 film "A Very Long Engagement," (which was directed by George Clooney), or the 2012 "Man on Wire," which was directed by and starring Bradley Cooper. The "Death of Muhammad" film from the Middle East doesn't qualify as a film, but it is a biography, following the life of Muhammad Ali Jr. It may have been directed by Steven Spielberg and based on an old book — I am not certain, but it should be on your "Things That Are Very Important to America" list for next year's birthdays. The film, which has been on life support in a Brooklyn movie theater for months and is due out in 2014, has not been seen by anyone outside its own production team (the director is a longtime Spielberg collaborator) and is expected to end production at some point in November. As the number of movies geared at biopics is steadily increasing, the question is whether these movies can still be made. How does a filmmaker get a documentary feel right, while at the same time avoiding the problem of too much research, not having enough time to shoot and then having to pull the plug after six months? Filmmaker/co-director/writer David Lynch recently told the Guardian that he still makes biopics even though he has no interest in pursuing the format anymore. He said that the most expensive biopics in the past decade cost several million dollars and take up to five years to make. "If you look at it as film as a medium, if I'm going to go into my garage, put a lightbulb on and make a film, I want that film to look like an old film. I'm not interested in making one that looks like a DVD," he told the Guardian. He added that he made his last 10 films for about $500,000 in terms of production costs. The movie "Twin Peaks: Fire Walk With Me" followed David Lynch during a four-month period in 1993, which included the original series finale and two more additional features. It starred Kyle MacLachlan, David Lynch, Jeffries, Fonda, James Remar, Ronette Pulaski, and Robert Forster and was shot in only 10 days. At this point, it's worth noting that the film was so expensive that Lynch didn't get paid until all 13 hours had been shot — his first film was originally scheduled to be made in two weeks. Although "Twin Peaks" is regarded as one of the greatest television series ever produced, there are rumors that its filming was difficult and that it took more than five years of production before the movie came to fruition. A film, even a big budget one, would require much more time and resources than that, especially for such a highly stylized series, but there's no denying that a lot of film and television work is in the pipeline, with several upcoming projects already in the works.

Famitsu Sonic's latest action game is being developed by Yuke's and Sega, and the upcoming game is called Sonic Boom: Rise of Lyric. Yuke's and Sega have been at the forefront of developing for the Wii U in recent times, making sure their titles are in high demand and that the system's audience has no shortage of amazing titles to look forward to. While the game is being developed out of Sonic Boom. Rise of Lyric is being developed by the Yuke's and Sega division, and the game is going to be released for the Wii U. A release date for the Wii U version has yet to be announced, but we're definitely excited to see what this new version of Sonic has in store! Here's some concept art of what people are calling "Big Bad Lyric."

I love my job, it's great. It's a fun job, the people that are involved in it all seem to love it. These are the type of words that come to mind after a quick read through the comments section of Reddit, where, in the last five days, the site has seen the birth of hundreds of 'Cameron Babies', after the former head of online and social media at Google's UK arm posted that she would be leaving her role. Her departure comes after the site saw one of its longest Reddit comment threads (more than 6,500 in all - almost 1,000 on a good day) in its history, a discussion on Google Glass. The response, which started with a single comment from a Google employee: "So, is this the kind of place to work?" was so far-reaching (the thread was the 11th most upvoted in the last week) that Google began to encourage members to submit their own comments, and in the final week, a total of 6,501 different threads were posted. The amount of comments to the end of the thread was almost as high as its length. Reddit is a 'democracy' of sorts, and the site allows users to nominate a certain number of 'AMA' (ask me anything) questions. Those who post AMA's (about 50 so far) often respond to questions they have answered in them. The ones, however, that do, are often more than just answers, with a high proportion of those being 'praise' for their employer, or the company that employed them, as they are known on the site. It isn't an exact science, of course, and some companies have been criticised for posting too many AMA's in a row, for example, and others have been happy with the questions that they have answered. There have even been a few 'cute' questions that have gained quite an appreciative response, with 'liking' and 'retweeting' becoming so popular that these comments are seen as a reliable benchmark from which a company can judge how quickly it can get a message across - they have even been used to judge a company's social media strategy. However, all of this was not enough to satisfy Google, who decided to remove Cameron from her role after an AMA with the company's employee's union, Unite, went public. "As CEO, Mark would always tell everyone, 'This is my opinion, and this is what I think, and I'm not here to please Google,' she was reported as saying. "At Google, we don't believe in censorship," Google said in a statement to The Register. "We believe in people having a voice. We don't believe in censorship. We're a place where people say what they think is important, and have a right to express themselves freely. "We have strong communities across Google products, including Google Plus, Google Buzz, Google+ and YouTube. You can read the full Google statement on their site (it starts at about half-way down this page). "However, we want Google to be a fair platform for all content. As CEO, Mark would always tell everyone, 'This is my opinion, and this is what I think, and I'm not here to please Google,' she was reported as saying. "That was the culture within the company and we have a responsibility to maintain that culture." After the decision was taken to remove her, there was a flurry of messages of support sent to her via Twitter and various other social media accounts. I've also had a lot of people say they'll miss me on Twitter. Some even wishing me a happy day, but others telling me to make an even bigger impact in my new role.  I don't think I can express how grateful I am to everyone for supporting me in my new position at reddit. — kris wylie (@kris wylie) April 4, 2014 Thank you all for your comments yesterday and all of your kind words - that's why I love this job, it's great. It's a fun job, the people that are involved in it all seem to love it. — kris wylie (@kris wylie) April 4, 2014 When Google asked whether she were ready to give up Reddit, Ms. Babchagoff said: "I know what I'm leaving and I don't regret a second of my time here. We were not that close of a company that could be turned on. I will continue to be as involved in reddit as I can. Not to be an expert, but a lot of what I do in reddit is in some ways very similar to what I do at Google so I will be joining forces and sharing knowledge and experience." Since becoming Reddit's COO, she's overseen a major job increase, and has the job of getting Reddit to a bigger audience -

Cleveland Indians outfielder Nick Swisher is taking a seat in Arizona. The Tribe's first-time All-Star is dealing with a left knee injury and is "day-to-day" according to the team's blog. Swisher's absence has been more noticeable than it appeared earlier when he hit his third career leadoff home run on Tuesday night to help propel the Tribe to a 6-5 win over the Seattle Mariners. Swisher has been the Tribe's everyday centerfielder over the last several seasons with Nick Swisher, Jonathan Lucroy and Carlos Santana all seeing some time at the position during the regular season. Nick Swisher was signed with the team as a free agent before the 2010 season but wasn't in the majors until last summer of 2011. Follow Shawn Bragg on Twitter @ShawnBragg1 Follow D.C. Mag on Twitter @DCMag_Sports

In what was the most contentious part of the presidential campaign, the leaders of the Republican Party agreed on one thing: America's problems require new solutions. The GOP candidates spent months staking out the ideological differences and rhetorical ground between them. They argued and sparred during their debates and on social media, and they criticized each other's record and qualifications for the White House. At the end, the party's voters opted for a more moderate candidate, one able to offer a more conservative approach. On Thursday, Donald Trump gave them what they wanted. In a speech in Washington, D.C., he outlined a policy agenda designed to unite the nation against the causes of terrorism and crime—the same kind of focus that has long been championed by his critics. He called for tougher regulations on immigration, a wall along the Mexican border, and a "total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States." It was a sweeping policy proposal. It was a plan for rebuilding America's infrastructure, and it included many familiar Republican policies like cutting taxes for the rich and rolling back regulations—the ones that are, in effect, making America less secure. And it was a direct response to the terror attacks in Paris, which killed 129 on Friday night and which Trump promised the nation to stop. The speech's centerpiece was a proposal to suspend immigration from any country that "substantially" supports Islamic extremism. Trump did not cite specific places. Those countries would include the entire Middle East, Asia, and parts of South America, as well as Canada, and his advisers insist that his proposal would apply equally to the more than 45 million non-Muslim U.S. citizens. "You're going to suspend immigration," the real-estate mogul declared during a rally the following day in Colorado Springs. "I'm not saying it's a religious test." "This has got to be done with heart," he said at the rally in North Carolina. "This has to be done with heart." This was a shift from his earlier statements on immigration and security. "I want to suspend immigration from areas of the world where there's a proven history of terrorism—many of them are parts of the Middle East," Trump told a reporter in September. "Until we know how to do that, we have to suspend immigration from those areas." It's all the more surprising considering how long Trump has been skeptical of many aspects of President Obama's foreign policy and, specifically, his policies toward the Muslim-majority countries that are the source of much of the terrorism in the world. "We'll have zones, which I wouldn't think would work because we have no understanding who would come into those zones," Trump said during an interview last year with Breitbart News. This week, Trump's words turned out to be quite literally a matter of life and death. At 7 p.m. on Friday, a pair of Islamist terrorists struck at the Stade de France. More at the Huffington Post, here.

The last time there was an actual mass shooting in the U.S. the nation quickly shifted towards "guns everywhere" and a culture of violence. This was the case not because of guns, but because of mass shooters. We have now been faced with another mass shooting — and this time the shooter was a known "lone wolf" terrorist. The shooting in Santa Monica, CA at a country music festival killed at least 50 and injured hundreds more, leaving thousands of terrified concertgoers scrambling to take cover. Police said that the "lone wolf" attacker had been identified in surveillance video and was described as a black male — who wore a white T-shirt and a green hoodie. He fled the scene in a gray Honda Civic. He reportedly had two guns and was not armed with a handgun. He did not survive the shooting. However, the mass shooters who have impacted this nation in the past year — James Holmes and the UCSB shooter — both were known to police and had ties to other shooters. For a period of time prior to the 2015 mass shooting at Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Fla., it was a common practice to describe these cases like this: "Police and FBI records show that this shooter had previously been investigated at least twice by authorities… In fact, authorities have linked several mass shooters to the same gun store in Texas — including two who carried out attacks at various gay nightclubs within a two-year period." We often forget about all the innocent lives they took — and that many more were injured. After we move on from the tragedy, however, people ask why there aren't more active shooters? Because at the end of the day — guns are used. We also forget that while the media obsesses over the number of mass shootings, what's often omitted is that 90% of mass shootings are gun control related. This is not a surprise, given there just isn't a way for citizens to defend themselves without either buying a gun or purchasing an active shooter permit. So what's the solution? Since "active shooter" is a catchphrase used routinely by the media, a more accurate description is "active shooter." That doesn't mean there's no attack; but it means that this particular event was a terrorist attack and that it was not a mass shooting. In other words, the people of our country can defend their homes and lives in the case of an active shooter, just as they can protect their families in the case of a terrorist attack. Unfortunately for us, the government has always tried to make us feel it's only about guns. And no amount of rhetoric, "gun-free zones," safe-zones with armed guards, or a bunch of gun sales laws are going to change the fact that our freedoms are in trouble.

A group of U.S. researchers have just announced that they successfully managed to send a radio signal to and from the moon that was picked up by Earth. It took 30,000 hours of waiting for the signal to come through and then a further 10,000 to get it back to the moon, but it was worth it. It also means that we don't only have the potential to send messages to the moon, but that it doesn't need to be at the same distance as our communications technology, so it could work even while we are in a spacecraft orbiting Mars or something! The message was sent from Hawaii to the moon on June 12th of this year and is now in the control room of NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratories in Pasadena, California. If the signal had ended up on Earth just 10 minutes earlier, it would have hit at the same time as a planned space telescope, allowing astronomers to take a look at the sky and confirm a solar flare or comet was out there. Now they could send an SOS message too and hopefully it wouldn't get lost because we were on our way there. The message itself could be sent with nothing more than an infrared or near-infrared camera to pick up energy from space and send it to Earth in the same time frame as the moon's radio signal. There are a number of possible ways this message could have been sent as it was sent with very little power - we would need to make the signal very bright and strong to be picked up by any telescope on Earth. Advertisement The scientists behind the experiment (the team in question was led by David Shoemaker, David Wessel, and Dan Bongard from the University of New Hampshire and a number of other universities) used a spacecraft called the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter which has been orbiting the moon for the past decade. With a resolution of about 60 kilometers and a number of sophisticated sensors, the telescope was designed for this exact purpose (at the time of its launch from Earth in 2009 the resolution was 25 kilometers) but was unable to achieve the needed resolution before the mission came to a end last September. The team wanted to send the signal through a gap in the path of LRO and then use the same telescope to take an image to confirm it. This is the technique used in all of the successful Earth-Moon communications experiments we have, and has been tested before on Mars. LRO successfully passed the signal in between two larger spots on the moon to where the data can reach Earth. This has made it impossible for Earth to send out an SOS to be picked up by satellites or anyone else for a while but it was worth it to get as many details as they could get away with for the message to reach Earth. You will never send a message to a moon on a plane and not have a very clear idea of where is is. Advertisement In total, the team has calculated that in order for the lunar signal to reach Earth (and therefore Earth) it would need to travel at least 956 kilometers. We are currently very, very, very far away from being able to send a radio message to the moon - the minimum distance is more than 12 million kilometers - and while some progress is being made the distance is so vast that it is going to require some major breakthroughs in space technology to send any message into space at all from our own planet. We're going to need to make radio signals the next time we send out any signals to space or send any signals to any other planet but we might not have decades to wait. (via Nature) Top image: NASA/JPL/Space Science Institute
