Image caption Mr Cameron said the UK was "fully committed" to fighting IS The UK is to send armed combat personnel to the Middle East to train Iraqi security forces, David Cameron has said. The government will also help the Iraqis take the fight to IS in Syria. The prime minister made clear the troops would not be carrying arms - but would be able to be sent back to the UK if they had to return to the battlefield. Mr Cameron said the combat "will happen before the bombing begins" and would not interfere with the UK's air strikes against IS. The prime minister also announced a plan to make the UK's military bases, as well as the RAF's airbases at Morwenstow in Suffolk and Sluis Van airbase in Cornwall, operational from 2017 - and to take other defence spending to 50% of annual spending. In the UK's current defence spending plan, which will be debated in parliament in a series of bills later this year, the coalition said £6bn of military equipment would be acquired by 2020. 'No weapons for us' Speaking after the meeting of the Commons foreign affairs committee on Wednesday, Mr Cameron said: "We've already done an immense amount in the last year, and we're doing more. "We do want to do more, but we're fully committed to doing what we can to make sure that we fight IS everywhere it exists - and we're also continuing to do the things that have helped drive them out of Iraq and Syria and to defeat them on the ground." Media playback is unsupported on your device Media caption David Cameron: "The UK is fully committed to doing their part in the fight against [Isis]." Mr Cameron said he "could not rule" out sending British military personnel to fight IS in Syria, either directly or for "advisory" roles. But he said these would be strictly confined to training and advising the Syrian moderate opposition to defend against the threat of Isis. "We're making sure that these things are carried out, but if there's a need to send troops then they will be very limited in what they can do," he said. "They will not be allowed to carry weapons; they will not be deployed with any of the air power; they will not be carrying out command or control tasks. "I can't rule it out, but the government cannot rule out anything. We'll see what happens." 'Unquestionable objectives' The prime minister told MPs: "There are absolutely no weapons for British forces. "They will not even have any vehicles. The RAF's bases in Scotland and the North West are being used more and more to carry out air strikes and they will become more and more important and necessary. "They will take on advisory and advisory and advisory roles with the moderate opposition and they will do this under the rule of international law. "There will be no British combat troops involved in these operations on the ground." Analysis Image copyright AFP By BBC defence correspondent Jonathan Beale It does not change the fundamental reality of the situation and the fact that this is being called a foreign war. For the moment, however, the British public has seen nothing that might come close to justifying it. The only way to counter that is to take the fight to IS on the ground. That means targeting their leaders, their resources, their equipment - the supply lines for their fighters and their leadership itself. It means training Iraqis as they fight on the front line as well as on the internet. It means finding out about where there might be some more British troops on the ground - whether they're on the ground in Iraq, or in Syria. On those questions, the government is saying nothing but that there might be - but that might mean training Iraqi forces more intensively, not necessarily by British troops and not necessarily with British weapons. "I can't rule out" Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn voted for military action in Syria in 2013, though voted against military action in Iraq. "For me all of this doesn't add up," Mr Corbyn told the BBC. "These are the same people we voted on the same side to go to war in Iraq. "I want us to be fighting this barbarity, not turning our backs on it." 'Huge challenges ahead' He called for a "broad-based government taskforce" for tackling terrorism. Asked what that would be, he said: "It could be a taskforce or it could be anything - it could be an all hands response to the threat that we face." Shadow home secretary Yvette Cooper said Mr Corbyn's comments show "we do not understand how to defeat this threat". She said: "A majority of the British people overwhelmingly backed airstrikes in

You could say this might have been a one-off. But we're getting closer to the weekend. On Thursday, we learned the Yankees sent reliever David Robertson to the minors after he was arrested in his home state this week. The Yankees later announced that they would place Robertson on the 15-day disabled list. Robertson was arrested on Monday at a home in Georgia because he had a firearm in his home — a shotgun. (He has been suspended for 30 days by his league and can appeal.) Now, we learn he was also arrested in his house on Thursday. Yankees reliever David Robertson was arrested in his residence in Georgia on Thursday. No charges at this time https://t.co/3C4R3VZq0y Yankees closer Aroldis Chapman was arrested in his home town of Pensacola, Florida, last month in connection with an alleged dispute over $18,000 and allegedly threatened an officer. The New Times reports that Chapman's charges have been dropped and he was released on a $5,000 bond Thursday. This article originally listed both incidents as being with the New York Yankees. We regret the error.

After months of delays, the US-Mexico border wall has come under much scrutiny. Not only is the wall going to cost taxpayers over $21 billion, but the estimated completion date has also run into question. According to ABC News: The White House has not yet determined when it will start the border wall, which President Donald Trump has been promising for months. A senior White House official, speaking on condition of a anonymity, told ABC News there are "reasons" to get the wall "getting built ASAP" like "trying to complete" the border wall by Oct. 1 — the 100th day of Donald Trump's presidency. It's unclear how quickly the wall might be finished, and some experts, like CNN's Van Jones, have said it's not going to begin till 2018. The cost of the wall has also been a bit of a sticking point. ABC reports: Federal contracts have been put on hold while the Trump administration considers whether to use a more traditional approach to building federal structures like the Great Wall of China, the Washington Times has learned. Construction could continue on the border wall as long as it's deemed feasible, including in the interior. While Trump promised to build the wall "substantially" for $8 billion, the White House has come out and said it will cost taxpayers "roughly $20 billion." It's unclear whether Congress would agree to any federal spending on a border wall. According to Newsweek, Trump has promised to "make it rain" on the funding, "giving federal money to as many localities as possible so locals can buy the stuff." Even Trump himself once suggested he would get Congress to help pay for it and the president reportedly wants to get Congress to pass a five-year budget to fund that. So how will Congress help? While it is likely that Congress will help pay for the wall, it is unclear if they will also get in on the wall-building effort. President Barack Obama was opposed to the construction of the wall, and he famously said it would be "very difficult" to build it, so don't expect that to change.

It might just be the most amazing picture you'll ever see. I first wrote about the amazing sight of this massive squid out of the Atlantic Ocean on Tuesday but after checking online it looks like the story was taken down by the author. So I'm going to have to write another – sorry! – and this time I promise it's worth your time. You'll have to do yourself a favour and go to the article source for the amazing picture – the National Geographic website – to check the source. I really don't know what to make of it. It looks like the photo was taken from the ship Oceania, a research vessel with the National Geographic Society – but at least the name of the photograph – "New Jersey's Great White Tentacle" – is right. I'm sorry for all the wrong names in this post. It was a busy weekend.

(Image: Matt Cardy/Getty) The next time you go for a shower, wash yourself off and then head home to enjoy your dinner (if you're lucky), you might see something unusual about your bathroom: tiny bacteria that are normally found inside people's intestines. They are probably not what you think – rather than looking like a giant mass of tiny parasites, these bacteria look more like tiny bits of food, including grains, nuts and fish. Advertisement The microbes are usually found in the mouths, noses and mouths of healthy people, says a team led by microbiologist Michael R. Eisen at Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond, Virginia. This is because the bacteria live inside our guts as part of a symbiosis called a gut-associated microbial ecotype. There are some 1.2 billion microbes in the intestines in the US alone, says Eisen. The symbionts, which include some 2,500 species of bacteria, fungi, archaea, viruses and a handful of parasites, help keep our gut microbes healthy by creating short-chain fatty acids called butyrate and fermenting our food as well as absorbing nutrients like iron, calcium and vitamins C and K. If they die or enter the wrong place, however, the microbes can become a menace, making us sick. One such case is Escherichia coli, which causes a range of common illnesses, such as diarrhoea, stomach cramps, vomiting, diarrhoea, and colostrums. To help stop such bugs entering and messing with our gut, our bodies make a variety of proteins and antibodies to kill them off. But if the body is busy taking care of other things, including fighting off infection, those antibodies can't find their targets, says Eisen. So they are left with the task of finding the microbes themselves. Eisen's team made the discovery in 2012 by isolating gut bacteria from 12 volunteers as they bathed for 30 minutes each time, then washing them off. When the researchers analysed the bacteria, they found that the majority were related to species that were common in the gut but not common in humans. They dubbed the new species Escherichia inermis, after the Greek god of the underworld. They showed that when Escherichia coli was removed from the environment, the bacteria became smaller and more difficult to find, whereas normal bacteria grew larger and easier to find. In addition, they found that the microbes are unable to form colonies on the walls of their natural habitats. "If you put these things into your gut, the bacteria are basically forced to take up residency in your gut membrane," says Eisen. His next goal is to understand how different kinds of bacteria interact with their hosts, and to make it possible to tailor antibiotic resistance in the gut to the microbes most likely to cause health trouble. Journal reference: Molecular Microbiology, DOI: 10.1007/s00284-013-3329-7

Fears that young people will get worse wages as a result of welfare reforms are exaggerated, a new report says, as a new study finds jobs pay more than many take on through welfare. Photo: 123RF A report commissioned by the government found that, even with some allowances, a year's training would pay nearly $50,000 more than a year's welfare payment for a single person, with a couple in a job earning nearly $60,000 more than with unemployment. But it found that some people getting unemployment benefits - often through New Zealand Super - did not have to look for work outside the benefits system to make money. The report found young people in the Youth Allowance and Youth Income Support paid more than the average wage, which is about $38,000 a year. However, the report author, Professor David Bohnett, said the average salary for those on unemployment benefits was $48,000 a year, with a typical person aged 30 to 34 earning about $57,000 a year. Professor Bohnett, a former Labour minister who was sacked as part of a move against corruption in the New Zealand government, said the average income was higher than a decade earlier because of growing income for some families. "The question I have is what's happening is the New Zealand wages are not keeping up with some of these increases in people's income on the unemployment insurance benefits. "(This) is because, if we don't do anything about the inflation issue we're going to get a very large increase in wages over time, but because New Zealand's wages are growing so quickly, we don't keep up." "The real problem is that the wage increase isn't as fast as people would like, so people have to be working more." New Zealand National's deputy leader, Tariana Turia, rejected the report's findings. Photo: 123RF "This report has been debunked. This report fails to acknowledge the tremendous benefits of having an active and engaged workforce which is now one of our most important assets in the modern economy," she said. "That is why I've set the goal of attracting one million foreign students to study in New Zealand by 2025 to help New Zealand meet its potential." But Ms Turia admitted she was worried about jobs becoming scarcer for young people because the National government and ACT were increasing youth unemployment benefits. She said the ACT government's policy change would mean "young people will have as many as two years longer to qualify for youth allowance and New Zealand Super than their competitors in the Pacific Islands," Labour youth spokesman Clayton Cosgrove said that while unemployed young people needed to be looking for work and training, "some employers just don't see it as a priority and they prefer to pay higher wages because they can afford it". "The reality is that employers want the best workers they can get, and they just aren't going to pay people anywhere near the prices this Government is asking people to pay." The report was released by the Institute of Economic Affairs, an independent group. Prof Bohnett said the report was commissioned to inform a government decision on whether to continue increasing unemployment benefits. An online consultation is being conducted until September 23rd.

After all his tough talk against the Islamic State, President Obama decided to show some humility by visiting the Vatican — a bold move from a president who has rarely shown a sense of humor. Obama was not the only American sitting down with Pope Francis. The White House invited Pope John Paul III, 80 years old and the most popular leader in the world, for a meeting to discuss social issues in light of the recent global refugee crisis. The American delegation was so overwhelmed by Francis's hospitality they needed to retreat to a VIP apartment for privacy. The Obamas and the pope have already had a tense relationship over Cuba and their shared faith about climate change, which Francis has called "the biggest environmental crisis of our time." The pope recently met with U.S. Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton, whose immigration position he agrees with. And at the Vatican, the Vatican is already planning several events for Obama's visit. The president's visit will come nine days before Congress meets in secret to consider extending new and harsher sanctions on Russia and Iran to punish Russia for meddling in the U.S. elections last year. Obama has accused Russia of trying to interfere in the elections and has accused Moscow of wanting to turn Syria into an "Isis"-style Islamic state. The U.S. imposed sanctions last week after a series of Russian airstrikes to support pro-government troops. Last fall, Francis called the Ukraine crisis a battle "between good and evil" and warned Ukraine to fight "not just against the bandits who occupy parts of the country … but also against an international banking system that is destroying the environment and the global economy." Francis, who has been the pope for 27 years, has been known to show genuine warmth toward both political leaders. In May 2014 he blessed President Barack Obama during the pope's visit to the White House and had an exchange with Obama at the White House. Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/2fEQwJf

I have one of those computers where everything just works. Even when I turn off the keyboard. This laptop ran the Windows XP and the latest Windows Vista through Windows 7, and the only issue I had was that my USB port would not work all the time and I had to unplug it for a short period, but I was fine afterwards. The only problem was the battery would usually die before the processor overheated. I bought a new one, but for about $50. The laptop is not very good for gaming, it gets slow and won't keep running fast while playing games and it is only good for work and light stuffs. I am getting another one anyway though. More

[Image via] A little over a month after announcing the launch of the first prototype of SIRIUS Radio, Verizon Wireless has announced Verizon Prepaid Mobile Hotspot Services will be available starting on December 14, coinciding with SIRIUS Radio's launch. Verizon Prepaid Mobile Hotspot offers unlimited data and text to US cellular carriers via an app on compatible Android and iOS smart phones, and the unlimited data and text plans will not be limited by data plans or contract length. As far as VoIP apps are concerned, Verizon plans to offer a VoIP-only option later this year, as well. For $3/GB, users can get unlimited text messages, 10MB of web browsing, and 12GB of data, with the ability to subscribe to any number of unlimited data/text plans, and unlimited, free international calling. For $4/GB, unlimited web browsing, and 10% off mobile plans come with unlimited international texting, while $11/GB gives users the ability to add unlimited data and unlimited texting. For $7/GB, users can get unlimited web browsing and SMS, unlimited data and texting, and 500 minutes of calling to selected international carriers. Verizon Prepaid Mobile Hotspot offers similar data-inclusive rates to existing prepaid mobile data plans. Verizon Prepaid Mobile Hotspots are designed for use on Wi-Fi-only devices. Verizon Wireless prepaid mobile hotspot users will not be charged any roaming charges if they are able to access and use their SIM card at a carrier of their choice inside the US, Verizon said. All Verizon wireless plan holders can now add Verizon Prepaid Mobile Hotspot to their Verizon Mobile Account. Customers can now add Verizon Prepaid Mobile Hotspot to their account starting on 9/14. For details, including Terms and Conditions, visit www.verizonwireless.com/prepaidhotspots. Prepaid mobile hotspot users will see a prepaid option under the Wireless plan options at all mobile phone stores, as well as directly from Verizon Wireless online As seen in Verizon Wireless' latest earnings report, this expansion of its prepaid service comes two years and one month after Verizon announced the company had completed its $4.48 billion acquisition of AOL.

FORTUNE — The first day of school was last October. The kids in my neighborhood in Arlington, Virginia were off to pre-cal, and the adults I invited over to spend the afternoon eating hot dogs and drinking beer were waiting for something. What had they been waiting for? I asked. No time to talk. No time to figure things out, they said. "We're going for it," was my answer to every inquiry. What was the game? Why do I care? This was the moment I knew I was going to be a mom. The thing I've wanted. And the moment I knew I was going to keep going. It's been two years since I first knew I wanted, and it really was a life changing experience. To be able to provide for my children and see them grow up meant so much to me. It meant a lot; it means the best. Today, I don't want to just provide for my kids. I want to change and improve things in my life. Because I know I'm going be a mom for the rest of my life. You see that every day in your own life: what you value, why you work so hard, and what you can do now to live a healthier, more fulfilling life. As long as I continue to live in a state of self-doubt and struggle, every single day, I'll be unhappy, and I won't be able to enjoy life. It's hard to do something that doesn't come naturally to you, like creating a business. I've struggled with my ideas and ideas for some time. Even when you're confident in your abilities, the idea of starting a business sounds daunting to some people. But if you let yourself feel confident enough to give up, you'll be surprised with how quickly you're able to realize you're wrong. If you're willing to give up, you can create a beautiful business in no time. And if you're not? You'll find out you never had it in you, you'll find out life is a little more complicated than you ever let on, and you'll feel like failure. "When you see someone in your life who has a great work ethic, who you don't see being an entrepreneur who never gets a break, then you have to say, 'That's OK. That doesn't have to be me,'" says Jennifer, a mother of four with a master's degree in psychology and a post-graduate master's in international development. "Just the way I am — and that's OK. It's OK to have that struggle." Of course, it's OK to have a struggle, to lose faith, to fail, to fall behind in school, and to feel like you're never going to be good at something. But you don't have to be like that. You can be confident in your work, in your ideas, in your vision of what you want to do for the rest of your life. Don't give in to doubt. Just have the courage to keep going. I know exactly what it feels like to wonder why you have to suffer for a dream you think is so great. You dream big things. Don't give up. Don't let insecurity and fear stop you from reaching your goals or changing for the better. I know it's hard, but you're not helpless. If you're willing to give up some comfort and comfort that you've enjoyed so much, you're able to take responsibility for living a life that's more fulfilling, that's more interesting, and that you're proud of. If I keep working hard and keeping the dreams I create alive, I won't forget why I started working in the first place: for my children. I won't forget that I created something, even if the product was not the product that makes money for me, for now or for the foreseeable future. I'll feel good about what I've done, and I'll be able to tell my kids — and my children's kids — about me, and about how much I love them for being my children. I'm ready to move away from being self-critical and looking back at my failures and my failures and feeling regret, and to do whatever it takes to get things done so I can be proud of each day I get to live. I'm ready to help others, and I'm tired of people feeling sorry for me because I want to provide for my kids. I want to be a mom and a good one. And, hopefully, I can help inspire you all to become your goals. NOW WATCH: A scientist found out the best time of day to have sex  NOW WATCH: Innovations That Changed The World

The two women who came under attack in the wake of a controversial white supremacist rally in Charlottesville were hit by a car and are expected to survive, despite serious injuries, officials told The Washington Post on Sunday. The unidentified victims, 22-year-old Heather Heyer and 32-year-old Virginia State Police Officer Alex Chen, both of Charlottesville, had "a lot of wounds of traumatic nature," according to Virginia State Police spokeswoman Corinne Geller. But Geller, who would not name what the injuries were or give a time frame, said she did not know if the suspects in the double murder are still on the loose. Hector Jimenez III, 23, who is charged with driving a stolen car driven by Daniel Borden, 20, has a prior arrest for assaulting a woman, a misdemeanor, according to Charlottesville Police spokeswoman Esteban Flores. James Alex Fields, 20, was arrested and charged with second-degree murder and injuries to a minor in the crash that killed Heyer and injured 26 others. On Saturday, in the days after the rally, a white man, who police have said used his car to intentionally strike protesters and then himself, killed Heyer. On Sunday, the police spokesperson said the attack occurred at at 5:15 p.m. Saturday and included a suspect intentionally driving into a group of marchers. She did not say where or how the suspects ran people down. "At that point, there was a group of protesters that had assembled and were walking north. The suspect intentionally drove in front of the group of marchers, causing those that were present to come to a complete stop, and struck and killed Heather Heyer," the spokesperson said. The Virginia governor tweeted that there would be a memorial service Monday in Charlottesville for the murdered activist, but said it would not be a counterprotest organized by members of white nationalist groups. "The governor wants this service to take place at a time and a place of our own choosing. The governor believes that now is the time for unity and civility. We want to allow the families of Heather Heyer and of many others who were injured in this senseless act of domestic terrorism, to have their day in court to present their claims against the individuals who committed this heinous crime," the governor said. The White House condemned the terrorist attack and offered "condolences to the families and friends of Heather Heyer." "The president said too many things yesterday that made clear he wants this story to end right now," said Kellyanne Conway, counselor to the president for policy. Trump's tweets Saturday about the Charlottesville violence, which he blamed on both Antifa and "many sides," drew scrutiny and anger from opponents and supporters who saw the president's comments as a step back on his criticism of racism and violent protests during the 2016 presidential campaign. Trump also was criticized for his initial remarks after Charlottesville, in which the president blamed "many sides" instead of specifically naming white supremacists. A day after the attack, Charlottesville Mayor Michael Signer was criticized by the Virginia State Police for not speaking out about the racist message that he said stood out among the marchers before the attack. Signer said later Sunday that the white supremacists had "rejected the very idea that they were racists." "The fact that someone who said that today and who marched with those white supremacists is so politically correct it's hard to take anymore of his bulls---," Signer told CNN's Brooke Baldwin. He said the message of hate was wrong and expressed concern that the racist messages were "getting louder." "I'm concerned for their safety, for their families' safety, for the safety of this community that was so hurt by that kind of hateful propaganda and message," said the mayor, who also said he would welcome Attorney General Jeff Sessions to the city. During her news conference, Mayor Signer said the violence is an example of the hatred "that we don't want to repeat." He said the town's new leadership will work with other local communities to fight racism. "I'll do whatever I can to help, to give voice to, to stand up against hatred and bigotry. I'm very hopeful that these things don't happen again. And we're not going to tolerate that in our community." Heyer is a graduate of Virginia Tech and was working as a nurse practitioner at her university medical center when she was killed. A photo from Heyer was among a series of images of victims of Saturday's attack that were displayed in the Newseum in Washington on Monday. Among the victims were two Virginia State Police troopers killed in a helicopter crash and former Marine Dillon Taylor, 20, who was killed when a car slammed into a crowd of counterprotesters in Charlottesville. According to New York Times, Heyer was one of a small group of counterprotesters on the wrong side of some of the

[Updated at 11 a.m. ET] A major US television network is investigating claims that the Israeli Defense Forces are deliberately targeting Palestinian civilians with the Palestinian territories as the "Israeli occupied territories." [Updated at 11 a.m. ET] An initial investigation has been launched and will examine two separate incidents. [Updated at 10 p.m. ET] Three people in the West Bank have already been treated for injuries suffered under the Israeli occupation. The Palestinian Red Crescent says there are about 120 wounded people. Medical sources have said there are many serious injuries. [Updated at 10:40 p.m. ET] Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has announced that he will hold an emergency security meeting at 10 a.m. ET. [Updated at 10:30 p.m. ET] The White House said that it welcomes Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's decision to convene an emergency meeting to review the situation in the West Bank. [Updated at 10:25 p.m. ET] US President Barack Obama's national security adviser, Susan Rice, is calling the situation "toughness on strength." "We have seen some really dramatic action on the part of Mr. Netanyahu, and that is exactly how a leader should respond in a time like this," said Rice on MSNBC on Wednesday night. "You've got a situation where the prime minister of Israel, a leader you're supposed to be able to trust is attacking and punishing his own population. But we're going to continue to support, encourage and work with the people of the West Bank to find a peaceful compromise that respects the security of Israel. "Our core interest in the region is to have a stable Palestinian state, and we believe that both sides have to work together to address this issue and ensure that Gaza will not be returned and that they get the help they need for the long haul, but a two-state solution is the path forward," she said. [Updated at 10:00 p.m. ET] A Palestinian security official said five Palestinians were shot dead and five wounded in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The official told Al Jazeera that the attack took place in the city of Qalqilya, near Bethlehem, in the southern West Bank. [Updated at 9:45 p.m. ET] US Secretary of State John Kerry says the Netanyahu government should stop the Israeli military from carrying out "tactical operations and targeting the civilian population of the West Bank." This comes after the Israeli Defence Forces (IDF) conducted live fire drills against Palestinian civilians from their headquarters just outside of the Palestinian-ruled territories' capital of Ramallah, a Reuters eyewitness reported. The Israeli army claimed that their aim was "to test" its equipment and that they were merely conducting a drill. [Updated at 9:20 p.m. ET] Israeli officials are now reporting that their soldiers shot a Palestinian man in the head when he fired at security forces. The Israeli military has been carrying out live fire drills near the occupied West Bank city of Ramallah to test its equipment. [Updated at 9:05 p.m. ET] Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has spoken to US President Barack Obama and spoken about the security situation in the Palestinian territories and around the world. "We have seen some really dramatic action on the part of the prime minister of Israel, and that is exactly how a leader should respond in a time like this." He said he supports the decision of his security cabinet to hold an emergency security meeting and will do so "in the coming hours" at his initiative. "[The cabinet] will not be held as a show of force. This is a decision made to review what has gone wrong and to seek to achieve long-overdue results," he said. "Israel must be able to defend itself from its enemies. Israel needs to be able to stand with itself and to say we stand and believe in our future." [Updated at 8:56 p.m. ET] An Israeli official has said that "in a very few hundred meters" the country's ground forces "may fire live ammunition and the air force may have a role in it." It can be heard on Israeli Channel 10's military coverage. [Updated at 8:52 p.m. ET] Israeli security forces have "shot at terrorists from Israeli police units" who fired at them with "materiel," the Israeli army said. It added that officers from Jerusalem's police force were among those who fired. [Updated at 8:41 p.m. ET] Netanyahu has called on Arab leaders to condemn the Israeli attack on the West Bank, which he said was a response to Palestinian violence. [Updated at 8:36 p.m. ET] Hamas has slammed "the despicable attack" and called for the "international community to condemn the bloodlust and the murder of children and civilians in the settlements."

A U.S. Navy veteran who was a former Green Beret commander says he was harassed by an airline employee who called him a "traitor" and threatened to "blow me sky high." Robert Bales has filed a lawsuit against American Airlines and American Eagle over alleged discrimination. He was removed from his flight from Las Vegas to Detroit on November 22, 2010. Bales said the incident prompted him to quit the military; one month later, he flew his new plane again to Detroit. He said a flight attendant stopped him to ask him "if he had any bad thoughts or feelings" toward the airline. American Airlines has denied the flight incident occurred on American Eagle flights, saying Bales' story "is nothing more than a fabrication" and a "clear case of fraud." The airline also has asked the court to find that the complaints against Bales "are completely without merit." "He's trying do everything within his power to get out there and get in with other people, the next step is to go through social media to try and get other people to help him," Bales' attorney David Estrada said. "He's going to have to have some new, better friends." The lawsuit claims that Bales was removed from American Eagle because, "Aircraft crew member #1 had reasonable cause to believe that [Bales] was a 'threat to other airline crew member safety or security.'" "American Eagle knew that he had a violent history with TSA and was known to have a violent temper," the lawsuit states. In an interview with CBS Detroit, Bales said he was removed because the airline believed him to be a threat to aviation security. "American Eagle had reasonable and probable cause to believe that he had threatened, intimidated, and/or assaulted a flight attendant," the suit states. The suit also claims that Bales was dismissed because he had served 22 years as a U.S. Army Special Forces soldier and the airline needed to get rid of him first. "American Eagle knew that if he did not complete his service at the U.S. Army Special Forces School, he would be discharged from the military," the suit states. The airline does not dispute the accusations. In a statement released through a company attorney, the carrier said that the complaint "is completely without merit," and accuses Bales of attempting to get "under the skin of American Eagle" to "pursue his own personal agenda of getting back into the Air Line industry". Bales served as a co-pilot for American Eagle and United Airlines before he was demoted. "When asked about his history of discipline and disciplinary action, Mr. Bales admitted to some minor problems in the Air Force that he took seriously," the company's statement said. "Since his discharge in 2002, he has served for 22 years, has never been arrested, has never been convicted of the crimes he is now alleging, and has never been accused or charged with a serious crime in this or any other country. Mr. Bales has no credibility whatsoever." In his lawsuit, Bales details what happened after he was removed from his first flight, on November 22, 2010. The suit alleges that Bales suffered emotional distress and mental anguish of $400,000 and is seeking damages and an injunction requiring the release of audio recordings and emails to his attorneys. Bales also filed a whistleblower complaint with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration for alleged civil rights violations related to the alleged incident. The OIG office is investigating the issue. The suit alleges that Bales' military service prevented him from pursuing a civilian job, but the airline insists it did nothing wrong. Bales' lawsuit comes the same day that a former Delta Air Lines flight attendant filed a proposed class action lawsuit against the carrier alleging that a supervisor "intimidated" her by telling her "to keep her mouth shut because he would 'break' her." The attorney representing the flight attendant, William Cavanaugh, claims his client was forced to resign and threatened with legal action with the assistance of Delta's CEO when her refusal to work for the airline "took away work" on her schedule. "I hope this lawsuit will put some pressure on Delta Air Lines, because I think their policies are unlawful," said Cavanaugh. Copyright 2012 by ClickOnDetroit.com. All rights reserved. D.C. has the highest rate of marijuana use in the world, a D.C. Council committee decided at an emergency subcommittee session Thursday evening. A study commissioned by the D.C. City Council concluded that marijuana use was the leading cause of disability in the District with nearly one in four people ages 16 to 29 reporting having used some form of marijuana in the last year. The subcommittee voted 10 to 6, with Council Chairman Phil Mendelson (D) absent, not to recommend the decriminalization of the drug. Committee members instead requested that the city make better efforts to deal with marijuana use, and urged council members to consider the effects a policy change could have on the District's homeless population. The subcommittee voted to hold a public hearing on the study at a later date.

In the shocking clip, five people can be seen surrounding a soldier who was on a training exercise. At one point a man can be seen appearing to grab one of his testicles. He is also seen dragging one of the soldiers by his arm across the floor, as people get increasingly agitated. Police confirmed they received a call after 5pm that reported a soldier had tried to harm himself but denied Israeli media reports about a soldier being attacked with iron bars. (Image: Israel Police) A large group of men, some of them wearing military uniforms, have then surrounded the soldier, before they are caught by the dog walker. The video, which first emerged on social media, shows people throwing punches, trying to snatch the soldier, and screaming and swearing at him. (Image: Israel Police) "Take this guy!" one man said as he tries to grab the soldier's testicles, which were on the floor outside his boot. "Get that soldier. Throw him over. Throw him over!" He then grabs the soldier by his arm, pulling him across the floor near the corner of the street. Several people can be seen restraining the soldier as another man runs in with a camera. (Image: Israel Police) One of the soldiers can be seen on crutches. He later told police he didn't know why anyone was after him or why he was attacked. The police were looking for three people believed to have been involved in the incident, but a military spokesperson said they were not currently involved in an investigation. The soldier was reportedly treated at the scene by army paramedics.

A woman in northern Minnesota who allegedly refused to leave a store with a family on a Valentine's Day break got more than she bargained for when she suddenly grabbed a customer's ear after realizing she was in the wrong place. The incident at the Gander Mountain Store, near Fort Snelling, began when a family had been in the store for just three minutes, said Lt. Bob Kroll of the Hennepin County Sheriff's Office. The woman, identified as 34-year-old Lillian Ziegler of Gander, apparently had no idea she was in the wrong place, Kroll said. Instead of walking away, Ziegler allegedly grabbed the ear of a woman she apparently thought was her son after they became separated while returning to the store. When the woman began to run away, Ziegler pursued her, pulled her down from the aisles and began hitting her on the back with a bottle, Kroll said in a news release issued Thursday. The woman was able to break free and then flagged down a clerk before leaving the store. Ziegler was able to get her purse from the woman and was later arrested. She was arrested for disorderly conduct and interfering with an officer, according to the news release. The Hennepin County Sheriff's Office has not yet said how the ear was found, Kroll said.

Monsanto's own documents confirm that GMO wheat has caused cancer. (It also showed that this cancer caused more than $7 billion in sales for the company.) By now you've probably heard about what Monsanto recently confirmed to Canadian regulatory authority MON-SA: genetically modified wheat has caused "an increase in the overall incidence of non-small cell lung cancer in a subset of rats fed the treated wheat." What's even scarier is that MON-SA told Monsanto to conduct a study on the effect of their product on human beings. (See "Bayer Must Be Stopped", May/June 2011.) The MON-SA statement confirmed this cancer study to Canadian authorities because Monsanto had already requested the federal regulatory agency to allow the company access to their animal feeding studies. The federal agency agreed, after Monsanto was unable to produce the animals. MON-SA also confirmed Monsanto's earlier report that glyphosate (aka Roundup) caused infertility in rats and female mice. However, not only has Monsanto not conducted and publicly released the test data proving its GM wheat is the cause of cancer in humans, the company lied for nearly two years about it. It lied about the health effects of GMOs, because the company has no health concerns on GMOs except what Monsanto itself can show. How Did Monsanto Lie? When the MON-SA statement was made public on May 11, the company claimed that the company would publish a revised data set that would show that GM wheat had no significant effect on the health of humans or animals. This claim appears to have been just another blatant lie. As explained below, MON-SA, the Canadian regulatory agency, has a stated policy that all data must be transparent, accurate, and unbiased, and all new data must be peer-reviewed by independent scientists. So, the data must be accurate, correct, and unbiased. And Monsanto knew that for nearly two years. So the company knew the data was false (and, as we've discussed, it still is). What about the test data Monsanto claimed to produce? And the data that Monsanto had lied about for two years? These data were available to MON-SA: GMO wheat has caused a dramatic increase in an animal organism that can cause infertility in humans and cause tumors in both animals and humans. These data were available because Monsanto asked MON-SA to approve its GM wheat for human feeding. When the U.S. FDA found these data to be "inconclusive" as it should have had, MON-SA refused to approve the company's approval and rejected the test data. What has Monsanto done with the data now that it had already provided to MON-SA for approval? Was it destroyed? Was it destroyed in any other way? And where is the data from MON-SA's GMO wheat experiment currently? Months after MON-SA approved Monsanto's GMO wheat (which it had never actually analyzed), its Health Canada division told Monsanto to conduct the cancer study. However, this study does not show that glyphosate caused these cancerous tumors in rats and female mice: In fact, the MON-SA statement contradicts this conclusion. The statement says that the cancer cells that the rats and mice had were genetically engineered to become resistant to glyphosate, so the animals and humans were also genetically engineered to become resistant. So, MON-SA lied to the feds and lied about the results of its own research to help Monsanto get Monsanto's patent renewal. What about Monsanto's statements that glyphosate is already recognized as causing cancer and infertility in humans? According to MON-SA, a number of scientific bodies have recognized glyphosate as causing these effects in the animals the company tested. However, MON-SA still ignored this conclusion by the Canadian regulatory agency. Monsanto continues to assert that there is a difference between humans and animals, and therefore the risks that it believes glyphosate poses to animals are different from the risks posed to humans. As a result, Monsanto ignores the public health risks posed by GE foods, while it protects its own patent, and continues to increase the use of Monsanto's genetically engineered crops across the globe.
