And, if that is not enough, many other countries (and Canada itself) have already banned GMOs. I would encourage you to call your representatives to stop this dangerous experimentation in the name of profits and power.

We've all had these moments in the store, where we'd come up to a stack of clothes or some other item and think, "Oh! I really like this! It might even be wearable for summer!" But what you don't really know is that the item, at least at that stage in its life cycle, is not "good enough," in the sense of being wearable for summer yet. After all, you've only got to think back to the summer of 2001 when The Gap first introduced their second line of "classic" jeans with skinny fit legs, and they were immediately hailed by the fashion establishment and fashion bloggers as a model for new ideas in the fashion world. "They were a perfect way to show you have fun with this whole slimmed down, sporty thing," says Jessica Kann , whose own career has been built on helping young designers, and even older ones, get their start in the industry. "They have these classic-to-modern silhouettes, and if you could only wear one of those things, this would be it." And as it happens, those skinny jeans were a perfect example of that type of modern slimming. In fact, they're so reminiscent of the Gap's original line, there's an entire clothing line (now known as the Gap Jeans Collection ) that's all about the same thing: a modern style of slim fit jeans with very tight or skinny leg openings. It's a kind of retro throwback for the modern clothing world. And so, with the idea of "slim fit" jeans and pants gaining prominence across the fashion landscape, you might be thinking, "Okay! I know what a skinny fit is!" But you're not quite prepared to do some of the hard leg work to really understand what those words actually mean. To answer: "Slim Fit" jeans are simply a variation on the basic slim jean cut that has a small leg opening and/or a thigh gap that is very close to or at the waist. "Slim Fit" pants are meant to be casual wear, so they are not meant to be wearing underneath another layer of clothing (although that can be a really creative way of using your jeans—try tying them around your waist to bring the hip fit into play). So what's the problem with "slim fit"? It's more appropriate to say that jeans that don't meet a certain standard of fit are not "slim fit," because a more casual, everyday, fit can be just as good. But when it comes to jeans-as-accessories, some of us forget this, and we think we need to have some "slim" fit just to make sure we look good. "The problem with skinny fits is that they are too fitted because the thigh gap and overall leg and waist is too small," explains Kann. "If the leg opening is a fraction of an inch wider your pants will look too tight, it won't drape well over your thighs or your hips, which can sometimes make them look baggy. And the leg opening won't be that great, it will be very small and you'll be very uncomfortable. And sometimes just making the leg opening a fraction wider than what you normally need is all it takes to make a pair of jeans be more fitted. It's not about fit, but about the balance of your body, how you are sitting and standing at that moment. And the right pair of jeans will be a blend of the two, with the leg opening being just enough to cover your thigh but not so much that there's gaping around your hips and a lot of leg and waist gap. It's really about making sure the shape is right."

It's the final countdown to WrestleMania 34. We're getting into the last month of the year with a ton of news about the biggest event in pro wrestling. There's lots in store on Sunday night, but before we get into that, we present a new version of our Best Of 2015 awards. WrestleMania is one of the biggest annual events on the wrestling calendar, but every year there is a new winner (or, at least, a new winner on our list). Here at the SB Nation office, we give out this awards on the last Saturday of the year, and the process is fairly simple. On the same date, I run an all-day online poll to pick our top 10 (which has to include three candidates), and then I run the results through a weighted algorithm to determine the winners—usually five different winners. It's a good way to highlight where we stand in the year, but it also highlights which guys we'd like to have seen win this year. And so: I had our staff vote for their top five choice for the awards of 2014. These are not necessarily the top contenders for the next year's award, just my picks for the guys likely to take it next year. So, without further ado… here's SB Nation's Best Of 2015 awards. Feel free to share them with your friends and followers. Farewells The year came to a close with a final tribute to the best of the best. The winners of our Best Of 2015 awards are listed below: SB Nation Best Of 2015 Winner, Wrestling Observer Newsletter Best Of 2015 Winner, Wrestlezone Best Of 2015 Winner, Wrestling INC. Best Of 2015 Winner, Wrestling Inc. Staff Picks Best Of 2015 Winner, PWTorch Best of 2014 Winner, Pro Wrestling Torch Best of 2014 Winner, Wrestling Observer Newsletter 2012 Award 2012 Winner, Wrestling Observer Newsletter Best of 2012 Winners of this year's award are now being listed, by award, at the top of this page. WrestleMania 34 This year's event in Tampa was a huge one for the company as it brought in some of the biggest stars and most popular superstars to date. The main event was the first WWE World Heavyweight Championship match since John Cena lost it last December. The reigning champion came out to music from Michael Jackson's Bad, a song that WWE fans (and particularly its young fans) have embraced for its references to the dark side and the potential power of the belt, and the crowd exploded. Cena was the obvious standout, as he was a fan favorite from the moment he joined the company. He and Randy Orton, who came off a shocking victory over The Wyatt Family at the Royal Rumble, looked good, and The New Day looked more or less the same—for whatever reason, they were in the ring and looked like they would win by default. For the first time at a WrestleMania, we got to see the return of CM Punk after an almost decade of inactivity, and although his performance, even without the massive mic work and pyro from the WWE, was great, he was still not the main event. The other main event featured John Cena, Big Show (although there will be debate about whether it was the correct choice of opponent given the size disparity that the champ and his opponent had, a factor that can often make the outcome of a match hard to predict) and Braun Strowman. Cena seemed to have no problems getting through the match—especially with the help of his finishers—but Strowman looked terrible, especially as they went into the match, when a knee and elbow injury kept him out of action earlier in the year during his return to the company. Cena and Show worked well as a tag team; it almost felt like the former WWE champion was the leader, and his aggression almost carried him through to victory. Strowman, although very good in the match, was clearly a step out of his comfort zone, and despite the crowd's reaction, it seems probable that he'll look to change his style to try to get over and be successful in WWE. WWE World Heavyweight Champion John Cena defeated Rusev by submission (rear naked choke) to retain the WWE World Heavyweight Championship, WWE on WWE Network, 4.2 out of 5 stars I'll be back next year to celebrate the end of another year of sports-entertainment coverage, and we'll probably take the Best Of 2015 awards one more time at that point.

The New York Times reported "Republicans have already raised millions," and the Washington Post added that it was "on pace to be the biggest-ever Republican fundraising quarter for any presidential candidate." So what exactly is this huge money surge? It's largely to win the battle for the superdelegates. As I noted, the first two states to vote, South Carolina and Nevada, have a significant number of superdelegates. The superdelegates (who were all but ignored on Super Tuesday) will pick the nominee, regardless of the popular vote, which is why Super Tuesday has become so important. If Donald Trump could win the majority of the delegates, he would have a lock on the nomination. But given how poorly Ted Cruz and John Kasich performed during their campaigns, he'll need to flip a lot more delegates in order to clinch the nomination. That's why these results are so important for the Republican Party, as the nomination could go to either candidate (at some point Cruz'll have to take him down). The only way to guarantee that is by winning the superdelegates. But with more than a week to go before the election, the polls show Trump just barely ahead of Hillary Clinton nationally. The big money influx will be from the Super PAC side (the Koch Brothers are already in it, according to the Wall Street Journal), and the GOP Party itself. The Hill reports that the GOP is expected to raise more than $100 million. The Koch brothers are expected to kick in $20 million, and the Republican Governors association is set to pay $7 million to help states run more competitive primary and caucus processes. The RNC will take in $11 million. The National Republican Congressional Committee, a political advocacy group that spent millions to defend Republican House and Senate incumbents, will give $2.9 million. In short, the Republicans have already spent what would be considered huge sums on the political war at this point in a presidential election. They seem to have made their decision to focus on "winning" rather than "preserving" the Republican Party as long as Trump is the nominee. I wonder if the Washington Post, which is a generally liberal outlet, felt the same way after Mitt Romney lost in 2012.

I've made this recipe for several people but a few of them found it bland. I'm sure they would've liked it better if I'd had the time to put the flavors to better use. In case it's needed, I'd suggest adding a few more slices of lemon into this for extra punch. This is a bit more complicated than the basic lemon cake recipe. The original recipe calls for a whole egg but you can sub an uncooked egg with a yolk. However, be sure to use an egg that's cooked well! The cake itself can be made in an 8×8" round cake pan or in a 6–8 inch square muffin tin. I'd suggest using a 6 x 9" or 8 x 11" circular measuring cup to pour in the batter. I find it easier to pour about one cup in from the top than to try to get all the batter in the container. This way I can flip the pan if necessary and still get all of it. The batter should be about 1 inch thick. I put mine in the cup on the top and let them freeze. When I cut the cake into individual servings I do this with the muffin cup underneath the first slice to try to keep from losing too much batter! The cake is best eaten right away after frosting, but it also makes delicious leftovers. The frosting is a one-bowl process. It requires a bit of elbow grease and patience. You will need to add more eggs if necessary so it's not super runny when it hardens. You can keep the frosting chilled in the fridge for several days and re-heat it as needed. This is a great quick, sweet dessert that you can make this afternoon and take to a potluck with your friends.

Brisbane Roar FC are pleased to announce the re-signing of forward Jack Hingert for the 2013/14 Hyundai A-League season. Hingert has agreed a one-year contract extension to continue his career at Brisbane Roar, after being granted his club-record contract for the 2013/14 season by executive general manager David Pourre. "It's been a difficult few years for Jack, with a number of injuries and then a transfer to England," said Pourre. "It's great to see him back in the Roar outfit with a fresh start. "He's a good character; the kind of guy who wants to perform for the Roar and he'll want to finish the year, hopefully, as champion of the flag." Hingert's arrival will come as good news for Roar Head Coach, John Aloisi, who will be hoping to re-sign his second-choice forward when the transfer market opens later this week. "I have a feeling Jack will want to extend his time with us," continued Aloisi. "I've had a number of good chats with him and obviously I'm sure there will be some negotiations that will come about that will have to happen between him and his family." Hingert, 24, has been an integral part of Roar's midfield over the past two seasons, scoring 10 goals in all competitions during the 2013/14 A-League season, including the most in the competition during last season with five goals and seven assists. The versatile forward has made 25 appearances for the Roar in all competitions since joining the Hyundai A-League in June 2008. "I've had three seasons in Brisbane, I am a local boy and it's great to be back with my family over there," said Jack Hingert, who played his first official game for Brisbane at the Hyundai A-League's match against Melbourne Victory at Suncorp Stadium in April. "I have always wanted to stay in Brisbane and this is an exciting next chapter for me." The Englishman joined Brisbane Roar for a reported three million Australian dollars, following his release from Manchester City this January. Hingert scored five goals in 16 appearances for City last season.

I've been in a dark and depressing place since getting my new bike on the day it arrived. I was planning to use this as my only bike and go back to riding my two bikes, but things have changed now and I have decided to stick it out. Now, that said, I'm pretty happy about the purchase. This is the first bike I've really liked to ride. It feels solid, it has the gears to get me all the way around town (on medium) and the tires have excellent grip without bogging me down.  I started the process of building this up on the second day. It started out as a standard mountain bike frame with a frame bag (for my bike, but you can use it on this as well). It started out as a bike for my son. He loves riding bicycles and is a little younger, but this is a perfect bike to help out my other little boys who are now old enough to ride around town. The little wheels are perfect for both his and my needs. But I noticed that there was a huge gap between the gears on this bike. So I bought a set of 11 speed pedals, added a shifter and started thinking about what I would do without the gears.  I then decided that perhaps a rear-center-drive system like the BBS02 is great at what it does. So I spent more time building this bike, using the BBS02 as a guide, and figured that by removing the drive rear wheel and rear derailleur and replacing everything with a rear center drive I could get a good set of gears without losing any speed. So we spent a couple of hours on the bike and at about 10:30pm on the fifth day had a completely working working ride with the new gears. I love this bike! When I'm out on the bike path and the roads are clear I really enjoy cruising at 10mph, going faster or slower depending on what I need to do at the time. I got a few "Wow's" but I haven't noticed any issues yet with using this bike.  I'm going to do a separate review on my new bike later in the week, and I'll update this with the details, because this bike has been a blast. The only changes that I've made to how I use the bike are that I removed the front wheel to have a more stable setup for the pedals. It was worth it; I can now get up to speed easily on the bike path with the pedals and it feels completely stable now!  The biggest reason I'm writing this is because it's so important to me that people like my reviews! If I could reach more people, and more like-minded people with this bike this would be a real success. I just want to encourage everyone to give this a try and see for themselves, and I truly think that it's worth it.

D.C. Police Chief Cathy Lanier. (Photo by Bill O'Leary/The Washington Post) The National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund is releasing another of its big-name cops lists, and D.C. gets a huge shout-out. The "Top 10 Best-Dressed DC Police" list, released Thursday, ranked D.C. cops according to their fashion sense. (D.C. was not on the previous list by the fund.) Chief Cathy Lanier, who has become something of the fashionista herself, came in at No. 1. Police Officer William Miller, who heads up District's homicide squad and works in the District's D.C. Sheriff's Office, came in at No. 2. According to the NLEOMF list, DC had a total of 50 police officers who appeared on the list — two were not on the previous list — plus an additional 19 who appeared on a separate list. "As we commemorate the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund's 50th Anniversary, we honor the hard work and sacrifice that law enforcement officers around the country and around the world have made, and continue to make," NLEOMF President and CEO Mike Lopez said. "For many more years to come, we will continue to honor their names by highlighting their outstanding achievements, achievements in their communities, and a dedication to protecting the public and our nation." In case you can't believe it, here's the full list: 1. Nellie B. Lanier Chief, D.C. Police Department 2. James D. Miller Supervisory Deputy Chief, District's Homicide Homicide Squad 3. Thomas P. Burke, Jr. District's Assistant Chief of Police 4. John W. Fulkerson, III Supervisory Detective, D.C. Homicide Homicide Squad 5. Frank W. Covington III District's Special Patrol Officer 6. John R. Fetterman D.C.'s Sergeant of Arms & Treasurer 7. James G. DeMent Supervisory Detective, D.C. Homicide Homicide Squad 8. William Z. Burt District's Sergeant of Arms and Treasurer 9. Stephen F. Harges III District's Sergeant of Arms and Treasurer 10. Frank S. Nalepa, III District's Sheriff Here are a few more things to note: • In his District's Homicide Homicide Squad, Officer William Miller earned the top-rated uniform rating, of "A." • Among DC's homicide detectives, Special Patrol Officer Stephen F. Harges III scored "A" for wearing a "business casual business suit," although there was no "sporting a business suit" rating in the list. • Among DC's homicide detectives, Deputy Chief William Z. Burt scored a high-scoring "A" in "A" clothing, which "may include traditional suits, traditional shirts and ties, and sport coats." The other officers who scored "A" included: • Senior Master Sergeant James G. DeMent, "A" clothing, a term the NLEOMF describes as "the color, style, and style of appearance with regard to appearance that is most typical of persons displaying leadership skills and authority by displaying appropriate attitudes, mannerisms, and body language." (The term means "inoffensive, well-dressed, and clean.") • Sergeant Edward J. Thomas, "A" clothing, a term the NLEOMF describes as "the color, style, and style of appearance with regard to appearance that is most typical of persons displaying leadership skills and authority by displaying appropriate attitudes, mannerisms, and body language." • Police Patrol Lieutenant George L. K. Pippin, "A" clothing, a term the NLEOMF describes as "the color, style, and style of appearance with regard to appearance that is most typical of persons displaying leadership skills and authority by displaying appropriate attitudes, mannerisms, and body language." (The term means "appearance that conforms to standards of cleanliness and good manners.") • Sgt. Michael D. Purdy, "A" clothing, a term the NLEOMF describes as "the color, style, and style of appearance with regard to appearance that is most typical of persons displaying leadership skills and authority by displaying appropriate attitudes, mannerisms, and body language."

As long as everyone is in good standing for two weeks, you can pay a portion of your monthly or yearly membership dues or membership fees. This is useful if you are in the market for a new bike or a new equipment that meets your needs at a lower cost. You will not have to pay again during the course of your membership. You can find the dues or membership fees tab at the bottom of the membership page. You can pay online or in person in our office or at the Bike Shop. For new members under 18, you will need to provide a parent's/legal guardian's (18+ year old) consent in order to pay dues. You may also obtain this consent from the parent/legal guardian when your 18th birthday is approaching by providing it in writing. If your membership is being paid automatically or in installments, there is a "Monthly Fees" checkbox you may check on the Membership Information tab of the registration form to indicate you want you monthly dues (or annual dues), monthly installment payment, or any combination thereof. You must indicate the appropriate payment type. If you are paying the monthly enrollment fee you will also receive a statement in the mail at the time of the enrollment period. In order to provide the most comprehensive cycling education, the department has established various membership dues levels for various ages and abilities and for individuals, families, and groups. Learn more about membership dues. What is a "Rental Membership?" Please be aware that there are no official policies that define what is a "rental", but the definition of rental often includes someone "renting" bicycles. Renting means the person (or business) renting/leasing the bikes is making money off the rental process by charging customers a lower price than the bikes would normally be sold for. Most times, you can buy a pair of reasonably used and quality bicycles at the normal price for that model in the stores. It is illegal in Chicago to offer rental bikes unless the bicycles being rented are being resold, so most of the bikes are sold at regular prices. The same goes for rental, but the bikes are being used by the customer and not just stored in your garage. The person renting the bicycles may not be a business. For example, if you rent a bicycle from a friend, you're likely not renting the bicycle for profit. But if you rent to a friend, you could be breaking the law, or at a minimum risking a fine. For more information about renting or reselling bicycles, please see the Office of the City Attorney's page on the topic

The New York Times says that President Obama's "biggest failure on health care" is his failure to fix the problems of Medicaid, a new entitlement program for the poor. In "Obamacare's Biggest Failure," reporter Jonathan Martin notes that while the Obama administration has insisted that Obamacare would cut spending and improve access to health care for low-income people, the program has been far less successful than most of the president's promised savings. He points to a 2014 report by the Commonwealth Fund showing that Medicaid spending is now set to double over the next 10 years. Martin writes: Even with those staggering numbers, [Health and Human Services] Secretary Kathleen Sebelius has repeatedly noted that expanding coverage will still be paid for by the health insurance industry, which receives $1 in tax credits from each premium dollar it spends. And some of those insurers have already begun jacking up premiums to cover the costs of caring for the uninsured, a policy known as "penalties" or "risk corridors." Some of those high-cost patients will likely remain uninsured. If that happens, Mr. Obama's health law could be making the entire program more expensive over what would previously have been its first two years. Obama's health care law is facing increasing criticism from his own party. In October the House overwhelmingly rejected an amended version of the health care law that would have repealed the health insurance subsidies — the part of Obamacare that relies on individuals to purchase their own insurance — and the part requiring employers to provide insurance coverage and that would have cut Medicaid's funding from the existing levels of $385 billion to $162 billion over ten years.

A former aide to President Donald Trump offered up a remarkable defense of his boss Wednesday — which we'll excerpt below. "I've never seen anything like this. It's so bizarre," the source told NBC News chief White House correspondent Hallie Jackson. "So many people in the administration now are basically just talking about him, talking about him with no focus on the mission or any other specific agenda for the president of the United States. I believe what's going to happen is that a lot of people who weren't in on the planning of this are going to be in for a surprise." Jackson then told him, "And you think it's inappropriate to be talking only about the president of the United States?" The source replied, "How could a guy be president who doesn't ever even seem concerned by the mission he's supposed to be overseeing?" Trump's first year in office has been defined by political chaos, leaks and questionable actions, from the firing of FBI Director James Comey and other ongoing probes to the hiring and removal of senior White House advisers like Steve Bannon and John Kelly.

Ahead of the release of Star Trek 3, JJ Abrams has been doing a great job of setting up a universe for the future. In fact, there is more than enough material to run multiple Trek series and movies on Star Trek's 20th anniversary, just as was the case with Deep Space Nine and Voyager. Abrams has already announced new films for the series and an online Trek documentary is scheduled to air on the anniversary of the television series (June 18). But there is still one item that I haven't heard about—the continuation of Trek Into Darkness. Speaking with Star Trek Magazine about the upcoming feature film, Abrams confirmed that Star Trek Into Darkness isn't going anywhere. But the film is not the only project currently in active development. With the anniversary approaching, I had a chat with Abrams about the next chapter of the Star Trek franchise, including the potential continuation. "I'm gonna be very explicit about this. I don't think we're not doing one more Star Trek," Abrams admitted. "I don't know what we're gonna do on Star Trek 3, 'cause it's kind of like an open question. I don't know if there's an outline to a script. … The story's been in my head forever. So the same thing applies to that. "If and when we do have the opportunity to do the second Star Trek movie, then I think that's definitely going to be the next Star Trek movie." He went on to tease, "I think it'll take place 10, maybe 15 years after, and it'll likely, in a strange way, be a sequel of the first one. I'm not sure." The question then becomes, what story could the sequel explore? "I think the third film is a fun, fun, scary movie," Abrams confirmed. "It's an adventure, because we're going to go to another planet, a new planet, with a story that's kind of an action adventure in many ways." But, if so, where does Phase II fall in that saga? "If and when we do have the opportunity to do the third film, we're gonna have to be really careful in how we approach it," Abrams stated. "If it's a little bit of a change and also a bit of a return to the characters that we've created, then that's something that is really possible." Perhaps not to worry, though. After discussing the next three Star Trek films, he also revealed that Abrams and his fellow writer Rian Johnson would be working on a follow up to the upcoming Star Wars film Rogue One. "As you know, Rian's writing one of the Star Wars movies," Abrams said. "So, it's been his scriptwriting and our conversations." The next Star Trek 3 is currently set for release on May 17, 2017. The movie stars Chris Pine as Kirk, Zachary Quinto as Spock, Zoe Saldana as Uhura, Karl Urban as Bones, Anthony Rapp as a mysterious villain named "Cooper" (as teased in the end credits of Star Trek Into Darkness), John Cho as Sulu, Simon Pegg as Scotty, and Anton Yelchin as Chekov.

It is in the area of the brain referred to as the amygdala — a dark, almond-shaped brain structure that helps regulate emotions and is involved in learning — that scientists have been studying the potential of marijuana, a substance widely thought of as a leading contributor to anxiety disorders. So far, they say it is still too soon to know if pot can directly help patients deal with anxiety and depression, but it appears to activate the area of the brain that causes anxiety, making it appear to have some of the same positive effects. "We do not know if it activates the same pathways as a benzodiazepine, but it has been demonstrated by other researchers it works," says David A. Yaffe, a medical scientist at the Medical University of South Carolina and the director of the Carolina-based Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies (MAPS) in Charleston. "Pot might help patients without causing a negative reaction." Marijuana is a drug that has been used around the world for many years, and its current legal status in some states makes for an unusual cross-disciplinary study of the compound; the drug is a Schedule 1 controlled substance in the United States. Although the substance can sometimes be grown as a plant and sold as an herb for therapeutic purposes, its use as a recreational drug is illegal and banned in most other countries (although in Europe many jurisdictions have moved toward relaxing their stance on the drug). It is also believed to affect the entire nervous system, triggering a range of side-effects. Because of those factors, it may be easy to see why many feel its effects are not quite as benign as many assumed. But with so much controversy surrounding the drug, it's unlikely to get back in the mainstream too soon, even if it works for some. "It is clear that while we learn more about marijuana, there will always still be people who are concerned that its benefits cannot be proven," says Michael Sorensen, who is the principal investigator on a federal grant for MAPS, and has written about the research being conducted in the marijuana field. "While it is possible, there is no guarantee that marijuana will ever be an effective treatment for the majority of patients." Still, it has been suggested that marijuana can actually treat symptoms of anxiety disorders, specifically panic, phobias, and social anxiety; patients with these conditions can also benefit from the use of marijuana. And studies have shown that marijuana's chemical makeup actually helps in the treatment of depression, bipolar disorder, and anxiety. However, marijuana itself does not appear any different than any other drug when it comes to the activity of its primary active ingredient THC (delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol). "It is not a drug like alcohol, opiates, or cocaine," says Yaffe, who is also director of the Neuropsychopharmacology Research Center, University of South Carolina. Yaffe says that THC itself is relatively benign, while its breakdown products, THCA and THB, are the main ingredients in marijuana that lead to its effects. The drug is also found in many plants, from the poppy to the cannabis plant to the eucalyptus plant, among other plants. The fact that these active substances come from various plants doesn't make it any more or less harmful than when they come from one plant-only. Yaffe compares THC and its breakdown products in a similar way to nicotine and its breakdown product, acetylcholine. Both have been discovered by different sources, both naturally occurring and artificially created, and both may cause various effects, including effects that cause the body to produce and release an active substance, Yaffe says. "There is no guarantee that one has any negative impact on the other," he says. "It may all be on the molecular level." There have been hundreds of studies in the medical literature on marijuana since the 1970s, and it has been studied so widely that there has been some debate as to whether or not it is safe. This week, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) announced its first-ever approval of medical marijuana for treatment of nausea associated with chemotherapy. This month, the FDA has also begun reviewing synthetic marijuana, which is now banned because of the addictive properties. According to data from the Drug Enforcement Administration, marijuana was the third most abused substance in America in 2002, just behind heroin and cocaine. While the substance can be used to treat cancer and AIDS-related nausea, those issues also present complications in its abuse, Yaffe says. But despite marijuana still being on the banned substance list, the substance is still legally available for prescriptions today. Yaffe and other researchers are also testing whether MDMA, commonly used as a recreational drug in the early 1990s, has a similar effect as marijuana on the brain, and if so, if it has any therapeutic value. "When MDMA was first used in this area, there were people who were very concerned; it caused seizures, euphoria was quite strong, mood swings, and

My husband and I were in a situation where we had to choose between keeping our marriage together, and keeping our careers and our families, she said. "We chose a career every couple of months, and I chose to keep working, because I love to work." "The fact that I was married to him all these years and he wasn't working — that hurt," she added. She said it took years to heal the pain caused by what she called a "bad divorce." The American Association of University Women estimates that 42 percent of all American families are already headed by men who work at the top of their fields. The report found that there is a significant income disparity between men and women who are married to those in the same profession, in part because women are still paid 77 cents for every dollar a man earns. That means in the United States, for every additional $500 a woman brings home, the man receives only 72 cents.

The next chapter of the KOF XIV storyline is starting soon! After more than 8 months of planning, KOF XIV's development team has finally completed the game that players have been waiting for: the last match of the New Year's Week tournament, and that is going on from November 8th to the 30th! And as the story continues on, the KOF XIV Development Team is finally looking for the community's support, making this tournament possible. The New Year's Week tournament, which became a great success, is going to end in less than a month's time. KOF XIV, in this event, will give players an opportunity to enjoy the best of the fighting game genre in an even more exhilarating environment! The first part of the battle between KOF XIV's development team and an external team of programmers for the game's storyline is starting now! It's a very special moment for us, as it marks our first collaboration. From this event, we want to show the world that we value and respect the cooperation between developers that we have found very impressive, and we look forward to even bigger collaborations in the future. With the New Year's Week tournament ending, it's time to focus on the events that will be coming up in the future, as well as the last tournament of the current season: the KOF XIV Championship Festival! This event will be held in December, from 16th to 22nd at the Tokyo Dome of the Nichinan Culture Park, and all tournament matches will be live-streamed on Twitch. This last match of the current season is already starting! It's going to be something that never happened before: both teams will be in their own tournament, competing for the KOF King of Fighters Tournament World Championship, as well as competing with other players from around the world! There are a total of 14 rounds throughout the season, with many top players from around the world participating in the event! The tournament starts this week. There will be 2 rounds each day, starting on Friday, Dec. 6th and finishing on Monday, Dec. 9th. All matches are scheduled to be streamed from the event in Tokyo Dome. The matches will be casted by our experienced gaming crew, along with two hosts from KOF XIV, and various commentators and analysts. If you are not already a member of the KOF XIV community, you can already tune in to this match: here. With such a great event happening in Japan for a very interesting game, we decided to use this opportunity to release a new playable KOF XIV character, the newly confirmed Sakura Matata. This powerful character combines the magic and the sharpness of Sakura with her unique skills and unique fighting style. This character's name is Sakura Matata, Sakura means "blossoming beauty", Mato means "fire" (or "firefly", as in the manga), and "ata" is Japanese pronunciation of the word "matata", which means bright, bright light. As you're now seeing, our artists have worked their magic with all of the game's artwork to provide Sakura Matata with her final look! In the game, Sakura Matata is the leader of the "Lightside Faction" and a master swordsman. Her ability to use the flames that are inherent in her body allows her to attack from many angles while remaining hidden from her enemy. She is also a very accomplished fighter, being able to block her opponents attacks and dodge their attacks to surprise them, or attack their bodies while they're at a disadvantage! This is a new playable character in the game for you to show off, and we hope that you will do so. The game's story is already complete, so the main focus will now be on getting this event ready for you. Once again, to show you our support of all of our players and fans, we will keep running the New Year's Week tourney and the KOF XIV tournament events for at least another month. The second day after the Boston Marathon bombing revealed how close, how many, to the finish line the suspects crossed before they were caught. At approximately 2 and a half miles into the course and about a mile from the finishing line, surveillance video captured the suspects crossing the finish line and they were quickly apprehended. For the first time in more than five years, the Boston Police Department's bomb unit and SWAT teams, which had been deployed to the Marathon, were called in to assist. For those on-scene after the bombing on April 15, 2013, it was the last time the Marathon would be run at the moment. The following day, however, there will be a celebration, albeit a quieter one. The Boston College women's cross-country team will participate in the second meet of the 2013 season. Last year, when the men's cross-country team was eliminated from the playoffs with a fourth-place finish, this year's women's teams finished in fifth and seventh place, respectively. The men's program, after finishing the 2013 season with a silver medal, is now on hiatus as the men prepare to compete at the Olympic Trials in Austin, Texas, next spring. The men's team still has two more races – the 2014 Atlantic Coast Conference men's hockey finals, scheduled for March 2-5 at the TD Garden, and the 2014 men's NCAA hockey championship, scheduled for March 7-10 at the Capital One Arena in Washington, D.C. This past season, Boston College was one of the most successful programs in college soccer going through both the NCAA tournament and the NCAA field. The Eagles finished second overall in the Ivy League and made it to the NCAA semifinals before falling to eventual champion Harvard in the title match. Despite all of its success, the men of the team are not out of the game. In May, coach Jim Curtin hired Tommy Di Carlo as an assistant coach. Di Carlo, an assistant for the last three seasons, had been at the helm at Bowling Green for two seasons before that and was a graduate assistant at Boston University last season. He brings with him plenty of experience on a college soccer team. He coached the Bowling Green program for 12 seasons from 1992 to 2009. The biggest question this preseason for the Eagles is how Di Carlo will fit into the program now that he has joined Curtin's staff on a permanent basis. Curtin had previously stated how valuable Di Carlo would be this season for the program. "I've made it pretty clear to Tommy that Tommy is an incredibly experienced collegiate coach," Curtin said last season. "He's coached in our conference from the time we've been at it. I've coached against Tommy in both of our leagues. I've talked to him and I've been aware of his career. It just makes a lot of sense. Tommy is one of our head coaching candidates. I'm really glad he decided to play for our program; he had done so for the last eight years as a graduate assistant; one of our assistants from the day that Tommy got hired, he's been with us since the beginning. He's an excellent coach and a player as well. So he's somebody who I want on our staff, one of our head coaching candidates and, obviously, a member of our staff next year." It was reported, at the time, that this was Curtin's first choice for a head coach, but the timing of his hiring would seem a bit odd in light of the fact that Di Carlo, while familiar with the NCAA, is unfamiliar with the Ivy League which will again include Boston College. While Di Carlo is familiar with the coaching staff, the coaching staff's familiarity with his coaching career has been something that Curtin and the staff have been working to rectify. "The Ivy League is going to be a challenging league. It was probably tough for [Curtin] to get the [Men's] program moving back in the right direction. We've got a young and talented program and I think Di Carlo will provide a lot of stability and leadership and I think Tommy's arrival is going to provide that as well." The one thing Di Carlo didn't bring to Boston College was a national title, but Di Carlo did have at least one of those a year ago. Last year, Tommy Di Carlo, a former Boston University and University of Hartford student athletic trainer, led the Eagles to the NCAA Women's National Championship in College All-Star Weekend in Boston and then, after a second-round loss to topranked UCLA in the College Cup semifinals, the Eagles won the National Championship outright in the College Cup finale against Temple. He and his team had been through so much together. They were one of six teams in the nation who finished in the top eight in the final NCAA Soccer rankings in 2012. New Hampshire police have found no evidence of a gunman on the grounds of the U.S. Open after a reported sighting in the area Monday afternoon, but the investigation into the incident continues. "It was a male in a vehicle, a dark-colored vehicle, at least the color of it, and he stopped and was talking to a police officer," said Capt. Kevin Miller of the New Hampshire State Police. "The man in the vehicle said he was in New Hampshire doing some business. He wouldn't give the officer's name, so the officer called 911," he said. "Right after we received the call, it was confirmed that it was an empty vehicle that was a sighting of someone with a firearm." "We are still searching for the person who was in this vehicle, and we do have a witness who spoke with that person," Miller added. State police received a 911 call from a man at 2:16 p.m. Monday, saying that a man was holding a weapon in New Hampshire. They also received another 911 call from someone who claimed to be the man. The witness, who was in New Hampshire, provided investigators with a license plate number, which led to the discovery of the empty vehicle. Miller said police had sent out a number of information-gathering teams to New Hampshire since Sunday when the first sighting of a man wearing a ski mask and wearing a bulletproof vest with black ski-type gloves was reported by the New Hampshire Sheriffs' Department. Officers with the New Hampshire State Police and the Manchester, New Hampshire, police were sent to each of three local police departments in New Hampshire -- Manchester, Concord and Lebanon -- over the weekend and conducted saturation patrols. Miller said investigators will continue to search the area around the Green Mountain Golf Course and surrounding countryside for any additional witnesses or vehicles that may be involved. "We would welcome any information as well that might provide details and help us with this investigation," Miller said. Anyone who may have been involved in the incident is asked to contact New Hampshire State Police at one of these numbers: 1-800-452-4321, Mon-Fri 7:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. and Sat. 10 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. or you may contact the Manchester Police Department at 761-631-2262.
